Ryanair steps up Lufthansa challenge with flights from Frankfurt
Ryanair steps up Lufthansa challenge with flights from Frankfurt
Business World (Digest)
November 01, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 416 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Irish low cost carrier Ryanair will on Wednesday announce plans to start flying from Frankfurt airport, a source 
familiar with the matter told Reuters, stepping up competition with Lufthansa on its home turf.
The flights will likely start from the summer 2017 flight season, which begins in March, the source said.
German daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, citing industry sources, said Ryanair would fly to popular Spanish 
tourist destinations such as Mallorca.
Airport operator Fraport has been in talks with low cost carriers to boost passenger numbers at Europe's fourth 
largest hub, and chief executive Stefan Schulte told Reuters last month that Fraport could offer financial incentives 
for a limited time to encourage new budget routes.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary has previously said high fees and long turnaround times at Frankfurt, London 
Heathrow and Paris Charles de Gaulle make it difficult for low cost operators to fly from those hubs.
The news will provide a further headache for Fraport's main customer Lufthansa, which has slowed growth at its 
main brand and has faced strikes while it tries to lower costs and expand its own budget unit Eurowings.
Shares in Fraport rose 2.8% on Tuesday, making them the biggest midcap gainer, while Lufthansa extended 
losses, down 1.6%, among the biggest fallers on the Dax, after the Reuters report.
Fraport in August cut its forecast for passenger numbers at Frankfurt this year, after attacks in Europe deterred 
long-haul travellers.
Ryanair steps up Lufthansa challenge with flights from Frankfurt
Only a few low-cost carriers, including Spain's Vueling and Iceland's Wow Air, offer flights from Frankfurt, 
accounting for just 4% of passengers. That compares with 20 to 30% at other major international hubs.
Ryanair, meanwhile, has been expanding in Germany, taking advantage of retrenchment by Germany's second 
largest carrier Air Berlin to add flights from Hamburg and Berlin, including on the Berlin-Cologne route popular with 
business travellers.
Fraport's Schulte will on Wednesday host a press conference with Ryanair's chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs 
and chief operating officer David O'Brien at Frankfurt airport, the companies said in press invitations sent out on 
Tuesday. They declined to comment on the reason for the press conference.
Lufthansa also publishes third-quarter results on Wednesday. Ryanair is due to report half-year results on Nov 7, 
when O'Leary is expected to give an update on the carrier's progress in attracting business customers. (Reuters)
Source:www.businessworld.ie
About us

End of Document
Ryanair to start shares buyback this week
Ryanair to start shares buyback this week
AirFinance Journal
November 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 248 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
Irish low cost carrier Ryanair will commence its latest shares buyback programme this week, according to chief 
financial officer Neil Soharan
The carrier announced a &euro;550 million ($608 million) buyback programme on 7 November, after receiving 
board approval. The programme will last four months to February 2017.
The carrier expect to split this 50/50 between American Depositary Receipts and ordinary shares, which will ensure 
it continues to comfortably exceed its 50% European Union ownership requirement.
With this latest initiative Ryanair will bring over &euro;1 billion back to shareholders since the beginning of the 
financial year, says Soharan.
At the end of September Ryanair had net cash of &euro;77 million despite having spent over &euro;600 million on 
capital expenditure, &euro;200 million on debt repayments and &euro;468 million on share buybacks during the half 
year.
The carrier completed its seventh share buyback in June at a cost of &euro;886 million, bringing its total returns to 
shareholders since 2008 to over &euro;4.2 billion.
“We will continue to return surplus funds to shareholders subject to market conditions as long as we remain 
profitable, cash generative, and can fund our capital expenditure (capex) and other operational requirements,” says 
the carrier.
Ryanair reported a 7% increase in first half profits to &euro;1.17 billion as AGB and lower fares delivered 12% traffic 
growth to 65 million customers and a 2% jump in load factor to 95%.
Load-Date: November 28, 2016

Ukraine International leases ninth 737-800 this year
Ukraine International leases ninth 737-800 this year
AirFinance Journal
November 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 155 words
Byline: Joe Kavanagh
Body
Ukraine International Airlines (UIA) has taken delivery of its ninth leased Boeing 737-800 this year.
The aircraft is the final delivery out of nine aircraft under the airline’s fleet modernisation plan for 2016. With this 
final delivery, UIA has lowered the average age of its fleet from 13.5 years to 11.5 years.
The 2009-vintage aircraft (MSN 37542) is owned by SMBC Aviation Capital and was previously on lease to 
Ryanair, according to Airfinance Journal Fleets.
So far in 2016, the airline has taken delivery of nine 737-800NGs and decommissioned two 737-500s as part of its 
fleet modernisation programme. Both retired aircraft are currently in storage and are expected to be returned to the 
lessors.
The airline now operates 39 aircraft, including 21 737s, with an average age of 8.4 years.
UIA took delivery of two used 737-800s from AerCap in May and will take a total of three aircraft from SMBC 
Aviation Capital this year.
Load-Date: December 19, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair extends 737-800 leases
Ryanair extends 737-800 leases
AirFinance Journal
November 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 156 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
Ryanair extended the leases on two Boeing 737-800 units to accommodate strong growth in passenger numbers, 
according to chief financial officer Neil Soharan.
During the first half of 2017, ended 30 September, the low-cost carrier took delivery of 21 new Boeing 737-800s. 
Plans for the second half includes 31 new aircraft.
Between April and September Ryanair transported 65 million customers and the carrier is on course to carry just 
over 119 million customers in its financial year.
Ryanair says this stronger growth requires a raise in its long term traffic forecast by over 10% from 180 million to 
over 200 million customers per annum by March 2024.
“To achieve this, we have already factored a number of aircraft disposal but we also have the option to extend the 
leases on some aircraft,” says Soharan.
Soharan adds that Ryanair has extended the leases on two 737-800 units for another three-year period starting in 
Spring 2017.

BA owner blames profit dip on weak pound; Airlines
BA owner blames profit dip on weak pound; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
October 29, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 16
Length: 475 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: IAG warns of possible rise in ticket price because of fall in value of sterling
Body
International Airlines Group, the parent of British Airways, blamed a "tough operating environment" including 
sterling weakness for a near 4 per cent drop in operating profit in its third quarter.
But the company's shares closed up 5.9 per cent at 438p yesterday, as the results were in line with market 
expectations, and IAG's trimming of its full-year profit target proved less dramatic than anticipated.
Willie Walsh, IAG chief executive, said the weak pound could prompt BA to increase ticket prices.
IAG , whose results were boosted by the acquisition of Ireland's Aer Lingus in August last year, said it expected to 
generate EUR2.5bn of operating profit before exceptional items in 2016, up 7 per cent on the 2015 figure. The 
company said three months ago it expected earnings to rise at a double-digit percentage rate.
IAG's operating profit for July to September fell 3.6 per cent to EUR1.2bn.
Several European airlines, including IAG, easyJet, Lufthansa and Ryanair have issued profit warnings since the 
summer, as they grapple with economic and political uncertainty after the Brexit vote, the impact of terror attacks in 
Europe and air traffic control strikes.
BA owner blames profit dip on weak pound; Airlines
IAG said yesterday that it had seen "no significant change in its short-term trading conditions". It has been 
especially hit by the fall in the value of the pound since the Brexit vote because, while IAG reports in euros, BA 
generates most of its revenue in sterling.
Mr Walsh said IAG's results were strong but had been affected by a "tough operating environment" and that air 
traffic control strikes had caused "continued disruption".
"You can see that the weakness of the pound has had a significant effect on our reported results," he said.
This effect involved a combination of currency translation from sterling into euros and "transaction impact": the 
weaker pound and its negative impact on UK consumers' willingness to travel.
In the third quarter, IAG's net profit rose 9.9 per cent to EUR930m as the company benefited from lower taxes 
compared with the same period last year.
Sterling weakness helped to send IAG's passenger revenue per available seat kilometre, a key performance metric, 
down 13.7 per cent to 6.96 cents.
But passenger load factors - the average proportion of full seats on each flight - dipped by only 0.1 percentage 
point, to 85.6 per cent.
IAG increased capacity by 11.3 per cent in the first nine months of the year compared with the same period in 2015.
That figure would have been only 4.1 per cent without Aer Lingus. IAG's other subsidiaries are Spain's Iberia and 
Vueling, a low-cost carrier.
Gerald Khoo, an analyst at Liberum, noted the impact of sterling weakness, adding: "FX is becoming a material 
headwind, mainly on the translation of sterling profits at British Airways, and recent exchange rate moves suggest 
this challenge will continue to grow."
Load-Date: October 28, 2016
End of Document
Britain has a sorry history of big policies backed by bogus justification; OPINION; Disputed plans for airport 
expansion and high-speed rail illustrate the farc....
Britain has a sorry history of big policies backed by bogus justification; 
OPINION; Disputed plans for airport expansion and high-speed rail illustrate 
the farce of our national decision-making process
Financial Times (London, England)
October 29, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMMENT; Pg. 12
Length: 994 words
Byline: John Kay
Body
The government has decided, again, to increase London's airport capacity by building a third runway at Heathrow . 
If all goes well - and there is absolutely nothing in the vexed history of this issue to suggest that it will - then the new 
facilities might be operational in 2030.
That history begins in 1968, when the Roskill Commission was appointed to assess London's airport capacity 
needs. The commission's conclusion in 1971 was that a new airport should be built at Cublington in 
Buckinghamshire, about 40 miles north-west of London.
The commission was distinguished, its report was thoughtful, and its conclusion was almost certainly right. There 
are no good sites for an airport in the crowded south-east of England, but neither of the two principal contenders for 
expansion are places where anyone would choose to build an airport now: Heathrow is too close to London and 
Gatwick is inconvenient for many potential passengers. Cublington was the right distance from the centre to 
minimise noise nuisance, and in the right direction for users' convenience.
But by the time the Roskill Commission reported, the Conservatives had replaced Labour in government, and well 
organised opposition from the shires had drained political support from the Cublington option. For several years, 
Britain has a sorry history of big policies backed by bogus justification; OPINION; Disputed plans for airport 
expansion and high-speed rail illustrate the farc....
politicians played with the fantasy that an airport might be built at Foulness in the Thames estuary. But this proposal 
never made economic sense. The Treasury was determined to kill it, and in 1975, when the political complexion of 
the government had changed yet again, the Treasury got its way.
Despite the projections of a slowdown, which had provided rationalisation for the decision to abandon Foulness, air 
traffic continued to grow rapidly. Stansted, built north-east of London during the second world war as a base from 
which to bomb Germany, was greatly expanded for commercial operations.
For civil aviation, however, closeness to London is more important than closeness to the Ruhr. Stansted became a 
white elephant, eventually finding a role as a base for low-cost airlines: Ryanair is much the largest operator there 
today.
The dreary catalogue of procrastination continued. In 2003 a new airport strategy favoured a third runway at 
Heathrow, to open between 2015 and 2020; in 2009 the Labour government finally and belatedly threw its weight 
behind this proposal. But the wheel of political fortune turned and the plan was scrapped after the 2010 election.
Another fantasy - that high-speed rail could substitute for airport capacity - was pursued for a while. But as planes 
continued to circle congested Heathrow, another commission was appointed, 44 years after Roskill, to review the 
options.
This new report favoured a third runway at Heathrow and after one year's further delay, Theresa May's government 
last week announced its support for this option. But this decision will not be the end of the story, only the beginning 
of a new chapter.
Why are British governments so bad at making these decisions? Politics is central to the answer. Yet many of these 
policy failures occur over issues that are not in any obvious sense political. There is no ideological division over 
high-speed rail, or Hinkley Point, or many of the catalogue of horrors compiled in The Blunders of Our Governments 
, by the political scientists Anthony King and Ivor Crewe.
But our adversarial system encourages governments of any complexion to review the policies of any previous 
government of any different complexion, and the dire consequences of these reversals are particularly obvious in 
the case of London airport expansion.
That tendency to knee-jerk opposition is reinforced by a paradox of democracy - the tyranny of the minority. No one, 
except the people employed there, wants an airport, nuclear power station or railway built next to their home; while 
it is to the general benefit that these facilities are provided. But the clamour of the few who fear they may lose a lot 
drowns the quiet voices of the many who stand to gain a little.
It is also increasingly easy for opponents to use judicial as well as political methods to obstruct and delay. In the 
case of airport expansion, the ability of a small group to veto any specific proposal may simply represent an 
intractable obstacle to any rational policy.
And that quest for rational policy has been blighted by bogus quantification. Roskill made a pioneering and widely 
praised attempt to use cost benefit analysis to define the relevant issues. By the time the Airports Commission 
reported in 2015, this modelling exercise had morphed into a monster, a black box with trailing wires whose 
processes no one could understand, and which offered endless numbers but no insight.
Such over-specified and convoluted models are used as rationalisations for decisions that have in reality been 
taken on quite different grounds.
The power of modern computing, far from facilitating good decision making, gets in the way. Consultants are 
dispatched to find supportive numbers. This happened with HS2 , the proposed high-speed link to Birmingham, and 
for years a policy in search of a justification. Competing cost benefit analyses yield the recommendations their 
sponsors want to hear. We have policy based evidence, not evidence based policy.
Britain has a sorry history of big policies backed by bogus justification; OPINION; Disputed plans for airport 
expansion and high-speed rail illustrate the farc....
These spurious impact assessments provide cover for the increasingly superficial basis on which policy is really 
made. Foulness sounded environmentally friendly, even if it was not much use as an airport. Expanding Heathrow 
is a gesture that allows the new government to claim that, despite Brexit, Britain is "open for business". HS2 is a 
transport project for the 21st century, a fast link to the Northern Powerhouse. The good policy is one that makes a 
good headline.
We suffer from what King and Crewe describe as a "deficit of deliberation". And the rise of populism that has had 
"enough of experts" does not suggest matters will get better any time soon.
The writer is an FT contributing editor
Load-Date: October 28, 2016
End of Document
European Equities Fractionally Higher as Banks Log Gains
European Equities Fractionally Higher as Banks Log Gains
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 27, 2016 Thursday 10:47 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 228 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.2% higher at 118.08 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Thursday morning. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by semiconductor company STMicroelectronics - New York Shares (STM), 
9.4% higher, followed by Sequans Communications (SQNS), a French developer of chipset solutions, up by 9.0% 
and Cellectis (CLLS), a French genome engineering company, up by 4.2%. Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria 
(BBVA) was 3.6% higher. 
In the UK, Barclays Bank (BCS) was up by 4.9%, followed by Amarin (AMRN), a biopharmaceutical company, 3.8% 
higher and Lloyds Banking Group (LYG), 2.9% higher. Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) was 1.9% higher. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by technology investor Nokia (NOK), down by 8%, followed by ABB 
(ABB), a Swiss company engaged in power and automation technologies, 6.3% lower  ad Logitech (LOGI), a Swiss 
hardware and software products developer, 3.4% lower. Telefonaktiebolaget (ERIC), a Sweden-based 
telecommunications operator, was 2.4% lower. 
And, in the UK, Amec Foster Wheeler (AMFW), an engineering conglomerate, was down by 22%, BT Group (BT), A 
communications services company, was 2.5% lower and diversified mining group BHP Billiton (BBL) was down by 
1.6%. Ryanair (RYAAY), a low-cost airline, was 1.1% lower. 
Price: 8.71, Change: +0.76, Percent Change: +9.56

Ryanair launches Bristol summer 2017 schedule
Ryanair launches Bristol summer 2017 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
October 27, 2016 Thursday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 403 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced the launch of Bristol summer 2017 schedule with two new summer routes to 
Bucharest and Venice and extra flights to Warsaw.
Body
Ryanair&#39;s Bristol Summer 2017 schedule will see more frequencies to sun destinations, lower fares (as 
Ryanair passes on lower fuel costs), and an even better customer experience, as it rolls out year 3 of its "Always 
Getting Better" customer experience programme, and will deliver: 2 new summer 2017 routes to: Bucharest (2 
weekly) & Venice Marco Polo (4 weekly); extra flights to Warsaw (4 weekly); 30 routes in total; and over 1.7m 
customers p.a. Ryanair will continue to connect Bristol with popular sun destinations on low fare services including 
Alicante (10 weekly), Malaga (8 weekly) and Palma (10 weekly), with better timings and lower fares, making 
Ryanair the ideal choice for UK customers. Ryanair&#39;s Head of Communications, Robin Kiely said: "We are 
pleased to launch our 2017 Bristol summer schedule (our biggest ever), which includes two new summer routes to 
Bucharest and Venice and extra flights to Warsaw, with 30 routes in total, which will deliver over 1.7m customers 
p.a. at Bristol Airport. "Customers can look forward to even lower fares when they make advance bookings for 
summer 2017, so there&#39;s never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair and we urge all 
customers who wish to book their summer 2017 holidays to do so now on the Ryanair.com website, where they can 
avail of the lowest fare air travel to and from Bristol. 
"To celebrate the launch of our Bristol summer 2017 schedule we are releasing seats for sale from just GBP19.99, 
which are available for travel between November and March and for booking until Monday (31 Oct). Since these 
amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
Pete Downes, Head of Aviation, Bristol Airport said: "We are delighted that Ryanair has chosen to add two new 
summer routes to the network available from Bristol Airport. Whether measured by total seats on sale or number of 
destinations featured, this is the most extensive schedule Ryanair has ever operated from Bristol Airport and offers 
customers living in the South West and Wales a wider range of choices than ever before. &nbsp; "Our new service 
to Bucharest in Romania represents the first time this destination has ever been served from the South West, 
demonstrating the important role regional airports continue to play in offering choice and connectivity with the added 
convenience of flying locally."

Eurozone stocks braced for Brexit-led upheaval Analysis: Equities
Eurozone stocks braced for Brexit-led upheaval; Analysis: Equities
Financial Times (London, England)
October 27, 2016 Thursday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS - BACK SECTION; Pg. 22
Length: 614 words
Byline: Michael Hunter
Highlight: Investor skills at a premium in sectors most exposed to a slowdown in the UK economy
Body
Brexit means Brexit, as UK prime minister Theresa May likes to remind people.
Britain's vote to leave the EU has also meant a rally in the UK stock market driven by the sharp decline in sterling. 
However, what Brexit means for eurozone equities remains more nuanced.
The UK's rupture with the EU lengthens a list of political risks that will go some way to shaping sentiment towards a 
European stock market that has underwhelmed investors this year.
The benchmark Euro Stoxx 600 is down about 5 per cent.
The list of potential political hazards include Italy's December referendum on constitutional reform, as well as 
German and French national elections next year.
"The euro area is already priced for political upheaval," says Karen Olney, a strategist at UBS. "On valuation 
grounds, euro area stocks look cheaper than their British peers, even as the UK faces the risks of its impending 
departure from the EU."
Eurozone stocks braced for Brexit-led upheaval Analysis: Equities
That's despite the Euro Stoxx 600 regaining all the ground it lost since the June 23 referendum. It's up about 12 per 
cent from its nadir in the immediate wake of the vote. However, it has not broken significantly over the closing level 
it reached on polling day, before the shock of the Brexit result.
Does this mean it's a good time to favour eurozone stocks?
Both the FTSE 100 and the FTSE 250 (which together make up the FTSE 350 shown on the chart above) have 
been led to records by the 18 per cent fall in the pound, which makes UK exports cheaper and flatters the sterling 
earnings of companies booking revenue in foreign currency.
While the euro has fallen back towards its lowest level since February, it has not provided as much support to 
European companies, especially those that earn a significant portion of profits in the UK currency.
Even with some arguing eurozone equities are undervalued, there are parts of the market with more exposure to 
the dangers of a "hard" Brexit , including Irish equities, European utility stocks and the car industry.
"We know which companies are most exposed," says Stephen Macklow-Smith, head of European equity strategy at 
JPMorgan Asset Management.
"I don't think the volatility caused undue dislocations, but it is premature [in the Brexit process] to take big calls on 
the depth of the danger."
When such calls are made, they are likely to include Irish stocks, where some of the companies exposed to any 
slowdown in the UK economy include Ryanair, the budget carrier, and Kerry Group, the food producer.
There are also European utility stocks with UK operations, including Spain's Iberdrola, RWE and EON of Germany, 
and France's EDF. Drawn from a defensive sector, these companies will have less to fear from a squeeze on 
consumer spending, but face a hit from a weaker pound.
The automotive industry is one of the most exposed, with the British market typically accounting for about a fifth of 
Germany's annual prediction, making it the biggest destination for exports by volume.
According to analysis from UBS, there are companies within the sector that remain inexpensive relative to their 
peers, including Daimler and Volkswagen. Such nuance within the wider picture emphasises that navigating the 
Brexit effect will put a premium on stockpicking skills within the most exposed sectors.
There is also a sense among investors that tense, detailed and long-running political talks are nothing new in the 
eurozone, and as the fundamentals improve, there could be more room for stocks to flourish.
Mr Macklow-Smith of JPMorgan adds: "For the markets, my hope is that economic logic will outweigh political and 
ideological considerations. There are an enormous number of hypotheticals."
And the risk of a hard Brexit is now emerging as one.
Load-Date: October 26, 2016
End of Document
EasyJet climbs after analyst predicts end to earnings downgrades; London
EasyJet climbs after analyst predicts end to earnings downgrades; London
Financial Times (London, England)
October 25, 2016 Tuesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS & INVESTING; Pg. 19
Length: 437 words
Byline: Bryce Elder
Body
EasyJet , the year's second-biggest FTSE 100 faller, rallied yesterday after UBS forecast an end to earnings 
downgrades.
UBS turned positive on easyJet, which climbed 1.4 per cent to 931.5p. A 47 per cent fall in 2016 means the stock is 
"pricing in material future value destruction" far in excess of that assumed for Ryanair, which has risen to a record 
premium relative to easyJet based on 2017 earnings, UBS argued.
Yet easyJet has plenty of flexibility left to cushion earnings by cutting costs, UBS argued. And with expectations 
having already fallen more than 40 per cent from the recent peak, earnings risk is now "at least neutral", it said.
A mixed wider market pulled the FTSE 100 lower by 0.5 per cent, or 34.07 points, at 6,986.40.
A third profit warning in a year sent Cobham falling 13 per cent to 139.7p, with analysts expecting a dividend cut to 
follow once the defence contractor's new chief executive takes charge.
Cobham's warning of "subdued" demand for marine satellite communications systems also weighed on Inmarsat , 
down 1.8 per cent to 682.5p. The satellite operator relies on shipping companies for around half its revenues.
"The challenging conditions Cobham reference in maritime look consistent with what we know already," argued 
Jefferies. "We don't see the language today as particularly incremental."
EasyJet climbs after analyst predicts end to earnings downgrades; London
Capital equipment stocks drifted after Caterpillar reported weaker sales for September, its 46th consecutive 
monthly decline. Ashtead was 1.1 per cent weaker at £13.10 and Aggreko lost 0.6 per cent to 815.5p. DCC , the 
oil distributor and logistics group, rose 1.9 per cent to £67.05 with Berenberg arguing that recent weakness was 
unwarranted.
Unilever edged 0.4 per cent lower at £34.72 and Reckitt Benckiser was 0.1 per cent weaker at £72.25 after 
Kimberly-Clark, the US-based maker of Kleenex tissues and Andrex nappies, cut 2016 earnings guidance.
It blamed "lower expected benefits from selling price increases, primarily due to the improved currency outlook".
STV gained 6.8 per cent to 427p after Crystal Amber, the activist investor, confirmed it had raised its stake to 10 per 
cent and repeated its long-held view that the Scottish ITV broadcaster should be a takeover target.
Crystal Amber has been lobbying for STV's sale since it first disclosed an interest in 2013, when the shares were 
306p, and was reported over the weekend to be willing to buy up to 20 per cent.
French Connection jumped 14.5 per cent to 37.5p on a report of possible bid interest . Stephen Marks , the 
fashion retailer's founder and 42 per cent shareholder, told Reuters : "There's no comment as there's no story."
Load-Date: October 24, 2016
End of Document

Big bank earnings set to dominate this week's results LONDON REPORT
Big bank earnings set to dominate this week's results; LONDON REPORT
City A.M.
October 24, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 19
Length: 160 words
Body
THIRD quarter earnings from some of the country's biggest banks will be investors' focus this week, with lenders 
set to report stronger-than-expected results.
Lloyds Banking Group will report results on Wednesday, followed by Barclays on Thursday and Royal Bank of 
Scotland on Friday.
Since the vote to quit the European Union in June, shares in RBS and Lloyds have fallen by about a quarter and 
this week's results will be the first to capture fully the post-referendum landscape.
Before investors turn their eye to banks, however, tomorrow brings first-half results for coffee and hotel group 
Whitbread, with consensus earnings per share expected to rise 12 per cent to 237p.
British Airways owner IAG posts third-quarter results on Friday after EasyJet and Ryanair both warned over profits 
recently.
Other numbers to look out for include trading statements from BP this morning and from Royal Dutch Shell on 
Friday, and an update from GLAXOSMITHKLINE on Wednesday.

Oct 22, 2016( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Smithfield Trust Co. increased its 
position in Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 0.9% during the second quarter, Holdings Channel[1] 
reports. The fund owned 1,616 shares of the company's stock after buying an additional 15 shares during the 
period. 
Smithfield Trust Co.'s holdings in Ryanair Holdings PLC were worth $113,000 at the end of the most recent quarter.  
A number of other large investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the company. Bayesian Capital 
Management LP bought a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter worth about $254,000. ING 
Groep NV bought a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the second quarter worth about $209,000. 
Commonwealth Equity Services Inc bought a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter worth 
about $298,000. Huntington National Bank increased its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 153.1% in the second 
quarter. Huntington National Bank now owns 4,287 shares of the company's stock worth $298,000 after buying an 
additional 2,593 shares during the last quarter. Finally, 1st Global Advisors Inc. increased its stake in Ryanair 
Holdings PLC by 8.8% in the second quarter. 1st Global Advisors Inc. now owns 4,608 shares of the company's 
stock worth $320,000 after buying an additional 371 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors own 
42.57% of the company's stock. Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) traded down 1.25% on 
Friday, reaching $73.37. 239,508 shares of the company traded hands. The stock has a market cap of $18.41 
billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 11.32 and a beta of 0.83. The stock has a 50 day moving average of $73.95 and

rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a report on Friday. Deutsche Bank AG downgraded shares of Ryanair 
Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Wednesday, September 7th. Zacks Investment 
Research upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'sell' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Tuesday,

report on Tuesday, July 5th. One analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, three have issued a hold rating and 
four have given a buy rating to the company's stock. The company presently has an average rating of 'Hold' and a 
consensus price target of $89.50. Ryanair Holdings PLC Company Profile Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) 
is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline 
serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco.

Ryanair 's new Faro route added to Belfast S 2017 schedule
Ryanair's new Faro route added to Belfast S 2017 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
October 21, 2016 Friday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 251 words
Highlight: Ryanair, Europe's No. 1 airline, extended its Belfast summer 2017 schedule by adding a new twice 
weekly route to Faro which will operate between June and August, with 12 routes in total including Berlin, London 
and Milan, and will deliver over 1.1m customers p.a. and support over 800 jobs at Belfast International Airport.
Body
Ryanair’s summer 2017 schedule will also see more frequencies to sun destinations for family holidays, lower fares 
(as Ryanair passes on lower fuel costs), an even better customer experience as it rolls out year 3 of its “Always 
Getting Better” customer experience programme, and will deliver: <ul><li>3 based aircraft</li><li>11 new S17 
routes including Faro (2 wkly), Lanzarote (2 wkly), Malaga (5 wkly)</li></ul>Tenerife (2 wkly) & Warsaw (2 wkly) 
<ul><li>12 routes in total including London Gatwick (4 daily)</li><li>Over 1.1m customers p.a.</li><li>Over 
800&nbsp;“on-site” jobs p.a.</li></ul>Ryanair’s Robin Kiely said: “We are pleased to add this new twice weekly 
route to Faro to our Belfast summer 2017 schedule, which&nbsp;includes 11 new summer routes and our 4 times 
daily service to London Gatwick, and will deliver 10% growth to over 1.1m customers p.a. and support over 800 
jobs at Belfast Airport. Customers can look forward to even lower fares when they make advance bookings for 
summer 2017, so there’s never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair and we urge all customers 
who wish to book their summer 2017 holidays to do so now on the Ryanair.com website, where they can avail of 
the lowest fare air travel to and from Belfast. 
To celebrate the addition of a Faro route to our Belfast summer 2017 schedule we are releasing 100,000 seats for 
sale from just &pound;19.99, which are available for booking until Tuesday (25 Oct).

Lufthansa buoyed by brighter profits outlook Airlines
Lufthansa buoyed by brighter profits outlook; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
October 21, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 16
Length: 302 words
Byline: Patrick McGee in Frankfurt
Body
Lufthansa's shares jumped almost 8 per cent yesterday after the German airline group unexpectedly raised its full-
year profit target, providing some relief for Europe's aviation sector.
Lufthansa late on Wednesday reported adjusted earnings before interest and tax of EUR1.68bn for the nine months 
to September 30, ahead of a consensus analyst forecast of EUR1.53m.
The Cologne-based group had issued a profit warning in July, citing economic and political uncertainty after the 
UK's June vote to leave the EU and several terror attacks in continental Europe.
Other European airline groups have also issued profit warnings blamed on similar factors, including International 
Airlines Group, easyJet and Ryanair.
But Lufthansa said the "difficult-to-forecast short-term bookings of -business travellers in September have 
developed better than expected".
In addition, measures to address excess fleet capacity and costs were starting to pay off. Lufthansa's shares ended 
the day up 7.9 per cent at EUR11.29.
For the full year, Lufthansa said it expected adjusted earnings before interest and tax to be roughly in line with 
2015, compared with a previous estimate of "below" the 2015 result of EUR1.817bn.
Lufthansa buoyed by brighter profits outlook Airlines
Analysts at Citigroup said this was "significantly better" than a consensus forecast of EUR1.461bn. In spite of the 
improved outlook, Lufthansa is braced for a 7-8 per cent fall in revenues at -constant currency in the fourth quarter.
It cautioned that long-term bookings were still burdened by political and -economic uncertainties.
UBS drew attention to the passenger airline unit's adjusted earnings before interest and tax of EUR1.41bn in the 
first nine months of this year, up from EUR1.35bn on the same period last year.
In spite of the share price rise yesterday, Lufthansa's stock is down more than a fifth this year.
Load-Date: October 20, 2016
End of Document

BANKS gave support to the FTSE 100 yesterday, buoyed by good performance from their US counterparts. It was a 
volatile trading day as the European Central Bank held policy steady. The FTSE 100 ended up 0.1 per cent, at 
7,026.90, following a choppy session.
The top risers were Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays, up 3.5 and 3.2 per cent respectively. Good results all 
week from US banks have helped UK banks with substantial fixed income, currency and commodity trading 
operations.
Elsewhere, advertising giant WPP fell 3.6 per cent after French rival Publicis Groupe said third-quarter sales grew 
by just 0.2 per cent.
Concern about advertising revenues hit broadcaster ITV as well, with its shares down three per cent after broker 
Liberum cut its target price for the stock.
Airline stocks found solid ground after German airline Lufthansa increased its profit target for the year. Shares in 
British Airways owner IAG, Easyjet and Ryanair rose 0.9 to 3.4 per cent.

Lufthansa Lifts Full-Year Earnings Forecast After Business Class Bookings Rise
Lufthansa Lifts Full-Year Earnings Forecast After Business Class Bookings 
Rise
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 20, 2016 Thursday 6:49 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 353 words
Body
 German airline operator Lufthansa (LHA.DE) raised its profit estimate for the full year after stronger-than-
anticipated bookings from business travelers in September.
The company now expects adjusted earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) "approximately on previous year's 
level," while earlier this year it indicated profit would decline, a statement published by the company late on 
Wednesday showed.
"Compared to the previous guidance, especially the difficult-to-forecast short-term bookings of business travelers in 
September have developed better than expected," the company said. "The capacity and steering measures initiated 
after the decline in long-term bookings were successful." 
Lufthansa said it now expects revenue to fall between 7% and 8% in the fourth quarter, less than the drop of  8% to 
9% seen in July. Adjusted EBIT in the first nine months of the year was 1.68 billion euros ($1.84 billion), compared 
with 1.69 billion euros a year earlier and the Passenger Airline Group business unit posted adjusted EBIT of 
1.41billion euros, up from 1.35 billion euros a year earlier, the company added. 
Revenue totaled 23.9 billion euros in the first nine months, down from 24.3 euros billion a year earlier. 
Lufthansa said unit costs excluding fuel and currency effects are expected to decrease by 2%-to-3% in the fourth 
quarter, in line with its previous estimates, while fuel costs would decrease by about 140 million euros in the fourth 
quarter compared with the same period last year. 
"Political and economic uncertainties continue to significantly burden long-term bookings, especially on long-haul 
routes to Europe," the company said in the statement. "Forecasting short-term bookings therefore remains 
challenging and may lead to significant volatility in earnings." 
Lufthansa Lifts Full-Year Earnings Forecast After Business Class Bookings Rise
It isn't the only airline operator to revise its guidance of late. On Tuesday, low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY, RYA.L) 
said that its annual profit growth would be lower than it previously estimated as a fall in the value of Sterling 
following Britain's referendum on continued membership within the European Union (EU) hurts business. 
Load-Date: October 21, 2016

British shares fall on some poor company updates
British shares fall on some poor company updates
Business World (Digest)
October 20, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 335 words
Byline: Business World
Body
British shares edged lower on Thursday as advertising giant WPP fell after sales growth at its French peer Publicis 
slowed and mid-caps NCC and Keller plummeted following disappointing updates.
Shares in WPP fell nearly 3% after Publicis Groupe , down 6%, said third-quarter sales grew by just 0.2% on an 
organic basis following the loss of large media accounts in the United States in 2015.
Concern about advertising revenues hit British broadcaster ITV as well, with its shares down 3% after broker 
Liberum cut its target price for the stock.
"We reflect the latest comments from media buyers into our forecasts, which suggest a weaker advertising 
momentum into Q4," Liberum said, lowering its net advertising estimate for 2016.
The blue-chip FTSE 100 index was down 0.2% by 0830 GMT after gaining in the previous two sessions. The FTSE 
250 index fell 0.4%.
The mid-cap index's underperformance was caused by sharp sell-offs in shares of some companies. Cyber security 
company NCC plummeted 35% and headed for its biggest-ever daily decline after it faced some contract 
cancellations and difficulties with some renewals.
Mid-cap engineering companies Keller slumped 25% and Senior fell 20% after both issued profit warnings .
However, airline stocks found some solid ground after German airline Lufthansa, up more than 7%, increased its 
profit target for the year and on expectations that the British government will approve a third runway for London's 
Heathrow airport.
British shares fall on some poor company updates
"All the signals point to the government finally approving the move. This could deliver a major boost to the UK's 
airline sector and knock-on positives for European carriers," ETX Capital analyst Neil Wilson said.
Shares in British Airways owner ICG, easyJet and Ryanair rose 2.2 to 3.3%.
The FTSE 100 index, dominated by internationally exposed companies, has surged more than 20% since a post-
Brexit sell-off in June following a drop in sterling. However, the index is up less than 9% since then in dollar terms. 
(Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie

Lufthansa lifts guidance after big September
Lufthansa lifts guidance after big September
City A.M.
October 20, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 136 words
Byline: VICTORIA BRYAN
Body
LUFTHANSA increased its profit target for the year after business bookings proved better than expected in 
September and its decision to cut back the amount of seats it planned to offer this year paid off.
The German carrier said yesterday it now expects 2016 adjusted earnings before interest and tax (Ebit) to be 
roughly on the level of last year, when it made just over (EURO)1.8bn (£1.6bn), against a previous forecast for a 
drop.
The upgrade comes in contrast to profit warnings this month from low-cost rivals Ryanair and Easyjet, whose 
greater exposure to the UK make them more vulnerable to weakness in the pound, which has tumbled since the 
country's June vote to leave the European Union.
Last-minute bookings for September, especially from business customers, were better than expected, the carrier 
said.

Ryanair blames weak pound as it issues profit warning; Airlines
Ryanair blames weak pound as it issues profit warning; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
October 19, 2016 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 15
Length: 446 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Body
Ryanair has become the latest big European airline to warn that this year's tough trading conditions will hit earnings 
as it cut its profit forecast for 2016-17 by more than 5 per cent, blaming the impact of the weak pound.
The Irish budget airline, which last issued a profit warning in 2013, had stood out in recent months among large 
European carriers for sticking to its earnings guidance.
But Ryanair said yesterday that the 18 per cent decline in sterling against the euro since the UK referendum on EU 
membership in June would cut its expected full-year net profit to a range of between EUR1.3bn and EUR1.35bn. 
Europe's largest low-cost airline by revenue had previously targeted a range of between EUR1.375bn and 
EUR1.425bn.
The company also warned that its strategy of cutting fares to fill its aircraft might reduce net profit for 2016-17 
further if passenger demand weakened or the pound continued to fall.
There have been months of speculation on whether Ryanair's profit forecast was achievable amid a European 
aviation market hit by fears over the impact of terrorism attacks, sluggish economic growth and air traffic control 
strikes.
But Ryanair's profit warning was less drastic than anticipated and its shares rose 5 per cent to EUR12.41 
yesterday.
Ryanair blames weak pound as it issues profit warning; Airlines
The company said average fares in the six months to September 30 had declined 10 per cent, against the 
previously guided 9 per cent, and that it expected a far sharper-than-anticipated fall for the six months to March 31. 
Average fares for the period would fall by between 13 and 15 per cent, against the previously guided 10 to 12 per 
cent.
Michael O'Leary , chief executive, told analysts the outlook meant the company was expecting only "slightly lower 
growth" in profit than before.
"We think this small reduction in the full-year guidance is justified and warranted, given the precipitous decline or 
weakness in sterling over the last number of weeks, particularly when some 26 per cent of our revenues are 
accounted for in sterling," he added.
The new profit forecast was "heavily dependent" on there being no further decline in sterling against the euro or 
additional weakness in fares for the second half of the financial year, he said.
Ryanair said the drop in fares should produce average load factors - the proportion of seats full on each flight - 1 
percentage point higher than previously expected at 94 per cent. It expects to carry 119m passengers in 2016-17, 
up 12 per cent on 2015-16.
"We're using lower prices to stimulate stronger demand than we would've seen this time last year in terms of 
volumes and we expect that to continue to be the case," said Mr O'Leary.
Additional reporting by Katie Martin
See Lex
Load-Date: October 18, 2016
End of Document
Next buoyed by hopes for increasing market share; London
Next buoyed by hopes for increasing market share; London
Financial Times (London, England)
October 19, 2016 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS & INVESTING; Pg. 19
Length: 418 words
Byline: Gavin Jackson
Body
Clothing retailer Next was the big winner among UK stocks yesterday thanks to an upbeat note from Deutsche 
Bank.
The shares gained 5.3 per cent, closing at £47.44. Analysts with the investment bank said the high-street brand 
would benefit from an increasing market share despite a challenging sales backdrop for clothing companies which 
have had to contend with "unhelpfully warm weather through late August and September".
As well as increasing its share, innovations in the company's mail-order business and an easier fourth quarter to 
compare the results to "leave us confident Next should see a reacceleration in sales as seasonal peak 
approaches", Deutsche said.
By contrast, luxury brand Burberry lost 7.2 per cent to close at £14.03. The fall came despite the retailer 
announcing a £125m boost in revenues due to the falling pound.
Sales fell in Hong Kong and Macau and the company's house broker Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded 
the stock citing "limited upside from here".
Supermarket chain Tesco enjoyed a 3.5 per cent increase in its shares, which closed at 208p, following reports 
from research group Kantar Worldpanel that the company had seen the first increase in market share for five years. 
Tesco was the only one of the "big four" supermarkets to see sales growth.
Next buoyed by hopes for increasing market share; London
Overall, the FTSE 100 finished up 0.8 per cent to close at 7,000.06.
Despite a profit warning from Irish budget airline Ryanair , its rival easyJet became the second-biggest gainer in 
the index.
While Ryanair warned that tough trading conditions and a falling pound would hit profits, it only cut its forecast by 5 
per cent - not as bad as the market feared. This helped easyJet to a 5 per cent increase on the day, leaving its 
shares at 918p.
Newcastle upon Tyne-based housebuilder Bellway announced a 40 per cent increase in its dividend after reporting 
increasing profits for the 12 months to the end of July. The company said that it had seen little effect from the result 
of the European referendum on demand for its houses .
The increase in the dividend will bring the total paid this year by the company, which is the UK's fourth-largest 
housebuilder, to 108p. The FTSE 250 company rose by 6 per cent to close at £23.86.
However, the biggest gainer in the mid-cap index was Restaurant Group , owner of chains including Chiquito and 
Frankie & Benny's, which jumped 8.8 per cent to close at 385p after news that the chief executive had increased his 
stake in the company.
The FTSE 250 finished up by 1.1 per cent at 17,994.41.

Ryanair warns sterling fall will hit annual profit
Ryanair warns sterling fall will hit annual profit
City A.M.
October 19, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 205 words
Byline: CAITLÍN MORRISON
Body
SHARES in budget airline Ryanair rebounded yesterday afternoon despite a warning that its full year profits are 
likely to be hit by the recent declines in sterling following June's Brexit vote.
The pound plunged to record lows in the wake of the EU referendum result, and has struggled to recoup its losses 
since.
Stock in the low-cost carrier first fell after it reduced its full year guidance by five per cent - it now expects profit to 
come in the (EURO)1.3bn (£1.16bn) to (EURO)1.35bn range, as opposed to the (EURO)1.375bn to 
(EURO)1.425bn range it previously predicted.
That caused its shares to fall as low as (EURO)11.45 at the open, before rising throughout the rest of the day.
"The primary cause of this slightly lower growth in full year profitability is the 18 per cent fall of sterling post-Brexit 
which will reduce second-half average fares by between 13 per cent to 15 per cent as opposed to the previously 
guided 10 per cent to 12 per cent," the airline said.
Ryanair also confirmed first half fares were "marginally weaker" than expected, dipping by 10 per cent as opposed 
to nine per cent, as previously guided. However, these lower fares will be partly offset by a better than expected 
cost performance, the group said.

FTSE 100 fuelled by rise in EasyJet and mining firms; LONDON REPORT

October 19, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 160 words
Body
MINING companies and budget airline EasyJet helped outweigh a sharp drop in Burberry's shares yesterday, with 
the FTSE 100 scraping back above the 7,000 mark. The blue-chip index ended up 0.8 per cent at 7,000.06 points, 
rebounding from a fall the previous day.
Among the biggest gainers was EasyJet, up 5.1 per cent. The stock has fallen about 40 per cent since Britain voted 
to leave the European Union and it issued a profit warning earlier this month. Investors said that there was value in 
EasyJet after rival airline Ryanair followed suit on in cutting its profit forecasts yesterday. Ryanair opened slightly 
lower, but ended over four per cent higher after the airline's chief executive said he expected the carrier's sales and 
market share to grow in the coming months.
Fashion label Burberry slumped 7.2 per cent after reporting results, with analysts at Liberum citing struggling 
wholesale figures despite a surge in UK sales thanks to the weaker pound.

Ryanair : cutting fayres
Ryanair: cutting fayres
Financial Times (London, England)
October 19, 2016 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 10
Length: 167 words
Body
British Airways decided recently to scrap free food and drink on short-haul flights. Ryanair flyers never enjoyed such 
costly frippery - which is why the Irish airline will weather the coming downturn in fares better than peers.
Yesterday, Ryanair reduced its full-year profit forecast by 5 per cent, to about EUR1.3bn. The main cause is the 
weak pound; about a quarter of revenue is in the British currency, against about half at easyJet.
This is worse news for rivals than for Ryanair. The airline is "load-factor active"; it cuts fares until planes are full. 
These fell 10 per cent in the first half and will fall up to 15 per cent in the second. But passenger numbers and load 
factors will be higher, largely at the expense of competitors. Costs will fall by more than expected.
That suggests that European aviation will be grim over the winter. Ryanair shares have done less badly than peers 
so far. Expect that trend to continue - and enjoy BA's fayre while you can.
Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com 
Load-Date: October 18, 2016
End of Document
Two sides of a weak pound: Burberry gains, Ryanair suffers
Two sides of a weak pound: Burberry gains, Ryanair suffers
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 12:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 606 words
Byline: By DANICA KIRKA, Associated Press
Dateline: LONDON 
Body
LONDON (AP) - The economic repercussions of the plunge in the British pound were on display Tuesday as the 
currency's drop helped boost sales at luxury goods maker Burberry but triggered a profit warning from budget 
airline Ryanair.
In simple terms, a weaker pound helps British exporters because it makes their goods cheaper abroad and hurts 
importers because foreign goods become more expensive in the U.K.
Burberry, which is based in Basingstoke, England, and reports its earnings in pounds, said first-half revenue rose 5 
percent because of the U.K. currency's decline against the dollar, euro and yuan. Meanwhile, Dublin-based 
Ryanair, which gets 26 percent of its sales from Britain but reports in euros, said profit would grow slower than 
previously forecast.
"There are clear winners and losers from the fallout in the pound," said Jasper Lawler of CMC Markets.
The pound has lost nearly a fifth of its value against the dollar since Britain's vote on June 23 to leave the European 
Union. That has boosted the value of overseas sales when they are converted back into the U.K. currency. For 
foreign companies like Ryanair the reverse is true unless they can raise prices in Britain.
British consumers were squeezed by these competing forces last week when Tesco, the country's biggest 
supermarket chain, pulled the popular breakfast spread Marmite and other products made by consumer goods giant 
Unilever off its website when the Netherlands-based company maker sought to raise prices. The two companies 
settled the dispute on Thursday without disclosing the terms.
Burberry said Tuesday that it benefited from the pound's weakness, reporting that revenue rose to 1.16 billion 
pounds ($1.42 billion) in the six months ended Sept. 30, from 1.1 billion pounds in the same period last year.
The company got and added boost as tourists from countries such as China and the U.S. flocked to London to take 
advantage of their increased buying power. Sales at British shops open for more than a year rose by more 30 
percent in the three months to Sept. 30.
Two sides of a weak pound: Burberry gains, Ryanair suffers
Bag sales were particularly strong, especially those of the equestrian inspired Bridle Bag.
Burberry said the pound's weakness should add at least 125 million pounds to full-year adjusted profit based on 
Oct. 12 exchange rates.
However, on an underlying basis, which excludes the impact of currency exchange rates, revenue fell 4 percent, a 
weak result that saw Burberry shares slide 7 percent.
"Unfortunately, the U.K. makes up a relatively small percentage of Burberry's sales," said George Salmon, an 
equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown. "So while the group has managed to deliver improving like-for-like growth 
in its stores this quarter, this was achieved against a pretty unchallenging comparative period. Conditions remain 
difficult."
Meanwhile, Ryanair cited the slump in the pound as the airline cut its forecast for fiscal 2017 earnings by 5 percent. 
Ryanair said it now expects to report net income of 1.3 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros ($1.43 billion), still 7 
percent better than in 2016.
The pound's drop means that average second-half fares will fall by between 13 percent and 15 percent, compared 
with the previous forecast of 10 percent to 12 percent, the airline said.
"The recent sharp decline in (the pound) post Brexit will weaken second half yields by slightly more than we had 
originally expected," Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said in a statement. "We would caution that this revised 
guidance remains heavily dependent upon no further weakness in second half fares or (the pound) from its current 
levels."
___
Shawn Pogatchnik in Dublin contributed to this story.
Load-Date: October 19, 2016
End of Document
European Equities Advance as Higher Oil Price Supports Commodities Gains
European Equities Advance as Higher Oil Price Supports Commodities 
Gains
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 5:46 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 348 words
Body
 European stocks were trading higher on Tuesday morning as a jump in the price of oil provided a fillip for mining 
companies while financial services stocks edged up despite hawkish comments made by a member of the US 
central bank's rate-setting committee on Monday. 
Federal Reserve Vice Chair Stanley Fischer was widely reported as saying on Monday that the US' central bank is 
"very close" to its employment and inflation targets, comments which subsequently fueled bets that US 
policymakers may raise rates in December. 
Oil prices were extending gains meanwhile, with Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, up 0.7% at $51.87 
per barrel while West Texas Intermediate, the main US measure, had added 0.7% to $50.28 a barrel at the time of 
writing. 
In equities, commodities stocks were among the biggest gainers on London's FTSE 100 Index, with BHP Billiton 
(BHP) adding 2.2% and Rio Tinto (RIO) rising 2%. William Hill (WMH.L) gained 2.4% after Canadian online 
gambling company Amaya (AYA.TO) ended merger talks with the British bookmaker. 
UK homebuilder Bellway (BLY.L) rose 2.5% in London after its annual profit beat analyst forecasts, according to 
news reports. Low-cost airline Ryanair (RYA.L) rose 1.5% in London even after lowering its full-year profit forecast 
which it blamed on the drop in the value of the pound.
Financial stocks also advanced across the Continent. Societe General (GLE.PA) gained nearly 3% in Paris, 
Germany's Aareal Bank (ARL.DE) gained 3.5% and Deutsche Bank (DB) rose 2% in Frankfurt. 
Remy Cointreau (RCOP.PA) rose 2.9% in Paris after its second-quarter revenue result beat analyst estimates on 
higher demand for its alcoholic beverages in China, according to news reports. Food products company Danone 
European Equities Advance as Higher Oil Price Supports Commodities Gains
(BN.PA) rose 0.6% even after it reported third-quarter revenue that slightly missed analyst estimates, according to 
news reports. 
The Europe-wide STOXX 600 index rose 1.1% and the euro-region blue-chip STOXX 50 index gained 1.2%. 
Frankfurt's DAX added 0.8%, London's miner-heavy FTSE 100 climbed 1% and Paris' CAC 40 rose 1.2% at the 
time of writing.

Ryanair Cuts Full-Year Forecast for Profit Growth Following Slide in Sterling
Ryanair Cuts Full-Year Forecast for Profit Growth Following Slide in Sterling
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 7:30 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 342 words
Body
 Low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY, RYA.L) warned on Tuesday that its annual profit growth will be lower than it 
previously estimated as a fall in the value of Sterling following Britain's referendum on continued membership within 
the European Union (EU) hurts business. 
Profit in the year ending March 31 is now expected to grow by 7% rather than the 12% the company previously 
forecast. Net income is projected to be in the range of  of 1.3 billion euros ($1.43 billion) to 1.35 billion euros rather 
than in the previously predicted range of between 1.375 billion euros and 1.425 billion euros. 
"This decline is primarily due to the impact of weaker sterling on our second-half fares," Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's 
chief executive officer, said. "While higher load factors, stronger traffic growth and better cost control will help to 
ameliorate these weaker revenues, it is prudent now to adjust full year guidance." 
In the June referendum UK voters opted to exit the EU, a scenario frequently referred to as 'Brexit', with the result 
taking markets by surprise and resulting in a sharp slump in the UK currency. The pound fell to a 31-year low 
following the referendum and, after a period of recovery, it revisited those lows on speculation that the government 
might be willing abandon the single market in favor of controling immigration. 
The decline in sterling will reduce second-half average fares by between 13%-to-15% as opposed to the previously 
estimated 10%-to-12%, Ryanair said. Fares in the first half were 10% weaker compared with the initially estimated 
9%, the company said. 
The budget airline said it will pursue a strategy of making sure flights are loaded rather than focusing on ticket 
prices. Full-year load factor will be 1% better than previously seen at 94%, it said. Full-year traffic will increase to 
119 million passengers, 12% higher than last year. The impact of lower fares on earnings will also be partly offset 
by lower costs. Ryanair sees full-year ex-fuel unit costs declining by 3% rather than by 1% as previously expected. 
Ryanair Cuts Full-Year Forecast for Profit Growth Following Slide in Sterling
Load-Date: October 19, 2016
End of Document
European Shares Rally As Weak Dollar Lifts Commodity Prices
European Shares Rally As Weak Dollar Lifts Commodity Prices
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 12:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 438 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European stocks are rallying on Tuesday, as a weaker dollar supported commodity prices 
and soft U.S. data dented hopes of a Fed rate hike in November.   Well-received earnings updates from the likes of 
Hays Plc, Bellway and R\xE9my Cointreau also buoyed investor sentiment ahead of Chinese GDP data due on 
Wednesday and the ECB meeting on Thursday.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index is currently up 1.20 
percent at 341.46 in midday trading after closing 0.7 percent lower in the previous session. 
The German DAX is rallying 1.3 percent, France's CAC 40 index is moving up 1.2 percent and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 
is adding 0.9 percent.   R\xE9my Cointreau shares are up more than three percent in Paris. The wine & spirits 
company reported a 2.5 percent rise in first-half sales on the back of improved cognac sales in China and robust 
demand for its premium cognac in the United States.  Mining stocks such as Anglo American, BHP Billiton, 
Glencore and Rio Tinto are up 2-3 percent, while energy majors Tullow Oil, Royal Dutch Shell and BP Plc are 
climbing 1-3 percent.   Shares of Hays Plc are moving up 2 percent. The recruitment company reported growth in 
net fee income for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, led by strong performance in its international businesses.  
Bookmaker William Hill is adding 1.5 percent after it ended talks of a possible merger with Canadian online poker 
giant Amaya.  Homebuilder Bellway is up over 1 percent on reporting a jump in full-year profit and raising its 
dividend.  Continental shares are tumbling 2 percent after the German tire maker cut its earnings outlook for fiscal 
2016, citing antitrust and warranty provisions.  Swiss logistics firm Kuehne + Nagel Group is losing 3 percent after 
its earnings for the first nine months of fiscal 2016 missed estimates.   Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings is 
rallying 2.5 percent in London despite lowering its profit outlook.   On a relatively light day on the economic front, a 
government report showed that U.K. consumer inflation hit a two-year high in September on higher clothing and 
transport costs, as a result of the weakening pound since the EU referendum vote.   Inflation rose to 1 percent from 
0.6 percent in August versus expectations for a 0.9 percent increase. Factory gate prices also rose at a faster pace 
of 1.2 percent annually in September, following a rise of 0.9 percent in August.  Globally, most Asian shares rose 
today and U.S. stock futures indicate a positive open, as the dollar weakened against rivals on uncertainty over 
when the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.

Ryanair cuts profit forecast amid plunging pound
Ryanair cuts profit forecast amid plunging pound
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 12:47 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 239 words
Body
       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, on Tuesday warned that it expects its annual 
net profit to fall by up to 125 million euros (138 million dollars), mainly due to a plunge in the pound since Britain's 
Brexit vote.  The airline said it expects net profit of 1.3 billion to 1.35 billion euros, down 5 per cent from a previous 
forecast of 1.375 billion to 1.425 billion euros, after the pound lost about 18 per cent of its value against the dollar 
since the Brexit referendum on June 23.  The fall in the British currency will reduce Ryanair's average fares by up to 
15 per cent in the second half of this year, it said. 
 'While higher load factors, stronger traffic growth and better cost control will help to ameliorate these weaker 
revenues, it is prudent now to adjust full-year guidance, which will rise by approx 7 per cent rather than our original 
guidance of 12 per cent,' Ryanair owner Michael O'Leary said in a statement.  'This decline is primarily due to the 
impact of weaker sterling on our H2 fares,' O'Leary said, adding that the new forecast 'remains heavily dependent 
upon no further weakness in sterling from its current levels.'  Budget airline easyJet issued a similar warning earlier 
this month, saying its annual profit is likely to suffer a 90-million-pound hit from the plunging pound and further 
impact from a fall in passenger numbers caused by security fears.   Copyright dpa

Sterling hits Ryanair profits
Sterling hits Ryanair profits
Business World (Digest)
October 18, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 217 words
Byline: Sim Pinder
Body
Ryanair trimmed its full-year profit forecast by 5% on Tuesday because of the fall in the value of sterling and said 
that average fares could drop by up to 15% this winter.
Ryanair earns about a third of its revenues in sterling while about 20% of its costs are in the currency, a company 
spokesman said.
The low-cost airline, Europe's largest, said it expects net profit for the year to March 31 of between 1.3 billion euros 
and 1.35 billion euros, down from a previous forecast of 1.375 billion euros to 1.425 billion euros.
The mean forecast of 16 analysts polled by Reuters ahead of the profit warning was 1.383 billion euros.
"The primary cause of this slightly lower growth in full-year profitability is the 18% fall of sterling post-Brexit, which 
will reduce second-half average fares by between 13% and 15%," Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said in a 
statement.
"We would caution that this revised guidance remains heavily dependent upon no further weakness in second-half 
fares or sterling from its current levels," O'Leary added.
Rival easyJet, half of the passengers of which originate in the UK, has already cut its profit forecast for the year to 
Sept. 30 in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the European Union and the subsequent fall in sterling. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair Cuts FY Profit View Amid Weak Sterling Post Brexit
Ryanair Cuts FY Profit View Amid Weak Sterling Post Brexit
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 9:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 295 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) Tuesday said it has reduced its 
full year net profit guidance by 5% to a range of 1.30 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros from a previous range of 
1.375 billion euros to 1.425 billion euros.  The company attributed the revision in outlook primary to the 18% fall of 
Sterling post Brexit which will reduce second-half average fares by between 13% to 15% as opposed to the 
previously guided 10% to 12%.  For the full year, profits are now expected to grow by 7 percent, compared to 
previously expected growth of 12 percent.  Further, Ryanair confirmed that its first half fares were marginally 
weaker at minus 10%, compared to previously guided minus 9%. However, these lower fares will be partly offset by 
a better than expected cost performance. 
 Ryanair now expects full year ex-fuel unit costs to decline by 3% compared to previously guided 1%. Ryanair also 
expects full year load factor to be 1% better than guided at 94%, and now expects that full year traffic will increase 
to 119m, which is 12% growth on last year's 106m customers.  Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary said, 'The recent 
sharp decline in Sterling post Brexit (which accounts for approx. 26% of Ryanair's FY17 revenues) will weaken H2 
yields by slightly more than we had originally expected. While higher load factors, stronger traffic growth and better 
cost control will help to ameliorate these weaker revenues, it is prudent now to adjust full year guidance....'  O'Leary 
added that the company would caution that this revised guidance remains heavily dependent upon no further 
weakness in H2 fares or Sterling from its current levels.  In London, Ryanair shares were trading at 11.71 euros, 
down 0.85 percent.

European Shares Rally As Weak Dollar Lifts Commodity Prices
On a relatively light day on the economic front, a government report showed that U.K. consumer inflation hit a two-
year high in September on higher clothing and transport costs, as a result of the weakening pound since the EU 
referendum vote.

prices also rose at a faster pace of 1.2 percent annually in September, following a rise of 0.9 percent in August.

against rivals on uncertainty over when the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.

Ryanair Cuts FY Profit View Amid Weak Sterling Post Brexit - Quick Facts
Ryanair Cuts FY Profit View Amid Weak Sterling Post Brexit - Quick Facts
RTT News (United States)
October 18, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 307 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) Tuesday said it has reduced its full year net 
profit guidance by 5% to a range of 1.30 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros from a previous range of 1.375 billion 
euros to 1.425 billion euros.
The company attributed the revision in outlook primary to the 18% fall of Sterling post Brexit which will reduce 
second-half average fares by between 13% to 15% as opposed to the previously guided 10% to 12%.
For the full year, profits are now expected to grow by 7 percent, compared to previously expected growth of 12 
percent.
Further, Ryanair confirmed that its first half fares were marginally weaker at minus 10%, compared to previously 
guided minus 9%. However, these lower fares will be partly offset by a better than expected cost performance.
Ryanair now expects full year ex-fuel unit costs to decline by 3% compared to previously guided 1%. Ryanair also 
expects full year load factor to be 1% better than guided at 94%, and now expects that full year traffic will increase 
to 119m, which is 12% growth on last year's 106m customers.
Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary said, "The recent sharp decline in Sterling post Brexit (which accounts for approx. 
26% of Ryanair's FY17 revenues) will weaken H2 yields by slightly more than we had originally expected. While 
higher load factors, stronger traffic growth and better cost control will help to ameliorate these weaker revenues, it is 
prudent now to adjust full year guidance...."
O'Leary added that the company would caution that this revised guidance remains heavily dependent upon no 
further weakness in H2 fares or Sterling from its current levels.
In London, Ryanair shares were trading at 11.71 euros, down 0.85 percent.

Ryanair trims 2017 profit forecast as British pound weakens
Ryanair trims 2017 profit forecast as British pound weakens
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 8:57 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 125 words
Dateline: DUBLIN 
Body
DUBLIN (AP) - Budget airline Ryanair has cut its 2017 profit forecast citing the slump in the British pound.
The Irish-based carrier reports earnings in euros but does hefty business in the United Kingdom. Chief Executive 
Michael O'Leary says the 18 percent drop in the pound's value since Britain voted in June to leave the European 
Union has hurt the euro value of 26 percent of the airline's sales.
As a result, he said Tuesday, Ryanair's forecast for net profits in fiscal 2017 was being cut by 5 percent to a new 
range of 1.3 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros ($1.43 billion to $1.49 billion), still 7 percent better than in 2016.
Fuel costs are projected to fall 3 percent. The airline expects passenger volume to rise 12 percent to 119 million.
