October 18, 2016 Tuesday 10:27 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 306 words
Byline: Gavin Lumsden
Highlight: Higher-than-expected inflation reading blunts  rally in the pound but FTSE 100 extend gains. Luxury 
brands group Burberry tumble.
Body
A higher-than-expected inflation reading blunted a rally in the pound but saw the FTSE 100 extend its gains on the 
day.
Having jumped 0.6% against the dollar earlier, sterling traded just 0.0070 higher at $1.2250  and down 0.0036 
against the euro after the Office for National Statistics said the annual rate of inflation jumped to 1% last month, up 
from 0.6% in August. 
This was ahead of analyst forecasts of a 0.9% rise and is the highest level   in the consumer price index (CPI) since 
later 2014.
Tom Stevenson of Fidelity International, the fund manager, said: ‘The significant leap in the CPI from August has 
primarily been as a result of the plummeting pound which has pushed up fuel prices.
‘Even though 1% is still some way off the Bank of England’s 2% inflation target, the impact of currency changes 
works with a lag so further rises in CPI should be expected. Indeed, inflation is expected to continue its upward 
charge, with some economists predicting that CPI could reach as much as 3% by next year, considerably 
overshooting the Bank of England’s target.’
UK government bonds steadied after yesterday’s sell-off with the yield on benchmark 10-year gilts slipping 0.003 to 
1.123% as their price rose. Yields on shorter-term gilts rose however, as their prices fell, with two-year gilt yields 
adding 0.018% to 0.222%.
The FTSE 100 advanced 75 points or just over 1% to 7,022, led by Easyjet (EZJ) which rose 3.8% to 906.5p after a 
warning from rival Ryanair (RYA.I) that the sharp fall in the pound would reduce full-year profits. Its shares gained 
2.5% in Dublin.
The impact of a weak pound was evident in results from Burberry (BRBY). Shares in the luxury goods company 
dived 8.5% or £1.28 to £13.84 after warning of continued subdued demand in Hong Kong. However, the decline in 
the pound means in sterling terms sales had risen.
Sterling stalls, FTSE extends gains after inflation report
Load-Date: October 18, 2016
End of Document
European ADRs Head South as Educational Resources Provider Pearson Slumps
European ADRs Head South as Educational Resources Provider Pearson 
Slumps
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 17, 2016 Monday 10:38 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 271 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.4% lower at 117.75 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Monday morning.
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Marine Harvest (MHG),  a Norwegian seafood company, 4.0% lower, 
followed by Ascendis Pharma (ASND), a Danish clinical stage biopharmaceutical company, down by 2.2% and 
French energy company Total (TOT), 1.4% lower. Aixtron (AIXG), a German provider of deposition equipment to 
the semiconductor industry, was 1.3% lower. 
In the UK, Pearson (PSO), an education company, was 9.1% lower after the provider of academic textbooks, 
courseware, certifications and online learning resources, posted a decline in sales for the past three quarters. Amec 
Foster Wheeler (AMFC), a global engineering conglomerate, down by 3.7% and Adaptimmune Therapeutics 
(ADAP), a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, 1.8% lower. Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) was 1.6% lower. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by Sequans Communications (SQNS), a French developer of chipset 
solutions, 5.2% higher, followed by CGG (CGG), a manufacturer of geophysical equipment, up by 3.0% and Italian 
telecommunications company Telecom Italia (TI), 2.3% higher. Aegon - New York Shares (AEG), a Dutch life 
insurance, pensions and asset management company, was 1.7% higher. 
In the UK, Midatech Pharma (MTP), an early-stage biopharmaceutical company, was 3.7% higher, followed by 
telecommunications company BT Group (BT) and Amarin (AMRN), a biopharmaceutical company, both 1.0% 
higher, and low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY), 0.9% higher.  
Price: 1.73, Change: , Percent Change: +0.00
European ADRs Head South as Educational Resources Provider Pearson Slumps

Oporto's happier valley Wine
Oporto's happier valley; Wine
Financial Times (London, England)
October 15, 2016 Saturday
Europe Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FT WEEKEND SUPPLEMENT - LIFE & ARTS; Pg. 19
Length: 1121 words
Byline: Jancis Robinson
Body
It used to take the Symingtons of the famous port family 12 minutes to commute by speedboat between their two 
wine farms, Quinta do Bomfim and Quinta dos Malvedos, on the river Douro. Today it's much longer. They have to 
proceed with caution because of the wash from so many large pleasure boats. Ricardo Sousa Campos is the 
commercial director of Quinta da Romaneira and, like most of those in the northern Portuguese wine business, is 
based in the principal city, Oporto. However, he is trying to get out. "You can't move for tourists nowadays," he 
says. "Everyone's signing up for Airbnb ."
Oporto - or Porto as it is known in Portuguese - is buzzing, perhaps benefiting from the downturn in tourism to the 
likes of Turkey and north Africa. Ryanair flies in visitors from 12 countries, EasyJet from five.
Last month, for the first time in a few years, I visited the spruced-up city and the beautiful Douro valley upstream. I 
was amazed by the growth in tourism - not least because when I first visited the city in 1976 it was truly grimy and 
seemed to be full of dirty washing, cobbles and barefoot children. According to the official figures, the number of 
hotel-bed nights has risen by 57 per cent since 2012, with revenues from hotels alone up 70 per cent in the same 
period, not counting Airbnb and the like. Oporto expects to notch up 10m bed nights in 2018. On every corner there 
seem to be stylish bars and restaurants that would not look out of place in Barcelona or Milan, and even the staid 
old port lodges in Vila Nova de Gaia, across the river from the old city, have transformed themselves into wine-
themed "experiences", with multilingual guides, souvenir shops and eating places.
Oporto's happier valley Wine
Adrian Bridge, managing director of The Fladgate Partnership that - with Taylor, Fonseca and Croft - is a major 
player in the port business, is now almost better known as a hotelier. He converted a bit of land next to the Taylor's 
lodge in Vila Nova de Gaia into The Yeatman, a luxurious hotel with a Michelin-starred restaurant, and is now 
drawing up plans to transform the Infante de Sagres, Oporto's most famous hotel. Last winter he performed a 
similar trick on the Douro valley's biggest hotel, the Vintage House in Pinhão, which overlooks all those excursion 
boats.
There are generous EU subsidies and loans for both building and renovating hotels, which have encouraged other 
wine producers to go into the hotel business, not just in Oporto and Gaia but in what was until recently the sparsely 
populated Douro valley , adding considerably to employment prospects there. Quinta de la Rosa, just outside 
Pinhão, for example, operates a popular small hotel as well as an admired wine farm.
The team behind another highly regarded producer of Douro table wines, Quinta do Vallado, has built 13 rooms at 
the quinta downstream of Pinhão and, more ambitiously, has created an eco-friendly eight-room hotel, Casa do Rio 
(river house), way upriver in the deserted Douro Superior region on the Spanish border. João Ferreira Álvares 
Ribeiro of Quinta do Vallado told me that from May this year they have enjoyed 100 per cent occupancy, and that 
their activities providing bed and board now represent 20 per cent of total turnover. "We stick to table d'hôte, so the 
margins are good - much better than in the wine business," he said. He is worried that tourism in his region is 
growing dangerously fast but admits that it certainly helps the reputation of his wines: "This year we'll sell 
EUR200,000 worth of wine in our shop - at double margin. That's more than our sales to most export markets."
The growth of tourism must be some consolation for wine exporters, who are grappling with the fallout from the 
economic collapse of their biggest export markets, Angola and Brazil.
The evolution of the Douro valley from deserted Unesco World Heritage site to tourist playground has been helped 
enormously by road building. Part of the magic of the Douro's extreme climate - blisteringly hot summers and 
testing winters - is because of the mountains as high as Ben Nevis that shield it from the Atlantic. When Adrian 
Bridge first came to Portugal in 1982 it took five-and-a-half hours to drive to Taylor's famous Quinta de Vargellas in 
the Douro valley; it now takes no more than two, thanks in particular to a 5.4km tunnel that opened last May. It is so 
new that when wine producer Dirk Niepoort drove me to the airport from the Douro last month, he initially forgot the 
new time-saving route.
It was only in the late 1970s that electricity arrived in the Douro, facilitated by the dams that have transformed a 
fast-moving river with rapids, over which flat-bottomed boats loaded with barrels of port used to be navigated every 
spring, into a series of lakes connected with locks for the pleasure boats. Port used to be foot-trodden in semi-
darkness but rising labour costs and electricity have resulted in a range of automated alternatives, involving various 
forms of stainless steel and silicone pads to emulate the human sole.
In the old days, when local workers were expected to spend eight hours picking grapes in the steep vineyards, 
followed by four treading them, are long gone, although a small proportion of top-quality port is still trodden by 80 
sticky purple feet. (This has, in its time, caused upset in some of the more fastidious markets - such as Japan.)
Looking ahead to even greater challenges finding labour, one of the most powerful port technicians, Charles 
Symington, of the family responsible for Dow, Graham, Warre and now Cockburn ports, has just begun trying out a 
mechanical harvester in the Douro. The terrain is so steep and varied that it is not an obvious candidate for 
mechanisation, but he is using a machine designed for the precipitous vineyards of the Mosel valley in Germany. 
The only modification needed, apparently, was a reverse gear - something it is far too late for the five Symington 
cousins, who invest all their dividends in new vineyards, to apply.
More columns at ft.com/robinson
Ports worth flying in for
Bottle-aged ports
Oporto's happier valley Wine
  Quinta do Noval 2014 (£495 a dozen in bond, Farr Vintners)
  Quinta de Vargellas, VinhaVelha 2011 (£245 a bottle, The Vintage Port Shop, Hampshire)
  Dow 2011 (£125 a bottle, Soho Wine Supply)
  Taylor 2000 (£344.04 for six bottles, Berry Bros & Rudd)
  Quinta do Vesuvio 1994 (£53.59 a bottle, Nethergate Wines)
  Quinta de Vargellas 1987 (£79.95 a bottle, The Vintage Port Shop)
  Graham 1985 (£60 a bottle, Palmers Wine Store, Dorset)
  Taylor 1977 (£99 a bottle, Four Walls Wine)
  Quinta dos Malvedos 1965 (£225 a bottle, Cambridge Wine Merchants)
Wood-aged ports
  Graham 1972 Single Harvest (£207 a bottle, Hedonism)
  Taylor 40-year-old tawny (£98.98 a bottle, Winedancer.com )

Oporto's happier valley Food and Drink - Wine
Oporto's happier valley; Food and Drink - Wine
Financial Times (London, England)
October 15, 2016 Saturday
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FT MAGAZINE; Pg. 49
Length: 1143 words
Byline: Jancis Robinson
Highlight: 'Oporto is buzzing - and even Vila Nova de Gaia's staid old port lodges have transformed themselves'
Body
It used to take the Symingtons of the famous port family 12 minutes to commute by speedboat between their two 
wine farms, Quinta do Bomfim and Quinta dos Malvedos, on the river Douro. Today it's much longer. They have to 
proceed with unaccustomed caution because of the wash
from so many large pleasure boats. Ricardo Sousa Campos is the commercial director of Quinta da Romaneira 
and, like most of those in the northern Portuguese wine business, is based in the principal city, Oporto. However, 
he is trying to get out. "You can't move for tourists nowadays," he says. "Everyone's signing up for Airbnb."

staid old port lodges in Vila Nova de Gaia, across the river from the old city, have transformed themselves into

Oporto's happier valley Food and Drink - Wine
Adrian Bridge, managing director of The Fladgate Partnership that - with Taylor, Fonseca and Croft - is a major 
player in the port business, is now almost better known as a hotelier. He converted a bit of land next to the Taylor's 
lodge in Vila Nova de Gaia into The Yeatman, a luxurious hotel with a Michelin-starred restaurant, and is now 
drawing up plans to transform the Infante de Sagres, Oporto's most famous hotel. Last winter he performed a

boats.

wine producers to go into the hotel business, not just in Oporto and Gaia but up in what was until recently the 
sparsely populated Douro valley, adding considerably to employment prospects there. Quinta de la Rosa, just

the quinta downstream of Pinhão and, more ambitiously, has created an eco-friendly eight-room hotel, Casa do Rio 
(river house), way upriver in the deserted Douro Superior region on the Spanish border. João Ferreira Alvares

the Douro valley; it now takes no more than two, thanks in particular to a 5.4km tunnel that opened last May. It is so 
new that when wine producer Dirk Niepoort drove me to the airport from the Douro last month, he initially forgot to 
take the new time-saving route.

fast-moving river with rapids, over which flat-bottomed boats loaded with barrels of port used to be navigated every 
spring, into a series of lakes connected with locks for the pleasure boats. Port used to be foot-trodden in semi-
darkness but rising labour costs and the arrival of electricity have resulted in a range of automated alternatives, 
involving various forms of stainless steel and silicone pads, designed to emulate the human sole.
In the old days, when local workers were expected to spend eight hours picking grapes in the steep vineyards, 
followed by four treading them in the winery, are long gone, although a small proportion of top-quality port is still 
(just) trodden by 80 sticky purple feet. (This has, in its time, caused upset in some of the more fastidious markets - 
Japan, for instance.)
Looking ahead to even greater challenges finding labour, one of the most powerful port technicians, Charles 
Symington, of the family responsible for Dow, Graham, Warre and now Cockburn ports, has just begun trying out a 
mechanical grape harvester in the Douro. The terrain is so steep and varied that it is far from an obvious candidate 
for mechanisation, but he is using a machine designed for the precipitous vineyards of the Mosel valley in Germany.
The only modification needed, apparently, was a reverse gear - something it is far too late for the five Symington 
cousins, who invest all their dividends in new vineyards, to apply.

European ADRs Edge Higher in Friday Trading
European ADRs Edge Higher in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 14, 2016 Friday 12:29 PM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 239 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks rose 0.06% to 118.35 on the Bank of New York Mellon Europe 
ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, gainers were led by geoscience firm CGG (CGG), and Italian telecommunications firm 
Telecom Italia (TI), which rose 3% each. They were followed by 3D printing company Materialise (MTLS), which 
climbed 2.7%, and technology company Criteo (CRTO), which was up 2.4%.
Decliners in continental Europe were led by Forward Pharma (FWP), and Ascendis Pharma (ASND), which fell 
4.9% and 3.3% respectively. They were followed by agricultural company Syngenta (SYT), and biopharmaceutical 
company DBV Technologies (DBVT), which lost 2.6% and 1.3% each.
In the U.K. and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical firm Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which climbed 
5.8%, and education and media company Pearson (PSO), which rose 2%. They were followed by Luxfer (LXFR), a 
global materials technology company, and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which were up 1.4% and 1.3% 
respectively. 
Decliners in the U.K. and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical company Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), and 
gold mining company Randgold Resources (GOLD), which fell 4.2% and 3.8% each. They were followed by Trinity 
Biotech (TRIB), which makes medical diagnostic products, and pharmaceutical company Shire (SHPG), which 
dropped 1.7% and 1.6% respectively. 
Price: 28.36, Change: +0.42, Percent Change: +1.51

Ryanair extends Belfast summer 2017 schedule
Ryanair extends Belfast summer 2017 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
October 13, 2016 Thursday 5:56 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 205 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has extended its Belfast summer 2017 schedule with a new route to Barcelona Girona 
starting in March 2017, in addition to 10 new summer services including Berlin, London and Milan.
Body
Ryanair's summer 2017 schedule will also see more frequencies to sun destinations for family holidays, lower fares 
(as Ryanair passes on lower fuel costs), an even better customer experience as it rolls out year 3 of its "Always 
Getting Better" customer experience programme, and will deliver: 1 new route: Girona (2 wkly); 10 new summer 
services including Lanzarote (2 wkly), Malaga (5 wkly) & Tenerife (2 wkly); 12 routes in total including London 
Gatwick (4 daily); 1.1m customers p.a.; and over 800 "on-site" jobs p.a. Ryanair's Head of Communications, Robin 
Kiely said: "To celebrate our new Belfast-Girona route, we are releasing seats for sale from just GBP24.99 for travel 
in March and April, which are available for booking until Thursday (29 Sep). Since these amazing low prices will be 
snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Uel Hoey, Belfast 
International Business Development Director, said: "Barcelona Girona is further proof of Ryanair's commitment to 
creating choice for Northern Ireland passengers and delivering pretty impressive growth from its new Belfast base. 
Once again, we will see more airline and airport-related jobs being created at no cost to the taxpayer."

Keywords Studios appoints group finance director
Keywords Studios appoints group finance director
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
October 13, 2016 Thursday 8:40 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: TECHNOLOGY & TELECOMMUNICATIONS
Length: 244 words
Highlight: Keywords Studios plc, a technical service provider to the video game industry, has appointed David 
Broderick as group finance director.
Body
David, will be based in Dublin and will replace Andrew Lawton who, after two years with the Group, has decided to 
pursue other opportunities closer to his home in the UK. Andrew will remain with the Group over the next month to 
work closely with David to ensure a smooth transition. 
David joins Keywords from Dublin-based Arconics, a high-growth aviation software company where he has been 
CFO since early 2015. Prior to this, David was the Finance Director of European regional airline, Stobart Air 
(formerly Aer Arann), during a period of significant growth in 2013-2014. David previously spent eight years at 
Europe's largest low-cost airline, Ryanair Holdings plc, the latter six years of which were spent as Head of Investor 
Relations and overseeing the group's Inflight Sales Unit's finances and operations. Andrew Day, Chief Executive of 
Keywords, "On behalf of the Board, I would like to thank Andrew for his positive contribution to the Group over the 
last two years. During his tenure, the Group has grown from 10 to 23 facilities across Europe, North and South 
America and Asia and achieved a near five-fold increase in revenues through organic growth and nine 
acquisitions." "We are delighted to welcome David to the Group. His extensive experience of working as a senior 
member of management teams within a number of high growth businesses will no doubt prove invaluable as we 
continue to develop Keywords Studios both organically and by acquisition."

Michael O'Leary offers to build P200m terminal at Dublin Airport
Michael O'Leary offers to build P200m terminal at Dublin Airport
Business World (Digest)
October 12, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 275 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
The Irish Times has today reported that Ryanair Chief Executive, Michael O’Leary, told a gathering that included 
Government ministers that his airline would provide a third terminal at Dublin Airport for €200 million.   There is 
speculation that Dublin Airport will need a third terminal if growth continues at the pace that saw it handle a record 
25 million passengers last year.
Mr O’Leary agrees that Dublin will need a third terminal but warns that the airport’s manager, State-owned DAA, 
should not have any involvement in it.   Mr O’Leary said recently Ryanair could provide the third facility and would 
do it for €200 million. The airline chief executive and DAA clashed regularly over the design and cost of the airport’s 
second terminal, which was completed in 2010. During that controversy, Ryanair several times said that it could 
build and operate a second terminal at Dublin itself.   According to the report, Mr O’Leary offered to build the third 
terminal when he was speaking to a Fine Gael business breakfast attended by several cabinet members, including 
Minister for Finance, Michael Noonan, and his colleagues Leo Varadkar, Simon Coveney and Richard Bruton last 
week.    He repeated Ryanair’s position that airlines should not pay any more for Dublin’s proposed second runway 
than the collective €250 million agreed with the Commission for Aviation Regulation two years ago.
This would add about 59 cent to the airport’s current passenger charge, which is capped at €9.87 a head. DAA has 
estimated that the cost of the new runway is likely to be €320 million, which could increase passenger charges.   
Source: www.businessworld.ie
About us
Load-Date: October 20, 2016
Michael O'Leary offers to build P200m terminal at Dublin Airport
End of Document
European Stocks Post Modest Gains as Designer Brands Edge Higher
European Stocks Post Modest Gains as Designer Brands Edge Higher
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 11, 2016 Tuesday 5:04 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 317 words
Body
 European stocks were marginally higher on Tuesday morning as gains by designer goods retailers offset declines 
by airlines that were dragged down by a jump in oil prices during the previous session. 
Brent oil, the international benchmark, was flat at $53.18 per barrel, at the time of writing after rising 3.4% in 
Monday, while West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark, was 0.1% higher at $51.42 a barrel, after adding 4.2% 
the day before. Oil trading sentiment has been influenced of late by Russia's announcement that it would join 
members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in curbing oil output.
OPEC is responsible for generating around 40% of oil globally and an agreement to lower oil production arrived at 
in principle towards the end of September is expected to be finalised at OPEC's meeting in Vienna before the end 
of the year.
In equities, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton (MC.PA) rose nearly 5% after reporting third-quarter sales that 
beat expectations. Other clothing and accessories retailers, such as Christian Dior, (CDI.PA), rose 4.5% in Paris 
and Burberry (BRBY.L) gained 2.8% in London. Hugo Boss (BOSS.DE) climbed 2.6% in Frankfurt.  
Aviation stocks were among the decliners in the morning session. Air France (AF.PA) dropped 1.1% and aircraft 
maker Airbus (AIR.PA) declined 2.5% in Paris. EasyJet (EZJ.L)  fell 0.8% in London, while Ryanair (RY4C.IR) 
dropped 1.1% in Dublin. 
And Victrex, (VCT.L) a supplier of polymers for industrial uses, soared more than 10% in London after posting 
annual sales that beat forecasts. Utility company E.ON (EOAN) rose 2% and Uniper (UN01.F) formed after the 
separation of E.ON fossil fuel assets into a separate company, gained 0.9% in Frankfurt. 
The pan-European STOXX 600 index slid 0.03%, London's FTSE 100 Index was 0.13% higher, Frankfurt's DAX 
was up by 0.11% and Paris' CAC-40 was 0.17% higher at the time of writing.
European Stocks Post Modest Gains as Designer Brands Edge Higher
Load-Date: October 12, 2016
End of Document
O’Leary: I would sack all Garda strikers
O’Leary: I would sack all Garda strikers
Sunday Business Post
October 9, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 366 words
Byline: Hugh O’Connell
Highlight: Ryanair boss brands RTÉ ‘North Korean rat-infested union shop’
Body
Michael O’Leary has said thousands of gardaí should be sacked if they do not show up for work next month, and 
compared RTÉ to North Korea.  
The Ryanair chief executive said the threat of industrial action by rank-and-file gardaí was “immoral”.  
O’Leary was addressing a private Fine Gael breakfast fundraiser in the Shelbourne Hotel last Wednesday.  
The event was attended by Minister for Finance Michael Noonan, who described O’Leary as Ireland’s “leading 
altogether decent man”. Several Fine Gael ministers, TDs and senators, as well as representatives from a number 
of top accountancy firms attended. 
O’Leary said RTÉ was a “North Korean rat-infested union shop” as he criticised the way in which it reported the 
recent bus strikes. 
The Garda Representative Association (GRA), which acts on behalf of 10,500 rank-and-file gardaí, has said 
members will unilaterally withdraw services next month after they rejected a revised pay deal from the Department 
of Justice. Talks are ongoing between the department and the GRA in a bid to resolve the dispute and avoid a 
mass walk-out of gardaí on November 4, 11, 18 and 25.  
O’Leary said that if 6,000 guards staged a walk-out, he would sack them all. He made the comparison to former US 
president Ronald Reagan’s decision to sack air traffic controllers when they went on strike in the 1980s.  
“He thinks we should go full Reagan on them,” said one backbencher who attended the event.  
While O’Leary said gardaí did a “fantastic job”, he did not believe they should be allowed to go on strike. He said 
gardaí earned higher than the average industrial wage and were allowed to retire after 30 years of service. In a 
O’Leary: I would sack all Garda strikers
wide-ranging speech and Q&A, O’Leary criticised striking bus workers and said he despised the way Dublin City 
Council pandered to cyclists “who pay nothing”.  
He said the state was “shit” at providing transport services and “really crap” at running the health service, saying 
they should both be privatised.  
O’Leary is said to have dismissed the notion that private sector workers are treated worse than public sector 
workers. He claimed that Ryanair workers were not unionised because they had good working conditions and were 
well paid.

Stocks See Further Downside Following Early Pullback - U.S. Commentary
Stocks See Further Downside Following Early Pullback - U.S. Commentary
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 7, 2016 Friday 6:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 553 words
Body
       WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - After moving modestly lower earlier in the session, stocks have seen some further 
downside in recent trading on Friday. The major averages have slid firmly into negative territory, hitting new lows for 
the session.   In recent trading, the major averages have climbed off their worst levels of the day. The Dow is down 
89.40 points or 0.5 percent at 18,179.10, the Nasdaq is down 33.58 points or 0.6 percent at 5,273.27 and the S&P 
500 is down 13.51 points or 0.6 percent at 2,147.26.  The weakness on Wall Street comes following the release of a 
report from the Labor Department showing that U.S. employment increased by less than expected in the month of 
September. 
 The report said non-farm payroll employment climbed by 156,000 jobs in September compared to economist 
estimates for an increase of about 176,000 jobs.  While the job gains in August were upwardly revised to 167,000 
from 151,000, the job growth in July was downwardly revised to 252,000 from 275,000.  The Labor Department also 
said the unemployment rate edged up to 5.0 percent in September from 4.9 percent in August. Economists had 
expected the unemployment rate to remain unchanged.  Meanwhile, the report said average hourly employee 
earnings rose by 6 cents to $25.79. Compared to the same month a year ago, average hourly earnings were up by 
2.6 percent.  Speaking at the Institute of International Finance's annual meeting in Washington, D.C., Federal 
Reserve Vice Chair Stanley Fischer said the jobs data was 'pretty close' to an ideal 'Goldilocks' reading.  Fischer 
said the rate of job growth is 'fully consistent' with a continued decline in unemployment and suggested the U.S. is 
close to full employment.  Analysts said the weaker than expected job growth should quell any speculation of an 
interest rate hike at Fed's next meeting in November, although a rate hike at the December meeting remains on the 
table.  Sector News  Chemical stocks have shown a substantial move to the downside on the day, dragging the 
Dow Jones Chemicals Index down by 1.9 percent. The pullback by the index comes after it ended the previous 
session at its best closing level in a month.  PPG Industries (PPG) is leading the chemical sector lower after 
warning of much weaker than expected third quarter earnings.  Significant weakness has also emerged among 
airline stocks, as reflected by the 1.4 percent drop by the NYSE Arca Airline Index. Ryanair (RYAAY) is posting a 
particularly steep loss.  Tobacco, natural gas, housing, and electronic storage stocks have also come under 
pressure, moving lower along with most of the other major sectors.  Other Markets  In overseas trading, stock 
markets across the Asia-Pacific region moved to the downside during trading on Friday. Japan's Nikkei 225 Index 
Stocks See Further Downside Following Early Pullback - U.S. Commentary
dipped by 0.2 percent, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell by 0.4 percent.  Meanwhile, the major European 
markets turned in a mixed performance on the day. While the U.K.'s FTSE 100 Index advanced by 0.6 percent, the 
German DAX Index and the French CAC 40 Index both dropped by 0.7 percent.  In the bond market, treasuries are 
seeing modest weakness, extending a recent downward trend. As a result, the yield on the benchmark ten-year 
note, which moves opposite of its price, is up by 1.7 basis points at 1.759 percent.

Stocks See Further Downside Following Early Pullback - U.S. Commentary
Stocks See Further Downside Following Early Pullback - U.S. Commentary
RTT News (United States)
October 7, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 561 words
Body
(RTTNews) - After moving modestly lower earlier in the session, stocks have seen some further downside in recent 
trading on Friday. The major averages have slid firmly into negative territory, hitting new lows for the session.
In recent trading, the major averages have climbed off their worst levels of the day. The Dow is down 89.40 points 
or 0.5 percent at 18,179.10, the Nasdaq is down 33.58 points or 0.6 percent at 5,273.27 and the S&P 500 is down 
13.51 points or 0.6 percent at 2,147.26.
The weakness on Wall Street comes following the release of a report from the Labor Department showing that U.S. 
employment increased by less than expected in the month of September.
The report said non-farm payroll employment climbed by 156,000 jobs in September compared to economist 
estimates for an increase of about 176,000 jobs.
While the job gains in August were upwardly revised to 167,000 from 151,000, the job growth in July was 
downwardly revised to 252,000 from 275,000.
The Labor Department also said the unemployment rate edged up to 5.0 percent in September from 4.9 percent in 
August. Economists had expected the unemployment rate to remain unchanged.
Meanwhile, the report said average hourly employee earnings rose by 6 cents to $25.79. Compared to the same 
month a year ago, average hourly earnings were up by 2.6 percent.
Speaking at the Institute of International Finance's annual meeting in Washington, D.C., Federal Reserve Vice 
Chair Stanley Fischer said the jobs data was "pretty close" to an ideal "Goldilocks" reading.
Fischer said the rate of job growth is "fully consistent" with a continued decline in unemployment and suggested the 
U.S. is close to full employment.
Analysts said the weaker than expected job growth should quell any speculation of an interest rate hike at Fed's 
next meeting in November, although a rate hike at the December meeting remains on the table.
Sector News
Stocks See Further Downside Following Early Pullback - U.S. Commentary
Chemical stocks have shown a substantial move to the downside on the day, dragging the Dow Jones Chemicals 
Index down by 1.9 percent. The pullback by the index comes after it ended the previous session at its best closing 
level in a month.
PPG Industries (PPG) is leading the chemical sector lower after warning of much weaker than expected third 
quarter earnings.
Significant weakness has also emerged among airline stocks, as reflected by the 1.4 percent drop by the NYSE 
Arca Airline Index. Ryanair (RYAAY) is posting a particularly steep loss.
Tobacco, natural gas, housing, and electronic storage stocks have also come under pressure, moving lower along 
with most of the other major sectors.
Other Markets
In overseas trading, stock markets across the Asia-Pacific region moved to the downside during trading on Friday. 
Japan's Nikkei 225 Index dipped by 0.2 percent, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell by 0.4 percent.
Meanwhile, the major European markets turned in a mixed performance on the day. While the U.K.'s FTSE 100 
Index advanced by 0.6 percent, the German DAX Index and the French CAC 40 Index both dropped by 0.7 percent.
In the bond market, treasuries are seeing modest weakness, extending a recent downward trend. As a result, the 
yield on the benchmark ten-year note, which moves opposite of its price, is up by 1.7 basis points at 1.759 percent.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com
Copyright(c) 2016 RTTNews.com. All Rights Reserved
Load-Date: October 8, 2016
End of Document
Clouds ahead: EasyJet profits in rapid descent
Clouds ahead: EasyJet profits in rapid descent
Financial Times (London, England)
October 7, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 25
Length: 389 words
Byline: Robert Wright
Body
Full-year pre-tax profits at easyJet were set to fall by a sharper than expected 28 per cent, Europe's second-biggest 
low-cost carrier warned yesterday.
The company's trading update , ahead of full results in November, follows a profit warning in June prompted by 
economic uncertainty, excess airline capacity and air traffic disruption.
But Carolyn McCall , chief executive, said tough conditions represented an opportunity for easyJet to "build and 
strengthen" its market position.
The company said it expected full-year pre-tax profits in a range between £490m and £495m, compared with 
£686m for the year to September 30, 2015 .
While easyJet has not previously forecast its profit for the year, analysts had expected a figure of between £497m 
and £517m.
EasyJet shares were down 6.9 per cent to a three-year low in London yesterday.
A series of European airlines have issued profit warnings as they absorb the impact of terrorist incidents, air traffic 
control disruption and economic uncertainty at a time when fleets are growing rapidly.
Clouds ahead: EasyJet profits in rapid descent
EasyJet's exposure to some of the markets suffering most severely from terrorism and its heavy dependence on the 
UK, where demand has suffered after the Brexit vote, has hit it hard.
The company faces a challenge from Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline by passenger numbers, which has 
consistently lower costs than its rival.
It said yesterday that its cost per seat, excluding fuel, was likely to fall a better than expected 1.1 per cent for the 
year ending September 30, after stripping out the effects of currency movements.
However, the company expected the negative effect of currency movements to reduce pre-tax profits by £90m 
compared with the previous year, a £35m increase from its forecast in June. It expected a similar impact for 2016-
17.
The company faces one-off costs for setting up an operation in mainland Europe to ensure it can continue to 
operate flights between EU countries once its base in Luton, near London, is outside the bloc.
The airline carried 73.1m passengers during the financial year, up 6.6 per cent on the previous year.
Ms McCall said: "We have been disproportionately affected by extraordinary events this year but our excellent 
network, cost control and revenue initiatives and our strong balance sheet underpin our confidence in the 
business."  Robert Wright
See Lex
Load-Date: October 6, 2016
End of Document
The blame Dame
The blame Dame
Financial Times (London, England)
October 7, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 14
Length: 358 words
Body
Airlines are fond of blaming delays and cancellations on external and "one-off" factors. They take the same 
approach to profit warnings; easyJet chief executive Dame Carolyn McCall said yesterday that full-year profits 
would be some £25m below consensus forecasts because of service disruption from strikes and terrorism, and 
currency movements.
Her excuses are justified. EasyJet is the biggest short-haul carrier in the UK (half of revenues) and the second-
biggest in France, so it is more exposed than peers to the effects of Brexit and terror attacks in Paris and Nice. 
Unlike Ryanair and Wizz, it reports in sterling, so it is no surprise that a weak pound has added £90m to full-year 
costs.
Dame Carolyn has also railed against the "irrational" expansion of other airlines . Here, she is on shakier ground. 
easyJet's own capacity grew 6.1 per cent in its final fiscal quarter and is set to grow by more next year. So far, it 
has filled those extra seats, but only by cutting prices. Revenue per seat was almost 9 per cent lower in the quarter.
True, easyJet has judiciously controlled the costs it can. But non-fuel expenses are set to rise slightly next year, 
even before any additional burden arising from negotiations with the pilots' union .
And while fuel costs will drop sharply - four-fifths of this year's requirements are hedged at almost $200 per tonne 
less than the previous year's - they will do so at other carriers, too. Ryanair has already pledged to pass on its 
sharply lower fuel costs in the form of lower fares.
The blame Dame
The 6 per cent fall yesterday means easyJet shares have almost halved over the past year, worse than low-cost 
peers. Pre-tax profit forecasts have come down by a third in the past six months. There is a silver lining: lower tax 
rates applied to deferred liabilities mean net income will fall by less than pre-tax profit.
That implies a dividend (based on a payout ratio of half of post tax income) of 53p a share for a yield of 5.6 per 
cent, higher than more challenged rivals such as Lufthansa and IAG. But like many of its setbacks, the tax windfall 
too is an external, one-off affair.
Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com 
Load-Date: October 6, 2016
End of Document
S&N falters after broker predicts more setbacks ahead; London
S&N falters after broker predicts more setbacks ahead; London
Financial Times (London, England)
October 7, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS & INVESTING; Pg. 33
Length: 423 words
Byline: Bryce Elder
Body
Smith & Nephew was among yesterday's biggest fallers after Berenberg cut the medical devices maker from its 
"buy" list.
Management's record of anticipating problems was "not great", while its conservative approach to the balance 
sheet was limiting growth prospects, the broker said.
The shares - which were trading ex a 12.3p dividend - slid 3.4 per cent to £12.22.
While S&N had been doing the right thing by cutting costs and investing in growth, the benefits over the past five 
years had been "largely offset by various mis-steps and one-off headwinds", said Berenberg.
Earnings growth has been blunted by issues including China market destocking, a slump in demand for metal-on-
metal hip replacements, the 2014 product recall of its Renasys wound therapy, and the failure of experimental 
spray-on skin.
Given S&N's diverse nature, both by geography and product, further setbacks were likely, the broker added.
On the possibility of S&N being a takeover target, Berenberg saw Johnson & Johnson as a more viable bidder than 
Stryker or private equity funds, which it said would struggle to find an exit.
S&N falters after broker predicts more setbacks ahead; London
S&N had been viewed as a takeout candidate since 1968, when Unilever launched a failed bid, and "investors 
cannot wait for ever", said Berenberg.
A sharp jump in gilt yields weighed across the wider market, pushing the FTSE 100 lower by 0.5 per cent, or 33.29 
points, to 6,999.96.
Airlines faded on a cautious update from easyJet , which dropped 6.9 per cent to a three-year low of 933.5p. British 
Airways owner IAG lost 3.9 per cent to 381.3p and Ryanair slid 1.2 per cent to sEUR11.74.
Marks and Spencer led the retailers lower, losing 2.1 per cent to 330.6p. Numis Securities downgraded M&S to 
"reduce" as part of research advising wariness of mature retailers, which it expected to underperform as Brexit 
weighed on employment growth.
Numis also turned cautious on Halfords , down 1.1 per cent to 347.1p, and Next , which slipped 1.2 per cent to 
£47.47.
Dunelm , a soft furnishings retailer, lost 4 per cent to 823p after reporting a difficult start to its financial year.
Leading the FTSE gainers, Croda took on 1.5 per cent to £36.11. UBS upgraded from "sell" to buy", largely on a 
positive view of the chemicals group's investment in a US bioethanol refinery.
With costs due to normalise in 2018, Croda would have the balance sheet capacity to nearly double its dividend and 
spend £100m a year on bolt-on acquisitions, UBS forecast.
Engineer GKN advanced 0.5 per cent to 333p. HSBC started coverage with a "buy" rating and 395p target price.
Load-Date: October 6, 2016
End of Document
Low cost airline Norwegian flies high as passenger numbers up
Low cost airline Norwegian flies high as passenger numbers up
City A.M.
October 7, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 165 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
LOW COST airline Norwegian carried nearly 2.8m passengers in September - an increase of 14 per cent on the 
same month last year.
Close to three million passengers flew with the airline last month, while total traffic growth increased by 21 per cent 
and capacity growth was up 19 per cent.
Norwegian CEO Bjorn Kjos said: "September's figures show that our positive development continues across all 
markets, both with more passengers and a high load factor.
"It is also satisfying to see that more customers are choosing Norwegian when they are flying between the US and 
Europe and Europe and Asia."
The airline's fleet renewal programme has been continuing throughout this year with the delivery of 21 new aircraft.
Kjos has previously praised the virtues of budget airlines. He noted in the mid-2000s that when fuel prices soared 
and competition from Ryanair and Easyjet became fierce, his airline would have to buy fuel-efficient planes and 
expand to new locations. It launched UK flights in 2003.

CITY MOVES WHO'S SWITCHING JOBS

October 6, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 19
Length: 408 words
Body
PAYPAL UK Mark Brant has been named managing director of PayPal UK. Mark has been promoted to this role 
following his tenure as general manager, merchant services UK. Mark joined PayPal UK in 2008 as director of large 
merchant sales before promotions to sales director and general manager of merchant services, UK in 2012. During 
his time leading the merchant services team, Mark has increased PayPal's availability as a way to pay across new 
and diverse sectors with significant new business customers including John Lewis and Ryanair, as well as Parent 
Mail. Before joining PayPal, Mark spent nine years at American Express where he led UK sales, retail and client 
management.
LGT VESTRA LGT Vestra has appointed Mark Myers to its financial mutuals team as a strategic adviser. Mark is 
stepping down in 2017 from his position as CEO of protection provider British Friendly Society after nearly seven 
years in the role. Mark's vision and forward thinking on the opportunities for the friendly societies sector are well 
known, and his appointment further strengthens LGT Vestra's positioning within this market. Mark will advise LGT 
Vestra on enhancing its position in the market, ensuring the firm continually improves its service offering to the 
friendly societies and financial mutuals, to meet this sector's ever increasing complex needs.
METRO BANK Metro Bank has appointed Andy Hallett as director of property and Hannah-Louise Smith as director 
of cash management and deposits. Both will report directly to Mark Stokes, managing director of commercial 
banking. Andy will be responsible for leading the bank's commercial property business and Hannah-Louise will 
oversee growing the Metro Bank's operational cash deposits and net interest income. Joining from NatWest, Andy 
was previously managing director - real estate finance. Hannah-Louise was formerly UK head of liquidity solutions 
for SME banking at Lloyds Banking Group.
ALDERMORE Aldermore has appointed Stuart Baty as head of business development - south for its invoice finance 
division. Stuart will be responsible for supporting SMEs across the south who need access to funding to grow their 
business. In his new role, Stuart will be reporting to Chris Meldrum, national business development director for 
CITY MOVES WHO'S SWITCHING JOBS
Aldermore invoice finance. Stuart has over 15 years of experience in providing finance to SMEs. He joins 
Aldermore from Santander where he was a director in the Invoice finance team.

Ryanair Slides 1% Impacted by EasyJet 's FY Profit Warning as UK Pound Continues Post-Brexit Decline
Ryanair Slides 1% Impacted by EasyJet's FY Profit Warning as UK Pound 
Continues Post-Brexit Decline
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 6, 2016 Thursday 11:07 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 130 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) American depositary shares were trading more than 1% lower on Thursday in 
sympathy with easyJet as the London-listed low-cost carrier issued a profit warning and as UK airlines face 
challenges due to the UK's impending split from the European Union. 
EasyJet warned on Thursday that its annual profits will be down by more than 25% due to the depreciation of 
sterling. Since the UK voted to leave the EU on June 23, sterling has depreciated by 16% against both the dollar 
and the euro.
Additionally, Brexit could also impair the company's profits as the UK losses its favorable trade status with the EU.
As a result, shares of UK airliners including Ryanair, Fastjet, and Flybe were all trading lower in London. 
Price: 72.13, Change: -1.01, Percent Change: -1.38

Ryanair set to create 3,500 jobs next year as it bolsters air fleet
Ryanair set to create 3,500 jobs next year as it bolsters air fleet
City A.M.
October 5, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 7
Length: 108 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
RYANAIR has announced a major recruitment drive as it plans to add 50 new aircraft in the coming year.
To prepare for the expansion, the airline will be hiring 2,000 new members of cabin crew, 1,000 pilots and 250 
aircraft engineers. It is also promoting over 300 First Officers.
Ryanair told City A.M. the staff would be spread throughout its 84-base European network, though it is still planning 
to cool off UK relations following the Brexit vote.
There will not be any additional aircraft in the UK next year - they will be allocated to EU airports instead, and 
Ryanair's UK growth rate will reduce from 15 per cent this year to six per cent next year.

geophysical equipment, 1.8% higher. Natuzzi (NTZ), an Italian furniture manufacturer, was 1.8% higher.

by Randgold Resources (GOLD), a gold mining business, down by 4.6% and Amec Foster Wheeler (AMFW), a 
global engineering conglomerate, 2.0% lower. Low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY) was 1.9% lower.

Ryanair To Create More Than 3,500 Jobs In 2017
Ryanair To Create More Than 3,500 Jobs In 2017
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 4, 2016 Tuesday 3:50 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 369 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L, RYAAY) said that it is to launch a major recruitment drive as it 
plans to take delivery of 50 new aircraft in the next 12 months.  Ryanair announced that it will be hiring 2,000 new 
cabin crew, 1,000 pilots and 250 aircraft engineers, as well as promoting over 300 First Officers on its command 
upgrade programme across its 84-base European network.  A range of new positions will also be created in IT, 
Sales & Marketing, Digital Experience, Finance and Commercial at Ryanair's Dublin office, and also at its Travel 
Labs Poland subsidiary in Wroclaw. 
 Eddie Wilson, Ryanair's Chief People Officer said, '2017 is set to be our busiest recruitment year to date, and we 
are continuing to invest heavily in talent for the future. Ryanair is now considered to be the 'go-to' airline for both 
cadet and direct entry hires, with our industry leading 5/4 roster for pilots, and both pilots and cabin crew have the 
opportunity to work on the youngest fleet in Europe as we take delivery of our new Boeing aircraft.  Ryanair noted 
that it will hire over 5,000 new people, As its aircraft numbers grow from 355 to over 500 in the next 5 years.  Last 
month, Air Berlin PLC (AIBEF.PK) said that its Board resolved to substantially restructure the group and implement 
a new business model. It will lay-off up to 1,200 full-time employees.  Air Berlin PLC & Co. Luftverkehrs KG would 
operate a reduced core fleet of 75 aircraft in a dual- hub strategy with long-haul flights from Berlin and Dusseldorf. 
All administrative functions will be concentrated in Berlin. The touristic business with 35 aircraft will be combined in 
a separate business unit with a view to evaluate strategic options.  Separately, Ryanair today said that its 
September traffic grew by 13% to 10.8 million customers, while load factor jumped 1% point to 95%, on the back of 
lower fares and the continuing success of our 'Always Getting Better' customer experience programme.  Ryanair's 
Kenny Jacobs said, 'As our recent guidance confirmed, we expect average fares to fall by between 10% to 12% in 
the 6 months to March 2017, so there's never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair.'      
Load-Date: October 4, 2016

Ryanair To Create More Than 3,500 Jobs In 2017
Ryanair To Create More Than 3,500 Jobs In 2017
RTT News (United States)
October 4, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 380 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L, RYAAY) said that it is to launch a major recruitment drive as it plans to take 
delivery of 50 new aircraft in the next 12 months.
Ryanair announced that it will be hiring 2,000 new cabin crew, 1,000 pilots and 250 aircraft engineers, as well as 
promoting over 300 First Officers on its command upgrade programme across its 84-base European network.
A range of new positions will also be created in IT, Sales & Marketing, Digital Experience, Finance and Commercial 
at Ryanair's Dublin office, and also at its Travel Labs Poland subsidiary in Wroclaw.
Eddie Wilson, Ryanair's Chief People Officer said, "2017 is set to be our busiest recruitment year to date, and we 
are continuing to invest heavily in talent for the future. Ryanair is now considered to be the 'go-to' airline for both 
cadet and direct entry hires, with our industry leading 5/4 roster for pilots, and both pilots and cabin crew have the 
opportunity to work on the youngest fleet in Europe as we take delivery of our new Boeing aircraft.
Ryanair noted that it will hire over 5,000 new people, As its aircraft numbers grow from 355 to over 500 in the next 5 
years.
Last month, Air Berlin PLC (AIBEF.PK) said that its Board resolved to substantially restructure the group and 
implement a new business model. It will lay-off up to 1,200 full-time employees.
Air Berlin PLC & Co. Luftverkehrs KG would operate a reduced core fleet of 75 aircraft in a dual- hub strategy with 
long-haul flights from Berlin and Dusseldorf. All administrative functions will be concentrated in Berlin. The touristic 
business with 35 aircraft will be combined in a separate business unit with a view to evaluate strategic options.
Separately, Ryanair today said that its September traffic grew by 13% to 10.8 million customers, while load factor 
jumped 1% point to 95%, on the back of lower fares and the continuing success of our "Always Getting Better" 
customer experience programme.
Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said, "As our recent guidance confirmed, we expect average fares to fall by between 10% 
to 12% in the 6 months to March 2017, so there's never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair."

Ryanair September traffic grows 13%

September traffic statistics released today by Ryanair shows that traffic grew 13% to 10.8m customers and rolling

Ryanair to create over 3,500 new jobs in 2017
Ryanair to create over 3,500 new jobs in 2017

October 04, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved

Length: 176 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair is to launch a major recruitment drive as it plans to take delivery of 50 new 
aircraft in the next 12 months.     Ryanair announced that it will be hiring 2,000 new cabin crew, 1,000 pilots and 
250 aircraft engineers, as well as promoting over 300 First Officers on its command upgrade programme across its 
84-base European network.
A range of new positions will also be created in IT, Sales & Marketing, Digital Experience, Finance and Commercial 
at Ryanair’s Dublin office and also at its Travel Labs Poland subsidiary in Wroclaw.   Ryanair’s Chief People Officer, 
Eddie Wilson said, "2017 is set to be our busiest recruitment year to date, and we are continuing to invest heavily in 
talent for the future. Ryanair is now considered to be the ‘go-to’ airline for both cadet and direct entry hires, with our 
industry leading 5/4 roster for pilots, and both pilots and cabin crew have the opportunity to work on the youngest 
fleet in Europe as we take delivery of our new Boeing aircraft."

IT recruiter Zartis.com to open Berlin office in expansion move
IT recruiter Zartis.com to open Berlin office in expansion move
Sunday Business Post
October 3, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 299 words
Byline: Leanna Byrne
Highlight: Cork firm to employ three staff in German office
Body
Cork IT recruitment firm Zartis.com is opening an office in Berlin as part of its ongoing European expansion. 
The company, which opened an office in Madrid in 2014, will open the German office with three staff in December. 
Founder John Dennehy said that while the company has staff working remotely, the demand for software 
developers in Berlin is growing. 
The company is already working with AskCharlie, a Berlin-based tech start-up that matches local service for users 
on-demand. 
“A huge amount of the people working in the tech sector are moving to Berlin. 
“That suits our model very well,” said Dennehy. 
Founded in 2009, Zartis.com started as a recruitment software company, but soon expanded its service to focus on 
IT recruitment. 
“We found that we weren’t getting good service from any recruiters that we went to, so we saw that there was a big 
opportunity for us to start finding good IT people for companies,” said Dennehy. 
Zartis.com uses its cloud recuitment software product HireHive.io to find candidates for growing companies with 
under 1,000 staff. 
The company is currently working with Seattle-based medical records software company Valant Medical Solutions 
to bring on new staff after it closed a $11 million funding round. 
It also seeks out IT staff for larger companies and was chosen to work with Ryanair in 2014 to recruit for its 
technology arm, Ryanair Labs. 
IT recruiter Zartis.com to open Berlin office in expansion move
It secured Lufthansa as its first big client in 2012. 
Dennehy, who is a serial entrepreneur, first started in business when he set up a web development company in 
1999. 
He also co-founded New York mobile communications company Fonepool, which then was sold to Jersey Telecom. 
In 2002, he co-founded Upstart Games with Barry O’Neill and Hiroshi Okamoto. 
It was sold to China’s Sun 3C Media for €11.5 million in 2006.

EasyJet buckles in for a bumpy ride
EasyJet buckles in for a bumpy ride
City A.M.
October 3, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 7
Length: 179 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
BUDGET airline EasyJet is braced for a sharp fall in pre-tax profits when it gives a trading update this week.
A combination of terrorist attacks, air control strikes and a hefty price war with Ryanair has taken its toll on the 
carrier, analysts say.
They are expecting profit before tax in the year to end of September to be heavily down - predictions ranged from 
£497m-£517m. Profit before tax for 2015 was £686m.
Rob Byde, airline analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald, told City A.M.: "Profits are expected to be down due to a weaker 
yield environment impacting all European carriers. The past year has seen a number of negative events, from 
terrorist attacks to air control strikes."
This summer, EasyJet along with British Airways and Ryanair, cancelled hundreds of flights due to French air traffic 
control strikes.
Meanwhile, fierce rival Ryanair threw down the gauntlet in May, cutting fares by seven per cent.
Last month, EasyJet boss Carolyn McCall said that the Brexit vote had impacted demand for holidays.
Despite this tough market, Byde said EasyJet was "generally trading well".

EasyJet boss Carolyn McCall said the Brexit vote has hit demand for holidays

Flybondi seeks $75m for 2017 launch
Flybondi seeks $75m for 2017 launch
AirFinance Journal
October 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 312 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
Argentine startup carrier Flybondi is in advanced discussions with international lead investors and Argentinian 
investors to raise $75 million in preparation for its planned launch next year.
The carrier has mandated US Investment Bank Raymond James as advisor for the capital raise.
Ultra-low cost carrier Flybondi is looking to launch operations in the third quarter of next year.
It will initially operate domestic routes from its Buenos Aires base and has started negotiations with the Argentine 
authorities to obtain an aircraft operator’s certificate.
“Flybondi plans to reach 30 aircraft in five years and transport over 8 million passengers on domestic and regional 
flights,” the startup said in a statement.
Early indications show Flybondi will not go head-to-head with Aerolineas Argentinas, as the start-up carrier aims to 
bypass Buenos Aires downtown airport Aeroparque.
Flybondi is headed by founder and former CEO of Flybaboo Julian Cook, who was also involved ina new European 
low-cost carrier with a focus on long-haul sectors after leaving the Swiss regional carrier. Cookannounced its 
intention to start a low-cost transatlantic carrier in June 2012 but lack of available aircraft has put the original plan 
on hold.
Argentine entrepreneur Gaston Parisier is also the co-founder of the carrier.
The start-up airline completed a seed capital round in August with the participation ofex-chief commercial officer 
and current board member of Ryanair Michael Cawley,ex-chief executive officer Air Canada, board member of 
Swiss Intl. Airlines & Allegiant Montie Brewer as well as Robert Wright, who founded UK carrier CityFlyer, alongside 
a group of Argentinian investors.
Cook told Airfinance Journal in an email that Flybondy will either operate Airbus A320s or Boeing 737-800s. “Plans 
are to operate six aircraft in the first year,” he says.

BA risks passenger grumbles with plan to scrap free meals on short-haul economy flights Airlines
BA risks passenger grumbles with plan to scrap free meals on short-haul 
economy flights; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 30, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 14
Length: 427 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Body
British Airways will phase out free meals in economy on short-haul flights in favour of paid-for food from Marks and 
Spencer.
The move by BA, part of the International Airlines Group, is in line with wider trends across the industry, where 
legacy airlines have made their services to economy passengers increasingly similar to those of their low-cost 
rivals. Travellers on EasyJet and Ryanair are already well used to the clicking sound of a paid snack cart.
However, the airline vowed to retain a free meal service for passengers in its Club Europe business seats .
Similar moves at other airlines have prompted protests from passengers who felt they were losing out with the loss 
of free meals.
After he was appointed last year, Oscar Munoz , chief executive of United Airlines, restored free snacks in short-
haul economy because of continuing passenger unhappiness about their removal.
British Airways said their decision followed "extensive customer research and feedback," which highlighted 
dissatisfaction with the airline's short-haul economy catering.
BA risks passenger grumbles with plan to scrap free meals on short-haul economy flights Airlines
"The research . . . found flyers want more choices that reflects what they would normally select when out and 
about," the airline said.
Alex Cruz , British Airways' chief executive, said that M&S was a "well-known, premium British brand".
"It's an ideal partnership, providing our customers with a choice of products they recognise and value," he said.
Passengers will be able to pay for meals with Avios, the points they accrue as members of BA's Executive Club 
frequent flyer programme.
Items will range in price from £1 for a packet of crisps to £4.95 for spiced chicken with quinoa and rice salad. The 
new arrangements will start from January 11 on flights to and from London Heathrow, and from summer next year 
at Stansted and Gatwick.
John Strickland, an independent airline consultant, welcomed BA's move, saying the airline had ended up in recent 
years in a "no man's land" in catering in short-haul economy.
"It's become very difficult to work out what the catering offering is," Mr Strickland said. "Am I going to get a 
breakfast, or some kind of damp, shrink-wrapped croissant or would I be better to go straight to Pret A Manger?"
Passengers would now know, Mr Strickland said, that they were going to have to pay for food.
But he went on: "You know you're going to be able to buy something of good quality."
Mr Strickland said passengers tended to complain initially about the loss of free food. But they grew happier once 
they realised the replacement, paid-for food offered better choice and higher quality.
Load-Date: September 29, 2016
End of Document
Lufthansa/Air Berlin: buying time
Lufthansa/Air Berlin: buying time
Financial Times (London, England)
September 30, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 14
Length: 334 words
Body
Adding dozens of aircraft to your fleet at a time when investors are growing concerned about excess capacity and 
weakening demand looks illogical. But for Lufthansa, a leasing deal with a rival is more about who flies the planes 
than who owns them.
On Wednesday, Lufthansa said that it would enter into a "wet lease" agreement with Air Berlin, under which the 
struggling smaller carrier will use 40 of its own aircraft to operate short-haul routes for Lufthansa.
For Air Berlin this is about survival. Cutting its fleet size will allow it to focus on longer haul routes and business 
destinations. Its leisure routes, hived off into a separate unit, might interest other carriers. These priorities suit its 
largest shareholder Etihad, without whose support Air Berlin would long since have collapsed.
Lufthansa will repaint Air Berlin's Airbus A320s in the livery of Eurowings, its low-cost unit, whose fleet will in effect 
grow by almost half.
A separate transaction - acquiring the remaining 45 per cent of Brussels Airlines - could expand it further.
Eurowings will make a loss in 2016 and it is not clear that the Air Berlin arrangement, which starts in 2017, will 
improve that. But beefing up the unit sends a message to the German pilots' union, with which Lufthansa remains 
locked in a dispute over pensions.
Eurowings pilots have less generous retirement arrangements.
Lufthansa/Air Berlin: buying time
Helping prevent a possible disorderly break-up of Air Berlin plays well poli-tically for Lufthansa. It also helps keep 
rivals at bay. Ryanair, with a big cash pile and rock-bottom costs, is keen on expanding in Germany. As long as it is 
confined to secondary airports in cities such as Frankfurt, Düsseldorf and Munich, its threat is blunted, leaving 
Lufthansa to focus on cutting its costs.
But it is only a stopgap. Lufthansa shares are down 30 per cent this year. A EUR500m bond sale was abandoned 
this week. Nervy investors would be more reassured by peace with the pilots, or profits at Eurowings.
Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com 
Load-Date: September 29, 2016
End of Document
Lufthansa 's plans to own remaining stake in Brussels Airlines take flight
Lufthansa's plans to own remaining stake in Brussels Airlines take flight
City A.M.
September 29, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 8
Length: 173 words
Byline: CAITLÍN MORRISON
Body
GERMAN airline Lufthansa said yesterday that its supervisory board has approved plans to buy the remaining 
chunk of Brussels Airlines that it didn't already own.
The carrier bought 45 per cent of Brussels Airlines owner SN Airholding in 2009 for (EURO)65m (£56m), with the 
option of buying the other 55 per cent from 2011 onwards.
Lufthansa is trying to boost its Eurowings business with acquisitions, and said earlier this year that it was discussing 
how to bring Brussels, which has a fleet of 49 planes, into its low-cost platform, which currently has around 90 
planes.
The transaction, which is subject to shareholders of SN Airholding approving the details of the deal, is expected to 
be concluded next year.
The supervisory board is also expected to discuss plans for Lufthansa to take on more jets for Eurowings from Air 
Berlin, sources told Reuters, to help make Eurowings the third largest low costcarrier in Europe behind Ryanair and 
EasyJet.
Last year, Lufthansa signed a 10-year deal with Inmarsat to provide internet on planes mid-air.

Ryanair CEO Reportedly Says Brexit To Impact Profit For Up To Four Years
Ryanair CEO Reportedly Says Brexit To Impact Profit For Up To Four Years
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 27, 2016 Tuesday 2:33 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 185 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Michael O'Leary, Chief Executive Officer of Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY), said 
that Britain's decision to quit the European Union will weigh on the Irish no-frills airline's profit for as long as four 
years, Bloomberg reported Tuesday.   The process of the U.K. withdrawing from the union could take two to four 
years, and would depress yields, a measure of ticket prices and profitability in the airline industry, the CEO 
reportedly said.  Meanwhile, O'Leary maintained its fiscal 2016 profit forecast of 1.38 billion euros or $1.55 billion, 
despite the risks posed by the aftermath of the ballot.  O'Leary said in a briefing with reporters in Brussels on 
Tuesday, 'The outlook for the U.K. economy is poor. This will mean slower GDP growth in the U.K. and European 
economies.'  The company has already taken contingency plans including shifting growth away from the U.K. for 
the next two years. The carrier is planning to send about 50 new aircraft due for delivery this year to outside U.K. 
routes.  In London, Ryanair shares were trading at 74.18 pence, down 1.17 percent.

Ryanair CEO Reportedly Says Brexit To Impact Profit For Up To Four Years
Ryanair CEO Reportedly Says Brexit To Impact Profit For Up To Four Years
RTT News (United States)
September 27, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 198 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Michael O'Leary, Chief Executive Officer of Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY), said that Britain's 
decision to quit the European Union will weigh on the Irish no-frills airline's profit for as long as four years, 
Bloomberg reported Tuesday.
The process of the U.K. withdrawing from the union could take two to four years, and would depress yields, a 
measure of ticket prices and profitability in the airline industry, the CEO reportedly said.
Meanwhile, O'Leary maintained its fiscal 2016 profit forecast of 1.38 billion euros or $1.55 billion, despite the risks 
posed by the aftermath of the ballot.
O'Leary said in a briefing with reporters in Brussels on Tuesday, "The outlook for the U.K. economy is poor. This 
will mean slower GDP growth in the U.K. and European economies."
The company has already taken contingency plans including shifting growth away from the U.K. for the next two 
years. The carrier is planning to send about 50 new aircraft due for delivery this year to outside U.K. routes.
In London, Ryanair shares were trading at 74.18 pence, down 1.17 percent.

News In Brief
News In Brief
Sunday Business Post
September 25, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 390 words
Body
Sligo craft brewer seeks barrel sponsors for beer roll-out
The White Hag, a brewery based in Ballymote, Co Sligo, is looking to raise €25,000 through an adopt-a-barrel 
programme, writes Emmet Ryan. 
The crowd-funding initiative aims to help the firm buy 100 barrels for its barrel-aged beers. 
The idea to have 100 barrels adopted at €250 each was inspired in part by the Scottish brewery BrewDog’s share-
offering schemes. 
“BrewDog has its Equity for Punks which has run very successfully. 
“Ireland is not quite at the scale where we can do that and we don’t have the marketing budget required for it,” said 
Paul Mullin, managing director of The White Hag. 
“Adopting a barrel gets people closer to the story and lets them see the barrels that the beers are going to be aged 
in.” 
Donors will get their names inscribed on the barrels along with receiving beer brewed in the adopted barrels every 
year for three years. 
Hayes predicts cross-border European mortgage market
Europeans could soon be free to cross borders to shop around for the lowest mortgage rates around the European 
Union, if a new European directive is pushed through, writes Leanna Byrne. 
The European Commission is expected to propose a directive aimed at harmonising national insolvency regimes by 
the end of the year. 
News In Brief
This could see the establishment of a cross-border mortgage regime in the EU, according to Dublin Fine Gael MEP 
Brian Hayes. 
Currently, EU citizens cannot avail of mortgages in other EU member states. 
“If we are to have a real internal market in the EU, cross-border mortgages should be the norm. 
“We’ve already got a banking union in place and one would think that if EU banks are under the same rules, cross-
border mortgages should be a given,” said Hayes. 
Dutch fuel company Argos takes Ryanair to High Court
Ryanair is being pursued in the High Court by Argos, a Rotterdam-based fuel supplier. 
The Dutch company, which is owned by Swiss company Varo Energy, lodged two sets of preliminary proceedings 
here last week but the cause of the dispute isn’t known. 
Ryanair’s spokesman said the airline didn’t wish to comment, and Argos did not respond when contacted. 
Argos is a leading petroleum and biofuel trading, storage and distribution company and has a network of service 
stations. 
It is active in the Belgium, Luxemburg, France, Germany and Switzerland.

Dublin-based technology firm CarTrawler, which provides car rental software to businesses, has promoted 29-year-
old Aileen O’Mahony to chief commercial officer. 
O’Mahony has worked for CarTrawler, which was bought by private equity companies BC Partners and Insight two 
years ago for €450 million, since 2012. 
She has over ten years’ experience in commercial positions. She has helped to sign some of the company’s largest 
partners including Ryanair, Aer Lingus, TUI, AirAsia, KLM and Swiss Airlines, according to an email to staff from 
CarTrawler’s chief executive Mike McGearty. 
“She most recently headed the strategic business unit and will bring those learnings, particularly with Ryanair, to 
bear on the business development, marketing and partner management teams,” he wrote in the email. 
CarTrawler provides its clients, including 95 international airlines and 2,000 global travel retailers, with real-time 
access to over 1,600 car rental agents, coach transfers, rail networks and chauffeur-driven services at 43,000 
locations in 195 countries. 
O’Mahony is replacing Michael Cunningham as chief commercial officer. He has been promoted to the position of 
senior vice-president of distribution strategy. 
Cunningham joined CarTrawler in 2011. 
His focus will be on the strength of executive level relationships with partners, McGearty’s email said. 
The appointments are part of the company’s plan to facilitate its future growth, according to McGearty.
