Fund charges have more baggage than Ryanair Investing
Fund charges have more baggage than Ryanair; Investing
Financial Times (London, England)
September 24, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FT WEEKEND SUPPLEMENT - MONEY; Pg. 20
Length: 1027 words
Byline: Merryn Somerset Webb
Body
There are no hidden fees in the fund management industry. Its critics keep going on about them, but they also "fail 
to identify conclusive signs of their existence". And that is because they don't exist. They are not "lurking within". 
They are instead the "Loch Ness Monster of investments", a figment of the imagination of financial journalists and 
feisty challenger businesses.
That, at least, is the (firm) view of the industry cheerleading Investment Association, which released a report on the 
matter over the summer. Is the IA right?
The analysis in its report - which attempts to show that not only are there no hidden costs but that even if there 
were, active funds outperform enough to compensate for those costs - is pretty ropey.
But it is really a matter of definitions. It isn't so much that charges in question are hidden than that they are in some 
cases disclosed, but not obviously (think accountancy fees, depository fees, custodian fees, external research 
costs) and in other cases unknown and hence tricky to disclose.
Transaction costs (commission plus stamp duty and the cost inherent in bid-offer spreads) are the main culprits 
here. A manager can't know in advance how much he will trade and in what volumes, so he can't tell you on 
January 1 how much he will have charged you for his trading over the year until December 31.
Fund charges have more baggage than Ryanair Investing
I've been trying to think of any other sector that works like this - where you buy a thing but are then hit with 
obligatory ongoing costs you can't know in advance. You could compare fund pricing to aviation pricing. A report 
from the Civil Aviation Authority this week pointed out that some 43 per cent of their revenues (on Jet2.com it is £39 
per passenger, for example) now come from additional fees, "or ancillary revenue" as the airlines like to put it, that 
is not included in the headline ticket prices.
Consider credit card booking fees, checked luggage fees, charges to book a seat and so on. These aren't hidden 
fees: you can find them reasonably clearly noted on most websites and they aren't always unreasonable. EasyJet 
charges you £80 to rebook if you miss your departure, for example.
But, like fund management costs, they aren't particularly transparent either. However, they aren't quite the same 
thing, simply because they aren't ongoing charges. They are services you can choose to have or not to have.
The same goes for all the other possible comparators. All-inclusive holidays that don't include wine, for example. 
Yes, wine is an extra unknown cost. But it is still a choice. Mark Warner can no more pipe rosé of an unknown price 
down your throat and bill you later than Ryanair can block the departure gate until you produce a piece of outsized 
luggage and agree to move from your assigned seat at the back by the loos to a more expensive emergency exit 
seat (much as it might like to).
Fund managers (and maybe governments) are the only group of service providers that can headline with one price, 
but announce some time later that the actual price was different (often double the original price) and that they have 
removed the difference from your account (over which they have full control). They get to tell you the predictable bit, 
but leave all the risk in the less predictable bits on your plate.
This is no good at all. That you never know what you will have to pay is one irritant, of course. But the other is that it 
remains very hard for investors to compare the cost of one fund with that of another.
Over the years I have suggested various ways of dealing with the problem of how investors are charged for funds. I 
thought it would be a good idea for funds to charge flat absolute fees, for example. Charging a percentage of assets 
just encourages asset gathering at the expense of good performance.
And I'm all for exploring how a very low absolute management fee could be combined with a performance sharing 
system for management and investors. But as I am not getting quite as much traction on this as I think I should be, 
I'd like to suggest an interim solution: the all-inclusive fund management fee.
Under this system, fund managers would be obliged to behave in the same way as travel agents offering genuinely 
all-inclusive holidays. They announce a price at the beginning and that is that. The price includes everything: 
management costs, all fees and commissions, all research and all trading costs.
Those costs may fluctuate across the year. They may be higher than the fund management company expects or 
they may be lower. But that's a problem for the firm not for the investor, just as the fluctuating costs of jet fuel and 
cheap prosecco are problems for Thomas Cook rather than for the prepaying punter.
The benefits of shifting to a system like this are obvious. First, it offers full clarity to the investor: all-in prices mean 
they can compare like with like. Second, it firmly forces the providers to explain why their costs are what they are. If 
they want to charge more for a fund that has high turnover they will be obliged to explain why they consider, for 
example, high turnover of investments to be a good thing (when it almost invariably isn't).
Third, it might lead to a reappraisal of costs across the board. If the fee is all-inclusive, the incentive to push costs 
down is high. So we might find fund managers looking for all-inclusive annual trading deals (a flat fee!) from their 
brokers or pushing down their legal and accountancy fees to levels those in non-financial industries might think 
reasonable.
This isn't a perfect solution to the problem of fees (the whole percentage charging thing will still be with us). But it 
would, I think, be an excellent way of beginning to make fund managers think and behave more like the providers of 
Fund charges have more baggage than Ryanair Investing
other services, which in turn would start to create real competition - and bring down the costs of investing. And that 
of course is the thing that matters almost more than anything else to our ageing, saving population: the less we pay 
away in costs, the more we will have to live on in our old age.
 Merryn Somerset Webb is editor-in-chief of MoneyWeek. The views expressed are personal; merryn@ft.com ; 
Twitter: @MerrynSW 
Load-Date: September 23, 2016
End of Document

customer experience programme, and will deliver: 3 new routes: Alicante (2 weekly), Faro (2 weekly), Malaga (2

Airport Managing Director, Carol Benzie, said: "We're delighted to announce another fantastic new route with 
Ryanair, following the earlier news that they will return to Aberdeen in February with routes to Alicante and Malaga. 
As the main point of entry to southern Portugal and the stunning Algarve region, Faro has long been a popular 
destination with holidaymakers in Aberdeen. The results of a leisure survey that we undertook earlier this year 
suggested that our local community would like to see the introduction of year-round flights to Faro. We listened to 
the feedback and have worked closely with Ryanair to respond to the demand. The twice-weekly service will begin 
in May 2017 and the arrival of 75,000 new customers per year to the airport will tie in with the exciting GBP20million 
revamp of our main terminal."

jobs at Glasgow and Prestwick airports. "Customers can look forward to even lower fares when they make advance

Better" customer experience programme, and will deliver: 3 based aircraft; 10 new S17 routes including Lanzarote 
(2 wkly), Malaga (5 wkly), Tenerife (2 wkly) & Warsaw (2 wkly); 11 routes in total including London Gatwick (4 
daily); 1.1 million customers p.a.; and over 800 "on-site" jobs p.a. In Belfast, Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said: 
"Customers can look forward to even lower fares when they make advance bookings for summer 2017. As our 
recent guidance confirmed, Ryanair expects average fares to fall by between 10% to 12% in the 6 months to March 
2017. There's never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair and we urge all customers who wish to 
book their summer 2017 holidays to do so now on the Ryanair.com website, where they can avail of the lowest fare 
air travel to and from Belfast. Belfast International Airport Managing Director, Graham Keddie said: "Three based 
aircraft underlines Ryanair's clear intention to go for growth in Northern Ireland. 
It's a hugely significant investment in its new hub and one that is based on clear passenger demand. "Ryanair said 
they would carry one million passengers in the first year of operation and I'm delighted to see that figure revised 
upwards. The potential is considerable, but it would be much more if we dealt with the regressive Air Passenger 
Duty (APD) tax that serves to slow down airline expansion and growth. "Again, I make the appeal to Ministers in the 
Northern Ireland Executive to realise the damage that APD is causing and move to reduce or remove it so that we 
can go on to create thousands of new jobs and open up new business opportunities."

Fatigue factor: EasyJet pilots vote to back action
Fatigue factor: EasyJet pilots vote to back action
Financial Times (London, England)
September 22, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 21
Length: 236 words
Byline: Robert Wright
Body
Pilots at easyJet voted overwhelmingly to back strike action in a dispute over fatigue, the pilots' union announced 
yesterday, in a fresh blow to Europe's second-largest low-cost carrier.
The British Airline Pilots' Association said 96 per cent of its 2,000 UK-based members at easyJet voted in favour of 
industrial action in the ballot. Turnout was 88 per cent.
However, it remains unclear whether the ballot will lead to flight disruption at the airline. Balpa said easyJet had 
made a "last-minute" offer to resolve the dispute.
"We will consider this carefully in meetings tomorrow before taking any further decisions," the union said, adding 
that there were no plans at present to undertake industrial action.
EasyJet said it was committed to working with Balpa to find a resolution to the issue. "EasyJet can reassure its 
passengers that no industrial action is currently planned by its UK pilots," it said.
The dispute revolves around pilots' unhappiness over the scheduling of their flights. Balpa has said the current 
practices are leading to excessive fatigue.
EasyJet's shares fell 10p to close at £10.31 after Balpa's announcement.
Fatigue factor: EasyJet pilots vote to back action
The ballot result presents a new challenge for easyJet, which faces fierce competition from Ryanair, whose costs 
are lower. The airline has suffered severe disruption from the economic uncertainty following the UK's vote to leave 
the EU as well as the threat of terrorism.
Robert Wright
Load-Date: September 21, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair launches enhanced Rate My Flight service mobile app
Ryanair launches enhanced Rate My Flight service mobile app
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
September 22, 2016 Thursday 1:46 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS; Technology & Telecommunications
Length: 163 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has launched an enhanced Rate My Flight service which is available in seven 
languages, allowing customers to provide reviews of their flight via the Ryanair mobile app.
Body
Ryanair's 'Rate My Flight' function offers customers the chance to rate their overall experience, boarding, crew 
friendliness, service onboard and range of food and drink, on a 5-star rating system, ranging from 1 star for very 
poor, to 5 stars for very good. The service is now available in Dutch, English, French, German, Italian, Polish and 
Spanish, via the Ryanair app, which can be downloaded from the iTunes and Google Play stores. Ryanair's Robin 
Kiely said: "Rate My Flight is the latest digital initiative launched under year 3 of our "Always Getting Better" 
customer experience improvement programme, which allows customers to provide real-time reviews of their flights 
via the Ryanair app. We welcome all customer feedback so that we can continue to improve all aspects of the 
Ryanair customer experience. Customers who want to rate their flight should download the Ryanair app, allow for 
push notifications, and will be sent the survey through the app upon landing."

business and leisure passengers within our catchment area, which stretches from the east to the west coasts of the 
UK and as far North as the Scottish borders. Coupled with increased frequencies on routes to a range of sunshine 
destinations, this commitment is yet another vote of confidence in Manchester and the wider North."

European ADRs Fractionally Higher as Pharma Stocks Rally
European ADRs Fractionally Higher as Pharma Stocks Rally
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 20, 2016 Tuesday 11:19 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 233 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.4% higher at 121.20 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Tuesday morning. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by Advanced Accelorator Applications (AAAP), a radiopharmaceutical 
company, 2.4% higher, followed by Marine Harvest (MHG), a Norwegian seafood company, and Sequans 
Communications (SQNS), a French developer of chipset solutions, both up 2.4%. Flamel Technologies (FLML), a 
French pharmaceutical company, was 2.0% higher.
In the UK, Amarin (AMRN), a biopharmaceutical company, was 2.0% higher, followed by mining major BHP Billiton 
(BBL), up by 1.9%, and health care companies Shire (SHPG) and GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH) 1.7% and 1.6% 
higher, respectively. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), a Sweden-based pharmaceutical 
company, 2.4% lower, followed by ArcelorMittal (MT), a Luxembourg steelmaker, down by 1.8% and Eni (E), an oil 
and gas exploration, company 1.3% lower. Criteo (CRTO), a French technology company, was 1.2% lower. 
And, in the UK, Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), a development-stage biopharmaceutical company, was 7.8% lower, 
followed by Pearson (PSO), an education company, down by 1.0%, and Amec Foster Wheeler (AMFW), a global 
engineering conglomerate, 0.9% lower. Low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY) was 0.8% lower. 
Price: 37.30, Change: +0.85, Percent Change: +2.33

Israel battles to revive tourism Holiday travel: Eilat
Israel battles to revive tourism; Holiday travel: Eilat
Financial Times (London, England)
September 19, 2016 Monday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: WORLD NEWS; Pg. 6
Length: 806 words
Byline: John Reed in Eilat
Highlight: Investment in airport and hotels aims to entice foreign visitors put off by violence
Body
Israel is trying to revive its struggling tourism industry by subsidising new budget hotels, paying airlines EUR60 for 
every passenger they fly into Eilat, and building a showpiece international airport to receive them north of the Red 
Sea resort.
Tourist visits to Israel have slumped since 2014, when its war against the militant group Hamas in the Gaza Strip 
and the subsequent wave of violence in Jerusalem caused many foreigners to cancel trips. During that time, Tel 
Aviv's Ben Gurion airport, Israel's main gateway to the world, was shut for two days after a rocket fired from Gaza 
landed about a mile away.
Israel's government is now trying to bring foreign visitors back and change the way they think about the country, in 
part by broadening its target market beyond religious pilgrims who come for its holy sites, to those seeking sand 
and sun. An advertising spot, launched in June in several European cities, shows a couple running along 
Jerusalem's Old City wall, then a Tel Aviv beach, under the slogan "Two Cities, One Break".
"Unfortunately, over the years tourism wasn't something that Israel invested in or put its efforts in, unlike what we 
did in the high-tech industry," Yariv Levin, Israel's tourism minister, told the Financial Times. "For most people in the 
world, Israel is not a tourist site that is even crossing their minds."
Israel hosted 2.8m tourists last year, down 4 per cent on 2014, according to economy ministry figures.
Israel battles to revive tourism Holiday travel: Eilat
The country is more expensive than rival Mediterranean tourist destinations and does not have enough low-priced 
rooms, government and tourism officials concede.
Mr Levin said that in an effort to build more, the government was giving "huge grants" to developers that built hotels 
with three stars or fewer, equivalent to 33 per cent of the overall cost.
In Eilat last week, hotels were full, with local tourists - including Palestinians celebrating the Muslim Eid al-Adha 
holiday - packing the town's open-air promenades and malls. Eilat is faring better than neighbouring Aqaba in 
Jordan or Taba, Egypt, which have seen an exodus of foreign visitors worried about Islamist terrorist attacks.
However, foreigners account for less than 10 per cent of visitors to Eilat, and tourist numbers fall sharply in winter. 
Occupancy at Eilat hotels last winter was about 62 per cent, said Yossi Chen, general manager of the city's 
Municipal Tourism Association. The city is hoping for 70 per cent this year with the help of new direct flights.
Last year Israel began offering foreign carriers flying to Eilat a EUR45 per passenger subsidy, plus another EUR15 
per visitor offered by the local hotels association.
Ryanair, the budget airline, began flights from Krakow in Poland, Kaunas in Lithuania and Budapest in Hungary, 
and from November will begin a service from Bratislava in Slovakia.
International arrivals to Eilat land at Ovda, an Israeli military airport that also accommodates civilian aircraft. The 
new Ramon airport, being built in the desert north of the city, is due to open in 2017, with a 34,000 sq metre 
terminal and stands for 29 aircraft.
Aviation authorities are touting the 1.65bn shekel ($437m) project as a gateway for foreign tourists and an 
alternative to Ben Gurion airport, which when foggy requires planes to divert abroad.
"This airport can be an alternative to Ben Gurion, even in times of peace," says Hanan Moscovitz, an Israeli airport 
authority official.
But some in the city are sceptical of the notion that "if you build it, they will come". While Eilat's visitor numbers 
compare favourably with Aqaba's and Taba's, it is often outcompeted by rivals in Europe and other countries.
"If a family wants to go abroad for a week or two-week holiday in Greece or Capri, it's a lot less expensive to do it 
there than to come do it here," concedes Red Fisher, general manager of Eilat's Manta Diving Resort.
Rotem Noam, chief executive of Erev Be'Eilat, which runs two local newspapers and a tourism guide, says: "Eilat is 
expensive relative to Greece, Cyprus and other destinations . . . We're aware of that, and we are struggling."
Mr Noam asserts that while Eilat's hotel services and facilities are often better than in Greece or Cyprus, and prices 
fall in low season, they are expensive in peak months.
He blames Eilat's steep costs on high wages, the costs of fitting and certifying hotels to meet kosher requirements, 
and regulatory issues - including a requirement that all swimming pools have lifeguards.
Mr Noam also asserts that the amount of money being invested in the Ramon airport is "not justified" when tourist 
numbers are modest, and most who come to Eilat are locals.
"I predict it's going to be deserted," he says. "You don't build an airport and expect people to come. You have to 
build hotels and rooms and attractions, and after that you build your airport."
Load-Date: September 18, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair August passenger traffic increases 11%
Ryanair August passenger traffic increases 11%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
September 19, 2016 Monday 10:54 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 107 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has reported that passenger traffic for the month of August 2016 was 11.5 million 
passengers, an increase of 11%, compared to 10.4 million passengers for August 2015.
Body
Load factor for the month of August 2016 was 96%, an increase of one percentage points, compared to 95% for 
August 2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's August traffic grew by 11% to 11.5m customers, while our 
load factor jumped 1% point to 96%. Lower fares post-Brexit and the continuing success of our "Always Getting 
Better" customer experience programme continue to deliver even more great value for our rapidly growing customer 
base. "As our recent guidance confirmed, Ryanair expects average fares to fall by between 10% to 12% in the 6 
months to March 2017. There's never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair."

Invested: Win, lose or draw breath?
Invested: Win, lose or draw breath?
Sunday Business Post
September 18, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1405 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: Brexit brings pain for some investors, but there will be winners too
Body
At the end of the first day of trading following the Brexit vote, the Ftse 100 was down by over 7 per cent. 
But dominated as that index is by global mining, multinational and international banking groups, it wasn’t surprising 
that its decline was only half that of the mid-cap 250 index, which is far more closely aligned to the domestic British 
economy, and fell by 13 per cent in the two trading days post-referendum. The Iseq fell by 16 per cent. 
The impact was heaviest on financial services stocks – Lloyds Banking Group and Barclays down 30 per cent, Bank 
of Ireland down 37 per cent and IFG, 15 per cent down over the same two days. 
The concerns about Brexit in the financial sector are on several levels. First, the macroeconomic level arising from 
a slowdown in the economy as uncertainty about the outcome of Brexit negotiations stalls investment decisions, as 
well as ‘big ticket’ consumer spending. For Bank of Ireland, a slowing British housing market will be the main 
concern as demand for residential mortgages slows. 
For IFG, the market clearly anticipates a loss of momentum in its wealth management services. Unlike most Irish 
stocks, the latter’s shares have fallen in September to below the levels in the immediate Brexit aftermath. 
Longer term, the implications for the larger indigenous British financial services groups are even greater than for 
Irish banks, given their heavy reliance on the passport that the EU provides to enable them to sell wholesale 
financial services across Europe without having to set up separately incorporated businesses in individual member 
states. This makes the City of London vulnerable – as reflected in the knocks to London and south-east-focused 
house-builders, as well as hotel groups, airlines and restaurant chains. 
However, hotel group Dalata – which has about 25 per cent of its hotel room space in Britain – has been able to 
offset some of the negative effects of Brexit in recent months by the weakness in sterling which has driven British 
visitors to its Irish hotels. Hence it has recovered about half of its share price fall since the referendum result. 
Invested: Win, lose or draw breath?
As to airlines, Ryanair, IAG and EasyJet have all seen their share prices fall – although disentangling the Brexit and 
international terrorism threats is impossible. However, Ryanair has recovered most of its fall since suggesting it is 
best-placed to fight a price war and adapt its capacity utilisation to more airports. At its current price-to-earnings 
ratio, the shares look attractive. 
So were worries about the implications of Brexit in the immediate aftermath of the result overdone? Or has the 
impact been offset by continued monetary easing and – linked to that – the fall in sterling against the currencies of 
Britain’s major trading partners? 
What is clear is that discrimination between the share prices of companies that risk being hard hit and those that 
might be relatively immune – or indeed capable of adapting – is essential. But those judgment calls will remain 
difficult until the terms of the Brexit – hard or soft – are known. 
Twelve weeks on from the referendum, the stock markets have recovered their poise: by the end of August, the 
Ftse100, 250 and 350 were not only up on their post-Brexit lows, they were up on their pre-Brexit highs. 
Four key factors have contributed to this: Firstly, weak sterling has pushed up the value of shares in companies 
which have a large proportion of their earning streams in the now more valuable dollar and euro. 
Secondly, since June, the market has had an opportunity to assess more carefully and discriminatingly those 
companies that are likely to take a big ‘hit’ from the uncertainty that the Brexit vote has engendered and indeed 
those who benefited from it. 
The third factor is the impact on asset values of continued quantitative easing, and the fourth is the doubt that many 
well-placed investors have in their minds as to whether Brexit will become a reality at all. 
The British public will have serious cause for reflection once the actual Brexit package is unravelled. Brussels 
seems adamant that under no circumstances will there be free access to the single market without free movement 
of people. With all of the key British stock indices now well ahead of where they were before the Brexit vote, 
investors must ponder: is Brexit a sure-fire thing? Maybe not. 
That said, as investors, we should hope for the best, but plan for the worst. Certain stock market sectors and sub-
sectors seem best avoided while we see how the negotiations proceed – or unravel. 
If a ‘hard’ Brexit proceeds, the sectors most exposed are likely to be those manufacturers whose supply chains and 
sales are international, domestic players who depend on plentiful supplies of relatively unskilled labour (food 
manufacturers, retailers and hoteliers), and those segments of the house-building industry which have a particular 
concentration on London and the south-east, given the uncertainty about Britain’s capacity to negotiate post-Brexit 
‘passporting’ rights for its City of London-based wholesale financial services businesses. 
A squeeze on the City of London – as the market is clearly anticipating – will have inevitable negative 
consequences for, in particular, the upper end of London and south-east house-builders – and estate agents, 
mortgage providers and commercial property developers focused on London and the south east. 
What about the impact of a change in the free movement of labour rules, which would halt the inward migration of 
relatively unskilled labour? It risks causing issues for the world’s largest sandwich manufacturer, Greencore, which 
saw its share price retreat substantially in the run-up to (and near-term aftermath of) the referendum. The shares 
have, however, begun to spring back in recent weeks – probably due to the company’s well-executed expansion 
programme in the US where it is now in the last lap of the rollout of significant new capacity. This programme offers 
the short-term prospect of diluting the negative impacts of Brexit and as market leader, should leave Greencore well 
positioned to squeeze out and acquire smaller competitors, thus increasing its overall scale, distribution economies 
and competitive advantage. 
A hard ‘Brexit’ is likely to have very serious consequences for the banking and financial services sector generally. 
One needs to remember that SMEs, corporate and other lending institutions benefit little in incremental terms from 
Invested: Win, lose or draw breath?
the upside in client borrowers because they do not hold equity in those businesses, but they can lose a lot from the 
downside because of the debt they have advanced to them. So while there are bound to be winners and losers from 
Brexit, the banks will not gain materially from their winning clients, but risk losing substantially from their losing 
ones, for example, property developers and house-builders. 
Significant change in the dynamics of an economy over the short-term can cause particular problems for SMEs 
which may not have the resources to adapt business models, and hence negative consequences for banks lending 
to SMEs. Many Irish investors will be exposed to the risks carried by the British arms of our two pillar banks, AIB 
and Bank of Ireland; the latter more than the former. 
But let’s not forget potential winners: Irish Continental Group could be a significant beneficiary of Brexit. The return 
of duty-free sales that would follow should boost its cross-channel revenues. Outsourcing groups – such as Serco 
and Mitie – might also benefit as businesses seek to downsize fixed central overheads in response to trading 
pressures and transfer some operating costs to outsourcers who may enjoy scale economies, enabling them to 
leverage technology-driven efficiencies that individual businesses cannot make scalable in respect of support 
functions. 
And keep an eye on the Green Reit and other real estate investment trusts which may well be a beneficiary of many 
British financial services operators transferring some of their operations to Dublin. 
Finally, with sterling weakness and an anticipated pick-up in inflation, the regulated British utilities are one hedge 
against sterling inflation as they are allowed to raise their water charges in line with the Britain’s inflation index. 
But for investors, one thing is certain: the uncertainty will have a cost in the form of reduced investment and slower 
growth at least until the air is cleared.
Load-Date: September 18, 2016
End of Document
European ADRs Edge Higher as Consumer Stocks Log Gains
European ADRs Edge Higher as Consumer Stocks Log Gains
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 15, 2016 Thursday 10:45 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 257 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.12% higher at 120.88 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Thursday morning.
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by Materialise (MTLS), a Belgian provider of 3D printing software and 
services, 4.8% higher, followed by VimpelCom - Com (VIP), a Dutch provider of telecommunications services, up by 
3.9%, and Edap (EDAP), a French medical devices developer, trading 2.8% higher. Ascendis Pharma (ASND), a 
Danish clinical stage biopharmaceutical company, was 2.1% higher. 
In the UK, Ryanair (RYAAY), a low-cost airline, and Diageo (DEO), a beverages company, led the gainers, both up 
by 1.5%, followed by high street bank HSBC (HSBC) and InterContinental Hotels (IHG), a hotel chain, both trading 
1.0% higher. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Sequans Communications (SQNS), a French developer of chipset 
solutions, 11.1% lower, followed by Sanofi (SNY), a French healthcare company, down by 1.5% and Banco Bilbao 
Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), a Spanish financial group, 1.3% lower. Telecom Italia (TI), an Italian 
telecommunications company, was down by 1.3%. 
And, in the UK, Randgold Resources (GOLD), a gold-mining company which operates in West and Central Africa, 
was 1.9% lower, followed by Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS),  a financial products and services provider, 1.7% lower 
and Luxfer (LXFR), a materials technology company, down by 1.1%. GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), a 
biopharmaceutical company, was 1.1% lower.

Hundreds of flights cancelled amid French air traffic control strike
Hundreds of flights cancelled amid French air traffic control strike
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 15, 2016 Thursday 6:11 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
       PARIS (dpa-AFX) - European airlines say hundreds of flights were delayed or cancelled on Thursday due to a 
strike by air traffic controllers in France.  Airlines Easyjet, Ryanair, British Airways and Aer Lingus each reported 
numerous flights cancelled due to the strike, which was set to impact thousands of passengers.  More than 300 
flights were estimated to be cancelled, as airlines in Europe reduced their offering by 15 per cent, according to 
lobby group Airlines for Europe (A4E).  The strike, which is expected to last for 35 hours, is the latest of several 
walk-outs this year by French air traffic controllers in protest at France's controversial labour reforms passed in July 
in an effort to jumpstart the country's flagging economy.  The labour action drew criticism from A4E lobbyists 
representing several airlines affected by the strike.  'The demands of increasingly mobile European citizens and 
businesses cannot be taken hostage by localized industrial action. It is about time to minimize the impact of these 
strike actions,' A4E chief Thomas Reynaert said, also criticizing a lack in measures from European authorities to 
prevent such strikes.  Europe has already seen several strikes this year by air traffic controllers in Italy, Belgium, 
Greece and France, leading to thousands of cancelled and delayed flights.   Copyright dpa

Ryanair Shareholders Okay All Resolutions
Ryanair Shareholders Okay All Resolutions
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 14, 2016 Wednesday 10:55 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 212 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) said Wednesday that its shareholders 
approved all resolutions by substantial majorities.  Ryanair Chairman, David Bonderman said, 'As our recent full 
year guidance confirmed, Ryanair expects average fares to fall by between 10% to 12% in the 6 months to March 
2017 (this winter), so there's never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair, with even more value for 
our rapidly growing customer base.'  The airline also briefed shareholders on the continuing success of its 'Always 
Getting Better' or AGB customer experience improvement programme, which has already enabled Ryanair to raise 
its full year traffic forecast to 117 million customers, with a full year net profit guidance range of 1.375 billion euros 
to 1.425 billion euros.  Ryanair noted that its customers can look forward to further improvements in the coming 
year including even lower fares, the early launch of the summer 2017 schedule, digital enhancements such as 
travel extras in the app, 'one-flick' payments and automatic check-in, a 'My Ryanair Club' with member benefits, and 
the launch of the Ryanair Rooms accommodation platform, as AGB continues to deliver for Ryanair's customers, 
people and shareholders.

Ryanair Shareholders Okay All Resolutions
Ryanair Shareholders Okay All Resolutions
RTT News (United States)
September 14, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) said Wednesday that its shareholders approved all 
resolutions by substantial majorities.
Ryanair Chairman, David Bonderman said, "As our recent full year guidance confirmed, Ryanair expects average 
fares to fall by between 10% to 12% in the 6 months to March 2017 (this winter), so there's never been a better time 
to book a low fare flight on Ryanair, with even more value for our rapidly growing customer base."
The airline also briefed shareholders on the continuing success of its "Always Getting Better" or AGB customer 
experience improvement programme, which has already enabled Ryanair to raise its full year traffic forecast to 117 
million customers, with a full year net profit guidance range of 1.375 billion euros to 1.425 billion euros.
Ryanair noted that its customers can look forward to further improvements in the coming year including even lower 
fares, the early launch of the summer 2017 schedule, digital enhancements such as travel extras in the app, 'one-
flick' payments and automatic check-in, a "My Ryanair Club" with member benefits, and the launch of the Ryanair 
Rooms accommodation platform, as AGB continues to deliver for Ryanair's customers, people and shareholders.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Shares Bought by Blair William Co. IL
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Shares Bought by Blair William Co. IL
Watchlist News
September 13, 2016 Tuesday 3:16 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved

Byline: Hanz Christensen
Body
Sep 13, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Blair William .... IL boosted 
its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 9.5% during the second quarter, according to its 
most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The firm owned 7,637 shares of the company's 
stock after buying an additional 664 shares during the period. Blair William .... IL's holdings in Ryanair Holdings 
PLC were worth $531,000 as of its most recent SEC filing. 
 A number of other institutional investors have also recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. Smithfield Trust Co. 
increased its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 0.9% in the second quarter. Smithfield Trust Co. now owns 1,616 
shares of the company's stock valued at $113,000 after buying an additional 15 shares during the last quarter. 
Nuveen Asset Management LLC increased its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 0.9% in the first quarter. Nuveen 
Asset Management LLC now owns 7,071 shares of the company's stock valued at $607,000 after buying an 
additional 63 shares during the last quarter. IFP Advisors Inc increased its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 
2.3% in the first quarter. IFP Advisors Inc now owns 2,896 shares of the company's stock valued at $249,000 after 
buying an additional 66 shares during the last quarter. Fulton Bank N.A. increased its position in Ryanair Holdings 
PLC by 5.4% in the second quarter. Fulton Bank N.A. now owns 5,551 shares of the company's stock valued at 
$386,000 after buying an additional 286 shares during the last quarter. Finally, 1st Global Advisors Inc. increased 
its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 8.8% in the second quarter. 1st Global Advisors Inc. now owns 4,608 
shares of the company's stock valued at $320,000 after buying an additional 371 shares during the last quarter. 
Institutional investors and hedge funds own 42.57% of the company's stock.  Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) traded down 0.81% on Monday, reaching $78.03. The company had a trading volume of 
714,938 shares. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12-month low of $66.09 and a 12-month high of $89.67. The stock 
has a market capitalization of $19.58 billion, a PE ratio of 11.84 and a beta of 0.81. The stock's 50 day moving 
average price is $72.39 and its 200-day moving average price is $78.08.  Several equities research analysts have 
issued reports on RYAAY shares. Evercore ISI downgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' 
rating and set a $90.00 target price on the stock. in a research report on Monday, June 27th. Zacks Investment 
Research upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'sell' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research report on Tuesday, 
August 30th. Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a research report on

Deutsche Bank AG Lowers Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) to Hold
Deutsche Bank AG Lowers Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) to Hold

September 12, 2016 Monday 12:46 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved

How Airbnb is adding to the rental crisis
How Airbnb is adding to the rental crisis
Sunday Business Post
September 11, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 873 words
Byline: Jack Horgan-Jones
Highlight: Critics say it is a cash cow for private landlords which is destabilising a housing market already in crisis
Body
It has been hailed as the Ryanair of the hotel industry – an energetic, cost-cutting, upstart threatening long-held and 
jealously guarded hegemonies. Airbnb has cut a swathe through the global property sector since it was founded on 
the quaint idea of hiring out an air mattress in your house. Since that day in 2008, it has grown exponentially, with 
more than 1.5 million beds now available for hire in cities around the world. It has been hailed as the epitome of the 
sharing economy – unlocking unused economic bandwidth, breaking down monopolies, and enriching culturally and 
monetarily those who use it. 
But critics say there is a dark side to Airbnb. For all its spiel about extra income and new friends, it has also grown 
into a massive industry in its own right. Stories abound of landlords controlling tens of properties, of 
professionalised service and high volumes of visitors. The explosion of Airbnb has facilitated the rise of a new 
business; but is the true cost of success only becoming clear now? 
“The last time I looked, there were 4,000 units available in Dublin on Airbnb, and just under 45 per cent of them 
were entire apartments,” said Lorcan Sirr, a lecturer in housing studies in DIT. “I calculated we could have housed 
650 families in all the Airbnbs that were available full time,” he said. The problem is that Airbnb is so wildly 
successful; providing the same yield as an annual lease in a fraction of the time, that it could be hampering the 
supply of units onto the open market. In a badly misfiring housing market, people like Sirr say that’s patently bad 
news. 
“The average stay in a Dublin Airbnb last year was €94 a night, and compare that against your average rent in 
2015, you’ll make an awful lot more money if you go at the Airbnb in any serious way.” 
In a housing crisis, Sirr argued, “the immediate term is managing that supply that we have already. Part of the 
management of the stock is empty houses and vacant houses, and we’re not good at that”. 
How Airbnb is adding to the rental crisis
And it’s not just Dublin where there are fears over the impact of Airbnb. Amsterdam, Berlin and Barcelona have all 
introduced rules around the service in an effort to temper its incursions into the private rental market. Murray Cox is 
an Australian photographer who is living in Brooklyn. He founded data-scraping website InsideAirbnb.com in an 
effort to delve deeper into Airbnb, its use and its impact.  
“I originally set about asking questions about how Airbnb was being used in the neighbourhood, especially as it 
intersects with housing issues which can be at the core of other issues in the neighbourhood.” 
The site collects and displays data on Airbnb throughout the world, it makes it visible and provides tools to look at 
Airbnb usage. 
“That was to show that Airbnb was an economic incentive for people thinking of renting to tenants that they can 
make more money through Airbnb,” he said of an analysis he ran on Los Angeles usage of the platform. The same 
analysis revealed that occupancy of just 83 nights on average yielded the same sum as a year-long lease.  
“There’s a big myth out there propagated by Airbnb and their hosts and their marketing team that people use it to 
rent spare rooms. In reality, in most cities, the majority are using it to rent out whole apartments,” he said. In Dublin, 
it’s 45 per cent.  
“People need to think about it. Even if they use it to travel, they should be thinking about how their use impacts the 
city where they’re going,” he said. He said that efforts to regulate it have often fallen flat, with bans, nightly limits 
and permitting systems all easily flouted by entrepreneuring Airbnbers.  
“It’s almost like the Wild West in many cities around the world,” he said.   
However, not everyone wants to see governments and regulators bully-foot their way in, raising the possibility that 
they could make the situation worse while trying to make it better.  
Ronan Lyons, assistant professor of economics at Trinity College Dublin and author of the Daft report, said the core 
issue is one of supply, not use of supply, and the sooner that is sorted out, the sooner cities like Dublin can move 
towards an accommodation that pleases everyone.  
“If you have lots of people who want to come to your city, either for a weekend or to live and work, that’s a good 
news story. That’s extra demand and that’s what city fathers should ultimately want. It only becomes a problem if 
the housing structure can’t respond to that extra demand by building more homes, or more bed spaces,” he said.  
“In terms of supply and demand, you want to be encouraging demand, whether people live there or are just coming 
as a tourist. If you just react to this by limiting demand, it shows a complete unwillingness to tackle the root problem, 
which is we haven’t figured out why it’s so expensive to build new accommodation, and therefore it’s not being 
built,” he said.  
Ultimately, Lyons says, it’s not for politicians to judge the merits of a use of supply – it’s their responsibility to ensure 
supply comes on stream. 
“Earning money from renting something on Airbnb versus Daft, it’s not clear to me why one is a good and one is a 
bad.” 
For now, it remains to be seen whether short-term letting could become a long-term problem.
Load-Date: September 11, 2016
End of Document
Short cuts
Short cuts
Financial Times (London, England)
September 10, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FT WEEKEND SUPPLEMENT - LIFE & ARTS; Pg. 7
Length: 437 words
Byline: Tom Robbins
Body
 Amsterdam Bugaboo, the Dutch company that transformed the pram and pushchair market when it was 
founded 20 years ago, is to launch its first range of luggage. Bugaboo pushchairs went on to be sold in 
more than 50 countries (and even honoured on a Dutch stamp in 2007). The company has similarly lofty 
ambitions for its luggage, billing it not simply as a range of suitcases but a "new mobility concept". The 
Bugaboo Boxer is a modular system based around a wheeled-chassis on to which different sized bags can 
be clipped. Fully loaded, the chassis can carry a full-size case, a carry-on bag and several smaller laptop 
and soft bags. The chassis alone weighs 3.2kg but the neat trick for air passengers is that it can be folded 
up to become part of the carry-on bag, thus avoiding eating into the weight allowance for checked bags. 
Bugaboo says the folded chassis will meet size regulations for carry-ons for "most" airlines (although not 
Ryanair). As with the company's pushchairs, prices are high: the chassis costs £480, full-size case £350, 
cabin bag £310. It will be available on September 26. bugaboo.com/bugabooboxer 
Hong Kong Cathay Pacific will fly its last passenger service using a Boeing 747 next month. The airline first began 
using the aircraft - the original jumbo jet - in 1979, and says its fleet of 747s has carried 160m people. Cathay has 
been gradually replacing its fleet with more fuel-efficient alternatives; the final passenger 747 flight will be from 
Tokyo to Hong Kong on October 1. Other airlines have made similar moves - Air France, Japan Airlines, Air New 
Zealand and Singapore Airlines have already retired their final 747s; Delta is due to follow suit in 2017. 
Nevertheless, 47 years after it first flew, the so-called "Queen of the Skies" is unlikely to disappear totally for several 
years yet: British Airways alone still operates 38. cathaypacific.com
Short cuts
California Timber Cove, a 1960s retreat perched on cliffs in Sonoma County, is to be relaunched this month 
following a major renovation. The resort opened in 1963 with buildings inspired by Frank Lloyd Wright and 
overlooked by "The Expanding Universe", a 93ft obelisk created by the Californian sculptor Beniamino Bufano. 
Photographer Ansel Adams was among many artists who became regular guests. After an eight-month closure for 
rebuilding and redecoration, it now has 46 guest rooms designed to appeal to the "modern hippie", with a mix of 
modern and retro furniture and heavy use of redwood and stone. The original A-frame structure remains, housing 
the bar and public areas. Double rooms cost from $210; timbercove resort.com
Tom Robbins
Load-Date: September 9, 2016
End of Document

EasyJet chief criticises 'irrational' legacy rivals Airlines
EasyJet chief criticises 'irrational' legacy rivals; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 9, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 18
Length: 369 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Body
The chief executive of easyJet yesterday accused some of Europe's legacy airlines of irrational behaviour, saying 
they were adding "deeply unprofitable" routes amid lacklustre economic growth on the continent.
At an aviation conference in London, Dame Carolyn McCall claimed certain rivals were chasing short-term, 
unsustainable revenues. She was speaking as European airlines grapple with economic uncertainty, air traffic 
control disruption and terrorism that have driven down fares and profits sharply.
EasyJet's shares fell in June after the low-cost airline warned that its profit would be hit by several factors including 
Britain's decision to leave the EU. However, speaking at the World Low-Cost Airline Congress, Dame Carolyn said 
some legacy airlines were adding new routes that would ultimately lose them money. The routes were currently 
making money because of lower oil prices, but that approach was "unsustainable" because fares would fall to 
reflect carriers' reduced fuel expenses, she added.
"There's a bit of irrationality in Europe at the moment," said Dame Carolyn. "[Airlines are] putting in capacity which 
is deeply unprofitable."
She said easyJet, by contrast, made money whether oil prices were high or low. Dame Carolyn did not name any of 
the legacy airlines whose tactics she was criticising. But Air France-KLM, International Airlines Group and 
Lufthansa have all come under pressure on European short-haul routes from low-cost airlines led by Ryanair and 
easyJet. EasyJet, however, faces its own challenges following Britain's vote to leave the EU in the June 
EasyJet chief criticises 'irrational' legacy rivals Airlines
referendum. The airline has become Europe's second-largest low-cost carrier by revenue by capitalising on the 
creation of a single EU aviation market in the 1990s.
This market allows EU airlines to operate services between any two destinations within the regional bloc, and 
easyJet has grown rapidly over the past 20 years through these arrangements.
But Dame Carolyn dismissed the Brexit vote's significance for easyJet, which plans to circumvent any regulatory 
changes by seeking an air operator's certificate in mainland Europe.
"We are a growth business," she said. "We'll continue to be a growth business, regardless of Brexit."
Load-Date: September 8, 2016
End of Document
Pearson hit by concerns over state of academic publishing sector London
Pearson hit by concerns over state of academic publishing sector; London
Financial Times (London, England)
September 9, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS & INVESTING; Pg. 19
Length: 450 words
Byline: Bryce Elder
Body
Pearson hit a three-month low after weak results from two competitors deepened concerns that academic 
publishing is suffering from a structural downturn.
John Wiley & Sons and Barnes & Noble Education both reported sharp falls in textbook sales, with Wiley warning 
that its traditional publishing business was "under considerable pressure, particularly in education".
Students are increasingly aware of textbook rentals and ebooks, and are getting books when needed rather than at 
the start of each academic year, Wiley said. Both companies also cautioned that campus bookstores have been 
keeping inventories tighter this year, having had a slew of returns in 2015.
The news "strengthens our conviction both that [Pearson] will both deliver another profit warning and that its 
problems are primarily structural in nature", said Liberum. "Our biggest concern with Pearson is in its US Higher 
Education business (estimated 45 per cent of group profits) and, primarily, that students are shifting away from 
expensive textbook purchases. Wiley's comments yesterday suggest that this shift is real and also that it appears to 
be gaining momentum."
Pearson, down 7.7 per cent to 797p, was also affected by news this week that the for-profit college ITT Technical 
Institute had shut down its 130 campuses . Regulatory scrutiny of US colleges is increasing, which will hit enrolment 
numbers and cut the chance of Pearson's higher education business recovering, said Goldman Sachs.
Pearson hit by concerns over state of academic publishing sector London
An uneventful wider market saw the FTSE 100 edge 0.2 per cent higher, up 12.12 points to 6,858.70. Micro Focus 
led the way, up 14.7 per cent to £22.43, after agreeing a reverse takeover of Hewlett Packard Enterprise's software 
division .
Airlines gained after EasyJet chief executive Carolyn McCall said at an airlines conference in London that the 
Brexit vote had no effect on long-term outlook, and that ticket pricing is "very similar" to last year. EasyJet rose 3.7 
per cent to £11.97 and IAG was up 4 per cent to 422.1p, helped by positive numbers overnight from Delta Air Lines.
Ryanair gained 3.3 per cent to EUR13.28, with Davy setting out a case for the stock to double. "A step-up in 
ancillary revenues, the game-changing economics of [Boeing] MAX deliveries and potentially more than EUR5.5bn 
in cash returns to shareholders over five years underpin a compelling medium-term investment case," it said.
RSA Insurance took on 0.9 per cent to 506.5p after HSBC turned positive, in part on sterling's recent weakness.
WPP slipped 1.1 per cent to £17.90 after Carat, the media buying agency owned by Dentsu, trimmed its 2016 and 
2017 global ad spend forecasts to reflect a sharp deterioration in the outlook for the UK and Brazil.
Load-Date: September 8, 2016
End of Document
European ADRs Move Higher in Thursday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Thursday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 8, 2016 Thursday 11:58 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 222 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks rose 0.21% to 124.86 on the Bank of New York Mellon Europe 
ADR Index on Thursday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical firm Nabriva Therapeutics (NBRV), which surged 
9.3%, followed by Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), which rose 5.9%. Voxeljet (VJET), which makes 3D printers, 
increased 5%, while CGG (CGG), a manufacturer of geophysical equipment, was up 3.4%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by ASML (ASML), a manufacturer of chip-making equipment, which 
dropped 1.6%, followed by specialty pharmaceutical company Flamel Technologies (FLML), technology company 
Criteo (CRTO), and Ascendis Pharma (ASND), which lost 1.4% each. 
In the U.K. and Ireland, the gainers were led by Irish airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which rose 3.8%, followed 
by biopharmaceutical company Amarin (AMRN), which increased 3.2%. Oil services firm Amec Foster Wheeler 
(AMFW) and Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) were up 2.5% and 1.7% each.
The decliners in the U.K. and Ireland were led by media group Pearson (PSO), which shed 7.3%, followed by GW 
Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), which was off 1.6%. Telecommunications company Vodafone Group (VOD), and gold 
mining company Randgold Resources (GOLD), dropped 1.6% and 1.3% respectively.

FTSE 100 Marginally Higher Despite Weak Data
FTSE 100 Marginally Higher Despite Weak Data
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 7, 2016 Wednesday 1:01 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 362 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares fluctuated on Wednesday, as a string of weak data offset gains in 
commodity-related stocks and well-received earnings results from Ashtead.  U.K. industrial output grew 0.1 percent 
in July from the previous month after staying flat in June, official data showed. Nonetheless, the monthly growth 
was in contrast to a 0.2 percent fall economists had expected. 
 Separately, survey data from the mortgage lender Halifax revealed that U.K. house prices climbed 6.9 percent in 
three months to August from last year after rising 8.4 percent in the three months ended July. The latest rate of 
increase was the weakest since October 2013, when prices grew the same 6.9 percent.  Elsewhere, data out of 
Germany showed that the country's industrial production fell by the most in almost two years in July, confounding 
expectations for an increase.   The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 8 points or 0.12 percent at 6,834 in midday 
trading after losing 0.8 percent the previous day.  Ashtead Group shares jumped 6 percent. The construction 
equipment provider lifted its full-year guidance after reporting a 4 percent rise in first-quarter pretax profit.  Oil major 
Tullow oil rose nearly 2 percent and Royal Dutch Shell gained 1 percent as oil prices rose on a weaker dollar.   
Precious metals miner Randgold Resources added 1.5 percent and Fresnillo rose 1 percent after gold futures 
rallied to log their highest settlement in nearly three weeks overnight.  House builder Barratt Developments dropped 
1.5 percent despite posting record pre-tax profits in the year to June, in line with its previous guidance.   Investment 
products provider Hargreaves Lansdown fell over 1 percent after announcing the departure of its chief executive, 
Ian Gorham.  Sports Direct International lost almost 10 percent as the embattled retailer forecast profit below 
analysts' estimates following a turbulent year.  EasyJet slid half a percent and Ryanair Holdings shed 0.8 percent 
after Deutsche Bank cut its ratings on the stocks.  Just Eat tumbled 3.5 percent after Amazon said it would launch a 
free one-hour restaurant delivery service for Prime members in London.      
Load-Date: September 7, 2016
End of Document

12,035 shares of the company's stock after buying an additional 900 shares during the period.

filing with the SEC.  Other institutional investors have also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the

research note on Monday, June 27th. Four analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating and four have assigned 
a buy rating to the stock. The company has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and a consensus price target of $92.00.

low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United

FTSE 100 Marginally Higher Despite Weak Data
FTSE 100 Marginally Higher Despite Weak Data
RTT News (United States)
September 7, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 372 words
Body
(RTTNews) - U.K. shares fluctuated on Wednesday, as a string of weak data offset gains in commodity-related 
stocks and well-received earnings results from Ashtead.
U.K. industrial output grew 0.1 percent in July from the previous month after staying flat in June, official data 
showed. Nonetheless, the monthly growth was in contrast to a 0.2 percent fall economists had expected.
Separately, survey data from the mortgage lender Halifax revealed that U.K. house prices climbed 6.9 percent in 
three months to August from last year after rising 8.4 percent in the three months ended July. The latest rate of 
increase was the weakest since October 2013, when prices grew the same 6.9 percent.
Elsewhere, data out of Germany showed that the country's industrial production fell by the most in almost two years 
in July, confounding expectations for an increase.
The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 8 points or 0.12 percent at 6,834 in midday trading after losing 0.8 percent the 
previous day.
Ashtead Group shares jumped 6 percent. The construction equipment provider lifted its full-year guidance after 
reporting a 4 percent rise in first-quarter pretax profit.
Oil major Tullow oil rose nearly 2 percent and Royal Dutch Shell gained 1 percent as oil prices rose on a weaker 
dollar.
Precious metals miner Randgold Resources added 1.5 percent and Fresnillo rose 1 percent after gold futures 
rallied to log their highest settlement in nearly three weeks overnight.
House builder Barratt Developments dropped 1.5 percent despite posting record pre-tax profits in the year to June, 
in line with its previous guidance.
Investment products provider Hargreaves Lansdown fell over 1 percent after announcing the departure of its chief 
executive, Ian Gorham.
Sports Direct International lost almost 10 percent as the embattled retailer forecast profit below analysts' estimates 
following a turbulent year.
EasyJet slid half a percent and Ryanair Holdings shed 0.8 percent after Deutsche Bank cut its ratings on the stocks.
FTSE 100 Marginally Higher Despite Weak Data
Just Eat tumbled 3.5 percent after Amazon said it would launch a free one-hour restaurant delivery service for 
Prime members in London.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com

French airlines cancels Luton link to NY Brexit fallout
French airlines cancels Luton link to NY; Brexit fallout
Financial Times (London, England)
September 6, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 19
Length: 206 words
Byline: FastFT
Body
French airline La Compagnie is to end business class-only flights between Luton airport and New York, blaming the 
Brexit vote for its decision.
In a statement on its website, La Compagnie said yesterday that it would instead introduce a second daily flight 
from Paris to New York.
The decision followed a similar move last week by British Airways to halve the number of its business class-only 
flights from London City airport to New York to one a day.
The last La Compagnie flight between London and New York will take off on September 24.
Customers who had booked tickets beyond that date will be offered a full refund or can choose instead to fly 
between Paris and New York. A transfer flight will be offered between London and Paris.
The young airline, which launched the business class-only flight from Luton in April last year, said its decision to 
end fights between London and New York came "in view of a new economic climate in Europe, fuelled by Brexit" 
which it added has "already affected various significant players within the airline industry".
Ryanair, the Irish low-cost airline, has curbed its UK growth plans following the EU referendum result in June and 
will shift its focus to expansion at other airports in Europe. FastFT
French airlines cancels Luton link to NY Brexit fallout
Load-Date: September 5, 2016
End of Document

Business-only airline says au revoir to Luton
Business-only airline says au revoir to Luton
City A.M.
September 6, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 5
Length: 170 words
Byline: OLIVER GILL
Body
A BUSINESS class-only, transatlantic airline has blamed the Brexit vote for suspending its London to New York 
route.
La Compagnie said the outcome of the EU referendum had created "long term uncertainty for the airline industry" 
and decided that it would replace the London Luton departure with a second daily flight from Paris to the Big Apple.
"The result of the EU referendum has created an unprecedented level of legal and economic uncertainty for airlines 
that service Britain," said La Compagnie founder Frantz Yvelin.
"[We] will focus on the Paris to New York route for the foreseeable future. We are the firmest believers of the UK's 
unique market position," he said.
Load factors on the Paris to New York route - the amount of available seats filled - are "already 80 per cent plus" 
compared to the 77 per cent on the London to New York journey.
The last flight will be on 24 September. Passengers booked beyond that date will be offered a full refund.
Wizz Air and Ryanair have also stated they felt a Brexit vote impact.
Load-Date: September 6, 2016
End of Document

Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Given Consensus 
Recommendation of 'Buy' by Brokerages
Watchlist News
September 3, 2016 Saturday 11:21 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 367 words
Byline: Micah Haroldson
Body
Sep 03, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Shares of Ryanair Holdings 
PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have received an average recommendation of 'Hold' from the eight ratings firms that are 
currently covering the firm. Four equities research analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating and three have 
issued a buy rating on the company. 
The average 12 month price objective among analysts that have issued a report on the stock in the last year is 
$91.00.  Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) opened at 75.00 on Monday. The stock has a market 
capitalization of $18.82 billion and a PE ratio of 11.24. The firm has a 50 day moving average of $71.20 and a 200-
day moving average of $78.36. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 52 week low of $66.09 and a 52 week high of $89.67.  
Several research firms have recently commented on RYAAY. Beaufort Securities reaffirmed a 'buy' rating on shares 
of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a report on Wednesday, May 25th. Zacks Investment Research downgraded shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Wednesday, May 25th. Evercore ISI 
downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating and set a $90.00 price objective 
on the stock. in a report on Monday, June 27th. Finally, Macquarie raised shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from an 
'underperform' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a report on Tuesday, July 5th. Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is 
a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving 
short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The 
Company's principal fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. Receive News ...tings for

Ryanair Reports 11% Increase in August Traffic
Ryanair Reports 11% Increase in August Traffic
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 2, 2016 Friday 6:17 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 72 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), an operator of a budget passenger airline, reported Friday an 11% increase in August 
passenger traffic compared to the same period last year.
For the month of August, passenger traffic reached 11.5 million passengers, while load factor gained 1 percentage 
point to 96%.
The company expects average fares to decline between 10% to 12% in the next six months to March 2017.

Apple boss tells Ireland : We will win EU tax fight
Apple boss tells Ireland: We will win EU tax fight
City A.M.
September 2, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 4
Length: 274 words
Byline: LYNSEY BARBER
Body
TIM COOK has lashed out at the EU's decision to recover a decade's worth of back taxes from Apple, calling it 
"total political crap" and accusing Europe of anti-US sentiment.
The chief executive said Ireland is being picked on and that its government and his company have both played by 
the rules in an interview with the Irish Independent.
"They just picked a number from I don't know where. In the year that the Commission says we paid that tax figure, 
we actually paid $400m. We believe that makes us the highest taxpayer in Ireland that year," he said.
Europe's competition watchdog has ordered that Ireland reclaim (EURO)13bn in unpaid taxes from Apple after an 
investigation which concluded it had an effective tax rate of just one per cent, amounting to state aid.
"I think that Apple was targeted here. And I think that [anti-US sentiment] is one reason why we could have been 
targeted. I think it's a desire to reallocate taxes that should be paid in the US to the EU," he said.
Cook wants Ireland to appeal the decision and he is confident Apple can win, he told the newspaper. Irish ministers 
will meet again today to discuss fighting the ruling in court after failing to come to a decision earlier in the week. In a 
separate interview with the Irish state broadcaster RTE, Cook called the ruling "maddening" and "wrong headed".
Outspoken Irish entrepreneur and Ryanair founder Michael O'Leary yesterday added his voice to the list of critics of 
the decision.
"Frankly the Irish government should turn around - they shouldn't even appeal the decision - they should just write a 
letter to Europe and tell them politely to f**k off," he said.
Apple boss tells Ireland : We will win EU tax fight
Graphic
 
Apple boss Tim Cook says he is maddened by the European Commission ruling
Load-Date: September 2, 2016

Ryanair 'very cautious' on winter travel outlook
Ryanair 'very cautious' on winter travel outlook
Business World (Digest)
September 01, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 428 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Europe's biggest low cost airline Ryanair is "very cautious" on its outlook for the winter as uncertainty from Brexit 
and security concerns from travellers persist, forcing the carrier to cut fares.
Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said Ryanair had stimulated travel demand by reducing summer prices by 9% 
after Britain's June vote to leave the EU, but was not sure what would happen from October onwards, when 
Europeans take fewer holidays.
That made him "very cautious" on the airline's forecast for profit to the year ended March 2017 to climb 13% to 
between 1.38 billion euros and 1.43 billion euros.
"That's the impact of Brexit, we're cutting fares much more steeply than in the past," he told a news conference in 
London. A weaker pound risks deterring British travel to euro countries.
"If the fares in the second half of the year fall by more than 10 or 12% then we'll have to revisit full-year guidance."
Europe's second biggest low cost carrier easyJet said in July it was unable to give an earnings forecast in the 
aftermath of Brexit, while Germany's Lufthansa downgraded its profit forecast and British Airways-owner IAG 
trimmed its 2016 growth plans.
O'Leary also on Wednesday gave further details of a plan to scale back capacity growth in Britain, where his Irish 
airline is the second biggest with an 18% market share. He saw growth of 6%in the 2017-18 financial year, from 
15% in the 12 months to March.
Ryanair 'very cautious' on winter travel outlook
That growth would have been between 10 and 15% had Britain not voted for Brexit and the uncertainty that brought, 
said O'Leary, a prominent campaigner for Britain to stay in the EU bloc.
O'Leary is also worried about an EU rule which states that EU airlines like Ryanair must be 50.1% owned by EU 
shareholders. If British investors were classed as non-EU, that would put Ryanair at odds with the rules.
He urged the UK government to allow the building of three new runways at each of London's biggest airports - 
Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted - schemes that arouse strong local opposition in heavily-populated southern 
England.
"It'll be a really good response to the whole post-Brexit, what's Britain's future in the world, are we open for 
business, open for trade? You can't be open for business if there's no runway capacity in the main city," he said.
Heathrow, London's biggest airport, is operating at full capacity and the government is due to make a long-delayed 
decision as to whether to build a new runway there or at no.2 airport Gatwick this autumn. Stansted, London's no.3 
airport, is Ryanair's biggest base. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: September 8, 2016
End of Document

Ryanair pleads with government to back three new London runways
Ryanair pleads with government to back three new London runways
City A.M.
September 1, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 203 words
Byline: JAMES NICKERSON
Body
BUDGET airline Ryanair has called on the UK government to be "radical" and approve runways at three airports in 
the south east.
The company said new runways at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted must be approved immediately to resolve the 
ever-crippling issue of aviation capacity.
The announcement comes as the country awaits the final decision on where to expand capacity, with Heathrow, 
Gatwick and the Heathrow Hub - an extension of Heathrow's northern runway - in contention.
Stansted is the base for a number of airlines, and is the largest base for Ryanair.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, said: "Ryanair calls on the new UK government to be radical in its 
decision making on new runways for London instead of picking just one."
O'Leary added that the airline was urging Theresa May to take urgent action to resolve runway capacity issues for 
the next 50 years.
He said the Prime Minister need to ensure "competition between airports delivers efficient facilities and prevents 
airlines and passengers being ripped off by gold-plated monopoly runways".
Business leaders have been pushing for a quick decision since the Davies Commission was published last July, 
which recommended building a third runway at Heathrow.
Ryanair pleads with government to back three new London runways
Graphic
 
Ryanair urged the UK government to take urgent action on airport capacity issues
Load-Date: September 1, 2016

Ryanair is World's favourite Airline according to Global report
Ryanair is World's favourite Airline according to Global report
Business World (Digest)
August 29, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 181 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair are this week celebrating being voted the World’s favourite airline.
This is according to IATA’s latest World Airline Transport Statistics which showed that Ryanair once again carried 
more international customers than any other airline.
Ryanair carried over 101.4m international passengers last year, almost 40m more than second-placed Easyjet 
(62.6m) and 55m more than Lufthansa in 4th place (46.9m).    Ryanair celebrated being named the world’s favourite 
airline once more by releasing 100,000 seats for sale across its European network, at prices starting from €19.99 
for travel in October and November.
These low fare seats are available for booking on the Ryanair.com website until midnight Monday (29 Aug).    
Ryanair’s Chief Marketing Officer, Robin Kiely said, "IATA has once again confirmed that Ryanair remains the 
world’s favourite airline as we became the first airline in the world to carry more than 100m international customers 
in one year, thanks to our “Always Getting Better” programme and by offering the lowest fares in Europe."
Source: www.businessworld.ie
About us

Ryanair extends Liverpool winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair extends Liverpool winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
August 23, 2016 Tuesday 7:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 311 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd., an Irish airline company, has extended its Liverpool winter 2016 schedule, with a new route 
to Marrakesh, Morocco, which will operate twice weekly from October 31, 2016.
Body
This is in addition to a new route to Sofia announced earlier, and 25 winter routes in total, which will help deliver 
1.9m customers p.a. and support 1,400 jobs at Liverpool Airport. Ryanair's Liverpool winter 2016 schedule will 
deliver: two new routes to Sofia (2 wkly) & Marrakesh (2 wkly); five new winter services to Bergerac (2 wkly), Gran 
Canaria (wkly), Pisa (2 wkly), Porto (2 wkly) & Szczecin (2 wkly); and more flights to Alicante (5 wkly) & Malaga (4 
wkly). Liverpool consumers and visitors can choose from 25 routes in winter 2016 and can look forward to further 
improvements under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme including more new routes, new digital features, 
new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Head of Communications, Robin Kiely said: "We are 
pleased to extend our Liverpool winter 2016 schedule with a new route to Marrakesh, which will operate twice 
weekly from 31st October and our 25 winter routes will help deliver 1.9 million customers this year and support 
1,400 "on-site" jobs at Liverpool Airport. 
Seats on our new route to Marrakesh are on sale now from just GBP24.99 and are available for booking until 
Monday (1 Aug) for travel in November. Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers 
should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Liverpool Airport's Robin Tudor said: "We are delighted to 
welcome this further expansion of Ryanair's network at Liverpool Airport with more flights on some of our key 
routes, and the addition of another new destination. This growth reaffirms the Airports commitment to expanding 
international connections for the Region, providing more choice to the travelling public, not only in the City of 
Liverpool but from across the North West and North Wales; whilst also delivering a 'faster, easier and friendlier' 
journey through the Airport."

Section: NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 73 words
Body
Ryanair will expand routes from UK bases in the winter. The airline, which was a staunch Remain supporter, 
warned in the wake of the Brexit vote that its 50 new aircraft due for delivery in 2017 will all be based in EU cities, 
as it predicts a Brexit-induced hit on the UK economy. Last night Ryanair said the UK route expansion, to cities 
such as Hamburg and Agadir, was not a U-turn on the plan, as routes were decided before the June vote.
