Boardroom Briefing
Boardroom Briefing
Sunday Business Post
August 21, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 585 words
Byline: Emma Kennedy
Body
Performance nutrition boost for Glanbia
Food group Glanbia reported an 11 per cent increase in its first-half earnings to €176.5 million. 
The company confirmed its forecast for earnings per share growth of eight to ten per cent this year, despite a 2.1 
per cent drop in revenue to €1.84 billion. 
In a statement, Glanbia said the strong first-half performance was driven by its performance nutrition division, with 
earnings before interest, tax and amortisation of €81.7 million at the unit, a 35 per cent increase on the same period 
a year earlier. 
“Sales of performance nutrition brands and value-added nutritional ingredients showed good growth in the first half 
of 2016, delivering on our vision to be a leading nutrition business,” managing director Siobhán Talbot said. 
The company’s ingredients division, Glanbia Nutritionals, delivered what the company said was “a satisfactory 
result in the context of ongoing challenging dairy markets” with earnings of €58 million, down by 4 per cent. 
Ryanair announces Italian expansion
Ryanair has welcomed the decision of the Italian government to reverse a €2.50 municipal tax increase and revise 
its airport guidelines, moves that have prompted it to reverse its decision to close its Pescara airport base in 
November and to accelerate its growth plans for the Italian market. 
The airline said it would allocate ten new aircraft, worth more than $1 billion, to the Italian market next year and 
launch 44 new routes, 21 of them at Rome and Milan airports and 23 at other regional airports. 
Ryanair also promised to deliver 10 per cent growth in passenger numbers to more than 35 million from the current 
32 million and to create 2,250 jobs at Italy’s airports. 
Boardroom Briefing
Mincon eyes acquisitions
Mincon Group, the engineering company that specialises in rock drilling tools, has reported an 11 per cent increase 
in revenue for the first six months of 2016. 
The company signalled that it was eyeing a number of acquisitions – but only if the price was right. “We have been 
active in approaching potential acquisition targets, but we did not see value for the group in the terms that were 
being sought by vendors, compared with the cost of investing in our own engineering competencies to build a 
competitive offering. We consider these opportunities on a case-by-case basis,” Mincon said in a statement. 
“We continue to engage in dialogue with potential acquisitions and investments, but in some cases, the asking price 
is not supported by the earnings,” the company said. “Nevertheless, there are fine companies in the sector worth 
acquiring, and we are actively continuing to identify and engage with those that we believe would add more than 
they would cost, and which would continue to fill out our geographic footprint, and our product and service offering.” 
Board change at Malin
Life sciences group Malin Corporation has announced that Sean Murphy has stepped down as a non-executive 
director. 
According to a statement from the company, Murphy was stepping down from the board “in order to be more 
appropriately positioned to best fulfil his duties as a senior operating and strategic executive within the company”. 
Upcoming results
A number of companies last week announced details of forthcoming results announcements. 
Hotel group Dalata will publish half-yearly results on Tuesday, September 6. 
On the same day, Applegreen will announce its interim results for the same period. Meanwhile, Total Produce will 
release its interim results a week earlier on Tuesday, August 30.
Load-Date: August 21, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair hikes Italy investment after Government does tax U-turn
Ryanair hikes Italy investment after Government does tax U-turn
Business World (Digest)
August 18, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 186 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair said on Wednesday it had reversed a decision to cut back operations in Italy and would 
instead invest a billion dollars in the country in 2017 after the government froze plans to hike passenger departure 
taxes.
Ryanair will add 10 new aircraft to its Italian network and open 44 new routes in a move it said would lift its 
passenger traffic by 10% to 35 million next year.
"We are talking about new investments in Italy that we are making by revisiting our programmes in Greece, Poland 
and Spain," Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary told reporters, suggesting his firm would cut back on operations in those 
three countries.
Ryanair said the plan envisaged creating 2,250 jobs at various Italian airports.
The low-cost airline said earlier this year that it planned to shed 600 jobs in Italy after the government announced it 
would raise departure taxes to 9 euros from 6.50 euros to help subsidize layoffs at former flagship carrier Alitalia.
However, the government put the planned hike on hold last month, encouraging Ryanair to boost its Italian network. 
(Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
About us
Ryanair hikes Italy investment after Government does tax U-turn
Load-Date: August 26, 2016

Ryanair To Invest $1 Bln For 10 Aircraft, Announces 44 New Routs
Ryanair To Invest $1 Bln For 10 Aircraft, Announces 44 New Routs
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 17, 2016 Wednesday 1:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 299 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair (RYA.L) Tuesday announced its plan to invest $1 billion for 10 new aircraft to the 
Itlalian market. The airline company will open 44 new routes with 21 at Rome and Milan and 23 at Italy's regional 
airports.  Further, the airline expects to grow Italian traffic by 10 percent or 3 million passengers to 35 million in 
2017. In addition 2250 jobs will be created by Italy's airports. 
  The company welcomed the reversal of 2.50 euro increase in municipal tax from September 1, 2016. The new 
guidelines of the Italian government have helped Pescara airport to sign a new growth agreement with Ryanair. 
Earlier it was planning for closure of the Pescara base in November.    Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said, 'We are 
extremely grateful to Prime Minister Renzi and Transport Minister Delrio for taking these initiatives to grow Italian 
tourism. All of this growth would have been lost to other EU countries if the Municipal Tax increase had not been 
reversed, and the airport guidelines had not been redrafted to comply with EU rules.'   Ryanair said it is in 
negotiations with Alghero airport and hopeful of reaching an agreement on completion of their current privatisation 
project in early September. The company is planning to release 100,000 seats for sale from just 8 euros, which are 
available for booking until midnight of August 18 and for travel in October and November. To avail the offer, 
customers can log on to www.ryanair.com.  The new summer 2017 routes announced by the airline are: Pescara - 
Copenhagen: Rome - Lourdes, Pescara - Krakow: Rome - Nuremberg, Bologna - Lisbon: Malpensa - Gran C., 
Bologna - Eindhoven: Bergamo - Edinburgh, Trapani - Prague: Bergamo - Luxembourg, Treviso - Krakow: Bergamo 
- Vigo, Bari - Liverpool: Palermo - Bucharest.

Ryanair To Invest $1 Bln For 10 Aircraft, Announces 44 New Routs
Ryanair To Invest $1 Bln For 10 Aircraft, Announces 44 New Routs
RTT News (United States)

Body
(RTTNews) - Ryanair (RYA.L) Tuesday announced its plan to invest $1 billion for 10 new aircraft to the Itlalian 
market. The airline company will open 44 new routes with 21 at Rome and Milan and 23 at Italy's regional airports. 
Further, the airline expects to grow Italian traffic by 10 percent or 3 million passengers to 35 million in 2017. In 
addition 2250 jobs will be created by Italy's airports.
The company welcomed the reversal of 2.50 euro increase in municipal tax from September 1, 2016. The new 
guidelines of the Italian government have helped Pescara airport to sign a new growth agreement with Ryanair. 
Earlier it was planning for closure of the Pescara base in November. Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said, "We are 
extremely grateful to Prime Minister Renzi and Transport Minister Delrio for taking these initiatives to grow Italian 
tourism. All of this growth would have been lost to other EU countries if the Municipal Tax increase had not been 
reversed, and the airport guidelines had not been redrafted to comply with EU rules." Ryanair said it is in 
negotiations with Alghero airport and hopeful of reaching an agreement on completion of their current privatisation 
project in early September.The company is planning to release 100,000 seats for sale from just 8 euros, which are 
available for booking until midnight of August 18 and for travel in October and November. To avail the offer, 
customers can log on to www.ryanair.com.
The new summer 2017 routes announced by the airline are: Pescara - Copenhagen: Rome - Lourdes, Pescara - 
Krakow: Rome - Nuremberg, Bologna - Lisbon: Malpensa - Gran C., Bologna - Eindhoven: Bergamo - Edinburgh, 
Trapani - Prague: Bergamo - Luxembourg, Treviso - Krakow: Bergamo - Vigo, Bari - Liverpool: Palermo - 
Bucharest.

Ryanair July passenger traffic increases
Ryanair July passenger traffic increases
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
August 16, 2016 Tuesday 6:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 138 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has reported that passenger traffic for the month of July 2016 was 11.3 million passengers, 
an increase of 12%, compared to 10.1 million passengers for July 2015.
Body
Load factor for the month of July 2016 was 96%, an increase of one percentage point, compared to 95% for July 
2015. Kenny Jacobs, Ryanair's chief marketing officer, said: "July was a record month for Ryanair as our traffic 
grew by 12% to 11.3m customers and we became the first airline in the world to carry over 11m international 
passengers in one month, with a load factor of 96%. "These record passenger figures were delivered at lower fares, 
and thanks to the continuing success of our "Always Getting Better" programme which continues to win new 
customers and new markets, despite yet more French ATC strikes and continuing post-Brexit market uncertainty. 
Our customers, and in particular families, are flying in even greater numbers this summer, thanks to Ryanair's lower 
fares that are already down 10% versus last year."
Load-Date: August 22, 2016
End of Document
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
Sunday Business Post
August 14, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 3381 words
Byline: Fearghal O’Connor
Highlight: The IAG boss Willie Walsh talks candidly about the airline’s future, Michael O’Leary, and retirement
Body
If Willie Walsh feels any great sense of personal vindication about the healthy state of Aer Lingus one year after his 
company IAG bought the former national airline, then he keeps it to himself. He recently left it to his chief financial 
officer Enrique Dupuy to deliver the assessment that Aer Lingus is now IAG’s star performer. 
“To be honest it is not often you hear Enrique say nice things about anything, and so for him to acknowledge the 
Aer Lingus performance is something special,” says Walsh. As we talk, his own assessment is business-like and 
unemotional. It was ever thus: Walsh adopted the same policy throughout his six-month courtship of Aer Lingus last 
year, a process that saw him win over the government, the markets and even the unions. 
“The company has performed well. The operational performance is strong. The customer performance is very 
strong. Aer Lingus management are doing a lot of very smart things. They have a lot of challenges. They are in 
probably the most competitive airport in the world, head to head with Ryanair. It’s an impressive performance. I’m 
very happy,” he says, finally allowing a glimpse of personal pleasure at the outcome. 
“I would say it has gone extremely well. I knew a lot about Aer Lingus from before obviously but the proposal to buy 
Aer Lingus wasn’t driven by me, it was taken by the team here. Given my background in Aer Lingus I was probably 
more. . . I wouldn’t say sceptical. . . but I was tougher on the team than I normally would be. I didn’t want it to be 
seen internally as something that Willie wanted to do and therefore we must push forward on it. It proved to be a 
very robust process as a result.” 
A year ago, the deal was controversial. There was a sustained campaign by some to stymie the bid. There were 
even parliamentary hearings and demands over routes, slots and jobs. A year on, the controversy has long been 
forgotten. The sky did not fall in. 
✽ ✽ ✽
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
The north Dublin-born chief executive of IAG, one of the biggest airline groups in the world, could be excused if he 
did have a private triumphant fist pump when the deal to buy Aer Lingus did finally close this time last year. 
Walsh had begun his career as an Aer Lingus pilot at 17. He took the job of chief executive in 2001 when no one 
else would, with the airline teetering on the brink of insolvency in post 9-11 shock and in desperate need of radical 
cutbacks. He quit three years later with the airline back on track with a brand new low-cost approach, but with Bertie 
Ahern’s admonishments for a failed management buyout proposal ringing in his ears. 
When he returned as boss of mighty IAG with an open cheque book in December 2014, offering to buy the 
government’s share, he was not greeted with open arms as a prodigal son. Now he can point to an airline that is 
looking to growth and expansion in a sector where many others face retrenchment. It is understandable then that he 
can’t resist a dig at those who loudly criticised his move to buy the former national flag carrier. 
“All of the doom and gloom merchants I hope are acknowledging that we have delivered what we promised, there 
hasn’t been any negatives and in fact the positives have been very significant,” he says. 
“There were a number of people who thought the world would end. I’m sure it is pleasing for everyone to see that 
hasn’t happened. Not only has it not happened but Aer Lingus has gone from strength to strength. There is still the 
exact same number of people employed in Aer Lingus today as when we acquired it. The suggestion that this was 
going to be bad for Aer Lingus and bad for Ireland, I don’t think most people believed that and we have 
demonstrated that it was not the case.” 
✽ ✽ ✽
Being chief executive of one of the biggest airline groups in the world has its perks, even if Walsh still likes to keep 
things simple. On a recent trip to Silicon Valley to launch a new British Airways service, Walsh got to spend 45 
minutes with Apple chief executive Tim Cook. 
“I had a one-on-one meeting with Tim, which was good. He was surprised to see that I still carry a Nokia phone.” 
Cook too is “very down to earth, very easy to talk to. . . friendly” and used to regularly fly in and out of Cork on Aer 
Lingus flights from London when visiting the Apple plant there, Walsh says. 
“It’s a perk of my job that I get time meeting industry leaders and spend some time talking to them about how they 
see the world. I’m always fascinated that they are interested in my views and how I see the world.” 
He has learned his trade as a chief executive by watching others, particularly their mistakes. 
“It’s not that difficult to be a leader. The difference between a manager and a leader is that as a leader you have got 
to be able to stand up and give bad news. Standing up and giving good news is something I find a lot of people are 
able to do but early on in my career as a chief executive I learned that I could not hide away in an office and expect 
others to pass on the bad news. Unfortunately in the airline industry you get plenty of opportunity to do that.” 
Being the bearer of bad news also draws plenty of abuse and conflict. In the wake of 9-11 Walsh cut more than 
2,000 jobs at Aer Lingus. After his move to the top job in British Airways he eyeballed the powerful British transport 
unions and won. When he arrived in Spain to merge Iberia with BA to create IAG he faced more hostility before 
getting his way. But, for Walsh, it’s all in a day’s work. 
“It’s not tough. If you sign up for the job, you sign up for that. If you are not prepared for that then don’t sign up. I 
went into the role of chief executive at Aer Lingus with my eyes open and I knew what I was being appointed to. No 
one could say better than me what the problem was and what the solution needed to be. Any chief executive who 
says they find it tough should have thought about that before they took on their role. If you are not prepared for that 
criticism you shouldn’t do the job.” 
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
For how long Walsh – a famous workaholic – is prepared to carry on doing the job is a question to which he gives 
an open response. When he joined Aer Lingus at 17, the retirement age for pilots was 55 and, he says, “you get 
that into your head”. 
“I had said when I was about 30 that I was still planning to retire when I was 55. I will be 55 in October but I will still 
be 55 until the 24th October, 2017. I’m not planning on it but I had come to terms with the fact that I will retire at 
some stage. I’ve seen a lot of people – a lot of them in Aer Lingus – coming up to retirement without thinking about 
it and then struggling with it. I love doing what I am doing and I’ve no intention of stopping at this stage but I will 
stop at some point. And when I do stop in my role at IAG my intention is to retire. I’ve been working in the industry 
since I was 17 and I came from a family where my father expected us to work during the summers so work is not an 
issue for me. 
“But I acknowledge that at some point you have to stop doing that and I am hoping to be in the fortunate position 
that I will be able to stop and maybe enjoy a few things that I haven’t been able to enjoy while I’ve been working. 
But I’m not planning on it and I have made it very clear that I am happy to continue as long as the board want me. 
The day I wake up and say ‘shit, I don’t want to do this’ is the day I’ll know it’s time for me to go.” 
Unlimited ambition
Walsh has inevitably spent much of his career looking over his shoulder at Michael O’Leary, not least because 
many of the cuts he has implemented have been aimed at helping various airlines better compete with Ryanair. 
He doesn’t get tired of being asked about his low cost rival, he says: “I openly talk about Michael. When I’m asked 
to make speeches it gives me a good 15 minutes of stuff to entertain people with.” 
O’Leary, he says, is “visionary” and “has to be admired like all leaders that are publicly able to change direction. 
That is not something that everybody is comfortable with. I don’t think he said he got it wrong but for him to be able 
to say ‘I might not have got it right’. . . and if he had known he would have changed earlier. . . I think you have to 
admire him for that.” 
He is impressed with the results of Ryanair’s recent transformation programme and sees opportunity in a possible 
passenger sharing deal that is under negotiation between Aer Lingus and Ryanair. 
“If customers want to use them to connect to us I don’t see any reason to not try and facilitate that. I have left that to 
[Aer Lingus chief executive] Stephen Kavanagh but talks are progressing. I have encouraged him to look at 
developing that relationship. We think there is an opportunity there so I remain optimistic that we will end up doing 
something with Ryanair. It’s on Stephen’s agenda, maybe not top of his agenda but he is certainly progressing it,” 
says Walsh, who is happy to leave the day to day business at Aer Lingus to Kavanagh. 
“It is no secret that I was a big fan of Stephen’s from the time I worked in the airline,” says Walsh. “He was 
instrumental in the building of the Aer Lingus strategy. He’s the brains behind the business there.” 
When IAG launched its bid in December 2014, the Aer Lingus board was in the process of recruiting a new chief 
executive and there was speculation about high profile candidates such as Qantas boss Alan Joyce and former 
Paddy Power boss Patrick Kennedy. 
“I made my views known to [then Aer Lingus chairman] Colm Barrington. While it was clearly a decision for Aer 
Lingus and the Aer Lingus board, and they clearly had to take that decision as an independent Aer Lingus, I had 
indicated to him that if Stephen wasn’t appointed he would probably leave the business and I would be top of the 
queue in offering him a job. The guy has a lot to contribute, he’s very talented, very bright. In his short term as Aer 
Lingus chief executive he has achieved quite a lot and there is a lot more for him to do.” 
Walsh intends “in due course” to step down as chairman of Aer Lingus, which he took on after the successful bid 
last year, with Kavanagh becoming executive chairman. 
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
“It has been a better year for Aer Lingus than expected but I wouldn’t say significantly better. But it is in line with 
what Stephen would have wanted to deliver. He is tough on himself and that is one of the things I admire about the 
guy. . . he sets very high standards and goals,” says Walsh. 
“It is still early days but we are not in any way limiting Aer Lingus’s ambition – quite the opposite. We in IAG don’t 
need to encourage them but we are encouraging them to be brave and to look at what they could do. And to be 
honest I am not limiting their ambition to just operating in Dublin or just in Ireland, but the focus should be Dublin 
because it is a hub and gives them the best opportunity. We have encouraged the team there to be aggressive in 
terms of what options might be available going forward.” 
Two new Airbus A330s due next year will provide for further transatlantic expansion but IAG is actively considering 
a possible order next year for an unspecified number of smaller Airbus A321LRs. Such an order represents “a 
potential game changer” for Aer Lingus, says Walsh, enabling the airline to boost frequencies on a number of  
transatlantic routes. 
“That would make Dublin an even more attractive hub because it would give you transatlantic options throughout 
the day making the hub work even better. That’s the way we are looking at the moment. . . although we have not 
committed to the 321LR, and there are other potential aircraft options, we think in the Aer Lingus context it is a very 
attractive proposition.” 
Any such ramping up of transatlantic traffic is dependent upon Dublin Airport becoming “an efficient, attractive, 
welcoming, pleasant hub”. 
“For Aer Lingus to fulfil the potential that we believe exists, Dublin needs to be an airport that people want to 
transfer through, not have to transfer through. There are lots of major hub airports people go to because they have 
no choice. We want people to actually look forward to transferring through Dublin because it is convenient, it’s 
friendly. . . all the things Dublin can be. But this will require full cooperation with DAA and IAA because it needs to 
be an efficient airport with smartly developed infrastructure.” 
In London, Walsh has consistently warned that a £23 billion price tag on a new runway at Heathrow, not to mention 
the political stalemate into which that project has fallen, will curtail growth. Dublin is being more pragmatic, he says, 
but like other airlines, he has concerns. 
“Infrastructure has to be efficient and has to be built with cost in mind. A runway is a simple piece of infrastructure. 
You don’t need to make it elaborate, you don’t need more runway than is required. Dublin is a good airport but it 
could be more efficient within the existing infrastructure, and the airport acknowledges that and is working to do 
that. If Dublin and the Irish economy continues to develop then a runway is definitely required, and as long as it is 
built in an efficient manner we will support it. We don’t want to see the costs for passengers at Dublin Airport 
increase.” 
Brexitunities
When Britain voted to leave the EU, IAG moved quickly to issue a profit warning. Operating profits were going to 
grow by almost £1 billion during 2016. Not so anymore, the airline told the markets. Business had already slowed 
ahead of the vote, it said, and conditions would remain difficult. The company’s share price plummeted 20 per cent. 
But Walsh remains sanguine and believes, for the most part, that IAG has taken the worst of its Brexit hit. The main 
negative from the referendum result for IAG was the sudden collapse in the value of sterling because although it 
reports its results in euro, its large British operation means that it does a lot of business in sterling. The weaker 
exchange rate means this sterling is translated at a much lower exchange rate, thus hitting euro profitability. 
“As a business we didn’t take a position on Brexit. I spoke personally that I thought Britain would be better off 
remaining in the EU and I voted to remain. But the people have spoken. We can argue whether it was the right or 
wrong decision for as long as we want, but the fact is that Britain will leave the EU. That means people are going to 
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
have to look at doing business in a different way. But it’s not going to stop people doing business and even the 
people who felt it would be negative have now got to start looking at the opportunities,” he says. 
Indeed, he believes Brexit is also an opportunity, particularly for Aer Lingus, because the weak pound makes Britain 
“very attractive” from a tourism and business point of view. Aer Lingus increasingly provides services from the US 
over Dublin into Britain and that is an opportunity, and weaker sterling will only encourage that traffic. 
Strong transatlantic growth has put Aer Lingus in a good place in another way too, he says. 
“Because of the amount of US business Aer Lingus now does, it has a very strong dollar revenue base, which is 
very positive for a European carrier in an industry that is typically short dollars.” 
Effectively, Aer Lingus has more dollar revenues than it has dollar costs, leaving it well placed to deal with a volatile 
currency environment. Of course, a series of terror attacks and political uncertainty in many countries means that 
the overall economic environment is also increasingly nervy – never a good thing for the aviation business, which is 
prone to cyclical downturns. But Walsh is determined to remain upbeat. 
“You have to put the noise to one side and look at what the fundamentals are like and the fundamentals are still 
okay,” he says. “Global economies are still relatively good at the moment. We are not in a 2008 or 2009 
environment. It is not a recession and we need to remember that. Growth is slow and in some cases weak and 
unsustainable, but there is growth out there. Where economies are growing that represents opportunities.” 
But, says Walsh, IAG is a pragmatic company, and while it believes demand for air transport will continue to grow, it 
has, like a lot of airlines, decided to scale back some of its plans to grow capacity. 
“That is the sensible thing to do. We are still growing because demand continues to grow but I think the industry is 
demonstrating its discipline. I remain reasonably optimistic about the outlook for 2017. I think the general economic 
environment will be better than 2016 and, yes, there are headwinds out there. But you can’t just look at those, 
you’ve got to focus on the opportunities too.” 
Regional growth
Walsh, who currently serves as both chairman of the National Treasury Management Agency (NTMA) and as 
president of the London Chamber of Commerce, is in a unique position to understand the shifting sands on both 
sides of the Irish Sea. Brexit will impact on the Irish economy, he says, but there are positives too, not least the 
possibility that for any businesses now planning to leave Britain, Ireland presents a real opportunity. 
But he is realistic too. When it comes to economics Walsh does not stray too far from philosophies that have always 
worked well for him when he faced troubled airlines. 
“Ireland has a small open economy so there are always going to be challenges. But the pace of growth was good 
this year and last year, and we have to continue to focus on that. The debt is being managed downwards and is 
ahead of target. The measures that were taken were tough and unpopular but I can’t see that there was any 
alternative. I think there is an appropriate rebalancing at the moment but that rebalancing can’t put at risk what 
recovery we have seen, and everybody wants to see that recovery expand beyond the areas that have felt it. 
“They want to see it go beyond Dublin and there is evidence that is happening, although not at a pace that 
everybody would like to see. When you travel to Dublin you can feel it. The restaurants are busy, the pubs are busy, 
the taxis are busy. Business people are more optimistic and employment opportunities continue to improve. But that 
hasn’t been felt nationally. I have a place in Tipperary and I spend a bit of time there. If I drive into Portumna there 
are still a lot of shops and pubs that are closed and haven’t felt the recovery that is in Dublin. But it is getting better 
and I hope that continues.” 
Of course, a huge airline group with an Irish subsidiary could play a big role in bringing growth to Ireland’s regions 
with new routes and expanded capacity. Is there potential for IAG and Aer Lingus to expand at Cork and Shannon? 
Willie Walsh: Captain’s log, one year on...
“Yes, there is. I’ve always been optimistic about Cork. It surprised me that Cork had seen its traffic numbers 
weaken the way it had but we’ve put capacity in there and we are putting capacity into Shannon. But we’ve got to 
be realistic. I think people who believe that you put airlines into a market when the demand doesn’t exist. . . that 
doesn’t happen. There has to be underlying demand. There has to be business demand. 
“There has to be support in the local economy. It’s not good enough that you have politicians saying that it should 
happen. That’s not going to deliver results and companies are not going to put expensive assets into markets 
unless they can see a return. And I make no apologies for that. We have to see a return on the investments that we 
make. If the support is there we will put capacity in and if it is not then we won’t. It’s as simple as that.” 
The company is putting capacity into Dublin because it sees a lot of demand there that is generated by its growing 
status as a hub for transfer traffic. 
“That leads to an improvement in connectivity and increase in schedules and frequencies that have a very 
significant positive effect on the local community. But Shannon and Cork are not hubs and won’t be,” Walsh says. 
“They serve point to point markets and there is strong demand for those markets but we will only serve them where 
the demand exists and we are not going to put more capacity than is justified by the underlying demand.” 
Walsh’s assessment is cold and logical as ever. But it’s hard to resist the feeling that when it comes to Irish matters, 
deep down there is always a hint of emotion.

Trade disputes and the industrial relations landscape
Trade disputes and the industrial relations landscape
Sunday Business Post
August 7, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 788 words
Byline: Nuala Clayton
Highlight: Employment matters
Body
Employers that do not engage in collective bargaining may be brought before the Labour Court for the investigation 
of a trade dispute. 
The Industrial Relations (Amendment) Act 2001 put in place a mechanism whereby the Labour Court can consider 
trade disputes (concerning the terms and conditions of workers), and make initial recommendations, followed by 
legally binding determinations, resulting from this consideration. 
Where a trade dispute has been referred to the Labour Court, an employer may seek to put forward an argument 
that the Labour Court has no jurisdiction to investigate the dispute. 
This typically arises in circumstances where an employer can show that, while it does not engage in collective 
bargaining with a trade union, it does so with a non-unionised excepted body of workers. 
The 2001 act was expected to have significant implications for non-unionised employers. 
However, in the 2007 case of Ryanair Ltd v the Labour Court (2007), the Supreme Court was satisfied that 
negotiations between Ryanair and staff groups which were not trade unions did amount to collective bargaining for 
the purposes of the 2001 act. 
It followed that the Labour Court did not have jurisdiction to deal with the dispute. This judgment altered the 
interpretation of the ambit of the 2001 act to such an extent that the referral of trade disputes was effectively set at 
naught for a prolonged period of time. 
Broad interpretation
Just over a year ago, on August 1, 2015, the Industrial Relations (Amendment) Act 2015 amended the 2001 act 
mechanism by seeking to enhance the rights of workers. 
Trade disputes and the industrial relations landscape
The introduction of new definitions of collective bargaining and excepted body created greater scope for disputes to 
be referred to the Labour Court for the first time since Ryanair. 
The broadening of the interpretation of the 2001 act mechanism was welcomed by trade unions and employee 
bodies alike. 
One year on, the Labour Court has made only one recommendation under the amended regime, in the recent case 
of Freshways Food Company and Siptu. 
The Freshways trade dispute
The dispute related to rates of pay and conditions of employment for Siptu members employed as general 
operatives in Freshways (a sandwich preparation and distribution business), which Siptu contended were less 
favourable than comparable workers in similar employment. 
Freshways does not recognise Siptu or any other trade union for the purposes of collective bargaining. However, 
the company submitted that it already engaged in collective bargaining with its staff representative group (the SRG) 
as an excepted body. 
Freshways put forward a 2.5 per cent pay rise agreed with the SRG in 2015, in an attempt to demonstrate that 
collective bargaining was taking place. 
The Labour Court examined the SRG and this argument in light of the new definitions of collective bargaining and 
excepted body. 
In determining that it did have requisite jurisdiction to investigate the dispute, the Labour Court decided that, even if 
it could be shown that the SRG negotiated with Freshways, the fact that it did so not only in respect of its own 
members, but also other employees, meant that it did not fall within the definition of an excepted body under the 
2015 act. 
The Labour Court was not satisfied that the one ad hoc example of a pay rise in 2015 demonstrated that 
“negotiation” was taking place nor did it amount to a “practice” of collective bargaining in line with the statutory 
definition. 
Recommendations by the Labour Court
In summary, the Labour Court recommended improvements to the workers’ terms and conditions to include three 
incremental pay increases by January 2018, enhanced paid sick leave and an additional day of annual leave for 
workers with more than five years’ service. 
A disciplinary and grievance procedure was also recommended, allowing for trade union representation, as was a 
mechanism for the referral of disputes to the appropriate service of the Workplace Relations Commission and/or the 
Labour Court. 
Implications for employers
The recommendation has significant implications for employers which do not engage in collective bargaining. Even 
where an employer already has a staff body with whom it engages in respect of terms and conditions of 
employment, it appears this may not be sufficient to meet the statutory definitions. 
The case is certainly indicative of the manner in which the Labour Court is likely to consider the common 
preliminary argument as to whether it has jurisdiction to investigate a dispute. 
One year on, while Freshways is the only recommendation made under the amended 2001 act regime, the stage 
has been set for more to follow. 
Trade disputes and the industrial relations landscape
Nuala Clayton is an associate in the employment and benefits department of William Fry
Load-Date: August 8, 2016
End of Document

Easyjet passenger tally jumps to 7.5m in July despite cancellations
Easyjet passenger tally jumps to 7.5m in July despite cancellations
City A.M.
August 5, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 152 words
Byline: OLIVER GILL
Body
EASYJET increased the number of passengers carried in July by nearly seven per cent compared to July 2015.
That figure put it behind growth of 12 per cent revealed by rival Ryanair this week, but load factors were 
comparable. The Luton-based airline filled 95.8 per cent of flights, an increase of 1.5 per cent on July 2015.
It carried a total of 7.5m passengers in the month but was blighted by the ongoing industrial action that has also 
impacted its rivals.
There were a total of 350 cancellations during the month and while this was comparable to 2015 - when there were 
318 cancelled - the majority of them (285 in total) were a result of fires at Rome's Fiumicino airport.
The airline's share price has lost over a third of its value since the referendum on Britain's membership of the EU.
It has previously highlighted a decline of economic and consumer confidence which created a "difficult" trading 
environment.

Carolyn McCall has a way to go to catch Ryanair's 11m passenger tally
Easyjet passenger tally jumps to 7.5m in July despite cancellations

Record month for Ryanair in July
Record month for Ryanair in July
Business World (Digest)
August 04, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 97 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair have today announced that traffic grew 12% to 11.3m customers in July. 
This means Ryanair is the first airline in the world to carry over 11m international passengers in one month, with a 
load factor of 96%.  
Ryanair’s Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said, "These record passenger figures were delivered at lower 
fares, and thanks to the continuing success of our “Always Getting Better” programme which continues to win new 
customers and new markets, despite yet more French ATC strikes and continuing post-Brexit market uncertainty."
Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair unveils Olympic return with its July passenger numbers
Ryanair unveils Olympic return with its July passenger numbers
City A.M.
August 4, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 104 words
Byline: OLIVER GILL
Body
NOT TO be overshadowed by the feats of sporting prowess at the forthcoming Rio Olympics, Ryanair said it had 
broken the world record for the most passengers carried by an airline during one month.
"July was a record month for Ryanair as our traffic grew by 12 per cent to 11.3m customers and we became the first 
airline in the world to carry over 11m international passengers in one month, with a load factor of 96 per cent," said 
Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs.
Load factors were 96 per cent, but Liberum said it may be a high-water mark. "Load factors are reaching their upper 
limit, [and are] likely to stabilise in the coming months."

Ryanair predicts Max 200 will be 'game-changer'
Ryanair predicts Max 200 will be 'game-changer'
Flight International
August 2, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 214 words
Body
Introduction to service of the Boeing 737 Max 200 will be a “game-changer” for Ryanair, the budget airline’s finance 
chief Neil Sorahan argues.
Speaking after the carrier released its first-quarter earnings on 25 July, Sorahan highlighted the aircraft as a key 
part of a “relentless focus on cost” at Ryanair.
“In 2019, we start to take delivery of the Boeing 737 Max 200 aircraft, or ‘The Game Changer’ as we’ve christened it 
at Ryanair, because we think it’s the next step up in the evolution of costs in Ryanair,” Sorahan says.
The airline has 100 of the jets on firm order, plus 100 options, Flight Fleets Analyzer shows.
Aside from a 16% improvement in fuel efficiency over Ryanair’s current fleet of 737-800s, the Max 200, a variant of 
the Max 8, will carry more passengers – 197 versus 189 – without incurring additional cabin costs, says Sorahan.
“This aircraft has 4%, or eight, more seats than the current 737. We get those seats without any additional cost in 
the cabin – we have a cabin crew member for every 50 passengers,” he notes.
Ryanair currently has 353 in-service 737-800s, Flight Fleets Analyzer indicates, with 115 outstanding firm orders for 
that variant, on top of its orders for the 737 Max.
New variant will carry more passengers than current narrowbodies
AirTeamImages
Load-Date: August 4, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair says business model can withstand recent headwinds
Ryanair says business model can withstand recent headwinds
Sunday Business Post
July 31, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 492 words
Byline: Fearghal O’Connor
Highlight: Airline expects to capture up to 23 per cent of the market within eight years
Body
Ryanair remains on target to carry almost a quarter of all European short haul passengers despite the challenges of 
Brexit and terrorism, according to the airline’s chief financial officer.
Ryanair expects to capture up to 23 per cent of the market within eight years, up from its current 15 per cent market 
share, said Neil Sorohan. The company’s share price was hit hard following the Brexit vote and seat sales have 
also been hit after each of the recent terrorist incidents, Sorohan acknowledged. 
“These incidents are very much a headwind for ourselves and other airlines,” he said. “We would notice in the 
immediate aftermath of any of those tragic events that bookings do tend to trail off a little bit. 
“We will typically stimulate the market with lower fares as we have always done, whether it is a volcano, Sars, foot 
and mouth or the terror events we are seeing this year.”
The airline reduced its fares overall by 10 per cent in the quarter to the end of June and is targeting a 6 per cent 
reduction in the current  quarter.
“Business still has to be done and people still want to travel, especially if you give them good value,” said Sorohan. 
“So, no, I don’t think the model is under threat. The plan is to grow to 180 million passengers by March 2024 and 
we have absolutely no plans to delay or defer any of our aircraft orders. 
“If anything, if we got an opportunity to pick up a couple more we probably would.” 
Ryanair is targeting 10 per cent growth this year to 117 million passengers, down from whopping growth of 18 per 
cent last year, although Sorohan acknowledged headwinds, not least in Britain, where it currently earns 28 per cent 
of its revenue.
Ryanair says business model can withstand recent headwinds
“Sterling volatility is the immediate issue,” he said. “However, we hear people like Mark Carney from the Bank of 
England saying there will be a recession in Britain by the end of the year.  
“All of these comments and statements will have an impact on consumer sentiment, confidence and potentially on 
growth. But this is where the strength of our model lies in that we have the lowest cost base of any airline out there. 
We can stimulate the market with our low costs and hit our targets.”
However, the Ryanair board is taking no chances and is preparing itself to take further action to bolster the airline’s 
share price if needs be. Last week, it sought, and was granted, permission from shareholders to double the number 
of its own shares it can buy back if it suffers any further market woes. 
Since February, Ryanair has spent €886 million buying its own shares, exhausting the 5 per cent of total shares 
limit agreed by shareholders last September. 
“There is currently no plan for any further buybacks, but the board recognised that we are in volatile markets at the 
moment and said that, rather than waiting until our agm in September, it would be prudent to go out and seek 
approval from shareholders for further buybacks if it’s in the best interest of the company,” said Sorohan.
Load-Date: August 2, 2016
End of Document
Market Talk
Market Talk
Sunday Business Post
July 31, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 768 words
Byline: Ian Guider
Highlight: Does a recently subdued Michael O'Leary know something that we don’t?
Body
Is O’Leary looking at lower profits?
Michael O’Leary is not a man to be cautious in the choice of his words. But there didn’t seem to be much of the 
usual bombastic language out of the Ryanair boss last week when he unveiled the company’s first-quarter profits, 
which came in at a very healthy €256 million. 
The word Brexit was mentioned no fewer than six times in the company’s statement. Later, during a call with 
analysts, O’Leary was downbeat as he told them that “there is a real risk to the downside in the second half of the 
year”. What’s bugging him and his airline? 
Ryanair’s stock has been hammered, in common with that of all airlines, since the Brexit result. There was almost a 
sense that it wanted to issue a profit warning last week. Is the outlook for Europe’s biggest airline – due to carry 117 
million passengers this year – really that bad? 
There will certainly be an inevitable slowdown in the British economy in the wake of Brexit. 
The signs are there already. The immediate effect will be on the spending power of tourists who have already 
booked their holidays and find that the value of the pound has been eroded since the vote. The long-term 
implications for travel won’t be known until the shape of Brexit emerges over the next couple of years. 
If there is a hard exit that results in Britain being ejected from Europe’s ‘open skies’ deal, the immediate effect will 
probably be the end of Ryanair’s three domestic British routes – out of a total of 1,800. Ryanair’s growth from British 
airports will also surely be curtailed, although its reliance on the market has eased, as it has expanded at a 
ferocious pace since the EU opened up its borders in 2004. 
Perhaps the bigger picture from Ryanair last week was that European travel has not so much been disrupted by 
Brexit, but by other events also outside its control. 
Market Talk
The two biggest problems facing not just Ryanair, but all airlines, are the ongoing spate of horrific terrorist attacks in 
Europe and the seemingly never-ending air traffic control strikes in France. 
It’s difficult to gauge how tourists will respond to the terror attacks on Brussels Airport earlier this year and, more 
recently, the horrific scenes in France and Germany. Ryanair said its bookings were currently ahead of this time last 
year by a small margin, but will travellers eventually change their behaviour and become more careful about going 
abroad? 
And those strikes by French air traffic control are really proving costly. Not only were 1,000 flights cancelled, but the 
cost is two-fold: accommodating passengers under the EU’s 261 directive and also putting them on rescheduled 
flights where it would normally charge late-booking passengers who pay more. 
In the past, Ryanair has been a dab hand at playing down prospects and then over-delivering. This time, it seems 
different. A €1.4 billion profit in the current financial year is not too shabby, and hardly a reason for O’Leary to be 
downbeat. 
Or does the airline chief, one of the longest-serving in the business, see trouble ahead for the industry? 
Yellen peril as Fed faces rate dilemma
Janet Yellen, chair of the US Federal Reserve, has more or less been told that should Donald Trump be elected 
president in November, her services will no longer be required at the US’s central bank. 
That probably won’t come to pass, and the steadying hand she has had on the US and global economies is 
probably needed now more than ever. 
Last Wednesday, the Fed said that the near-term risks to the US economy had diminished, and that there was a 
possibility of raising interest rates at one of its three remaining meetings this year, maybe as soon as September. 
The US economy has recovered, no doubt, but can it withstand another rate rise? Last year, when Yellen first tried 
to move on rates, she was put off by a tantrum in the stock markets. 
When rates did rise in December 2015, the reaction was actually quite relaxed. That was in a pre-Brexit world. The 
outlook for the US economy might be okay, but can the same be really said for the rest of the world? 
Britain, despite last week’s decent second-quarter GDP figures, is almost certainly heading into recession. The 
eurozone is, as ever, dependent on Mario Draghi keeping quantitative easing going. Yellen has always been 
cautious about the reverberations of the Fed decisions, but it looks as though there will be a divergence between 
what the Fed does and what the rest of the world does, for the first time since 2008, when everyone moved in 
tandem. On top of all the uncertainties that the global economy faces, this is not what’s needed right now. 
Load-Date: August 2, 2016
End of Document

IAG profits soar but Walsh foresees weaker times Airlines
IAG profits soar but Walsh foresees weaker times; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
July 30, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 18
Length: 421 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Unit revenues dip but low fuel prices and Aer Lingus deal help to boost results
Body
International Airlines Group, the owner of British Airways and Iberia, yesterday revealed a sharp fall in unit 
revenues and warned of uncertainties after the Brexit vote and operating disruption.
Passenger revenue per available seat kilometre for the first half - an important operating metric - fell 7.2 per cent 
against the first half of 2015, to EUR6.67. Non-fuel unit costs per available seat kilometre held steady at EUR5.33. 
The company said it was cutting planned capacity expansion for the second half of the year.
However, the continued effect of low fuel prices, contributions from the acquisition last August of Ireland's Aer 
Lingus and a EUR65m boost from exceptional items helped the group to record net profits up 67 per cent to 
EUR554m. Revenue rose 4.1 per cent to EUR10.8bn. The figures were in line with analysts' forecasts.
In the second quarter, operating profits before exceptional items were EUR555m, up from EUR530m for the same 
period of 2015. Without Aer Lingus, the figure would have been EUR487m.
Willie Walsh, chief executive, said that the figures represented "another strong performance" for the quarter, despite 
a negative currency impact - principally because of sterling's weakness - of EUR148m.
"Numerous external factors affected our airlines including the impact of terrorism, uncertainty around the UK's EU 
referendum and Spain's political situation and increased weakness in Latin American economies," Mr Walsh said.
IAG profits soar but Walsh foresees weaker times Airlines
IAG had already warned of a weaker than expected trading environment on June 24, hours after the result of the 
EU referendum, amid the economic uncertainty surrounding the vote. A series of other European airlines have 
detailed the effects of economic uncertainty, air traffic control strikes and terrorism since.
The UK's easyJet and Germany's Lufthansa issued gloomy updates on performance last week.
However, while Ryanair has voiced willingness to engage in a price war to fill its expanding aircraft fleet, IAG said it 
had cut back on its planned capacity expansion to reflect the market slowdown. Mr Walsh said he was "not 
concerned at all" at the prospect of losing market share to undercutting by rivals.
The company's projections for the rest of the year included a warning that it was continuing to experience a "weaker 
trading environment" in its UK point-of-sale business, accounting for about a third of total revenue.
It expected the pound's weakness to hit profits reported in euros and anticipated at least EUR80m in costs in the 
second half from air traffic disruption.
Load-Date: July 29, 2016
End of Document
Malaysia Airlines inks $2.75B deal for 50 Boeing Max jets
Malaysia Airlines inks $2.75B deal for 50 Boeing Max jets
Associated Press Financial Wire
July 27, 2016 Wednesday 9:06 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 365 words
Dateline: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia 
Body
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) - Malaysia Airlines said Wednesday it has agreed to buy up to 50 Boeing Max 
planes in a deal worth $2.75 billion as part of its fleet renewal and said it hopes to relist on the stock exchange by 
2019.
The airline's new CEO, Peter Bellew, said the deal included 25 firm orders, worth $2.75 billion, and the right to 
purchase another 25 jets, with deliveries to start in 2019. Airlines usually get a discount from aircraft list prices.
It marked the first major purchase after the ailing national carrier was taken private after years of financial losses 
and further hit by two air disasters in 2014 - the disappearance of Flight 370 and the loss of another plane shot 
down over Ukraine.
The airline is undergoing a $1.56 billion overhaul that included cutting 6,000 jobs and axing unprofitable routes.
Bellew, Ryanair's former director of flight operations, took over July 1 from Christoph Mueller, a turnaround veteran 
who recently resigned abruptly due to personal reasons.
Part of the management team under Mueller, who was hired last year, Bellew said the carrier is on track to become 
profitable by 2018 and that it aims to relist on the local bourse by March 2019.
The new 737 Max jets will be a "game changer" for the airline with sharply lower costs and greater efficiency, 
cutting fuel cost as much as 15 percent, he said.
The planes will be used for routes to growth markets in China, India, Pakistan and South Korea, and their purchase 
will be financed using loans and internal funds.
Bellew said the deal will not affect the turnaround program and that it made more economic sense to buy rather 
than lease the planes.
"We will have a lot more to do in the next five quarters to make sure the airline gets back on track but we are there 
at the moment," Bellew said,
Malaysia Airlines inks $2.75B deal for 50 Boeing Max jets
"Malaysia Airlines is now on a path to growth across the ASEAN region. This new aircraft order will set the stage for 
our continued recovery and success into the next decade," he added.
Late last week, officials of the three countries searching for the disappeared Flight 370 aircraft said the operation 
will be suspended once the current search area in the Indian Ocean has been completely scoured.
Load-Date: July 28, 2016
End of Document
Provident rebounds from referendum low after boost to profits London
Provident rebounds from referendum low after boost to profits; London
Financial Times (London, England)
July 27, 2016 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS & INVESTING; Pg. 19
Length: 446 words
Byline: Thomas Hale
Body
Provident Financial was the largest riser on the FTSE 100 yesterday as the non-standard lender continued its 
post-Brexit rebound.
The stock added 5.7 per cent to close at £27.48, after its first-half results showed a boost to adjusted pre-tax profits. 
The company tumbled by a quarter after the referendum, but is now within 6 per cent of its price before the vote. "In 
the financials universe, considering results and the upbeat outlook, and the relatively defensive nature . . . it 
definitely gives people that cause for optimism," said Justin Bates, an analyst at Liberum.
Virgin Money was one of the biggest risers on the FTSE 250 after it reported a rise in underlying profits before tax 
in the first half. The stock rose 8.7 per cent to close at 266p. But it is still down more than 27 per cent since the 
referendum.
"Since the vote to leave the EU we have experienced continued strong customer demand and no evidence of 
changes in customer behaviour," chief executive Jayne-Anne Gadhia said.
Barratt Developments lost 3.3 per cent to close at 405.3p, amid a broader drop in housebuilders' share prices 
following the Brexit fallout.
Analysts at Deutsche Bank cut their price target for Barratt from 667p to 575p. The bank also cut the price targets of 
several other housebuilders.
Provident rebounds from referendum low after boost to profits London
"Reflecting Brexit, with the overarching caveat of an unusually high degree of uncertainty, we have rebased 
forecasts for the housebuilders to reflect a possible moderate downside scenario," Deutsche analysts wrote. They 
added that government policy, such as the Help to Buy equity loan programme, could provide the sector with 
potential upside.
Taylor Wimpey lost 2.8 per cent to close at 144.9p. Crest Nicholson fell 1.3 per cent to close down at 401.6p.
EasyJet was a significant faller on the FTSE 100 amid further warnings of the company's exposure to Brexit risk.
The stock lost 3 per cent to close at 989.5p, and hit its lowest level in more than three years. It is now trading at 35 
per cent below its level before the June 23 vote. Goldman Sachs cut its price target from 1310p to 1280p.
A report from Fitch, the rating agency, identified EasyJet, along with Ryanair and British Airways, as the most 
exposed European airlines following the referendum.
"Slower UK economic growth, lower consumer confidence and a weaker pound are likely to result in slower growth 
in passenger traffic, while uncertainty about the UK's access to the European single aviation market adds longer-
term risks," the agency said.
ITV was another of the biggest losers on the FTSE 100 yesterday. It dropped 2.3 per cent to close at 184.8p. 
Analysts at Kepler Cheuvreux cut the broadcaster's target price from 225p to 185p.
Load-Date: July 26, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair to move/cancel Rome Ciampino flights for two weeks in October 2016
Ryanair to move/cancel Rome Ciampino flights for two weeks in October 
2016
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 27, 2016 Wednesday 3:34 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 125 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced that it will move/cancel its Rome Ciampino flights due to a two-week runway 
closure in October 2016.
Body
The majority of Ryanair flights from 14th to 29th October inclusive will operate to/from Rome Fiumicino Airport, 
while a number of flights have regrettably been cancelled. All affected customers have been notified by email. 
Ryanair advises all those travelling to/from Rome during this two-week period to log on to the Ryanair.com website 
for the latest travel information and rebooking options. Ryanair's Robin Kiely said: "Rome Ciampino Airport will 
close for runway maintenance for a two week period in October, meaning the majority of our Ciampino flights will 
move to Rome Fiumicino, with a number unfortunately cancelled. All affected customers been notified by email and 
we sincerely apologise to all customers affected by this runway closure."

Top stories

fears about the UK’s decision to leave the EU.

in Britain.

the star of the 1990s dotcom boom.

upward revision in earnings forecasts.

Ryanair Q1 profit increases
Ryanair Q1 profit increases
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 26, 2016 Tuesday 9:50 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 201 words
Highlight: Ryanair has reported that profit attributable to the equity holders of the parent for the first quarter ended 
June 30, 2016 was E255.5 million, or 19.90 cents per diluted share, compared to E245.1 million, or 17.81 cents per 
diluted share, for the same quarter ended June 30, 2015.
Body
Total operating revenues for the first quarter ended June 30, 2016 were E1.69 billion, compared to E1.65 billion for 
the same quarter ended June 30, 2015. Operating profit for the first quarter ended June 30, 2016 was E306.8 
million, compared to E288.4 million for the same quarter ended June 30, 2015. Profit before tax for the first quarter 
ended June 30, 2016 was E286.5 million, compared to E277.8 million for the same quarter ended June 30, 2015. 
Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said: "This modest 4% increase in Q1 profit to E256m is in line with previous guidance. 
The absence of Easter in Q1 and on-going market volatility arising from terrorist events, and repeated ATC strikes 
(particularly in France) weakened fares on close-in bookings and caused almost 1,000 flight cancellations. 
We remain committed to our load factor active/yield passive strategy which is why Q1 fares fell 10% to under E40. 
Traffic rose 11% and load factor improved 2 points to 94% as our Always Getting Better ("AGB") customer 
experience programme continues to win new customers and new markets. Ancillary sales rose to 26% of revenues 
(24% in PY Q1). Cost control remains core which is why unit costs reduced 9% (ex-fuel down 4%).
Load-Date: August 1, 2016

Ryanair warns it is ready to launch a price war Airlines: Brexit fallout
Ryanair warns it is ready to launch a price war; Airlines: Brexit fallout
Financial Times (London, England)
July 26, 2016 Tuesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 15
Length: 689 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Carrier to push ahead with expansion as it shifts focus from UK to mainland Europe
Body
Ryanair yesterday signalled its willingness to take on rivals in a price war, even as the low-cost airline warned of the 
"downside" risks from the UK's Brexit vote and laid out plans to cut back in the UK.
Neil Sorahan , chief financial officer of Europe's biggest low-cost airline by revenues, dismissed the idea that the 
group should cut back on expansion and signalled the company's willingness to keep aircraft full even at much 
lower fares.
The comments could signal trouble for rivals such as easyJet, the UK-based low-cost carrier, Germany's Lufthansa 
and International Airlines Group, which all have higher cost bases than Ryanair, which is based in Dublin. Ryanair 
projected that its average fares, which were down 10 per cent year-on-year in the April to June quarter, would fall a 
further 6 per cent in the current quarter.
Mr Sorahan was speaking as Ryanair announced post-tax profits for April to June, the first quarter of its financial 
year, in line with most analysts' expectations at EUR256m. The figure, 4 per cent up on the same quarter last year, 
reflected the effects of terrorist incidents and air traffic control disruptions during the quarter. Revenues rose 2 per 
cent to EUR1.69bn.
Ryanair warns it is ready to launch a price war Airlines: Brexit fallout
Ryanair's figures follow warnings last week from both easyJet, its UK-based low-cost rival, and from Germany's 
Lufthansa about the impact of the Brexit uncertainty, recent terrorist attacks and severe air traffic disruption on 
profitability.
Ryanair maintained its forecast for post-tax profits for the year to March 2017 to rise around 12 per cent to a range 
of EUR1.37bn to EUR1.42bn, although it warned of "significant risks to the downside".
"If you have the lowest costs and a pretty strong balance sheet, like we do, it's pretty compelling," Mr Sorahan said 
of the arguments for continuing to seek growth.
He pointed out that in 2005, the last time Ryanair significantly expanded its fleet, the company had "stimulated the 
market" with fares as low as EUR1 to bring passengers into its then-network, chiefly between secondary airports.
"Now we're in so many primary airports, we're getting loads of opportunities to grow, so it's easier to stimulate the 
market and convince people they want to travel," he said.
Ryanair's shares closed 6.3 per cent up at EUR11.59 in Dublin yesterday. The company underlined its 
determination to take market share when it announced as part of the results that it expected full-year passenger 
traffic of 117m, 10 per cent up on the last financial year. The figure is 1m higher than the last announced projection.
Michael O'Leary , chief executive, said Ryanair would open 133 new routes for the winter 2016 timetable. 
Nevertheless, he sounded far less positive about the UK, where Ryanair has its biggest single base at London 
Stansted.
Mr O'Leary predicted a "considerable period of political and economic uncertainty in both the UK and the EU" in the 
aftermath of the Brexit vote.
"This uncertainty will be damaging to economic growth and consumer confidence," he said.
The company would focus its growth efforts on other parts of Europe in light of the Brexit vote, he added.
"We will pivot our growth away from UK airports and focus more on growing at our EU airports over the next two 
years," Mr O'Leary said. "This winter we will cut capacity and frequency on many London Stansted routes, although 
no routes will close."
In the longer term, however, there might be opportunities for the airline if UK-registered competitors were no longer 
able to operate intra-EU routes or had to sell stakes in EU-based airlines, Mr O'Leary added.
EasyJet operates a significant number of flights between other EU member states. International Airlines Group, the 
parent of British Airways, owns Spain's Iberia and Vueling and Ireland's Aer Lingus.
The average fare for the quarter was EUR39.92. Unit costs fell 9 per cent including the effects of falling fuel prices 
and 4 per cent excluding fuel.
Ryanair increased the number of passengers it carried during the quarter by 11 per cent to 31.2m.
Thanks to the effect of share buybacks, earnings per share rose 12 per cent - faster than net profits - to EUR20.01.
See Lex

Ryanair set to pivot growth away from UK
Ryanair set to pivot growth away from UK
City A.M.
July 26, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 5
Length: 123 words
Byline: HAYLEY KIRTON
Body
RYANAIR has confirmed it is shifting its strategy away from the UK in a trading statement yesterday, which also 
revealed a modest boost to profits and revenue.
The company announced profits before tax for the three months to June of (EURO)286.5m (£239m), up three per 
cent on last year's (EURO)277.8m.
Meanwhile, revenue also grew to (EURO)1.7bn, up two per cent on the prior year.
Customers increased 11 per cent, going from 28m to 31.2m as average fares fell 10 per cent to (EURO)39.92 "The 
absence of Easter in quarter one and ongoing market volatility arising from terrorist events, and repeated air traffic 
control strikes weakened fares on close-in bookings and caused almost 1,000 flight cancellations," said Ryanair 
boss Michael O'Leary.

Ryanair : plane sailing
Ryanair: plane sailing
Financial Times (London, England)
July 26, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 14
Length: 147 words
Body
If anyone could use a holiday, it is European airline executives. Terrorist attacks at airports, strikes by continental 
air traffic controllers and the drop in the pound have all damaged the prospects for earnings. Low-cost carriers 
should do best - and Ryanair looks to be seated most comfortably.
For one, Ryanair offers the lowest average fares in Europe, while pushing down costs. In yesterday's first-quarter 
result its fares fell 8 per cent, yet its operating profit margins rose. While rival easyJet plans to add staff in the UK, 
Ryanair will reduce flights there.
In the battle of the skies, only the most profitable will stay aloft. Ryanair (and easyJet) are both expanding their 
fleets. That explains why valuations for European airlines have sunk toward four-year lows. Only Ryanair has 
managed to steadily improve its return on equity (now 34 per cent) throughout. Buckle up.
Load-Date: July 25, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair to shift growth focus from UK following EU exit vote
Ryanair to shift growth focus from UK following EU exit vote
Associated Press Financial Wire
July 25, 2016 Monday 1:54 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 308 words
Byline: By SHAWN POGATCHNIK, Associated Press
Dateline: DUBLIN 
Body
DUBLIN (AP) - Ryanair, Europe's biggest short-haul airline, plans to reduce winter services at its main London hub 
and pursue growth at other bases because of weakened British economic prospects following the country's vote to 
leave the EU.
CEO Michael O'Leary made the announcement Monday as part of Ryanair's first-quarter earnings , which 
underscored the company's unrelenting growth and profit increases.
Ryanair reported a 4 percent rise in net profit to 256 million euros ($233 million) as it carried 31.2 million 
passengers in the April-June period, 11 percent more than a year ago. That was partly achieved by charging fares 
averaging 39.92 euros ($36.35), 10 percent less than in the same period of 2015.
Shares in Ryanair were up 5.7 percent at 11.53 euros ($10.50) on the latest set of expectations-beating figures 
from the Dublin-based carrier.
O'Leary called British voters' June 23 referendum rejection of continued EU membership "a surprise and a 
disappointment" that would undermine consumer demand, including at Ryanair's biggest hub, Stansted Airport, 
northeast of London. He had campaigned for the United Kingdom to remain in the 28-nation bloc.
He said Ryanair might benefit competitively in the medium term if the U.K. does quit the EU, because this might 
force British-registered competitors such as easyJet to withdraw from intra-EU routes, while Irish-registered Ryanair 
would face potential regulatory challenges only to its internal British services. The Republic of Ireland remains firmly 
committed to EU membership.
"In the meantime, we will pivot our growth away from U.K. airports and focus more on growing at our EU airports 
over the next two years," he said.
Ryanair left unaltered its full-year forecast of a 12 percent profit gain of around 1.4 billion euros ($1.28 billion).

Ryanair to shift growth focus from UK following EU exit vote

Ryanair stays on track for record profit, but Brexit risks linger
Ryanair stays on track for record profit, but Brexit risks linger
Business World (Digest)
July 25, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 424 words
Byline: Sim Pinder
Body
Budget carrier Ryanair Holdings PLC said it remains on track for its highest-ever profit this year despite Britain's 
vote to leave the European Union, but warned it may yet have to review guidance since Brexit had created huge 
uncertainty.
Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary said in an online presentation to investors on Monday that there remains a 
very real risk that profit guidance will be cut later in the year, but he "did not see the evidence to justify" a cut right 
now.
On Monday Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers reiterated a forecast made before the June 23 Brexit 
referendum that profit after tax would grow 13 percent in the year to end-March 2017 to between 1.38 billion euros 
($1.51 billion) and 1.43 billion euros.
"I don't think any other airline in Europe will be delivering or forecasting that kind of profit growth, but all of the 
clouds on the horizon suggest there are significant risks to the downside in the second half of the year," O'Leary 
said.
Rival easyJet PLC last week said it was unable to give an earnings forecast in the aftermath of Brexit, a deadly 
attack in Nice and an attempted coup in Turkey, while Germany's Lufthansa warned on profit.
O'Leary said in a statement Ryanair would offset the impact of a fall in the value of sterling since the Brexit vote by 
shifting some capacity away from Britain starting this winter.
He warned the company faced further disruption if Britain failed to secure access to Europe's Open Skies 
agreement, but that these risks would be manageable.
Ryanair stays on track for record profit, but Brexit risks linger
Ryanair flies 40 million of its 100 million-plus passengers a year to and from Britain and has its largest hub at 
London's Stansted Airport.
The carrier said a combination of Brexit, militant attacks in Europe and air traffic control strikes had hit average 
fares, which would fall by an average of 8 percent in the six months to September compared with an earlier forecast 
of a fall of up to 7 percent.
It maintained its forecast of a fall in fares of between 10 percent and 12 percent in the winter months, compared 
with a year ago, but lower fares will increase passenger numbers to 117 million from an earlier forecast of 116 
million.
Ryanair's share price hit an all-time high in January as a drive to boost customer service levels helped it to increase 
passenger numbers by more than a third in three years.
But it has fallen 20 percent since the Brexit vote amid concerns it would face a triple whammy of weaker sterling, a 
British recession and increased regulatory hurdles. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: July 25, 2016
End of Document
European Shares Rise Ahead Of Central Bank Meetings
European Shares Rise Ahead Of Central Bank Meetings
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 25, 2016 Monday 12:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 489 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European stocks rose on Monday as low-cost airline Ryanair posted a slight increase in 
first-quarter net profit and William Hill said it received a 'highly preliminary' approach from 888 Holdings and Rank 
Group regarding a potential combination.  Better-than-expected German business sentiment data and a 
communique issued by the G20 ministers pledging to boost sluggish global growth also underpinned investor 
sentiment.   The IFO Institute's German business climate index came in at 108.3, down from 108.7 the previous 
month but comfortably above the expected score of 107.5.  The U.S. Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan are 
set to meet later this week amid hopes that policymakers will sound dovish enough to help limit the economic fallout 
from Britain's shock vote to leave the European Union. 
 The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was up 0.6 percent in midday trading after closing 0.1 percent lower on 
Friday. The German DAX was rallying 0.9 percent and France's CAC 40 index was rising 0.6 percent while the 
U.K.'s FTSE 100 was marginally higher in choppy trade.  Dutch consumer electronics giant Philips Electronics 
gained over 2 percent after backing its FY16 outlook.  Julius Baer Group climbed 4 percent after the Swiss private 
banking group reported an increase in its first-half profit.  Swedish mobile telecoms gear maker Ericsson AB rallied 
3 percent as its chief executive Hans Vestberg stepped down with immediate effect after more than six years at the 
helm.  French household equipment manufacturer SEB sored more than 6 percent in Paris after saying it expects to 
achieve an organic sales growth above 5 percent and an increase in operating result from activity above 10 percent 
in 2016.  L'Oreal gained 1 percent. The cosmetics company has agreed to buy IT Cosmetics, one of the fastest 
growing prestige beauty brands in the United States, for a cash purchase price of $1.2 billion.  LafargeHolcim rose 
1.2 percent. The cement giant has signed a pact with Siam City Cement Public Company Limited for the divestment 
of its interest in Holcim Lanka for an enterprise value of $400 million.  Air France KLM fell almost 3 percent as its 
cabin crew unions prepare to begin a seven-day walkout this week.  Casino operator Rank Group rose half a 
percent and online gambling operator 888 Holdings rallied 3 percent in London while ailing bookmaker William Hill 
soared 7 percent.   Ryanair Holdings climbed 6 percent after reiterating its fiscal 2017 profit forecast.  Aberdeen 
Asset Management advanced 2.5 percent after releasing its trading update for the nine months to June 30.  Banks 
traded mostly lower, with Barclays losing over 1 percent, Lloyds Banking Group declining 1.5 percent and the Royal 
European Shares Rise Ahead Of Central Bank Meetings
Bank of Scotland Group moving down half a percent.   Gold miner Fresnillo lost 1.5 percent and Randgold 
Resources retreated 2.5 percent as gold extended losses on a firmer dollar.      
Load-Date: July 25, 2016
End of Document

July 25, 2016 Monday 12:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 236 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares fluctuated in a narrow range on Monday, as losses among gold miners and 
banking stocks offset increased activity in midcap stocks after William Hill said it received a 'highly preliminary' 
approach from 888 Holdings and Rank Group regarding a potential combination.   Better-than-expected German 
business sentiment data helped underpin investor sentiment as investors brace for key central bank meetings this 
week in the U.S. and Japan. 
  The IFO Institute's business climate index came in at 108.3, down from 108.7 the previous month but comfortably 
above the expected score of 107.5.  The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 10 points or 0.16 percent at 6,741 in midday 
trading after gaining half a percent on Friday.  Casino operator Rank Group rose half a percent and online gambling 
operator 888 Holdings rallied 3 percent while ailing bookmaker William Hill soared 7 percent.   Ryanair Holdings 
climbed 6 percent after reiterating its fiscal 2017 profit forecast.  Aberdeen Asset Management advanced 2.5 
percent after releasing its trading update for the nine months to June 30.  Banks traded mostly lower, with Barclays 
losing over 1 percent, Lloyds Banking Group declining 1.5 percent and the Royal Bank of Scotland Group moving 
down half a percent.   Gold miner Fresnillo lost 1.5 percent and Randgold Resources retreated 2.5 percent as gold 
extended losses on a firmer dollar.
