European Markets Finished Mixed After Early Gains Eroded
European Markets Finished Mixed After Early Gains Eroded
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 25, 2016 Monday 6:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 686 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - The European markets ended the first session of the new trading week with mixed 
results. The markets got off to a positive start Monday following the release of the better than expected German 
business sentiment report. However, the markets pared their gains in the afternoon.   The late reversal was partly 
due to the pullback in crude oil prices. 
Weakness in metal prices also weighed on mining stocks, while financial stocks also struggled. Investors were also 
in a cautious mood ahead of this week's policy meetings for both the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve.   The 
pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index dipped 0.01 percent. The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip stocks 
increased 0.03 percent, while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major U.K. companies, lost 0.29 
percent.  The DAX of Germany climbed 0.50 percent and the CAC 40 of France rose 0.16 percent. The FTSE 100 
of the U.K. declined 0.30 percent, but the SMI of Switzerland finished higher by 0.00 percent.  In Paris, household 
equipment manufacturer SEB soared 7.07 percent after saying it expects to achieve an organic sales growth above 
5 percent and an increase in operating result from activity above 10 percent in 2016.  LVMH increased 1.51 
percent, after it sold Donna Karan International Inc. to U.S. company G-III Apparel Group for $650 million.  L'Oreal 
gained 0.37 percent. The cosmetics company has agreed to buy IT Cosmetics, one of the fastest growing prestige 
beauty brands in the United States, for a cash purchase price of $1.2 billion.  LafargeHolcim rose 0.35 percent. The 
cement giant has signed a pact with Siam City Cement Public Company Limited for the divestment of its interest in 
Holcim Lanka for an enterprise value of $400 million.  Air France KLM fell 2.32 percent as its cabin crew unions 
prepare to begin a seven-day walkout this week.  In London, casino operator Rank Group dipped 0.51 percent and 
online gambling operator 888 Holdings gained 3.38 percent, while ailing bookmaker William Hill soared 4.85 
percent. William Hill said it received a 'highly preliminary' approach from 888 Holdings and Rank Group regarding a 
potential combination.  Ryanair Holdings surged 6.33 percent after reiterating its fiscal 2017 profit forecast.  
Aberdeen Asset Management advanced 0.60 percent after releasing its trading update for the nine months to June 
30.  Consumer electronics giant Philips Electronics gained 2.10 percent in Amsterdam after backing its FY16 
outlook.  Julius Baer Group climbed 2.91 percent in Zurich after the private banking group reported an increase in 
its first-half profit.  Mobile telecoms gear maker Ericsson AB rallied 3.45 percent in Stockholm as its chief executive 
Hans Vestberg stepped down with immediate effect after more than six years at the helm.  Germany's business 
European Markets Finished Mixed After Early Gains Eroded
sentiment weakened in July as the 'Brexit' vote made businesses less optimistic about their future. Nonetheless, 
they assessed a slight improvement in the current situation. The business climate index fell less-than-expected to 
108.3 in July from 108.7 in June, survey results from the Munich-based Ifo economic institute showed Monday. The 
expected score was 107.5.  U.K. industrial orders declined further in July, the Industrial Trends Survey from the 
Confederation of British Industry showed Monday. The total order books balance dropped to -4 percent in July from 
-2 percent in June. The export order books declined notably to -22 percent from -14 percent in the prior month.  
British business confidence plunged to its lowest level in seven-and-a-half years, after the surprise 'Brexit' vote, 
survey results from the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) showed Monday.  The quarterly CBI Industrial 
Trends survey showed that 52 percent of firms were less optimistic about the general business situation than three 
months ago, while 5 percent said they were more optimistic, giving a balance of -47.   That was the lowest figure 
since January 2009, when it was -64, the survey said. Optimism about export prospects for the year ahead also fell, 
down to -11.

End of Document
Wall Street Set To Start Data-Heavy Week On Subdued Note
Wall Street Set To Start Data-Heavy Week On Subdued Note
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 25, 2016 Monday 12:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 895 words
Body
       WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - Early indications suggest that Wall Street stocks may open Monday's session on a 
slightly positive note, even as the averages trade either at record high or near highs. Asian stocks ended on a 
lackluster note, while as stocks opened in Europe, some encouragement came from positive earnings from 
companies such as Philips and Ryanair and a German business sentiment reading. Commodities are weaker but 
the dollar is mixed. The domestic markets could react to the direction of commodity prices, some earnings news 
flow and M&A news if any. 
 As of 6:15 am ET, the Dow futures are adding 5 points and the S&P 500 futures are gaining 0.25 point while the 
Nasdaq 100 futures are moving down 2.25 points.  U.S. stocks extended the gains in the week ended July 22nd, 
rising for four straight weeks, as earnings optimism helped to overcome valuation concerns and fears concerning 
the economic uncertainty.  Housing, consumer, durable goods orders and GDP data along with the FOMC meeting 
are likely to headline the economic events of the week. The 2-day FOMC meeting that begins on Tuesday, the 
advance second quarter GDP data due on Friday, the Commerce Department's new home sales report for June 
scheduled to be released on Tuesday and the Commerce Department's durable goods orders report set to be 
released on Wednesday are among the closely focused reports/events of the week.  Traders may also sift through 
the jobless claims report, the National Association of Realtors' pending home sales index for June, the results of 
MNI's Chicago business barometer survey for July, some Fed speeches, the Conference Board's consumer 
confidence index for July, final estimate of the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for July. The 
results of some regional manufacturing surveys, the results of S&P/Case-Shiller house price survey for May and the 
results of the Treasury auctions of 2-year, 5-year and 7-year notes round up the economic events of the week.  The 
Dallas Federal Reserve is scheduled to release its regional general activity index for July at 10:30 am ET. 
Economists expect the index to improve to -12 from -18.3 in June.  The Treasury is set to announce the results of 
its auction of 2-year notes at 1 pm ET.  Reports suggest that Yahoo (YHOO) may be close to announcing a deal to 
sell its core search assets to Verizon (VZ).  Liberty Interactive (LVNTA, LVNTA) announced that it has completed 
the spin-off of its subsidiary CommerceHub and accordingly Liberty and CommerceHub will trade as separate 
public companies, with the latter trading under the symbol CHUBB on July 25th, 2016 on the OTC Markets.  Crane 
(CR), EverestRe (RE), Express Scripts (ESRX), Gilead Sciences (GILD), J&J Snack Foods (JJSF), Las Vegas 
Wall Street Set To Start Data-Heavy Week On Subdued Note
Sands (LVS), Sanmina (SANM), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Waste Connections (WCN) are among the 
companies due to release their quarterly results after the close of trading.  The major Asian markets ended mixed, 
as the commodity retreat and lackluster risk sentiment weighed on the averages. The Singaporean, Japanese and 
Taiwanese markets retreated, while the rest of the major markets advanced.  The Japanese market ended 
marginally lower, as the yen selling stalled. The Nikkei 225 average ended down 6.96 points or 0.04 percent at 
16,620, dropping for the second straight session. Australia's All Ordinaries hovered in positive territory throughout 
the session, ending up 33.20 points or 0.60 percent at 5,608, its highest level since August 5th, 2015.   China's 
Shanghai Composite ended 3.01 points or 0.10 percent higher at 3,016. Staging a recovery in the final few minutes 
of trading, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed at 21,993, up 29.17 points or 0.13 percent.   On the economic 
front, final estimates released by Japan's Cabinet Office showed that a leading economic indicators index for Japan 
fell in May. The index declined to 99.7 in May from 100 in April, while the flash estimate was at 100. The coincident 
index fell to the lowest reading since August 2013 and the lagging economic indicators index also moved down 2.4 
points to 112.9.  The Ministry of Finance reported that the nation's trade surplus came in more than expected in 
June. The trade surplus came in at 692.84 billion yen in June compared to a deficit of 40.6 billion deficit in May. 
Economists expected a surplus of 474.4 billion yen. Exports fell a less than expected 7.4 percent year-over-year 
and imports slumped 18.8 percent.  European stocks rose notably, as traders digest positive corporate results and 
a German business sentiment reading, which fell less than expected.  In major corporate news, Philips reported 
better than expected earnings for the second quarter, helped by cost savings. The company also expects further 
earnings improvement in the second half of the year. Ryanair reported a modest increase in first quarter profits but 
maintained its forecast for the full year despite the Brexit and terrorist threat overhangs.   On the economic front, the 
results of a survey by IfO showed that German business sentiment weakened in July. The business climate index 
fell 0.4 points to 108.3 in July, while economists expected a worse decline to 107.5. The expectations index 
declined 0.9 points to 102.2 compared to the consensus estimate of 101.1, while the current conditions index rose 
0.7 points to 114.7.

Management Inc.

Body
Jul 25, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Envestnet Asset Management 
Inc. decreased its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 0.1% during the first quarter, Holdings 
Channel[1] reports. The fund owned 49,452 shares of the company's stock after selling 44 shares during the period. 
Envestnet Asset Management Inc.'s holdings in Ryanair Holdings PLC were worth $4,244,000 at the end of the 
most recent reporting period. A number of other large investors have also recently made changes to their positions 
in the company. Bayesian Capital Management LP purchased a new stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
during the first quarter worth about $254,000. Nuveen Asset Management LLC increased its stake in Ryanair 
Holdings PLC by 0.9% in the first quarter. Nuveen Asset Management LLC now owns 7,071 shares of the 
company's stock worth $607,000 after buying an additional 63 shares during the last quarter. Renaissance 
Technologies LLC increased its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 1.5% in the first quarter. Renaissance 
Technologies LLC now owns 3,618,619 shares of the company's stock worth $310,550,000 after buying an 
additional 53,900 shares during the last quarter. HBK Investments L P increased its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC 
by 111.2% in the first quarter. HBK Investments L P now owns 29,973 shares of the company's stock worth 
$2,572,000 after buying an additional 15,780 shares during the last quarter. Finally, Geode Capital Management 
LLC increased its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 5.5% in the first quarter. Geode Capital Management LLC now 
owns 87,630 shares of the company's stock worth $7,520,000 after buying an additional 4,569 shares during the 
last quarter. Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) traded up 1.58% on Monday, reaching $68.78. 
826,241 shares of the company were exchanged. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12-month low of $66.09 and a 12-
month high of $89.67. The stock's 50-day moving average is $75.22 and its 200 day moving average is $80.49. The 
firm has a market capitalization of $18.03 billion and a PE ratio of 10.81. A number of research firms have recently 
weighed in on RYAAY. Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a research 
note on Wednesday, May 25th. Zacks Investment Research upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'hold' 
rating to a 'strong-buy' rating and set a $95.00 price target on the stock in a research note on Saturday, April 16th. 
Macquarie upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from an 'underperform' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a 
research note on Tuesday, July 5th. Finally, Evercore ISI downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' 
rating to a 'hold' rating and set a $90.00 price target on the stock. in a research note on Monday, June 27th. One 
analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, four have issued a hold rating and four have issued a buy rating to the 
company. Ryanair Holdings PLC presently has a consensus rating of 'Hold' and a consensus price target of $92.00. 
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a

low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United

Sensex Breaches 28000; Nifty Hits 52-week High To Close Above 8600
Sensex Breaches 28000; Nifty Hits 52-week High To Close Above 8600
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 25, 2016 Monday 1:28 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 317 words
Body
       NEW DELHI (dpa-AFX) - Indian shares rallied on Monday, with fairly positive global cues and sustained foreign 
fund inflows on optimism over the passage of the GST (Goods and Services Tax) Bill in Parliament's ongoing 
monsoon session underpinning investor sentiment.   The benchmark S&P BSE Sensex climbed 292.10 points or 
1.05 percent to 28,095.34 while the broader CNX Nifty index finished up 94.45 points or 1.11 percent at 8,635.65. 
Banks led gainers, with Yes Bank, ICICI Bank, SBI, Bank of Baroda, Federal Bank and PNB climbing 2-8 percent.   
Kalyani Steels soared 20 percent on reporting a 62 percent jump in quarterly net profit. 
IL&FS Engineering and Construction Company jumped 6 percent on winning the Rs 532.67 crore Nagpur Metro 
Rail Project.  Automaker Maruti Suzuki India rallied 3 percent as the Japanese yen slipped on mounting speculation 
that the Bank of Japan will introduce new economic stimulus at the end of a two-policy meeting that ends July 29.  
ONGC, HPCL, BPCL, Indian Oil, Mangalore Refinery & Petrochemicals and Chennai Petroleum rallied 2-8 percent 
after reports that the Oil Ministry is assessing potential merger of 13 state companies to create a giant corporation.  
Dr Reddy's Laboratories tumbled 3 percent ahead of its June quarter results scheduled for Tuesday. Tata Steel, 
Bajaj Auto and Grasim Industries fell about 1 percent each.   Globally, Asian stocks held somewhat steady, 
although lower commodity prices on a firmer dollar and caution ahead of two key central bank meetings this week 
served to limit the upside across the region.   Underlying sentiment remained supported after G20 finance chiefs 
and central bankers pledged to use all policy tools to boost global economic growth.  European stocks rose in early 
trade as Ryanair maintained its full year profit guidance and a gauge of German business sentiment fell less than 
expected in July.      
Load-Date: July 25, 2016
End of Document

Julius Baer Group climbed 2.91 percent in Zurich after the private banking group reported an increase in its first-half 
profit.
Mobile telecoms gear maker Ericsson AB rallied 3.45 percent in Stockholm as its chief executive Hans Vestberg 
stepped down with immediate effect after more than six years at the helm.
Germany's business sentiment weakened in July as the 'Brexit' vote made businesses less optimistic about their 
future. Nonetheless, they assessed a slight improvement in the current situation. The business climate index fell 
less-than-expected to 108.3 in July from 108.7 in June, survey results from the Munich-based Ifo economic institute 
showed Monday. The expected score was 107.5.
U.K. industrial orders declined further in July, the Industrial Trends Survey from the Confederation of British Industry 
showed Monday. The total order books balance dropped to -4 percent in July from -2 percent in June. The export 
order books declined notably to -22 percent from -14 percent in the prior month.
British business confidence plunged to its lowest level in seven-and-a-half years, after the surprise "Brexit" vote, 
survey results from the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) showed Monday.
The quarterly CBI Industrial Trends survey showed that 52 percent of firms were less optimistic about the general 
business situation than three months ago, while 5 percent said they were more optimistic, giving a balance of -47.
That was the lowest figure since January 2009, when it was -64, the survey said. Optimism about export prospects 
for the year ahead also fell, down to -11.

Wall Street Set To Start Data-Heavy Week On Subdued Note
Wall Street Set To Start Data-Heavy Week On Subdued Note
RTT News (United States)
July 25, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 903 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Early indications suggest that Wall Street stocks may open Monday's session on a slightly positive 
note, even as the averages trade either at record high or near highs. Asian stocks ended on a lackluster note, while 
as stocks opened in Europe, some encouragement came from positive earnings from companies such as Philips 
and Ryanair and a German business sentiment reading. Commodities are weaker but the dollar is mixed. The 
domestic markets could react to the direction of commodity prices, some earnings news flow and M&A news if any.
As of 6:15 am ET, the Dow futures are adding 5 points and the S&P 500 futures are gaining 0.25 point while the 
Nasdaq 100 futures are moving down 2.25 points.
U.S. stocks extended the gains in the week ended July 22nd, rising for four straight weeks, as earnings optimism 
helped to overcome valuation concerns and fears concerning the economic uncertainty.
Housing, consumer, durable goods orders and GDP data along with the FOMC meeting are likely to headline the 
economic events of the week. The 2-day FOMC meeting that begins on Tuesday, the advance second quarter GDP 
data due on Friday, the Commerce Department's new home sales report for June scheduled to be released on 
Tuesday and the Commerce Department's durable goods orders report set to be released on Wednesday are 
among the closely focused reports/events of the week.
Traders may also sift through the jobless claims report, the National Association of Realtors' pending home sales 
index for June, the results of MNI's Chicago business barometer survey for July, some Fed speeches, the 
Conference Board's consumer confidence index for July, final estimate of the University of Michigan's consumer 
sentiment index for July. The results of some regional manufacturing surveys, the results of S&P/Case-Shiller 
house price survey for May and the results of the Treasury auctions of 2-year, 5-year and 7-year notes round up the 
economic events of the week.
The Dallas Federal Reserve is scheduled to release its regional general activity index for July at 10:30 am ET. 
Economists expect the index to improve to -12 from -18.3 in June.
The Treasury is set to announce the results of its auction of 2-year notes at 1 pm ET.
Reports suggest that Yahoo (YHOO) may be close to announcing a deal to sell its core search assets to Verizon 
(VZ).
Wall Street Set To Start Data-Heavy Week On Subdued Note
Liberty Interactive (LVNTA, LVNTA) announced that it has completed the spin-off of its subsidiary CommerceHub 
and accordingly Liberty and CommerceHub will trade as separate public companies, with the latter trading under 
the symbol CHUBB on July 25th, 2016 on the OTC Markets.
Crane (CR), EverestRe (RE), Express Scripts (ESRX), Gilead Sciences (GILD), J&J Snack Foods (JJSF), Las 
Vegas Sands (LVS), Sanmina (SANM), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Waste Connections (WCN) are among the 
companies due to release their quarterly results after the close of trading.
The major Asian markets ended mixed, as the commodity retreat and lackluster risk sentiment weighed on the 
averages. The Singaporean, Japanese and Taiwanese markets retreated, while the rest of the major markets 
advanced.
The Japanese market ended marginally lower, as the yen selling stalled. The Nikkei 225 average ended down 6.96 
points or 0.04 percent at 16,620, dropping for the second straight session. Australia's All Ordinaries hovered in 
positive territory throughout the session, ending up 33.20 points or 0.60 percent at 5,608, its highest level since 
August 5th, 2015.
China's Shanghai Composite ended 3.01 points or 0.10 percent higher at 3,016. Staging a recovery in the final few 
minutes of trading, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed at 21,993, up 29.17 points or 0.13 percent. On the 
economic front, final estimates released by Japan's Cabinet Office showed that a leading economic indicators index 
for Japan fell in May. The index declined to 99.7 in May from 100 in April, while the flash estimate was at 100. The 
coincident index fell to the lowest reading since August 2013 and the lagging economic indicators index also moved 
down 2.4 points to 112.9.
The Ministry of Finance reported that the nation's trade surplus came in more than expected in June. The trade 
surplus came in at 692.84 billion yen in June compared to a deficit of 40.6 billion deficit in May. Economists 
expected a surplus of 474.4 billion yen. Exports fell a less than expected 7.4 percent year-over-year and imports 
slumped 18.8 percent.
European stocks rose notably, as traders digest positive corporate results and a German business sentiment 
reading, which fell less than expected.
In major corporate news, Philips reported better than expected earnings for the second quarter, helped by cost 
savings. The company also expects further earnings improvement in the second half of the year. Ryanair reported a 
modest increase in first quarter profits but maintained its forecast for the full year despite the Brexit and terrorist 
threat overhangs. On the economic front, the results of a survey by IfO showed that German business sentiment 
weakened in July. The business climate index fell 0.4 points to 108.3 in July, while economists expected a worse 
decline to 107.5. The expectations index declined 0.9 points to 102.2 compared to the consensus estimate of 101.1, 
while the current conditions index rose 0.7 points to 114.7.

Ryanair says Brexit may affect profit forecasts
Ryanair says Brexit may affect profit forecasts
Sunday Business Post
July 25, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 371 words
Byline: Bloomberg News
Highlight: Airline sticks to guidance, but expects bigger drop in fares
Body
Ryanair has warned that it may lower its profit forecast for the current financial year amid weakening travel demand 
stemming from Britain’s decision to exit the European Union.
The uncertainty surrounding economic growth and consumer confidence following the Brexit vote will lead to further 
fare declines in the second quarter with the company now predicting an 8 per cent drop in fares in the six months to 
the end of September, compared with an earlier forecast of a decline of 5 per cent to 7 per cent. While Ryanair 
stuck to a target for net profit for the year to the end of March 2017 to rise to between €1.38 billion and €1.43 billion, 
the company said there were risks to the forecast.
“This time I don’t see too many risks to the upside, I only see risks to the downside,” chief financial officer Neil 
Sorahan said in an interview. “We’ll stimulate the demand if we have to to get the passengers on the planes,” he 
said, adding that a one pence decline in sterling against the euro translates into a drop of €8m off the budget 
airline's after-tax profit.
Net profit in the three months ended June 30 increased 4.5 per cent to €256m, Ryanair said in a statement this 
morning. An 11 per cent jump in passengers helped offset a 10 per cent decline in ticket prices in its first financial 
quarter.
Europe’s 
biggest 
discount 
airline 
is 
expecting 
profit 
growth 
rates 
to 
slow, 
following 
http://www.businesspost.ie/ryanair-full-year-profit-rises-by-43-to-e1-2-billion/, as terrorist attacks in Europe depress 
demand for leisure travel. Fares were already falling as low fuel prices encouraged airlines to add flights to seek 
market share, while tour operators shifted planes to European routes from destinations seen as at risk of terrorism, 
including Egypt and Turkey.
The carrier, which had http://www.businesspost.ie/ryanair-calls-for-yes-vote-in-brexit-referendum/ for Britain to stay 
in the trading bloc, will continue with plans to expand its growth on mainland European routes while cutting back on
Ryanair says Brexit may affect profit forecasts
frequencies flying out of its London Stansted base. Ryanair has previously said it will reallocate 50 planes due for 
delivery this year to bases outside Britain to offset an anticipated decline in demand from British travellers.

Sensex Breaches 28000; Nifty Hits 52-week High To Close Above 8600
Sensex Breaches 28000; Nifty Hits 52-week High To Close Above 8600
RTT News (United States)
July 25, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 327 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Indian shares rallied on Monday, with fairly positive global cues and sustained foreign fund inflows on 
optimism over the passage of the GST (Goods and Services Tax) Bill in Parliament's ongoing monsoon session 
underpinning investor sentiment.
The benchmark S&P BSE Sensex climbed 292.10 points or 1.05 percent to 28,095.34 while the broader CNX Nifty 
index finished up 94.45 points or 1.11 percent at 8,635.65. Banks led gainers, with Yes Bank, ICICI Bank, SBI, 
Bank of Baroda, Federal Bank and PNB climbing 2-8 percent.
Kalyani Steels soared 20 percent on reporting a 62 percent jump in quarterly net profit. IL&FS Engineering and 
Construction Company jumped 6 percent on winning the Rs 532.67 crore Nagpur Metro Rail Project.
Automaker Maruti Suzuki India rallied 3 percent as the Japanese yen slipped on mounting speculation that the 
Bank of Japan will introduce new economic stimulus at the end of a two-policy meeting that ends July 29.
ONGC, HPCL, BPCL, Indian Oil, Mangalore Refinery & Petrochemicals and Chennai Petroleum rallied 2-8 percent 
after reports that the Oil Ministry is assessing potential merger of 13 state companies to create a giant corporation.
Dr Reddy's Laboratories tumbled 3 percent ahead of its June quarter results scheduled for Tuesday. Tata Steel, 
Bajaj Auto and Grasim Industries fell about 1 percent each.
Globally, Asian stocks held somewhat steady, although lower commodity prices on a firmer dollar and caution 
ahead of two key central bank meetings this week served to limit the upside across the region.
Underlying sentiment remained supported after G20 finance chiefs and central bankers pledged to use all policy 
tools to boost global economic growth.
European stocks rose in early trade as Ryanair maintained its full year profit guidance and a gauge of German 
business sentiment fell less than expected in July.

Ryanair Q1 Net Income Rises; Maintains Profit Guidance
Ryanair Q1 Net Income Rises; Maintains Profit Guidance
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 25, 2016 Monday 7:24 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 186 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported that its first-quarter profit to equity holders 
of parent increased year-over-year to 255.5 million euros from 245.1 million euros. Earnings per share in euro cent 
was 19.90 compared to 17.81.  Total operating revenues from continuing operations were up 2% to 1.69 billion 
euros from 1.65 billion euros, prior year. Traffic was up 11% to 31 million.  Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said: 'This 
modest 4% increase in profit is in line with previous guidance. The absence of Easter in Q1 and on-going market 
volatility arising from terrorist events, and repeated ATC strikes (particularly in France) weakened fares on close-in 
bookings and caused almost 1,000 flight cancellations.'  Ryanair maintained its guidance, that full year profits will 
rise by approx. 12% to a range of 1.375 billion to 1.425 billion euros, but cautioned that post Brexit there are 
significant risks to the downside during the remainder of the year. Ryanair now believes its fiscal year traffic will 
grow by 10% to 117 million customers, up 1 million on previous guidance.      
Load-Date: July 25, 2016

Ryanair Q1 Net Income Rises; Maintains Profit Guidance - Quick Facts
Ryanair Q1 Net Income Rises; Maintains Profit Guidance - Quick Facts
RTT News (United States)
July 25, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported that its first-quarter profit to equity holders of parent 
increased year-over-year to 255.5 million euros from 245.1 million euros. Earnings per share in euro cent was 19.90 
compared to 17.81.
Total operating revenues from continuing operations were up 2% to 1.69 billion euros from 1.65 billion euros, prior 
year. Traffic was up 11% to 31 million.
Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said: "This modest 4% increase in profit is in line with previous guidance. The absence 
of Easter in Q1 and on-going market volatility arising from terrorist events, and repeated ATC strikes (particularly in 
France) weakened fares on close-in bookings and caused almost 1,000 flight cancellations."
Ryanair maintained its guidance, that full year profits will rise by approx. 12% to a range of 1.375 billion to 1.425 
billion euros, but cautioned that post Brexit there are significant risks to the downside during the remainder of the 
year. Ryanair now believes its fiscal year traffic will grow by 10% to 117 million customers, up 1 million on previous 
guidance.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com

Oil majors and GDP numbers set to steer markets LONDON REPORT

City A.M.
July 25, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 15
Length: 165 words
Body
MARKETS in the UK and Europe seem to be running out of momentum recently but a influx of earning reports this 
week may go some way to liven things up. The blue-chip FTSE 100 was up 0.5 per cent at 6,730.48 points at its 
close on Friday, its fifth straight week of gains.
The latest GDP numbers from the UK, US and the Eurozone will dominate the agenda however as investors get 
their first peek at growth in the second quarter.
Tomorrow second-quarter results from BP are expected to show cash flow remains under pressure as well as fresh 
restructuring charges. Royal Dutch Shell has a trading statement due out on Thursday.
Lloyds Banking Group is expected to bolster profits when its updates the market with its half-year results on 
Thursday. Barclays posts its halfyear figures on Friday after a better-than-expected results season from its US 
counterparts, but Brexit will remain the dominant issue.
Other data to watch for comes from Ryanair this morning and British Airways owner IAG on Friday.

Jul 23, 2016( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Pictet Asset Management Ltd. 
maintained its position in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) during the first quarter, Holdings 
Channel[1] reports. The fund owned 3,250 shares of the company's stock at the end of the first quarter. 
Pictet Asset Management Ltd.'s holdings in Ryanair Holdings PLC were worth $270,000 as of its most recent SEC 
filing. Several other hedge funds have also added to or reduced their stakes in the stock. IFP Advisors Inc boosted 
its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 2.3% in the first quarter. IFP Advisors Inc now owns 2,896 shares of the 
company's stock worth $249,000 after buying an additional 66 shares during the last quarter. Commonwealth 
Equity Services Inc acquired a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter worth about $298,000. 
Marietta Investment Partners LLC acquired a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter worth 
about $667,000. Pinnacle Associates Ltd. acquired a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the fourth quarter 
worth about $1,643,000. Finally, Stifel Financial Corp boosted its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 30.0% in the 
fourth quarter. Stifel Financial Corp now owns 21,986 shares of the company's stock worth $1,901,000 after buying 
an additional 5,075 shares during the last quarter. Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) traded down 0.03% 
during trading on Friday, reaching $67.71. The company's stock had a trading volume of 414,823 shares. The 
company has a market cap of $17.75 billion and a price-to-earnings ratio of 10.55. The stock's 50 day moving 
average is $75.22 and its 200 day moving average is $80.49. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12 month low of $66.09 
and a 12 month high of $89.67. RYAAY has been the topic of a number of recent research reports. Beaufort 
Securities reiterated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a research note on Wednesday, May 25th. 
Zacks Investment Research upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'hold' rating to a 'strong-buy' rating and set a 
$95.00 target price on the stock in a research note on Saturday, April 16th. Raymond James Financial Inc. 
increased their target price on Ryanair Holdings PLC to $100.00 in a research note on Friday, March 25th. 
Macquarie upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from an 'underperform' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a research note on 
Tuesday, July 5th. Finally, Evercore ISI lowered Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating and set a 
$90.00 target price on the stock. in a research note on Monday, June 27th. One research analyst has rated the 
stock with a sell rating, four have issued a hold rating and four have given a buy rating to the company. The stock 
presently has a consensus rating of 'Hold' and an average price target of $92.00. Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair 
Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger 
airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and 
Morocco. The Company's principal fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. Want to see

on Friday, March 25th. Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a report on 
Tuesday, April 5th. Zacks Investment Research upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'hold' rating to a 'strong-
buy' rating and set a $95.00 price objective for the company in a report on Saturday, April 16th. Evercore ISI 
lowered Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating and set a $90.00 price objective for the company. 
in a report on Monday, June 27th. Finally, Macquarie upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from an 'underperform' rating 
to a 'neutral' rating in a report on Tuesday, July 5th. One research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, four 
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Buys 43,425 Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY)
have issued a hold rating and four have issued a buy rating to the company's stock. The stock presently has a 
consensus rating of 'Hold' and an average price target of $92.00. Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a 
holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving 
short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The 
Company's principal fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. Want to see what other

Ryanair selects QlikTech's in memory business discovery platforms
Ryanair selects QlikTech's in memory business discovery platforms
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 22, 2016 Friday 9:02 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS; Technology & Telecommunications
Length: 373 words
Highlight: QlikTech International AB has announced that Ryanair has selected QlikView and Qlik Sense, a provider 
of in memory business discovery platforms.
Body
Taking pride in offering low-cost flight options, Ryanair is continually improving its customer proposition and with 
Qlik, the Ryanair Business Intelligence team has consolidated data from across the organization to drive insights 
and make business decisions. Shane Finnegan, Senior BI Developer at Ryanair said, "Different audiences wanted 
to consume their data in different ways. We wanted a platform that would allow us to meet these differing needs. 
Qlik offered two complementary products to do just that-QlikView and Qlik Sense. QlikView can be used by staff 
who have in-depth analytical roles, such as for those who work in Finance or Marketing. Qlik Sense has then been 
overlaid on top of this so that staff in more time-sensitive departments-say in Ground Ops or Flight Ops-can get 
quick and easy-to-digest data visualizations, showing instantly what's going on, where there's an issue, quantify the 
issue, and address the issue." In the future, Ryanair hope to use Qlik to continue to improve their in-flight retail 
offering, as well as helping to optimize the supply chain by understanding the anticipated passenger mix on a given 
flight and matching this with an appropriate range of products and sufficient stock for the flight. "With Qlik, we're 
building a complete overview of what's going on across the business and it is playing a major role in the way we are 
evolving the services we offer to customers," continues Finnegan. "Ultimately, we want to find the best ways to 
make our customers happy on-board, while being able to offer them the lowest fares on the market-and Qlik gives 
us the foundation to make educated decisions which will make that notion a reality." Sean Farrington, RVP, 
Northern EMEA at Qlik said, "Ryanair is Europe's most popular airline, helping passengers travel around Europe on 
the lowest fares. We're glad Qlik is helping the airline to improve the services it can offer to its customers while 
driving efficiencies and, ultimately, continuing to offer the best deals on flights. Our technology has been designed 
to get analysis into the hands of all and it's great to hear that staff across the airline are able to interact with data in 
the way that suits them best - that's our value proposition."

which will deliver over 1.7m customers p.a. and support 1,300 jobs at Bristol Airport. This Bristol to Venice Macro

Ryanair launches new Birmingham summer schedule 2017
Ryanair launches new Birmingham summer schedule 2017
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 22, 2016 Friday 12:53 PM GMT

Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has launched its new Birmingham summer schedule 2017, with three new routes to Chania, 
Girona and Reus, two new summer services to Sofia and Warsaw, and more flights to Faro, Gran Canaria, Ibiza, 
Palma and Tenerife, which will deliver almost 2.3 million customers per annum and support 1,700 jobs at 
Birmingham Airport.
Body
Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 28 Birmingham routes in 
summer 2017 and look forward to further improvements, as Ryanair continues its "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. 
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to launch our biggest ever Birmingham 
summer 2017 schedule, 3 months earlier than last year, which includes 3 new routes to Chania, Girona and Reus, 
the continuation of our winter services to Sofia and Warsaw to summer, and more flights to Faro, Gran Canaria, 
Ibiza, Palma and Tenerife, which will deliver almost 2.3m customers p.a. and support 1,700 jobs at Birmingham 
Airport, as we grow our operation by 20%. "To celebrate the launch of our Birmingham summer 2017 schedule, we 
are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European network from just GBP19.99, which are available for 
booking until Monday (25 Jul). Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log 
onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
William Pearson, Aviation Director, Birmingham Airport, said: "We are delighted that Ryanair has launched its 
summer 2017 schedule even earlier this year, giving passengers travelling from Birmingham Airport more choice on 
a total of 28 routes. With three new routes now available for booking, Chania, Girona and Reus, passengers have 
more destinations than ever to choose from when planning their 2017 summer holiday."

Uncertainty drags on airline profits Travel & leisure: Europe
Uncertainty drags on airline profits; Travel & leisure: Europe
Financial Times (London, England)
July 22, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 12
Length: 919 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Carriers' margins knocked by waning consumer confidence, terrorism and weak sterling
Body
Distant rumblings of trouble for Europe's airlines look to be gathering into a full-blown storm after two of the region's 
biggest operators blamed worse than expected financial performances on terror attacks and increased economic 
uncertainty.
Shares in easyJet fell more than 5 per cent yesterday after the UK low-cost carrier's trading update highlighted how 
ticket prices were falling amid waning consumer confidence partly linked to the Brexit referendum .
Germany's Lufthansa late on Wednesday issued a profit warning that it blamed on repeat terror attacks in Europe 
and increased economic and political uncertainty. Its shares fell almost 6 per cent yesterday.
The disappointing performances come ahead of figures on Monday from Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost carrier 
by revenue, which are expected to confirm the aviation industry is entering a descent after several years of steady 
climbing.
"We're at the end of the big bull run for earnings," says Robin Byde, analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald Europe.
The results reflect not only weakening passenger demand - amid expectations of slowing global economic growth - 
but also a loss of industry discipline over fleet capacity, say analysts. Ticket prices are falling partly because airlines 
are pressing ahead with plans for new aircraft and routes, even as demand grows more slowly than anticipated.
Uncertainty drags on airline profits Travel & leisure: Europe
"There's too much capacity," says Mr Byde. "Therefore you're seeing this weaker [average fare] environment."
The question is whether the industry can regain capacity discipline, and better align the introduction of new aircraft 
with growth in demand.
Gerald Khoo, analyst at Liberum, says restraint is vital if the industry is to push returns back to last year's buoyant 
levels. "It needs to regain some discipline on capacity growth," he adds.
But there is no doubt that a series of global events has also caused a serious, unanticipated tailing-off of demand.
International Airlines Group, owner of British Airways and Iberia, issued a profit warning the day after the UK's June 
23 referendum on EU membership, citing weaker than expected trading in the run-up to the poll.
Three days later, easyJet issued a profit warning for the April to June quarter because of several factors including 
air traffic control strikes.
It also highlighted the risk of an economic slowdown after Britain's vote to leave the EU.
The sharp fall in sterling's value since the UK referendum appears to be deterring many British travellers from 
heading overseas for summer holidays.
The truck attack in Nice on July 14 - France's third terror atrocity in 18 months - has also hit demand.
Last weekend's attempted coup in Turkey has created further uncertainty over another popular holiday destination.
The effect has been global. Delta Air Lines of the US announced last week it would cut transatlantic capacity to the 
UK this winter to offset the effect of Brexit uncertainty on demand.
Carolyn McCall , easyJet's chief executive, said yesterday the "economic and operating environment" had been 
"difficult" in the three months to June 30.
"More recently, currency volatility as a result of the UK's referendum decision to leave the EU as well as the recent 
events in Turkey and Nice continue to impact consumer confidence," she added.
Airlines are likely to respond to the problems by, among other things, embarking on cost-cutting.
Lufthansa said it planned to reduce underlying unit costs excluding fuel by 2 to 3 per cent in the second half of 
2016, to tackle an expected 8 to 9 per cent decline in revenues.
However, not all airlines have an incentive to rein in capacity to support ticket prices.
While it could be in the interests of higher-cost flag carriers such as Lufthansa to avoid flooding the market with 
additional aircraft, budget airlines will be more confident that falling prices work to their advantage.
EasyJet expects a year-on-year capacity increase of 6 per cent in the present quarter.
Mr Byde points out that easyJet, Ryanair and other low-cost carriers tend to shape the ticket price environment for 
the whole market.
"Both companies will see this as quite a good opportunity to revert to their good old business model of cutting prices 
and taking market share," he predicts.
Woeful results
Kenya Airways breaks own record
Kenya Airways yesterday highlighted the scale of the turnround task at the company when it broke its own record 
for the country's worst corporate results. The airline reported a net loss of Ks26.2bn ($258m) for 2015-16, up from 
Uncertainty drags on airline profits Travel & leisure: Europe
Ks25.7bn in the previous financial year, as its results were hit by a series of one-off items, including charges linked 
to a poor fuel hedging policy.
Kenya Airways is seeking to recover from a failed expansion strategy, and, in spite of the record-breaking loss, 
analysts drew encouragement from an improvement in the company's underlying performance.
The airline's operating loss narrowed from Ks16.3bn in 2014-15 to Ks4.1bn in 2015-16, and Eric Musau, an analyst 
at Standard Investment Bank, said: "From an operating perspective, I think they're really improving. They're headed 
in the right direction and I don't think they have anything major left to clear."
But shares in Kenya Airways , which has recorded four successive years of losses, fell more than 8 per cent on 
Wednesday to Ks4.35. The stock has dropped 87 per cent in the past five years. Mbuvi Ngunze , chief executive, 
acknowledged that it had been "a very tough year" but highlighted how the airline's revenue had increased 5 per 
cent in 2015-16. John Aglionby
Load-Date: July 21, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair adds more flights for Austrian World Cup qualifier
Ryanair adds more flights for Austrian World Cup qualifier
Business World (Digest)
July 22, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 167 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair has added more World Cup specials from Dublin to Bratislava for Ireland’s 
World Cup 2018 qualifier against Austria in November.   Ryanair has now scheduled 2 special return flights from 
Dublin to Bratislava for Ireland v Austria (12 November) in Vienna, alongside its regular daily Dublin - Bratislava 
service, so even more Irish fans can travel on the lowest fares and start dreaming of Russia 2018.    Ryanair’s 
Robin Kiely commented, "The extra seats we added earlier in July sold out quickly, as support for the Boys in 
Green continues to grow following their exploits at the Euros, and the excitement is building as the World Cup 2018 
campaign takes off."
He added, "We’re pleased to add another extra return flight to Bratislava for Ireland’s away game against Austria on 
12th November, so that more Irish fans can get to the big match all on the lowest fares, which are only available for 
booking on the Ryanair.com website."
Source: www.businessworld.ie

FTSE 100 Falters Ahead Of ECB Decision; Travel Stocks Hit Hard
FTSE 100 Falters Ahead Of ECB Decision; Travel Stocks Hit Hard
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 21, 2016 Thursday 12:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 236 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares fell slightly in lackluster trade on Thursday as investors waited for the 
European Central Bank's first policy meeting after the Brexit vote.   The central bank is widely expected to leave its 
monetary policy unchanged, but investors are watching for signs of future easing in the post-Brexit era. 
 The benchmark FTSE 100 was down 32 points or 0.48 percent at 6,696 in midday trading after gaining half a 
percent on Wednesday.  Sterling turned lower against the dollar after official data showed British retail sales 
declined more than expected in June. Sales volumes fell 0.9 percent from the previous month, marking the biggest 
fall so far this year.  EasyJet shares slumped nearly 7 percent. The low-cost airline reported lower quarterly revenue 
and declined to give guidance on its full-year profits due to uncertainty caused by the EU vote, the recent terror 
attack in Nice and the failed coup in Turkey.  British Airways owner International Consolidated Airlines Group fell 
over 4 percent and Ryanair Holdings lost 4.5 percent while travel service providers TUI and Thomas cook fell over 2 
percent each.  Real estate investment trust Land Securities Group declined 2 percent after warning of subdued 
demand for commercial property.   SABMiller edged up marginally as U.S. antitrust officials approved beer giant AB 
InBev's $108 billion takeover of the London-based rival.      
Load-Date: July 21, 2016
End of Document
European Shares Retreat As Travel Stocks Plunge
European Shares Retreat As Travel Stocks Plunge
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 21, 2016 Thursday 12:41 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 459 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European stocks fell on Thursday, with travel stocks coming under heavy selling 
pressure, after Lufthansa cut its full-year profit target and EasyJet reported a fall in third-quarter revenue.   
Disappointing U.K. retail sales figures and caution ahead of the ECB meeting and President Mario Draghi's press 
conference later in the day also weighed on markets.   Sterling turned lower against the dollar after official data 
showed British retail sales declined more than expected in June. 
Sales volumes fell 0.9 percent from the previous month, marking the biggest fall so far this year.  The European 
Central Bank is widely expected to leave its monetary policy unchanged, but investors are watching for signs of 
future easing in the post-Brexit era.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was down 0.4 percent in midday 
trading after rising 1 percent in the previous session in response to a slew of positive earnings reports.  The 
German DAX, France's CAC 40 index and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 were down between 0.2 percent and 0.4 percent.   
EasyJet shares slumped nearly 7 percent in London. The low-cost airline reported lower quarterly revenue and 
declined to give guidance on its full-year profits due to uncertainty caused by the EU vote, the recent terror attack in 
Nice and the failed coup in Turkey.  British Airways owner International Consolidated Airlines Group fell over 4 
percent and Ryanair Holdings lost 4.5 percent while travel service providers TUI and Thomas cook fell over 2 
percent each.  Deutsche Lufthansa plunged more than 7 percent in Frankfurt after cutting its 2016 profit forecast 
due to repeated terrorist attacks in continental Europe.  Automaker Daimler rose over 1 percent on reporting a 7 
percent rise in second-quarter net income and reaffirming its full-year outlook.  Advertising and communications 
company Publicis Groupe rallied 4 percent in Paris on posting a 0.9 percent increase in second-quarter revenue on 
a reported basis.  Real estate investment trust Land Securities Group declined 2.5 percent after warning of subdued 
demand for commercial property.   SABMiller edged up marginally as U.S. antitrust officials approved beer giant AB 
InBev's $108 billion takeover of the London-based rival.  Swiss engineering firm ABB rose almost 2 percent after its 
quarterly operational earnings before interest, taxes and amortization beat analysts' estimates.  Actelion 
Pharmaceuticals gained 1 percent. The Swiss biotechnology firm raised its annual core profit guidance after 
delivering a strong performance in the first half.  Unilever rose half a percent. The Anglo-Dutch consumer products 
giant left its full-year target unchanged after reporting a 2 percent increase in first-half profit.      
European Shares Retreat As Travel Stocks Plunge
Load-Date: July 21, 2016
End of Document

MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 21, 2016 Thursday 2:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 258 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has launched its Newcastle summer schedule 2017, with three new routes to Faro, Girona 
and Palma, five new summer services to Gdansk, Lanzarote, Tenerife, Warsaw and Wroclaw, and more flights to 
Alicante, Dublin and Malaga, which will deliver 750,000 customers per annum and support 560 jobs at Newcastle 
Airport.
Body
Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 11 Newcastle routes in 
summer 2017 and look forward to further improvements, as Ryanair continues its "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. In 
Newcastle, Ryanair's Head of Communications, Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch our biggest ever 
Newcastle summer 2017 schedule, 3 months earlier than last year, which includes 3 new routes to Faro, Girona 
and Palma, the continuation of our winter services to Gdansk, Lanzarote, Tenerife, Warsaw and Wroclaw to 
summer, and more flights to Alicante, Dublin and Malaga, which will deliver 750,000 customers p.a. and support 
560 jobs at Newcastle Airport, as we significantly grow our Newcastle operation. "To celebrate the launch of our 
Newcastle summer 2017 schedule, we are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European network from just 
GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Thursday (21 Jul). Since these amazing low prices will be snapped 
up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
John Irving, Business Development Director at Newcastle International Airport, said: "We are delighted to see 
Ryanair continue to expand their offering from Newcastle. The new routes to Faro, Girona and Palma increases the 
choice of flight options to these popular destinations from Newcastle and we expect these flights to be well received 
by the North East travelling public."

to Girona, four new summer services to Bratislava, Gran Canaria, Vilnius and Warsaw, and more flights to Alicante,

In Leeds, Ryanair's Head of Communications, Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch our biggest ever Leeds 
Bradford summer 2017 schedule, 3 months earlier than last year, which includes a new route to Girona, the

Alicante, Faro, Ibiza, Krakow, Lanzarote, Palma and Tenerife, which will deliver 1.3m customers p.a. and support 
975 jobs at Leeds Bradford Airport, as we grow our operation by over 20%. "To celebrate the launch of our Leeds 
Bradford summer 2017 schedule, we are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European network from just 
GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Thursday (21 Jul). Since these amazing low prices will be snapped 
up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Tony Hallwood, Aviation 
Development Director at Leeds Bradford Airport said: "We are thrilled that Ryanair are significantly increasing their 
capacity from Leeds Bradford in summer 2017, offering their widest ever low cost flight choice from Yorkshire's 
gateway airport. 
With 5 new routes, including 3 to European capital cities, Ryanair's expanded flying programme of 25 routes will 
deliver wider business destination choice and encourage a growth in inbound tourism to Yorkshire, while increasing 
the choice for leisure and city breaks for our region's holidaymakers. "This substantial growth is fantastic news for 
our regional economy and highlights the continued growth and strength of the Leeds City Region alongside 
supporting the creation of new jobs across Yorkshire. We look forward to welcoming a 20% growth in the number of 
passengers flying from Leeds Bradford with Ryanair next summer who can now increasingly fly from closer to 
home."

The Bilderberg boys: O’Leary invited Noonan to secret summit
The Bilderberg boys: O’Leary invited Noonan to secret summit
Sunday Business Post
July 17, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 472 words
Byline: Hugh O’Connell
Highlight: Conference frequently attracts criticism for its secretive nature.
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary was responsible for inviting Finance Minister Michael Noonan to the 
secretive Bilderberg conference in Germany, it has emerged. 
Noonan and O’Leary both attended the annual gathering of the world’s political and business elite in Dresden last 
June. 
The conference, which was founded in 1954, is aimed at fostering dialogue between Europe and North America, 
but frequently attracts criticism for its secretive nature. There is no agenda, no minutes are taken, no report issued 
and no journalists are allowed at the event.  
O’Leary wrote to Noonan on March 24 last, saying that “for my sins I am now the Irish member of the Bilderberg 
Steering Committee which allows me to invite two guests of Irish nationality” to the meetings.  
In the letter obtained under the Freedom of Information Act, O’Leary informed Noonan that attendees are a “very 
senior list” of European and US politicians and business leaders.  
Discussions over three days are subject to Chatham House rules, a rule where information disclosed at a meeting 
can be reported but the source may not be identified.  
Attendees must be present for the entire conference, the letter said. O’Leary also informed Noonan that he was not 
allowed to bring personal or security staff or family members. In conclusion, the airline boss said: “I think you will 
find it a stimulating weekend.”  
A further invitation was issued by the Bilderberg secretariat on April 14 with a follow-up on May 6, the day the 
government was formed.  
The Bilderberg boys: O’Leary invited Noonan to secret summit
Noonan was not in a position to accept the invitation until May 12, after the formation of the Fine Gael-led minority 
government.  
The total cost of the trip to Bilderberg for Noonan and his private secretary Justin Nolan was €2,673, including 
Noonan’s €1,434 stay at the Hotel Taschenbergpalais Kempinski, where the conference was taking place.  
A spokesperson for Noonan said the minister was invited in his capacity as Minister for Finance and that it was 
normal for the department to cover the minister’s costs unless he is on personal business.  
Correspondence released under the Freedom of Information Act also showed that several members of the public 
wrote to Noonan querying in what capacity he was attending the summit.  
Some objected strenuously to his attendance. Independent TD Tommy Broughan also wrote to Noonan asking if he 
would report to the Dáil on his three days at Bilderberg.  
There was no response to the emails from Noonan’s office.  
But in response to a parliamentary question last month, the minister said that at the meeting, he set out to 
attendees the “opportunities that exist in Ireland for investors and multinational companies”.  
“A number of the business attendees represented companies which have very significant investments in Ireland that 
support thousands of Irish jobs,” he said.
Load-Date: July 18, 2016
End of Document

Irish consumer spending rises 6.1% in June Irish consumer ...
Irish consumer spending rises 6.1% in June; Irish consumer ...
Business World (Digest)
July 12, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 345 words
Highlight: Irish household expenditure across all payment types (cash, cheques and electronic payments) was up 
+6.1% year-on-year in June according to Visa's latest Irish Consumer Spending Index.
Body
Irish household expenditure across all payment types (cash, cheques and electronic payments) was up +6.1% 
year-on-year in June according to Visa's latest Irish Consumer Spending Index.
The data shows that the pace of growth slowed slightly compared to previous months (+9.2% in May and +9.6% in 
April) but was still slightly faster than the average for the series which began in September 2014.
The increase in spending was driven by a range of factors, including increased demand with travel agents and 
airlines, as well as a rise in car sales.
During June, the Irish Travel Agents Association reported that 50% of their members had experienced an increase 
in bookings for summer 2016, which helped boost the Recreation & Culture sector, with spending up +13.9% year-
on-year. Furthermore, increases in direct bookings with airlines and new car sales in June also led to the Transport 
& Communication, recording a double-digit increase (+11.0%) in expenditure. The success of Ireland's football team 
saw a number of airlinesput on extra flights during the month, with airlines like Ryanair reportingan increase in 
passenger traffic during June. The Society of the Irish Motor Industry also reporteda 12% increase in new car sales 
during the month during the same period. Spending via eCommerce was up +15.3% year-on-year in June, while 
Face-to-Face growth only rose +2.0% year-on-year, the weakest rise in spending on the high street since 
December 2014. A slowdown in expenditure was also recorded at Clothing & Footwear stores, with spending up 
just +0.3% year-on-year. This was the weakest rise in the current 20-month sequence of expansion. Ireland 
Country Manager at Visa, Philip Konopik says, "Irish consumer spending remains buoyant, with expenditure during 
the second quarter of 2016 +8.3% higher compared to the same period in 2015." He added, "While every sector 
benefited from the increase in spending, there was a marked contrast between the monitored categories with only 
two sectors recording double digit growth during the month." Source: www.businessworld.ie

to Alicante (5 weekly), Krakow (4 weekly), Lanzarote (3 weekly) & Tenerife (3 weekly); 15 routes in total; and 51 
weekly flights. Ryanair is the ideal choice for both business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 15 
Leeds Bradford routes in winter 2016 and look forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting 
Better" programme, which includes more new routes, Business plus and Leisure Plus fares, new digital features, 
new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to launch 2 more new 
routes from Leeds Bradford to Bratislava and Vilnius, as part of our winter 2016 schedule, which will deliver 1.1

services will be popular with both leisure and business customers and we look forward to continuing to grow both 
traffic and jobs at Leeds Bradford Airport.

Ryanair to add two new routes to Alicante and Malaga
Ryanair to add two new routes to Alicante and Malaga
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 11, 2016 Monday 12:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 364 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced two new Aberdeen routes to Alicante and Malaga starting in February 2017, 
which will deliver 50,000 customers per annum at Aberdeen International airport.
Body
These new Aberdeen routes are ideal for leisure customers who can now enjoy the benefits of Ryanair's "Always 
Getting Better" programme, which includes new digital features, new cabin interiors, new Leisure Plus and 
improved Business Plus services, and even more low fares. In Aberdeen, Ryanair's Head of Communications, 
Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to announce our return to Aberdeen as we launch two new routes to Alicante 
and Malaga, beginning in February and operating twice weekly, which will help deliver 50,000 annual customers at 
Aberdeen Airport. We look forward to working closely with the team at Aberdeen Airport to deliver more routes, 
traffic and growth in the future. 
"While these routes are ideal for holidaymakers, APD remains a continuing barrier to inbound tourism and the 
development of business routes in Scotland. One need only look at the example of Ireland which saw its annual 
traffic fall by 7m following the introduction of APD in 2009, only to dramatically rise following its removal in 2014. 
Ryanair has already confirmed to the Scottish Government the growth opportunities possible if APD is removed in 
its entirety. "Seats on our new Aberdeen routes to Alicante and Malaga are on sale now from just GBP30.99 for 
travel in February and March, which are available for booking until midnight Thursday (7 July). Since these amazing 
low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
Aberdeen International Airport Managing Director, Carol Benzie, said: "This is fantastic news from Ryanair and it 
clearly demonstrates the opportunity that exists for leisure capacity here in Aberdeen. Earlier this year we 
undertook a leisure survey in which we asked our local community which destinations they would like to see 
introduced from their local airport. Our route development team took the survey results to the recent Routes Europe 
conference in Krakow and Ryanair has responded to this data by introducing services to two of the most requested 
routes, Alicante and Malaga. The twice weekly, year-round services will commence in February 2017 and we look 
forward to welcoming Ryanair back to Aberdeen."
Ryanair to add two new routes to Alicante and Malaga

Aeroflot chief readies airline for take-off Interview: Vitaly Saveliev
Aeroflot chief readies airline for take-off; Interview: Vitaly Saveliev
Financial Times (London, England)
July 11, 2016 Monday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 18
Length: 809 words
Byline: Kathrin Hille in Moscow
Highlight: Cuts to capacity and staff are transforming struggling flag carrier into a modern operator
Body
The chief executive of Aeroflot springs to life when he pulls out his iPad. On the tablet, Vitaly Saveliev can follow 
everything that is happening at the airline at any moment.
"Here's what I see at 7am, here it's updated again at 9am, it shows the accumulated data," he says, pointing to the 
multicoloured, moving charts on his screen. "We see that yesterday we did 613 flights. On the same day in 2009, 
we did 230 flights altogether. How we have grown up, right?"
In the past eight years, Mr Saveliev has transformed Russia's flag carrier from a struggling hulk into a modern 
company on a par with most European peers.
When he joined Aeroflot in April 2009,Russia was in the throes of its last economic crisis. The breakdown of Air 
Union, another Russian airline, stranded hundreds of thousands of passengers. Aeroflot was battling not to have its 
aircraft seized by creditors. The company flew 8.8m passengers a year with 15,000 staff - way above the global 
benchmark of 1,000 staff per 1m passengers.
"This year we will fly 30m passengers," says Mr Saveliev. "So we should today be a company with at least 27,000 
to 28,000 staff, but we have only about 20,000. And that is efficiency". When overhauling the company, Mr Saveliev 
looked at how US airlines had survived the crisis after the September 11 terror attacks - by sharply cutting capacity 
Aeroflot chief readies airline for take-off Interview: Vitaly Saveliev
- and he did the same. The chief executive also cut staff, first in the 2009 crisis and again in 2014, as the fall in oil 
prices and western sanctions started driving Russia into recession.
Last year, Aeroflot reported a Rbs6.5bn net loss as the Russian economy contracted by 3.7 per cent and Russians 
sharply cut overseas travel. However, things are now rebounding.
The company expects a profit this year as its passenger load factor - a measure of capacity - rose in the first 
quarter to 78.5 per cent from 76 per cent, even as Russia's overall aviation market continued to slide.
Mr Saveliev says the board is preparing to change its forecast from the Rbs3.1bn loss it expected in November.
Aeroflot has also made structural changes, using international peers such as Lufthansa, Air France and Alitalia as 
its model.
Since 2011, it has set up a holding structure and within it has established a budget airline, merged a handful of 
different subsidiaries into one called Rossiya, and moved Aeroflot itself, the group's flagship, upmarket.
Pobeda, the group's budget airline, flew 3.1m passengers last year, making it the world's fastest-growing airline, 
and is profitable.
According to Aeroflot, it operates its 12 aircraft 15 hours per 24 hours, a metric higher than UK-listed Ryanair.
Mr Saveliev expects both the budget and the premium segments to grow, while the mid-market segment will 
stagnate or shrink - something he says is a worldwide trend.
"In Europe, it's either budget or business," he says. "But in Russia, the middle class is not fully formed yet."
He wants to use Rossiya to capture the large part of the population that is not ready for flying budget but not 
affluent enough to fly premium, a market he estimates at 7m to 9m passengers a year.
"If the number of passengers in the segment Rossiya is positioned in drops, we will grow the budget airline, and will 
squeeze things a little. If that segment lives on, we will keep Rossiya."
But as a state carrier , Aeroflot does have some constraints. Mr Saveliev says the group is not expanding Pobeda 
as fast as it could due to criticism that Aeroflot might become a monopolist in the Russian market - fears he rejects 
as "seriously exaggerated".
Over the past few months, Aeroflot has hired half of the 11,000 staff of Transaero, its largest privately owned 
competitor in Russia, which went bankrupt last autumn. Aeroflot was forced to fly 1.96m Transaero passengers and 
compensate many more for cancelled flights. This task imposed by the government cost the company Rbs17bn, 
and it was compensated only by the assignment of 34 routes that previously belonged to Transaero.
Analysts say Mr Saveliev should be well placed to balance political demands with commercial ones, as his career 
has straddled government and business.
He has held senior posts at banks such as Rossiya, the lender built by members of president Vladimir Putin's inner 
circle in the 1990s, and Menatep, the bank of then oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky, as well as state gas company 
Gazprom. Mr Saveliev also had a role at the ministry of economy and trade. He joined Aeroflot from AFK Sistema, 
the holding company of oligarch Vladimir Yevtushenkov, where he oversaw telecoms.
This profile has helped Mr Saveliev tackle his job at the airline with a fresh perspective, analysts say.
"Saveliev's government relations, resources and reputation ensured a high level of autonomy for Aeroflot's 
management," says Stanislav Shekshnia, an affiliate professor at Insead, the French business school.
Load-Date: July 10, 2016
Aeroflot chief readies airline for take-off Interview: Vitaly Saveliev
End of Document
