Brexit: The Dickensian repercussions of Britain ’s decision to leave the EU
Brexit: The Dickensian repercussions of Britain’s decision to leave the EU
Sunday Business Post
July 10, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1364 words
Byline: Stephen Kinsella
Highlight: British citizens will soon realise that the Brexit vote was a vote for a smaller, poorer, less influential 
Britain
Body
There’s something Dickensian about the contrasting approaches of the Irish and British governments to the Brexit 
crisis. Remember Dickens’s opening line from A Tale of Two Cities, a collage of stories from London and Paris in 
the 1770s? 
“It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the 
epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of light, it was the season of darkness, it was the 
spring of hope, it was the winter of despair.” 
I can’t stop thinking about this line since I started reading the book to my sons recently. Dickens’s book is really 
about how ordinary things change after an extraordinary event. In his case it’s the French Revolution, which 
overthrew a monarchy to establish a republic. In our case it’s the potential dissolution of the European Union and 
the weakening of one of Ireland’s largest trading partners. Somehow in its universality Dickens’s line speaks to the 
kind of large structural change we’re seeing post-Brexit. 
It was the best of times
The financial markets have been battered since June 24. The Ftse 100 index of very large multinational firms, which 
benefit from the incredibly weak sterling level, is up €30 billion. British exporters have seen huge increases in 
demand for their newly-cheap products. Some currency speculators made out like bandits, and anyone holding gold 
is feeling very smug indeed. Little Englanders and euro-sceptics are triumphant. This is their moment. 
It was the worst of times
The Ftse 250 index has lost €38 billion in value. The Eurostoxx banks index, which tracks the 30 largest banks in 
the eurozone, has lost over €110 billion. 
Brexit: The Dickensian repercussions of Britain ’s decision to leave the EU
Over half of the £25 billion Investment Association property sector has now suspended trading, with five of the 
largest British property funds suspending any redemptions. Companies importing products have been hammered 
and are issuing negative profit guidance, especially airlines such as EasyJet and Ryanair. 
Employers cut almost 800,000 job ads following the result in order to compensate, somehow for austerity. Local 
authorities and city councils across Britain have to prepare to lose large percentages of their budgets, bringing in 
austerity measures for those who need government services the most. 
In England, the EU funds more than £5 billion. In Wales they’ll lose almost £2 billion, and in the North, they’ll lose 
almost £400 million. Scotland will lose over £700 million. Here, Minister for Finance Michael Noonan revised down 
his estimates of Irish GDP growth from 4.3 per cent to 3.4 per cent, and while insisting the figures for Budget 2017 
were sound, he admitted the future of the Irish economy was now more uncertain. 
Ireland’s fortunes depend on the ultimate form the Brexit takes. Whether it’s a Norway-style or a World Trade 
Organisation-style deal matters hugely to us. 
It was the age of wisdom
Bank of England governor Mark Carney earned every penny of his £800,000 salary. Carney has given three major 
briefings since the Brexit result on June 24, each one more commanding than the last. Without a functioning 
government or opposition, the governor is the de facto leader of the British response to Brexit, and even he admits 
pulling the bank’s monetary policy levers will probably not be sufficient to avoid a period of uncertainty and 
recession. 
It was the age of foolishness
Each of the main protagonists of Brexit has now walked off the pitch. Boris Johnson, Michael Gove, David 
Cameron, Nigel Farage. Each of these men has caused his own share of the problems that will afflict Britain, 
Ireland, the EU and the world for decades. Whatever their individual talents, their collective foolishness will not be 
forgotten by history. And history is what they all are. 
It was the epoch of belief
Many Irish commentators are seizing the uncertainty of Brexit as an opportunity for Ireland to increase its flow of 
inward foreign direct investment, especially if Britain gains a Norway-style in/out, free trade agreement. 
This is the positive belief that the potential costs of Brexit in trade are swamped by the potential benefits in 
increased inflows of cash. 
As I wrote last week, I’m not convinced of this case, but I’m willing to keep an open mind. Those 17 million people 
who voted to leave voted for 17 million reasons. 
It’s not for me to try to explain the reasons behind their choices, but it certainly had something to do with a deeply 
held belief in a reassertion of sovereignty. This reassertion may not take place through the Brexit negotiation phase. 
The protracted nature of these negotiations – if they are ever triggered – may give time to let the British people 
understand the benefits of being within a free trade area, while also managing somehow starting to solve the 
problems the referendum result threw up. These problems could have been solved, arguably, by less austerity and 
more capital spending in areas left behind in recent decades, but that won’t be the solution in the future as a 
diminished Britain fights to retain its transfers to its regions. 
It was the epoch of incredulity
Very few people seemed to believe the Irish government’s initial assertion on the morning after the Brexit result that 
everything was going to be grand, and that they had a plan. Yet their plan is reasonably sound, even if their 
Brexit: The Dickensian repercussions of Britain ’s decision to leave the EU
assurances on the state’s finances are highly contingent after 2017. What the Irish government can influence, it will 
influence, but the systems within official Ireland will need to adapt rapidly to whatever trade deal looks like 
emerging. 
Meanwhile, in Britain, the shock at the lack of a plan post-Brexit by the mandarins of the Treasury and the Cabinet 
Office is now subsiding, and all await the results of the Tory leadership election to see which way the plan might be 
developed. No one believes the front-runner for that contest, Theresa May, actually wants Britain to leave the EU, 
despite her campaigning on the result, and their are questions over the CV of Andrea Leadsom, the other 
challenger. 
It was the season of light, it was the season of darkness
The Labour and Conservative parties have collapsed and are fractured by the Brexit result. These two parties have 
monopolised power for 100 years in Britain. That may change now. The post-Brexit results have seen large 
increases in race and religion-related incidents in Britain. The Metropolitan Police has recorded three race hate 
crimes every hour since the referendum result was announced. 
It was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair
The hope is that Britain will negotiate a trade deal that is very similar to the one it already has. The facts are that it 
will take whatever deal a belligerent EU chooses to give it and call that a success. It may be years before we 
understand the true impact of the Brexit vote, but it is a vote for a smaller, poorer, less influential Britain. 
The discussion on soft and hard borders between the Republic and the North of Ireland, not to mention the altered 
relationship between the EU, Ireland and Britain, the failure to launch of the all-island North-South Brexit forum, are 
all causes for despair, after more than 40 years of trying to make the movement of people, goods and services and 
capital as frictionless as possible. 
There is a large contrast between the reactions of the Irish and British governments. Ireland has at least the 
outlines of a plan and is adopting a watching stance, though now everything is contingent on the form of trade deal 
Britain strikes with the EU. Britain has effectively no plan, and the four nations that make up the United Kingdom 
have differing priorities. 
For example, when it really dawns on the farmers of the North that the CAP is going bye-bye, when trucks are 
stopped on their way into Newry, and when the little Englanders’ pet passports aren’t accepted on the way to their 
Spanish holiday homes any more, the realities of the Brexit result will become apparent. 
Dickens’s opening line ends with “we had everything before us, we had nothing before us, we were all going direct 
to Heaven, we were all going direct the other way”. That’s about the sum of where we are with Brexit.
Load-Date: July 11, 2016
End of Document
Rocky road ahead for companies of Ireland Inc
Rocky road ahead for companies of Ireland Inc
Sunday Business Post
July 10, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1287 words
Byline: Barry J Whyte
Highlight: In the aftermath of Brexit, is there a raft of profit warnings on the way?
Body
‘What impact does Brexit have on our business?” DCC chief executive Tommy Breen wondered aloud to this 
newspaper in November of last year. 
“We think probably relatively modest because I’d say that we don’t trade really across borders. I think where we are 
at the moment I don’t think it makes much material impact on our business.” 
So far, Breen’s prediction has been borne out for DCC. 
Josh Puddle, an analyst with Berenberg, said the company – which has risen from £65.50 on the morning of the 
referendum to a two-month high of £66.50 – had proved “very resilient [following Brexit] partly because of the 
company’s continental European earnings. Partly because the main product they’re distributing and selling – oil and 
gas – is pretty resilient”. 
For plenty of other Irish companies, the fallout from Brexit has been decidedly more mixed. Some have seen their 
share prices plummet; some have held up well. What does that mean for the looming earnings season? Are we 
likely to see a raft of profit warnings? 
Gerard Moore, head of equity research at Investec, believes that, overall, Brexit is bad for the Irish economy. “A 
slowdown in Britain will impact trade between the two countries,” which is worth €34 billion annually, making it 
Ireland’s second largest export market. 
According to Moore, there are a number of different layers of impact for Irish companies. “The stocks that have 
fallen the most are those that are exposed to the financials; British construction or construction companies exposed 
to the British economy; companies exposed to British-Irish trade; and then everyone else,” he said. 
Rocky road ahead for companies of Ireland Inc
The companies most at risk of diminished earnings, according to Moore and Investec, are stocks like Ryanair (down 
from €13.68 a share to its current price of just over €11 since Brexit), Grafton (from £7.12 on the day of the 
referendum to £4.60) and Kingspan (down from just over €25 to around €19). 
For all three companies, a slowdown in the British economy will take a chunk out of their sales, with hard-pressed 
consumers likely to fly less, while the construction industry has already begun to slow down. 
The currency volatility will also have an impact. According to Moore and Investec, the companies most likely to be 
hit by the drop in the value of sterling – one of the major symptoms of Brexit – are the likes of Origin, C&C and 
Ryanair, which all have significant exposure to Britain and report in euro. 
The more risk-averse investment environment – for as long as it will persist – will also take a toll, with a greater 
impact on banks like Bank of Ireland and Permanent TSB, both of whom have seen their share prices hit quite 
badly. 
Bank of Ireland is down by nearly 40 per cent because it has more than 40 per cent of its loan book in Britain, while 
PTSB is likely to struggle in its sale of its British mortgage loan book. 
Nevertheless, Robert Eason, head of research with stockbroker Goodbody, echoed the views of many in the market 
in saying that it’s still too early to know just what earnings season will bring, since share price volatility does not 
correlate to profit drops necessarily. 
“It’s your basic 101 course in finance – markets can’t price uncertainty. That’s why it’s finding this whole episode 
difficult,” he said. “Saying that a company with a lot of British revenue, or denominated in sterling, is likely to be 
worst hit – they’re qualitative comments, but putting the quantitative behind that is the hard thing.” 
For Eason, management teams won’t have enough time or information to draw solid conclusions. “We’re still going 
to be in a political vacuum [come earnings season],” he said. “Two more months of data in their underlying 
businesses – is it enough to extrapolate going forward six months? A year? No one knows.” 
Moore agreed that it was unlikely to produce a raft of profit warnings. Several companies in Britain have already 
issued profit warnings, such as estate agent Foxtons, airline EasyJet, and Aer Lingus’s owner IAG. 
Meanwhile, several other companies have begun the process of managing shareholders’ expectations with what 
Moore described as ‘soft’ profit warnings. 
Plenty of companies “when they look at 2017 might be less bullish than they were”, he said. 
“It’s hard to accuse them of having a profit warning, because they haven’t given a profit guidance. But you could 
see consensus numbers move down for 2017.” 
Moreover, some Irish companies might well benefit from Brexit, analysts say. 
“The property companies have performed well with the belief that Ireland might attract more financial services and 
proportionally more FDI,” according to Eason. “In contrast to Hibernia – and Green has been pretty strong too – 
British Reits are down.” 
Moore pointed to “some of the food companies that should also do relatively well. Total Produce is only down 2 per 
cent [while] Kerry is only down 2 per cent”. 
While discretionary spending by consumers was likely to be hit by any British slowdown, he said, “there’s a 
difference between buying food and an extension to your house or a holiday in Spain”. 
Some will benefit from the foreign exchange swing. Companies like DCC and Grafton – the former of which has 
seen its share price rise, the latter of which has seen it plummet – both report in sterling but have significant 
exposure outside Britain, so could get a technical boost to earnings because of the exchange rate. 
Rocky road ahead for companies of Ireland Inc
Other companies are well insulated, despite being in vulnerable sectors. 
According to Christian Hjorth, an equity analyst with Numis in London, construction materials company CRH, for 
example, is one of the companies least impacted by the Brexit referendum in Britain thanks to its diversification into 
the US and EU. 
“The share price is holding up very well. CRH is now on a price-to-earnings ratio for 2017 of about 13 times. You’ve 
got others in the building material space, British focused names, smaller in size, but trading at ten times and below.” 
He agreed, though, that it was difficult to predict more broadly which companies would actually report lower 
earnings on the back of Brexit. 
“It has been a bit of a wait-and-see. It’s hard to get numbers to a particular point,” he said. 
The fallout from Brexit may even see some London-listed companies decide to take up a Dublin listing, a prospect 
that the Irish Stock Exchange could capitalise on, though the “long-term impact of the decision will be largely 
determined by the terms of the British exit”, according to a spokesperson for the Irish Stock Exchange. 
“We will work with the Irish government and other stakeholders to ensure that our competitiveness and our position 
as a gateway to Europe are protected and enhanced,” the spokesperson said. 
The spokesperson acknowledged that Brexit gave rise to “some very serious issues . . . for the British capital 
markets” and that “companies who only have British listings and no EU listings will be constrained in their ability to 
access investors in the EU”. 
Ireland then, becomes a favourable listing venue in the event that the City of London and the Ftse become 
estranged from the EU’s financial markets. 
“The Irish Stock Exchange already facilitates dual listings with London as many companies want both a euro and a 
sterling quote to enable better distribution, so we will be able to assist companies requiring access to the EU, while 
maintaining their London listing, should the need arise.” 
However, with the British government in disarray and Article 50 yet to be triggered to begin a formal withdrawal from 
the EU, Eason said: “No one knows what the outcome will be – that’s the problem we’re facing. 
“There’s a political element to all of this. Britain has decided to get rid of all its leaders, and that puts us in a 
vacuum.”
Load-Date: July 11, 2016
End of Document
Strike chaos sees 1,000 Irish flights cancelled
Strike chaos sees 1,000 Irish flights cancelled
Sunday Business Post
July 10, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 465 words
Byline: Fearghal O’Connor
Highlight: Aer Lingus and Ryanair hit as air traffic controller stoppages in France affect 200 flights this month
Body
More than 1,000 Irish airline flights have been cancelled so far this year because of ongoing air traffic control strikes 
across Europe. 
Aer Lingus and Ryanair have been badly hit because of strike action that disrupted crucial European airspace on 
average every 13 days. 
The latest stoppages by French air traffic controllers last week – the 13th this year – saw a further 200 flights 
cancelled during the busiest month of the year for airlines. 
Since March, strikes in Greece, Italy, Belgium and France have caused over 3,500 cancellations by major 
European airlines, with nearly a third of these cancellations hitting the two major Irish airlines. 
Airlines for Europe (A4E), which represents 11 major airline groups, including Ryanair and Aer Lingus owner IAG, 
published a PwC study that found ATC strikes between 2010 and 2015 resulted in 30,000 cancellations across 
Europe and reduced EU gross domestic product by up to €9.5 billion. “One of the things this study looked at is the 
impact not just on airlines but on other sectors, particularly tourism,” Thomas Reynaert, managing director of A4E, 
told this newspaper. 
“Because of the importance the airline industry plays for connectivity to a city like Dublin, there is an automatic 
impact on the economy. If you decrease mobility, as these strikes do, business meetings have to be cancelled and 
tourists don’t get to their destination.” 
Ryanair boss Michael O’Leary told a recent A4E conference in Brussels that the difficulties for holidaymakers from 
cancelled flights have been exacerbated because flights to popular destinations in the Mediterranean have very 
high load factors this summer. 
This has meant passengers often cannot be accommodated on alternative flights, said O’Leary. 
Strike chaos sees 1,000 Irish flights cancelled
Passengers often have to buy a brand new ticket at a totally different price or must cancel their plans altogether, 
according to Reynaert. 
“So Irish holiday makers’ vacations are spoiled, the southern European tourism staff who are waiting for them to 
arrive at hotels and resorts lose out as well and a lot of tourism business is destroyed,” he said. 
European carriers have long lobbied for the so-called single European sky that would see air traffic control functions 
taken out of the hands of national operators in favour of a transnational system and which would be less prone to 
this type of disruption. 
But Ireland and Britain are two of the few countries to have made significant progress on this. 
“Fragmentation is never good and we would like to see a better functioning single market,” said Reynaert. 
“That is why we are encouraging the European Commission and the member states to continue to implement the 
single European sky. 
“But it would be wrong to comment at this time what the impact of a Brexit might be on that long-term project.”
Load-Date: July 11, 2016
End of Document

Ryanair adds extra flights for Ireland's Austrian World Cup Qualifier; Ryanair 
adds ex...
Business World (Digest)

Highlight: It was announced today that Ryanair havelaunched World Cup specials from Dublin to Bratislava for 
Ireland's World Cup 2018 qualifier against Austria in November, following huge demand from Irish football fans.
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair havelaunched World Cup specials from Dublin to Bratislava for Ireland's World 
Cup 2018 qualifier against Austria in November, following huge demand from Irish football fans.
The airline has scheduled an extra return flight from Dublin for Ireland v Austria (12 November) in Vienna, alongside 
its regular daily Dublin-Bratislava service, so even more Irish fans can travel on the lowest fares and start dreaming 
of Russia 2018.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Robin Kiely said, "The Boys in Green did us proud at the Euros and with the 
World Cup 2018 qualifying campaign getting under way in just 2 months' time, demand from Irish supporters has 
never been stronger."
He added, "We're pleased to add an extra return flight to Bratislava for Ireland's away game against Austria on 12th 
November, allowing even more fans to start out on the road to Russia - all on the lowest fares, and only available 
for booking on the Ryanair.com website." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair May passenger traffic increases 12%
Ryanair May passenger traffic increases 12%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 7, 2016 Thursday 6:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 143 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has reported that passenger traffic for the month of May 2016 was 10.6 million 
passengers, an increase of 12%, compared to 9.5 million passengers for May 2015.
Body
Load factor for the month of May 2016 was 94%, an increase of two percentage points, compared to 92% for May 
2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's May traffic grew by 12% to 10.6m customers, while our load factor 
jumped 2% points to 94%. These record monthly numbers and load factors were delivered, at lower fares, despite 
the ongoing disruptions being caused by ATC strikes in France, as lower fares and the continuing success of our 
"Always Getting Better" customer experience programme continue to deliver even more great value for our 
customers. "Ryanair customers can look forward to more improvements, as part of Year 3 of our "Always Getting 
Better" programme, which includes even lower fares, more new routes, new digital features and new cabin interiors, 
as Ryanair continues to deliver the lowest fares and the most on time flights in Europe."

Body
Load factor for the month of June 2016 was 94%, an increase of one percentage points, compared to 93% for June 
2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's June traffic grew by 11% to 10.6m customers, while our load factor 
jumped 1% point to 94%. These record monthly numbers and load factors were delivered, at lower fares, despite 
the repeated disruptions caused by unacceptable French ATC strikes, and we are again calling on the European 
Commission to urgently take action to reduce the impact of these ATC strikes on Europe's citizens and the single 
market."

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Stake Boosted by UBS Group AG
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Stake Boosted by UBS Group AG
Watchlist News
July 6, 2016 Wednesday 1:23 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved

Byline: Micah Haroldson
Body
Jul 06, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> UBS Group AG boosted 
its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 115.6% during the first quarter, according to its most 
recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. The fund owned 102,569 shares of the company's stock after buying an 
additional 54,991 shares during the period. 
UBS Group AG's holdings in Ryanair Holdings PLC were worth $8,802,000 at the end of the most recent quarter. 
<nl/> A number of other large investors also recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. IFP Advisors Inc 
raised its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC by 2.3% in the first quarter. IFP Advisors Inc now owns 2,896 
shares of the company's stock worth $249,000 after buying an additional 66 shares during the last quarter. 
Commonwealth Equity Services Inc bought a new stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter 
worth $298,000. Marietta Investment Partners LLC bought a new stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC during 
the first quarter worth $667,000. Profund Advisors LLC raised its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC by 16.7% 
in the fourth quarter. Profund Advisors LLC now owns 12,990 shares of the company's stock worth $1,123,000 after 
buying an additional 1,860 shares during the last quarter. Finally, Pinnacle Associates Ltd. bought a new stake in 
shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC during the fourth quarter worth $1,643,000. <nl/> Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) opened at 69.56 on Wednesday. The firm's 50-day moving average is $79.98 and its 200-day 
moving average is $81.88. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12-month low of $66.09 and a 12-month high of $89.67. 
The firm has a market cap of $18.24 billion and a PE ratio of 10.83. <nl/> Several equities research analysts have 
recently commented on RYAAY shares. Raymond James Financial Inc. boosted their price target on shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC to $100.00 in a report on Friday, March 25th. Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on 
shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a report on Friday, May 6th. Evercore ISI lowered shares of Ryanair Holdings 
PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating and set a $90.00 price target for the company. in a report on Monday, June 
27th. Zacks Investment Research lowered shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a 
report on Wednesday, May 25th. Finally, Macquarie upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from an 
'underperform' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a report on Tuesday. Six equities research analysts have rated the stock 
with a hold rating and four have issued a buy rating to the company. The stock currently has an average rating of 
'Hold' and a consensus price target of $92.00.<nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company 
for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-
point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet 
consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats.<nl/> Want to see what other hedge funds are holding

German fraud investigators raid Ryanair pilot rooms at six airports
German fraud investigators raid Ryanair pilot rooms at six airports
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 6, 2016 Wednesday 3:17 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 130 words
Body
       Koblenz, GERMANY (dpa-AFX) - Raids have been carried out on the rooms of Ryanair pilots at six German 
airports as part of a tax and social insurance investigation, a senior public prosecutor confirmed to dpa on 
Wednesday.  The Irish budget airline's partner companies are suspected of indulging in fraud relating to tax and 
social insurance payments, said Hans Peter Gandner, senior prosecutor for the city of Koblenz.  Several dozen 
officers carried out the raids on Tuesday at Berlin's Schoenefeld airport, as well as at the airports in Cologne, 
Weeze in North Rhine-Westphalia, Frankfurt-Hahn, Bremen and Baden-Baden.  The raids resulted from an 
investigation dating back years into two British temporary employment agencies that supply pilots to Ryanair.   
Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: July 6, 2016
End of Document

maintained its position in Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) during the first quarter, according to its most 
recent disclosure with the SEC. The institutional investor owned 1,493 shares of the company's stock at the end of 
the first quarter. 
BlackRock Japan Co. Ltd's holdings in Ryanair Holdings PLC were worth $128,000 at the end of the most recent 
quarter. Other hedge funds have also bought and sold shares of the company. IFP Advisors Inc increased its stake 
in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 2.3% in the first quarter. IFP Advisors Inc now owns 2,896 shares of the company's 
stock worth $249,000 after buying an additional 66 shares during the period. Commonwealth Equity Services Inc 
acquired a new stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter worth about $298,000. Profund Advisors LLC

additional 5,075 shares during the period. Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) traded down 
2.609% during mid-day trading on Tuesday, reaching $69.245. 402,101 shares of the company's stock traded 
hands. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 1-year low of $66.09 and a 1-year high of $89.67. The company has a market 
capitalization of $18.16 billion and a P/E ratio of 10.786. The firm has a 50-day moving average price of $80.13 and 
a 200-day moving average price of $82.04. RYAAY has been the subject of a number of research analyst reports.

research report on Friday, March 25th. Beaufort Securities reissued a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings 
PLC in a research report on Tuesday, April 5th. Finally, Macquarie raised shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from an 
'underperform' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a research report on Tuesday. Six research analysts have rated the 
stock with a hold rating and four have issued a buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair Holdings PLC presently 
has a consensus rating of 'Hold' and an average target price of $92.00. Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a 
holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving

Ryanair continue to be affected by French ATC strikes Ryanair continu...
Ryanair continue to be affected by French ATC strikes; Ryanair continu...
Business World (Digest)
July 5, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Highlight: Ryanair has been forced to cancel 102 flights on today over France.
Body
Ryanair has been forced to cancel 102 flights on today over France.
Over 18,000 Ryanair customers will have their flights and holidays cancelled tomorrow and over 100,000 others will 
suffer severe delays.
Ryanair advised customers travelling on Tuesday to check the status of their flight on the Ryanair.com website 
before travelling to the airportand urged all its customers to sign its "Keep Europe's Skies Open" petition, which it 
will present to the European Commission when it accrues a million signatures.
Ryanair's Chief MarketingOfficer, Kenny Jacobs said, "These unacceptable French strikes have become weekly 
events by now, aimed at causing maximum disruption for families and business passengers, which is why we are 
calling on the European Commission to take action to prevent these ATC strikes from disrupting the travel plans of 
Europe's citizens and their families." He added, "The recent Brexit vote underlines that the EU Commission must 
begin to deliver real benefits for Europe's consumers, and show families and holiday makers that Europe is on their 
side and will not allow a small group of French ATC unions to repeatedly close the skies over Europe." Source: 
www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: July 8, 2016
End of Document

EasyJet weighs up flight abroad for HQ Airlines
EasyJet weighs up flight abroad for HQ; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
July 2, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 19
Length: 532 words
Byline: Michael Pooler
Highlight: Carrier considers setting up continental legal base amid Brexit uncertainty
Body
Budget airline easyJet is drawing up plans to move its headquarters to continental Europe following Britain's vote to 
leave the EU .
The possible relocation is aimed at safeguarding its status as Europe's second-largest budget carrier by revenue, 
amid uncertainty over the UK's trade relations with the bloc after withdrawal.
No final decision has yet been taken, and any move would see easyJet set up a legal base rather than transfer its 
core functions overseas. The company's determination is likely to hinge on the government's ability to negotiate a 
post-Brexit settlement that is favourable to the airline industry.
Like its bigger rival Ryanair, easyJet capitalised on the creation of a single EU aviation market in the 1990s that 
allows airlines to operate services on any route within the bloc.
But Britain's exit from the EU has cast doubt over whether UK-based carriers will remain part of this arrangement, 
and throws up complications for overseas airlines that fly into British airports.
Underlining investor concerns, stocks in the sector took a hammering after the referendum. This week easyJet's 
shares dropped by nearly a fifth after it warned that profits would be hit by Brexit.
EasyJet weighs up flight abroad for HQ Airlines
Following a report on Sky News yesterday, the FTSE 100 group said it had no plans to move from Luton, where it 
was founded more than 20 years ago and continues to have its headquarters with about 1,000 employees.
The company said: "EasyJet is lobbying the UK government and the EU to ensure the continuation of a fully liberal 
and deregulated aviation market within the UK and Europe. This would mean that easyJet and all European airlines 
can continue to operate as they do today."
But it confirmed it had begun a formal process to acquire an air operating certificate in a continental European 
country which could allow it to set up headquarters there and continue flying throughout the EU without restrictions, 
should trade barriers emerge.
One person close to the company said this "contingency" plan would involve the creation of a legal entity requiring 
no more than a "handful" of employees.
A change in corporate structure would probably see the UK operation become a subsidiary of the new European 
company. The process to acquire an air operating certificate would take "months, not years", the person added.
John Strickland, director of JLS Consulting, said: "Having a business registration in one country and fulfilling some 
or all of your functions elsewhere is being done already [in Europe], so I don't see that this is beyond the bounds of 
possibility."
He pointed to IAG, the owner of British Airways, which is registered in Spain. "But many of their commercial 
functions are spread out geographically according to operating airline [and] country. Its centre is actually in the UK 
at Heathrow," Mr Strickland said.
EasyJet held meetings this week with EU officials in Brussels and the UK's transport department. Chief executive 
Dame Carolyn McCall has said easyJet remained "confident" in the strength of its business model after the Brexit 
vote.
"Until the outcome of the UK/EU negotiations are clearer easyJet does not need to make any other structural or 
operational changes," the group said.
Load-Date: July 1, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair snapped up E150m of its own shares after Brexit Ryanair snapped...
Ryanair snapped up E150m of its own shares after Brexit; Ryanair snapped...
Business World (Digest)
July 1, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 248 words
Highlight: The Irish Independent has today reported that Ryanair will consider taking advantage of any persistent 
weakness in its share price following last week's Brexit vote to buy back more of its own shares.
Body
The Irish Independent has today reported that Ryanair will consider taking advantage of any persistent weakness in 
its share price following last week's Brexit vote to buy back more of its own shares.
Shares in the airline were hammered by the Brexit vote and a profit warning issued by Easyjet following the 
decision by the UK to leave the European Union.
Ryanair's shares were trading at E11.30 yesterday compared to E13.68 before the referendum result. Following the 
share buyback in the past week, the carrier has now completed an E885m share buyback programme, buying just 
over 65m shares at an average price of just under E13.48 each.
But the airline has now reached the 5pc buyback limit secured under a resolution at its annual general meeting last 
year. It said it will hold an extraordinary general meeting later this month to seek shareholder approval to engage in 
further buybacks. According to the report, Ryanair Chief Executive, Michael O'Leary claimed the airline's board 
authorised the repurchase of E150m worth of its own shares at an average price of just under E11.85 in the 
immediate aftermath of the UK Brexit vote last week. "It is sensible to request approval from shareholders to allow 
the board consider further share buybacks over the next 15 months should they deem it in the best interests of 
shareholders to do so," said Mr O'Leary. He added that the airline does not intend to engage in a formal buyback 
programme this year, however. Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: July 6, 2016
End of Document
The Short View
The Short View
Financial Times (London, England)
July 1, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: THE SHORT VIEW; Pg. 13
Length: 372 words
Byline: Jonathan Eley
Body
This year Ireland commemorated the centenary of the Easter Rising - the rebellion that set it on the path to 
independence from Britain. For the country's investors, a more recent "independence day" has been a rather less 
happy occasion.
Between the close of trading on June 23 - the day of the UK's referendum on EU membership - and the close on 
June 29, the ISEQ Overall share index dropped more than 12 per cent. That is worse than any other major 
European stock benchmark and more, in local currency, than even the UK-centric FTSE 250. In euro terms, the 
FTSE 250 fell by more than the ISEQ, although not much more.
Aside from the UK itself, Ireland has the most to lose from Brexit. The Economic and Social Research Institute has 
estimated that each percentage point reduction in UK GDP knocks 0.3 points off Ireland's.
But the links are not as strong as they were. Some 15 per cent of Ireland's exports go to the UK, whereas it used to 
be half. And Ireland's economy has been powering ahead: it expanded more than 6 per cent last year.
Also, what applies to the broader economy does not always apply to the stock market. Esri found that the impact of 
Brexit would be more acute for smaller companies. Ireland's largest listed groups - the top five account for almost 
three-quarters of the stock market's capitalisation - are more international. Sterling revenues vary: 28 per cent of 
the total at food group Kerry, about the same at Ryanair. At building materials group CRH, the Americas account for 
The Short View
twice as much profit as Europe. Many of the sterling-dominated companies, like Paddy Power and Grafton, have 
moved their primary listings to London.
What, then, might explain the index fall? Ireland's stock market is small: the FTSE 250's capitalisation is almost five 
times that of the ISEQ Overall. That could have exacerbated the decline. In times of stress, investors sell the stocks 
they can, not necessarily those they should.
The Easter Rising ended in defeat, yet within a decade Ireland achieved independence. Now, Brits are queueing for 
Irish passports . Brexit could be nasty for some Irish companies, but the latest steep declines seem to be pricing in 
an awful lot of bad news. Things should get better.
jonathan.eley@ft.com 
Load-Date: June 30, 2016
End of Document
Lufthansa reaches deal with cabin crew in long-running industrial row
Lufthansa reaches deal with cabin crew in long-running industrial row
City A.M.
July 1, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 177 words
Byline: VICTORIA BRYAN
Body
GERMAN carrier Lufthansa and its main cabin crew union yesterday reached a deal in a long-running dispute over 
pay, conditions and pensions, a boost for the airline which is also negotiating with pilots.
The deal was achieved thanks to a mediator, who will formally announce the terms on Tuesday once a few final 
details have been agreed, the two sides said. Until then, both sides said they had agreed to keep the terms 
confidential.
Lufthansa is trying to cut costs to better compete with low-cost rivals within Europe, such as Ryanair and EasyJet, 
and also with leaner rivals such as Emirates and Turkish Airlines, on long-haul routes.
Lufthansa management and the cabin crew union UFO have been at loggerheads since September 2013, when 
Lufthansa said it wanted to cancel a decades-old early retirement scheme.
The row culminated in November, when UFO staged the longest-ever strike in the German carrier's history. A 
dispute with its pilots stretches back four years but the union and Lufthansa said last month they hope to reach a 
deal by the end of July.
Reuters
Graphic
 
Lufthansa reaches deal with cabin crew in long-running industrial row
A deal has been done with Lufthansa cabin crew - now only the pilots are in dispute

Malaysia Airlines appoints Bellew as its new CEO
Malaysia Airlines appoints Bellew as its new CEO
Associated Press Financial Wire
June 30, 2016 Thursday 12:22 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 236 words
Dateline: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia 
Body
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) - Malaysia Airlines' chief operating officer has been named its new CEO, state 
investment agency Khazanah Nasional said Thursday.
Khazanah, the airline's key shareholder, said in a statement that Peter Bellew's appointment will ensure "continuity 
and further progress" in the airline's restructuring.
Bellew, a former Ryanair executive, will replace Christoph Mueller, who has resigned due to "changing personal 
circumstances." Mueller will be on leave and formally step down in September, far ahead of the end of his three-
year contract.
"Proud day. Just been appointed CEO of Malaysia Airlines. We will fix it," Bellew tweeted.
The national airline suffered years of financial losses before two disasters in 2014 - the disappearance of Flight 370 
and the loss of another plane shot down over Ukraine. The airline was taken private by Khazanah, and Mueller, a 
turnaround veteran, was hired last year to oversee a $1.56 billion overhaul that included cutting 6,000 jobs and 
axing unprofitable routes.
Bellew, Ryanair's former director of flight operations, was part of the new management team.
In an interview with The Associated Press in April, Mueller described the airline as a "ship that has many leaks" but 
said things were back on the right track. He said the carrier recorded a profit in February, its first positive monthly 
result in years, and is on track to return to the black by 2018.
Load-Date: July 1, 2016
End of Document

BlackRock Group LTD Reduces Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
BlackRock Group LTD Reduces Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Watchlist News
June 29, 2016 Wednesday 4:29 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 639 words
Byline: Kyle Jackson
Body
Jun 29, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex) BlackRock Group LTD 
decreased its position in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 6.6% during the first quarter, 
according to its most recent disclosure with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The fund owned 
212,239 shares of the company's stock after selling 15,114 shares during the period. BlackRock Group LTD owned 
about 0.08% of Ryanair Holdings plc worth $18,215,000 at the end of the most recent quarter. Several other large 
investors have also modified their holdings of the stock. 
IFP Advisors Inc increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 2.3% in the first quarter. IFP Advisors Inc 
now owns 2,896 shares of the company's stock worth $249,000 after buying an additional 66 shares during the last 
quarter. Commonwealth Equity Services Inc acquired a new stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc during the first 
quarter worth about $298,000. Profund Advisors LLC increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 
16.7% in the fourth quarter. Profund Advisors LLC now owns 12,990 shares of the company's stock worth 
$1,123,000 after buying an additional 1,860 shares during the last quarter. Pinnacle Associates Ltd. acquired a new 
stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc during the fourth quarter worth about $1,643,000. Finally, Stifel Financial 
Corp increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 30.0% in the fourth quarter. Stifel Financial Corp now 
owns 21,986 shares of the company's stock worth $1,901,000 after buying an additional 5,075 shares during the 
last quarter. Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) traded up 1.384% during mid-day trading on 
Wednesday, reaching $68.576. 555,407 shares of the company's stock traded hands. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 
12-month low of $66.09 and a 12-month high of $89.67. The company's 50 day moving average is $80.95 and its 
200 day moving average is $82.31. The company has a market cap of $17.98 billion and a P/E ratio of 10.542. 
RYAAY has been the subject of several recent analyst reports. Zacks Investment Research downgraded shares of 
Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Tuesday, March 8th. Evercore ISI 
downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating and set a $90.00 target price for the 
company. in a report on Monday. Raymond James upped their target price on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc to 
$100.00 in a report on Friday, March 25th. Finally, Beaufort Securities reaffirmed a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc in a report on Tuesday, April 5th. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, 
five have given a hold rating and four have assigned a buy rating to the stock. The company has a consensus rating 
of 'Hold' and an average target price of $92.00. Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for 
Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-
point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet 
consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. Want to see what other hedge funds are holding

Ryanair launch Shannon winter 2016 schedule Ryanair launch ...
Ryanair launch Shannon winter 2016 schedule; Ryanair launch ...
Business World (Digest)
June 29, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 121 words
Highlight: Ryanair have today launched theirShannon winter 2016 schedule. The winter schedule will have 12 
routes in total and 2 new winter services to Fuerteventura and Malaga.
Body
Ryanair have today launched theirShannon winter 2016 schedule. The winter schedule will have 12 routes in total 
and 2 new winter services to Fuerteventura and Malaga.
To celebrate these new winter routes to Fuerteventura and Malaga, Ryanair are releasing 100,000 seats for sale 
across their European network from just E19.99, which are available for booking until Monday (4 July) for travel until 
October.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Robin Kiely commented, "We are pleased to launch our Shannon winter 2016 
schedule, with 12 routes in total and 2 new winter services to Fuerteventura and Malaga, which will help deliver 
760,000 customers per annum and support 600 on-sitejobs at Shannon Airport."

O'Leary: Ryanair could push into EU at expense of UK after Brexit
O'Leary: Ryanair could push into EU at expense of UK after Brexit
City A.M.
June 29, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 15
Length: 101 words
Byline: JAMES NICKERSON
Body
BUDGET airline Ryanair has warned that it may shift its focus away from the UK and on to the EU after the 
referendum yielded a Brexit victory last week.
Just days after the UK voted to leave the EU, Ryanair's chief executive cast doubt on whether the company would 
place any of its new aircraft in the UK next year.
"We are taking another 50 aircraft next year. Would we place any of those in the UK? It is highly unlikely," Michael 
O'Leary told the Wall Street Journal. "We will pivot all of our growth into the EU."
Airlines have been among those hardest hit on the FTSE exchanges following Thursday's vote.
Graphic
 
Ryanair's boss said there clearly is going to be a hit to UK GDP and to European GDP

End of Document
Ryanair will shift investment away from UK after Brexit vote Ryanair will sh...
Ryanair will shift investment away from UK after Brexit vote; Ryanair will 
sh...
Business World (Digest)
June 28, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 274 words
Highlight: Ryanair is very unlikely to deploy new planes on United Kingdom routes next year and will focus on the 
European Union instead after Britain voted to leave the bloc, the Irish airline said on Monday.
Body
Ryanair is very unlikely to deploy new planes on United Kingdom routes next year and will focus on the European 
Union instead after Britain voted to leave the bloc, the Irish airline said on Monday.
The Irish low-cost airline, Europe's largest by passenger numbers, flies 40 million of its 100 million-plus passengers 
a year to and from the United Kingdom and has its largest hub at London's Stansted Airport.
Its shares have fallen over 23%since the United Kingdom voted on Thursday to leave the European Union.
Chief Executive Michael O'Leary, one of the most vocal business leaders campaigning in favour of continued EU 
membership, had repeatedly warned he would cut investment in Britain if it voted to leave. "It's unlikely we will base 
any additional aircraft in the UK in 2017 as they will be allocated to European Union airports instead," a Ryanair 
spokeswoman said in an emailed reply to questions. Earlier on Monday O'Leary told the Wall Street Journal the 
airline planned to "pivot all of our growth into the European Union," but that the airline's overall growth targets 
remained unchanged. The Irish-registered airline said it may consider setting up a UK operating licence if Britain 
fails to secure full access to European Union's Open Skies air traffic system. Ryanair expects passenger volumes 
from the United Kingdom will grow relative to last year, but that fares would be lower, the spokeswoman said. 
However, weakness in sterling, whose value has fallen from 1.31 euros to 1.20 since Britain's vote, is likely to have 
a negative impact on Ryanair's earnings, which are reported in euros. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: July 1, 2016
Ryanair will shift investment away from UK after Brexit vote Ryanair will sh...
End of Document
Bullish Fernandes plans to dominate low-cost segment
Bullish Fernandes plans to dominate low-cost segment
Flight International
June 28, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHT INTERVIEW
Length: 1258 words
Body
AirAsia Group chief executive looks to Ryanair for inspiration, but acknowledges ownership rules present 
formidable hurdle
Given the chance, AirAsia would combine all of its overseas affiliates with its main Malaysian operation, as a step 
toward “complete domination” of the Southeast Asian low-cost market. Group chief executive Tony Fernandes says 
that if national shareholding regulations were relaxed, AirAsia would “happily invest fully to take complete ownership 
of all” its units.
For the time being, though, AirAsia must settle with up to 49% stakes in its overseas affiliates, owing to the foreign 
ownership caps affecting airlines.
The company has built an impressive list of affiliates over the years – although not all are entirely successful. It 
holds a respective 49% of AirAsia India, AirAsia Japan and Indonesia AirAsia, 45% of Thai AirAsia and 40% of 
Philippines AirAsia. Of these, Thai AirAsia has enjoyed good profitability, while the others have seen mixed 
fortunes.
“Maybe we made the mistake of under-investing in some countries such as Indonesia, which becomes a problem. I 
want to invest, but some of our shareholders aren’t fully keen,” laments Fernandes. “We can become like the 
Ryanair of Asia as a consolidated group. It would be so profitable because of our huge network, connectivity and 
brand.
“Imagine that machine – if my Philippines and Indonesia [units] are profitable,” he adds, referring to their respective 
operating losses in the first quarter of 2016. AirAsia Philippines recorded an operating loss of Ps306 million ($6.5 
million), compared with one of Ps679 million for the same period a year earlier. Indonesia AirAsia’s figures show an 
operating loss of Rp82.7 billion ($6 million) for the quarter: a marked improvement on the Rp389 billion loss the 
year before.
floodgates
Bullish Fernandes plans to dominate low-cost segment
Fernandes describes his company’s smallest affiliate – AirAsia India – as an “unmitigated success... opening the 
floodgates” for its Malaysian and Thai units to begin tapping the Indian market. This is despite delays to its launch, 
which finally occurred in May 2014, and the short tenure of the carrier’s first chief executive, Mittu Chandilya, who 
left after less than a year at the helm.
Fernandes declines to talk about Chandilya’s departure, and acknowledges that the Indian operation has been a 
slow-starter. Still, the group plans to grow its India-based fleet to 20 aircraft, from the current six.
“AirAsia India is moving along nicely. Aviation is a gestation project. It’s not something you can just go in there 
today and make millions of dollars tomorrow,” he says.
Fernandes does not give a date for AirAsia Japan’s launch, but says it is working towards that milestone. The start-
up received its air operator’s certificate in October 2015, at which point early 2016 was being targeted for the 
beginning of operations. AirAsia Japan will operate from a base at Ch bu Centrair airport near Nagoya, and fly 
initially to Sapporo, Sendai and Taipei Taoyuan in Taiwan.
Despite having his hands full with the core Malaysian business and five overseas units, Fernandes admits he is not 
satisfied with the status quo. “The world waits for nobody. It’s a dichotomy – do you throw away a great opportunity, 
or try and keep [the joint-venture] small? I hope to be in Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and I believe AirAsia 
Singapore could be a reality soon. The Singapore government is now much more proactive in discussions with us.”
low value
Fernandes is flatly dismissive of the recently formed Value Alliance, which sees Cebu Pacific, Jeju Air, Nok Air, 
NokScoot, Scoot, Tigerair, Tigerair Australia and Vanilla Air team up in what is essentially a sprawling interline 
partnership.
“It is a Mickey Mouse alliance,” he says. “What a joke. It’s simply desperation on their part. What passenger will 
take six airlines to go from one place to another? If ownership regulations were to change, it might be better for all 
of them to own equity in each other and create one brand. That would be something worth looking at. I value 
innovation and people creating ideas, but Value Alliance will struggle.”
Fernandes remains optimistic about the ASEAN Open Skies agreement, which was fully ratified by member 
countries Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and 
Vietnam in May.
Indonesia and Laos were the last two countries to agree the pact, which means that any airline in the region can 
launch as many international flights as the market can support. This plays to one of AirAsia’s strengths: its large 
fleet size.
Fernandes believes that although obstacles remain, the agreement is key to liberalising the market. He says: “It’s 
great all countries have signed, but it doesn’t solve everything – airports can say ‘I have no slots left’, leaving you 
back at square one. But I’m bullish that when ASEAN is fully liberalised, fifth freedoms, sixth freedoms will come in.”
However, he is not concerned that the pact may mean more competition. “If the competition is better than us, and 
we get our arse kicked, we deserve to get our arse kicked. You can’t hold competition back – it makes us smarter 
and better.”
Since the start of the 2015 financial year, the AirAsia Group held back capacity and growth to conserve cash.
When weakness in the Malaysian Ringgit and concerns about the company’s accounting methods hit AirAsia stock 
hard in 2015, Fernandes and partner Kamarudin Meranun boosted their combined stake from 18.9% to 32.4%; 
raising MYR1 billion ($247 million) for the firm.
“We showed commitment, because we think the company was undervalued – and it still is,” he explains.
Bullish Fernandes plans to dominate low-cost segment
Both Fernandes and Kamarudin have become “100% more involved” in the day-to-day running of operations, and 
he says the company has paid off around $400-500 million of debt since the additional stake purchase.
By 2017, AirAsia will look to expand toward China and India as areas of growth, due to the large potential of the 
countries. In another recent interview, Fernandes disclosed that the group’s flights in and out of China contributed 
19% of its total revenue, while India represented 3%.
“I’m happy if I can maintain that same level for China. But India is really where the action is,” he says. “There is tons 
of potential and space to grow. The sky is the limit there. If the Indian government and private airports give us more 
landing rights, it will be good for business for them too.”
Flightglobal’s Fleets Analyzer database shows that overall the AirAsia Group operates 167 Airbus A320ceos, with 
303 A320neos set for delivery until 2028.
The group expects to receive its first three Neos by the end of this year, with 16 scheduled to arrive in 2017 and 32 
during 2018.
Asked whether AirAsia might have over-ordered, Fernandes quips: “We need those aircraft, and are looking to 
order more. We are in talks with Airbus now, so keep a look-out. If I can have 1,000 aircraft, I’ll gladly take them.”
Fernandes has become “100% more involved”
in group’s day-to-day operations

gestation project.

can just go into today
and make millions of

AirTeamImages
Indian operation is smallest affiliate, but has sharp growth plans

Ryanair demands EU flies in to prevent French strikes
Ryanair demands EU flies in to prevent French strikes
City A.M.
June 28, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 208 words
Byline: JESSICA MORRIS
Body
BUDGET airline Ryanair is urging the EU to take action after the latest airline strike orchestrated by French air 
traffic control unions.
It comes as the low-cost carrier was forced to cancel 166 flights to, from and over France today. It said that 30,000 
Ryanair customers will have had their flights cancelled, while more than 100,000 others will suffer severe delays.
It wants the European Commission to require French ATC unions to engage in binding arbitration rather than 
strikes, while allowing Europe's other ATCs to operate overflights over France and protect flights over France amid 
the strikes.
Kenny Jacobs, chief marketing officer at Ryanair, said: "It is time for action by the European Commission following 
this latest French ATC strike aimed at disrupting as many travel plans as possible."
He continued: "The frequency of these strikes, right in the middle of holiday season only serves to underline how 
urgent action is required to help reduce the impact of these strikes.
"After last week's Brexit vote in the UK, the EU Commission must begin to deliver real benefits for consumers, and 
urgent action to ameliorate the effects of these repeated French ATC strikes and prevent them disrupting the travel 
plans of millions of citizens."
Load-Date: June 28, 2016
Ryanair demands EU flies in to prevent French strikes
End of Document
European Shares Extend Losses On Brexit Worries
European Shares Extend Losses On Brexit Worries
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
June 27, 2016 Monday 1:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 362 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European stocks extended Friday's steep losses as banks fell again on concerns about 
their long-term profits and financial health. Investor sentiment remains cautious despite central banks around the 
world moving to reassure markets.  The U.K. economy is strong and its banks and financial system are healthy, 
U.K. Chancellor George Osborne told a press conference on Monday, although he admitted that it will not be plain 
sailing in the days ahead. 
 The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was down 2.8 percent in midday trading after plunging as much as 7 
percent in the previous session.  The German DAX, France's CAC 40 index and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 were down 
between 1.5 percent and 1.8 percent.   Spain's IBEX drifted into negative territory after climbing about 2 percent in 
early trade, as caretaker Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy emerged as the clear winner in Spain's general election.  
Barclays' shares were down 13 percent in London and the Royal Bank of Scotland traded down about 15 percent. 
Shares in both were temporarily suspended earlier in the session.   Regional banks Commerzbank, Deutsche Bank, 
Credit Agricole, BNP Paribas, Societe Generale Group, Credit Suisse, UniCredit and Intesa lost 4-8 percent.   
Foxtons Group slumped 23 percent and easyJet plummeted 18 percent after both warned that Britain's referendum 
decision to quit the European Union will hit their financial performance this year.   Travel group TUI dropped 3 
percent on saying the fall in the pound would hit profits. Budget airline Ryanair and British Airways-owner 
International Airlines Group both fell around 8 percent each.  British property developers also fell sharply, with 
Berkeley Group Holdings, Barratt Developments and Taylor Wimpey falling 11-15 percent.   Swedish truck maker 
Volvo AB plunged 9 percent after making an additional provision of 250 million euros in connection with the ongoing 
EU Competition Investigation.   Sanofi rose 1 percent in Paris after the drug maker reached definitive agreements 
with Boehringer Ingelheim to swap Sanofi's animal health business 'Merial' and Boehringer Ingelheim's consumer 
healthcare business.      
Load-Date: June 27, 2016
European Shares Extend Losses On Brexit Worries
End of Document
FTSE 100 Extends Losses As Bank Shares Crash
FTSE 100 Extends Losses As Bank Shares Crash
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
June 27, 2016 Monday 12:16 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 252 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares fell further on Monday after financial experts warned recession is a 'near 
certainty' for the British economy.  The U.K. is ready to face the future with a strong economy that will adjust to the 
new situation, Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne said today in his first remarks since Britons voted to 
leave the EU in the June 23 referendum. 
 But he added that it was 'inevitable' that the U.K. economy would face an 'adjustment' in the wake of the Brexit 
vote.  The benchmark FTSE 100 was down 74 points or 1.20 percent at 6,065 in midday trading after declining 3.2 
percent on Friday.  Barclays' shares were down over 12 percent and the Royal Bank of Scotland traded down about 
15 percent. Shares in both were temporarily suspended earlier in the session.   Foxtons Group slumped 22 percent 
and easyJet plummeted 18 percent after both warned that Britain's referendum decision to quit the European Union 
will hit their financial performance this year.   Travel group TUI dropped 2.5 percent on saying the fall in the pound 
would hit profits.   Property developers also fell sharply, with Berkeley Group Holdings, Barratt Developments and 
Taylor Wimpey falling 11-13 percent.   Budget airline Ryanair and British Airways-owner International Airlines Group 
both fell around 8 percent each.   Insurer Aviva retreated 4 percent. The company said that its capital position is 
resilient to market stress and Brexit would have no significant operational impact on it.

European Shares Extend Losses On Brexit Worries
European Shares Extend Losses On Brexit Worries
RTT News (United States)
June 27, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 372 words
Body
(RTTNews) - European stocks extended Friday's steep losses as banks fell again on concerns about their long-
term profits and financial health. Investor sentiment remains cautious despite central banks around the world 
moving to reassure markets.
The U.K. economy is strong and its banks and financial system are healthy, U.K. Chancellor George Osborne told a 
press conference on Monday, although he admitted that it will not be plain sailing in the days ahead.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was down 2.8 percent in midday trading after plunging as much as 7 
percent in the previous session.
The German DAX, France's CAC 40 index and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 were down between 1.5 percent and 1.8 
percent.
Spain's IBEX drifted into negative territory after climbing about 2 percent in early trade, as caretaker Prime Minister 
Mariano Rajoy emerged as the clear winner in Spain's general election.
Barclays' shares were down 13 percent in London and the Royal Bank of Scotland traded down about 15 percent. 
Shares in both were temporarily suspended earlier in the session.
Regional banks Commerzbank, Deutsche Bank, Credit Agricole, BNP Paribas, Societe Generale Group, Credit 
Suisse, UniCredit and Intesa lost 4-8 percent. Foxtons Group slumped 23 percent and easyJet plummeted 18 
percent after both warned that Britain's referendum decision to quit the European Union will hit their financial 
performance this year.
Travel group TUI dropped 3 percent on saying the fall in the pound would hit profits. Budget airline Ryanair and 
British Airways-owner International Airlines Group both fell around 8 percent each.
British property developers also fell sharply, with Berkeley Group Holdings, Barratt Developments and Taylor 
Wimpey falling 11-15 percent.
Swedish truck maker Volvo AB plunged 9 percent after making an additional provision of 250 million euros in 
connection with the ongoing EU Competition Investigation.
European Shares Extend Losses On Brexit Worries
Sanofi rose 1 percent in Paris after the drug maker reached definitive agreements with Boehringer Ingelheim to 
swap Sanofi's animal health business "Merial" and Boehringer Ingelheim's consumer healthcare business.

RTT News (United States)
June 27, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 262 words
Body
(RTTNews) - U.K. shares fell further on Monday after financial experts warned recession is a 'near certainty' for the 
British economy.
The U.K. is ready to face the future with a strong economy that will adjust to the new situation, Chancellor of the 
Exchequer George Osborne said today in his first remarks since Britons voted to leave the EU in the June 23 
referendum.
But he added that it was "inevitable" that the U.K. economy would face an "adjustment" in the wake of the Brexit 
vote.
The benchmark FTSE 100 was down 74 points or 1.20 percent at 6,065 in midday trading after declining 3.2 
percent on Friday.
Barclays' shares were down over 12 percent and the Royal Bank of Scotland traded down about 15 percent. 
Shares in both were temporarily suspended earlier in the session.
Foxtons Group slumped 22 percent and easyJet plummeted 18 percent after both warned that Britain's referendum 
decision to quit the European Union will hit their financial performance this year.
Travel group TUI dropped 2.5 percent on saying the fall in the pound would hit profits.
Property developers also fell sharply, with Berkeley Group Holdings, Barratt Developments and Taylor Wimpey 
falling 11-13 percent.
Budget airline Ryanair and British Airways-owner International Airlines Group both fell around 8 percent each.
Insurer Aviva retreated 4 percent. The company said that its capital position is resilient to market stress and Brexit 
would have no significant operational impact on it.

Airlines: brace position
Airlines: brace position
Financial Times (London, England)
June 27, 2016 Monday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 18
Length: 315 words
Body
If you can use some exotic booze . . . let's fly away, sang Frank Sinatra. Airline executives could use a bucket of 
pina coladas and a one-way ticket. Their profits are highly cyclical. Travel is largely discretionary, and the industry's 
fixed costs are high. Unsurprisingly, they took the result of the UK's referendum badly.
IAG shed a fifth of its market capitalisation when it issued a profit warning to coincide with the referendum result . 
The owner of British Airways and Iberia - which relies largely on business travellers - reported subdued demand in 
the run-up to the vote.
Ryanair and easyJet are more exposed to the leisure market. Seats were already being discounted to fill planes. As 
a weaker pound makes travel dearer for Brits, bigger discounts may be needed. That will hurt margins.
Soft sterling might create downward pressure in other ways, too. BA, which accounts for the majority of IAG's 
operating profit, earns mostly in pounds, reports in euros and buys its fuel in dollars. Fuel and currency exposures 
will be hedged in the short term. The long-term impact is unclear.
Britain's participation in the Open Skies agreement - which allows airlines to operate from any EU airport - is 
expected to be part of Brexit negotiations. If they do not get the access they want, airlines such as easyJet are likely 
to relocate their UK bases to the continent.
The MSCI Europe Airline index had risen by nearly half in three years, comfortably beating the FTSE Eurofirst 300. 
Airlines leveraged economic growth, cheap financing and lower oil prices to expand capacity. Investors were 
already fretting about the consequences , in Europe and the US. They will fret more now. One consolation: 
Airlines: brace position
uncertainty reinforces the need for reform at legacy carriers. Both Air France-KLM and Lufthansa remain embroiled 
in damaging industrial relations disputes. Darkening skies may force co-operation.
Load-Date: June 26, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair forced to cancel 166 flights Ryanair forced ...
Ryanair forced to cancel 166 flights; Ryanair forced ...
Business World (Digest)
June 27, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 160 words
Highlight: Ryanair has been forced to cancel 166 flights to/from and over France tomorrowdue to the strikes by 
French ATC unions.
Body
Ryanair has been forced to cancel 166 flights to/from and over France tomorrowdue to the strikes by French ATC 
unions.
This will mean 30,000 Ryanair customers will have their flights cancelled tomorrowand over 100,000 others will 
suffer severe delays.
Ryanair advised customers travelling on Tuesday to check the status of their flight on the Ryanair.com website 
before travelling to the airport and urged all customers to sign its Keep Europe's Skies Open petition, which it will 
present to the European Commission when it accrues a million signatures.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said, "It is time for action by the European Commission following 
this latest French ATC strike aimed at disrupting as many travel plans as possible." He added, "The frequency of 
these strikes, right in the middle of the holiday season only serves to underline how urgent action is required to help 
reduce the impact of these strikes." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Brokerages Set Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY ) Price Target at $94.33
Brokerages Set Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Price Target at 
$94.33
Watchlist News
June 26, 2016 Sunday 10:27 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 427 words
Byline: Hanz Christensen
Body
Jun 26, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Shares of Ryanair Holdings 
plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been given a consensus rating of 'Hold' by the ten research firms that are covering the 
firm. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell recommendation, four have given a hold 
recommendation and four have assigned a buy recommendation to the company. 
The average twelve-month price target among brokers that have issued ratings on the stock in the last year is 
$94.33. An institutional investor recently raised its position in Ryanair Holdings plc stock. BB...ecurities raised its

O’Leary to speak at Fine Gael fundraiser
O’Leary to speak at Fine Gael fundraiser
Sunday Business Post
June 26, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 197 words
Byline: Hugh O’Connell
Highlight: Airline boss set for business breakfast
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary is to speak at a Fine Gael fundraiser in Dublin later this year. 
The outspoken airline boss has been invited to address the party’s Dublin Bay South €55-a-plate business 
breakfast at the Shelbourne Hotel on October 5. 
The annual event is one of Fine Gael’s main fundraisers with the money going towards the local constituency 
organisation. It is usually attended by ministers, TDs, members and business people. 
Taoiseach Enda Kenny was last year’s guest speaker while the event was addressed by British ambassador 
Dominic Chilcott in 2014. O’Leary has often been critical of the Irish political system. In April, he criticised 
independent TDs and said that Ireland needed to be more sensible than electing “the local favourite or the local 
lunatic”. 
“We need to, whenever the next election comes around, vote in parties who are capable of running the country for a 
four or five year period,” he told RTÉ. 
Although he has not stated his political allegiances publicly, O’Leary has been critical of Sinn Féin and other left-
wing parties, saying he would emigrate if a wealth tax was introduced and describing it as “populist nonsense and 
rubbish”.
