Sinn Fein calls for Irish unity poll Sinn Fein calls...
Sinn Fein calls for Irish unity poll; Sinn Fein calls...
Business World (Digest)
June 24, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 761 words
Highlight: Northern Ireland's deputy leader Martin McGuinness called for a vote to unite the two sides of the Irish 
border on Friday, as stocks tumbled and the damaging economic and political fallout from Britain's decision to quit 
the EU were immediately felt.
Body
Northern Ireland's deputy leader Martin McGuinness called for a vote to unite the two sides of the Irish border on 
Friday, as stocks tumbled and the damaging economic and political fallout from Britain's decision to quit the EU 
were immediately felt.
Ireland has the EU's fastest-growing economy but also more to lose than any other member state from Brexit with 
far-reaching implications for its trade, economy, security of energy supplies and peace in British-ruled Northern 
Ireland.
After 56% of Northern Irish voters sought to remain in the EU compared to the 52%of the United Kingdom as a 
whole who voted leave, Sinn Fein's McGuinness said it was imperative that London called a referendum on a united 
Ireland.
"The British government now has no democratic mandate to represent the views of the North in any future 
negotiations with the European Union and I do believe that there is a democratic imperative for a 'border poll' to be 
held," McGuinness told RTE. "The implications for all of us on the island of Ireland are absolutely massive. This 
could have very profound implications for our economy (in Northern Ireland)." The call from Sinn Fein, Northern 
Ireland's largest Irish nationalist party, was later rebuffed by First Minister Arlene Foster. Taoiseach Enda Kenny, 
who has said his government had a full-scale contingency plan in place should its nearest neighbor and largest 
trade partner vote to leave, called an emergency cabinet meeting shortly after the result. The outcome has very 
significant implications for Ireland and the EU as a whole, a government statement said. Ireland's central bank had 
warned that a withdrawal would hurt economic growth and jobs and significantly impact the financial sector, while a 
government-commissioned report found it could cut trade with Britain by at least 20%. Irish banks, whose exposure 
to the UK accounts for around 21 percent of total assets, led the Irish stock market nine percent lower, with shares 
Sinn Fein calls for Irish unity poll Sinn Fein calls...
in Bank of Ireland and permanent tsb down 21% and 17% down by 0845 GMT. Europe's largest airline by 
passenger numbers Ryanair , building materials group Kingspan and packaging producer Smurfit Kappa also fell 
sharply. The local bourse was down by as much as 16% earlier on Friday. The yield on Ireland's benchmark 10-
year bonds was marginally higher at a near record low 0.78%. Finance Minister Michael Noonan said earlier this 
week that an estimated cumulative Brexit-related hit on the Irish economy of as much as 1.6%of GDP would be 
"containable." As the UK voted on Thursday, Noonan told parliament that while the downside was "definite," any 
upside was only speculative, referring to the possibility that some companies keen to stay in the EU might move 
from Britain to Ireland. Irish exporters will be the first to suffer, as the pound weakened significantly against the 
euro, making their euro-priced goods more expensive. Foreign Minister Charlie Flanagan told Reuters on 
Wednesday that the government will have to consider helping firms exporting into Britain. Farmers and food 
producers, major UK suppliers, are especially vulnerable. "This development is unambiguously negative for the Irish 
economy," said Philip O'Sullivan, chief economist at Investec Ireland. Of most concern to Dublin is the impact on 
Northern Ireland, which has the only land frontier between the United Kingdom and the rest of the EU. It was 
marked by military checkpoints until a 1998 peace deal ended three decades of sectarian violence. Flanagan said 
the reintroduction of a hard border would have to be considered in any negotiation and that the return of controls, 
for customs or security, could pose a difficult challenge for the peace process. The dismantling of military border 
posts was a key aspect of the peace deal between Catholic nationalists seeking a united Ireland and Protestant 
unionists who wanted to keep Northern Ireland British. Over 3,600 died in the conflict. Northern Ireland's pro-British 
First Minister Foster dismissed the call by her deputy, McGuinness, for a vote on Irish unity as "opportunistic." 
Britain's Secretary of State for Northern Ireland may call such a vote at any time, according to the 1998 agreement. 
It also specifies that the Secretary "shall" order a referendum if it appears likely that a majority of those voting would 
seek to form part of a united Ireland. "There is no way even if there was a border poll that it would be in favor of a 
united Ireland," Democratic Unionist Party leader Foster told Northern Ireland's Radio Ulster. (Reuters) Source: 
www.businessworld.ie

Sinn Fein Calls for Irish Unity Poll as Brexit Fallout Begins
Sinn Fein Calls for Irish Unity Poll as Brexit Fallout Begins
Newstex Blogs
Voice of America
June 24, 2016 Friday 7:01 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 853 words
Body
Jun 24, 2016( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex) Northern Ireland's deputy leader 
Martin McGuinness called on Friday for a vote to unite the two sides of the Irish border as stocks tumbled in the 
economic and political fallout from Britain's decision to quit the EU. Ireland has the EU's fastest-growing economy 
but also more to lose from Brexit than any other member state, with far-reaching implications for its trade, economy, 
security of energy supplies and peace in British-ruled Northern Ireland. After 56 percent of Northern Irish voters 
sought to remain in the EU compared to the 52 percent of the United Kingdom as a whole who voted to leave, Sinn 
Fein's McGuinness demanded that London call a referendum on a united Ireland. 
"The British government now has no democratic mandate to represent the views of the North in any future 
negotiations with the European Union and I do believe that there is a democratic imperative for a 'border poll' to be 
held," McGuinness told national Irish broadcaster RTE. "The implications for all of us on the island of Ireland are 
absolutely massive. This could have very profound implications for our economy (in Northern Ireland)." The call 
from Sinn Fein, Northern Ireland's largest Irish nationalist party, was rebuffed by pro-British First Minister Arlene 
Foster and Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny, who said there were much more serious issues to deal with. Kenny 
called an emergency cabinet meeting shortly after the result and afterwards published a plan his government had 
prepared in advance, listing actions it would take over trade, investment, British-Irish relations and Northern Ireland. 
Unabiguously negative Ireland's central bank had warned that a withdrawal would hurt economic growth and jobs 
and significantly impact the financial sector, while a government-commissioned report found it could cut trade with 
Britain by at least 20 percent. Irish banks, whose exposure to the UK accounts for around 21 percent of total assets, 
led the Irish stock market eight percent lower, with shares in Bank of Ireland and permanent tsb down 25 percent 
and 21 percent down at 1345 GMT. Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers Ryanair , building materials 
group Kingspan and packaging producer Smurfit Kappa also fell sharply. The local bourse was down by as much as 
16 percent earlier on Friday. The yield on Ireland's benchmark 10-year bonds [IE10YT=TWEB] was marginally 
higher at a near record low 0.84 percent. The country's debt agency said its funding position was strong with limited 
financing needs for the rest of the year and through the first half of 2017. The cost of insuring exposure to Irish 
government debt nearly doubled on Friday, surging to the highest level in nearly 2-1/2 years. Finance Minister 
Michael Noonan, who earlier this week said an estimated cumulative Brexit-related hit on the Irish economy of as 
much as 1.6 percent of GDP would be "containable", said the outcome would not derail his immediate budget plans. 
"There is nothing catastrophic for Irish fiscal policy on the horizon," Noonan told national broadcaster RTE with the 
caveat that the hit to economic growth could limit his budget plans beyond 2018. Investec Ireland said it will likely 
cut its GDP forecasts for 2016 and 2017 that are currently in line with government predictions of 5 and 4 percent, 
Sinn Fein Calls for Irish Unity Poll as Brexit Fallout Begins
calling the referendum result "unambiguously negative" for the Irish economy. Davy Stockbrokers said that while it 
did not think a Brexit will be sufficient to push Ireland into recession, it could lower growth by 1 to 2 percent in both 
years. Ratings agency S...aid Brexit had no immediate impact on Ireland's sovereign ratings and it expected the 
Irish economy to stay resilient enough to withstand the negative impacts. Brexit may not be all bad for Ireland, and 
Noonan said there may be some upside if companies keen to stay in the EU moved to Dublin from London. The 
contingency plan calls for marketing efforts to be intensified in sectors like financial services for firms wanting to be 
based in the EU. Border controls But of most concern to Dublin is the impact on Northern Ireland, which has the 
only land frontier between the UK and the rest of the EU. It was marked by military checkpoints until a 1998 peace 
deal ended three decades of sectarian violence. Foreign Minister Charlie Flanagan told Reuters this week that the 
reintroduction of a hard border would have to be considered in any negotiation and that the return of controls, for 
customs or security, could pose a difficult challenge for the peace process. The dismantling of military border posts 
was a key aspect of the peace deal between Catholic nationalists seeking a united Ireland and Protestant unionists 
who wanted to keep Northern Ireland British. Over 3,600 died in the conflict. Kenny said Ireland would do its utmost 
to keep the country's decades-old common travel area with Britain. His plan says that options for possible customs 
and excise controls, including the role of modern technology, would be analyzed with a view to minimizing trade 
restrictions.

Everything To Know About Brexit
Everything To Know About Brexit
International Business Times News
June 23, 2016 Thursday 8:14 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1054 words
Byline: Lydia Tomkiw
Body
Jun 22, 2016( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) After absorbing 
months of campaigning, voters in the U.K. are headed to the polls Thursday to decide whether to remain in the 
European Union. Amid tight polls with only a day to go before voting, here's everything you need to know about the 
vote, the issues driving both sides and the economic implications. What is Brexit? The popularity of combining 
celebrity couple names has crossed into the realm of European politics. 
Brexit is a combination of 'Britain' and 'exit' and has become the shorthand name for Thursday's referendum. The 
official question voters will be asked is: 'Should the United Kingdom remain a member of the European Union or 
leave the European Union?' This is the first vote of its kind in the history of the economic and political bloc in its 
modern form. Why is the vote happening? The U.K. and the EU have had a rocky relationship in recent years. The 
U.K. joined the EU in 1973[1] and today 73 members of the European Parliament hail from the U.K. Prime Minister 
David Cameron promised to hold a referendum on U.K. membership in the EU if he was re-elected in 2015 and he 
has kept his word. Both the U.K. Independence Party (UKIP) and Cameron's own Conservative Party have pushed 
for the vote. Pro-EU supporters hold placards and banners during a 'Yes to Europe' rally in London's Trafalgar 
Square, ahead of Thursday's EU referendum, on June 21, 2016. Photo: NIKLAS HALLE'N/AFP/Getty Images Who 
gets to vote? While the deadline to register to vote has already passed, anyone registered to vote[2] in the U.K. is 
eligible to take part in the referendum. Commonwealth citizens living in the U.K. as well as Gibraltar, British citizens 
living overseas who have registered to vote in the last 15 years and Irish citizens who were born in Northern Ireland 
are all eligible to cast a ballot. While voting by post and proxy are both possibilities, budget airline Ryanair ran a 'Fly 
Home to Vote Remain' sales campaign (the airline supports Britain staying[3] in the EU). '[The] seat sale proved 
extremely popular, so much so that we extended it for 24 hours,' Ryanair told International Business Times in an 
email. What has the campaign looked like and what are the issues? Campaigning has been intense over the last 
several months. The 'leave' camp[4] has argued that the referendum presents the opportunity for Britain to take 
back control it has lost in the large EU bureaucracy and has highlighted the amount of money sent every week to 
Brussels, the capital of the EU. Immigration has also been in the spotlight with the 'leave' camp arguing, 'We will 
control our borders.' The 'leave' camp has argued Britain would have greater control over its own economy outside 
of the EU.https://twitter.com/vote_leave/status/745324472316502016The 'remain' camp[5] has argued that the U.K. 
is 'stronger, safer and better off in Europe.' While admitting to problems with the EU, the 'remain' camp has focused 
its energy on the economic argument, stressing that British jobs and trade are tied to the EU and that the EU adds 
billions of dollars to the British economy every year. Staying in the EU is the status quo choice that many business 
executives have called for. Who are the biggest 'leave' and 'remain' supporters? From retired soccer player David 
Everything To Know About Brexit
Beckham ('remain') to British-born American TV host John Oliver ('remain') and actress Elizabeth Hurley ('leave'), 
celebrities, CEOs and political leaders have been taking stands[6] on which way they want to the vote to go.           
https://twitter.com/StrongerIn/status/745316210645016576On the political front, Cameron is leading the 'remain' 
side while UKIP party leader Nigel Farage has been rallying the 'leave' side. Business leaders from Coca-Cola to 
JPMorgan Chase, fearing economic implications of Britain outside of the EU, have come out urging voters to 
choose 'remain.'Play Video[7] What happens if the U.K. votes to leave? The short answer is no one really knows. If 
the U.K. does vote to leave, it would be the first country to do so. Experts estimate it could take several years for 
the country to work out new trade relations with the EU. The U.K. is the world's fifth-largest economy[8] and many 
businesses use it as a jumping-off point to the Europeanwide market. That has economists and business owners 
worried[9] about trade arrangements, currency fluctuations and slower economic growth in the U.K. If the 'leave' 
vote wins, economists have predicted the British pound could weaken against the dollar. The Bank of England has 
warned that uncertainty over the referendum is the 'largest immediate risk'[10] to financial markets around the 
globe. Is the vote binding? No, it is not legally binding. Parliament will still have to pass laws[11] for the U.K. to exit 
the EU, but it is unlikely Parliament would go against the people's decision. There is no minimum turnout needed, 
and to win the vote a simple majority is needed. When will we know the results? Polls will close at 10 p.m. GMT (6 
p.m. EDT)and local results will be declared as they come in. Around 4 a.m. local time it should start to become clear 
which side has the lead, the BBC reported[12]. The final result will be announced at the Manchester Town Hall. [ 1]:       
     http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/member-countries/unitedkingdom/index_en.htm [ 2]:            
http://www.aboutmyvote.co.uk/upcoming-elections-and-referendums/eu-referendum

Ryanair schedules special return flights from Dublin to Lyon for Euro 2016; 
Ryanair schedul...
Business World (Digest)
June 23, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 163 words
Highlight: It has been announced today that Ryanair has scheduled special return flights from Dublin to Lyon for 
Ireland's historic last 16 European Championship clash with France on Sunday, 26th June.
Body
It has been announced today that Ryanair has scheduled special return flights from Dublin to Lyon for Ireland's 
historic last 16 European Championship clash with France on Sunday, 26th June.
Ryanair's Euros specials will depart from Dublin on Saturday 25th June at 08.10hrs and Sunday 26th June at 
05.55hrs, and return from Lyon at 21.25hrs on Sunday 26th June, and at 00.30hrs and 12.00hrs on Monday 27th 
June.
Ryanair say this follows unprecedented demand from Irish fans. The airline has warned that seats are extremely 
limited and the flights will operate with hand baggage only.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Robin Kiely commented, "We've been inundated with requests from Irish fans 
ever since the final whistle blew in Lille last night and we've scheduled 5 special Euro 2016 flights for Ireland's 
crunch tie against France on Sunday in Lyon, departing Dublin on Saturday and Sunday morning, and returning on 
Sunday night and Monday morning." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair warns of two to three-year downturn if Britain leaves the EU Ryanair warns o...
Ryanair warns of two to three-year downturn if Britain leaves the EU; 
Ryanair warns o...
Business World (Digest)
June 22, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 418 words
Highlight: Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary warned on Tuesday of a two to three-year economic downturn if Britain 
votes to leave the European Union and said that Brussels has been given a "wake-up call" regardless of the result 
of Thursday's UK referendum.
Body
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary warned on Tuesday of a two to three-year economic downturn if Britain votes to 
leave the European Union and said that Brussels has been given a "wake-up call" regardless of the result of 
Thursday's UK referendum.
Speaking at an aviation conference in Paris, the head of the Irish budget carrier -- Europe's largest airline by 
passenger numbers -- said that economic and political disruption could weaken the rest of the 28-nation bloc if UK 
voters back a so-called Brexit.
"If Brits vote to exit, I think the European Union as a project is doomed," O'Leary said. "I think they will inevitably be 
followed by others. I think you would have a two or three-year economic downturn with huge uncertainty that would 
be very bad, not just for the UK economy but for the European economy, which is already struggling."
The Irish entrepreneur is one of the most vocal business leaders urging voters to back continued European Union 
membership in Thursday's referendum. Both sides in the closely fought contest claim significant business support. 
"In my business it depends very much on what the exit looks like," O'Leary told the Paris Air Forum, hosted by La 
Tribune. But he suggested that a vote to leave would penalise a generation that grew up on cheap connectivity to 
the rest of Europe and put at risk a system of unrestricted routes on which Ryanair and other budget airlines have 
built rapid growth. Analysts say it is still unclear whether Britain, Ryanair's biggest single market, would continue to 
have unfettered access to EU airports under complex aviation rules. O'Leary was speaking before travelling to 
London to join the climax of the campaign, alternating between defending membership of a reformed EU and 
criticising its bureaucracy. "Even if Britain votes to remain, Europe and certainly Brussels has had a wake-up call," 
he said, adding that a clear message has already been sent to the EU's bureaucracy. "If you guys in Brussels don't 
Ryanair warns of two to three-year downturn if Britain leaves the EU Ryanair warns o...
... start improving the single market and improving the lives of Europe's citizens, this thing is going to fall apart." 
Ryanair has often clashed with the European Commission over passenger compensation, taxes and other issues. It 
is now lobbying for a clampdown by European authorities on repeated air traffic controller strikes. Willie Walsh, 
head of British Airways owner IAG, has been more cautious about the impact of a Brexit, saying that it would "not 
have a material impact" on his business. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: June 27, 2016

Ryanair Rome Fiumicino flights to move from Terminal 3 to Terminal 2
Ryanair Rome Fiumicino flights to move from Terminal 3 to Terminal 2
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
June 22, 2016 Wednesday 3:52 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 154 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced that all of its Rome Fiumicino flights will move from Terminal 3 to Terminal 2 
from June 28, 2016.
Body
All Ryanair customers due to depart from Rome Fiumicino should continue to use Terminal 3 up to and including 
Monday, 27th June, and then use Terminal 2 from Tuesday, 28th June. Ryanair's Rome Fiumicino summer 2016 
schedule includes 18 routes, with 3 new routes Alicante, Kos and Malta, and extra flights to Barcelona, Bari, 
Brussels and Palermo, which will deliver 3.8m customers at Rome Fiumincino Airport this year, and support almost 
3,000 on-site jobs. Ryanair's Robin Kiely said: "As part of our continuing customer experience improvements under 
our "Always Getting Better" programme, we are pleased to announce that we will move all of our Rome Fiumincino 
flights from Terminal 3 to Terminal 2, from Tuesday, 28th June. All Ryanair customers departing from Rome 
Fiumicino should use Terminal 2 from next Tuesday, 28th June, and we look forward to continuing to grow traffic, 
routes and jobs at Rome Fiumicino Airport."

Ryanair expands London Stansted winter 2016 schedule with new 
Luxembourg route
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
June 20, 2016 Monday 2:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 211 words
Highlight: Ryanair has expanded its London Stansted winter 2016 schedule with a new daily service to 
Luxembourg from September 2016.
Body
The new service is the newest addition to its European route network (and 33rd country of operation) and the 4th 
new Stansted route this winter in addition to Hamburg, Timisoara and Toulouse, which will deliver 20m customers 
p.a. and support 15,000 jobs at London Stansted Airport.. This new Luxembourg route is ideal for both business 
and leisure customers, who can now choose from 109 Stansted routes in winter 2016, on the lowest fares, and look 
forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme, which includes more new 
routes, new digital features, and new cabin interiors. Ryanair's Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch a new 
London Stansted route to Luxembourg, our newest market, with a daily service starting from Sepetember, as part of 
our winter 2016 schedule, which includes 3 other new routes to Hamburg, Timisoara, Toulouse and will deliver 20m 
customers p.a. and support 15,000 jobs at London Stansted Airport S"eats on our new Luxembourg route are on 
sale now from just GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Monday (23 May) for travel in September. Since 
these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and book 
themselves a low fare trip to Luxembourg."

Ryanair to launch new accommodation service
Ryanair to launch new accommodation service
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
June 20, 2016 Monday 9:08 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 255 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has announced that it will offer a new accommodation service, Ryanair Rooms, from 
October 1, 2016.
Body
With "Ryanair Rooms", the airline will widen the range of accommodation it offers to customers beyond just hotels 
to include (a) hotels, (b) hostels and B&Bs and (c) homestay/villas and other 'room' offers, but all will be at the 
lowest possible prices for Ryanair customers. This latest customer initiative follows the launch of Ryanair Car Hire 
last August, (in partnership with CarTrawler) and will be the latest digital improvement delivered by Ryanair Labs, 
under the "Always Getting Better" programme, which includes a best-in-class personalised website, and dynamic 
mobile app. 
Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's low fares revolutionised air travel for Europe's passengers - now with 
"Ryanair Rooms", we're going to transform booking accommodation. Launching on 1st October, "Ryanair Rooms" 
will offer consumers the biggest range of accommodation, including hotels, hostels, B&Bs, homestays and villas, via 
the Ryanair.com website, but all with the same lowest prices we guarantee with our flights. "More and more 
customers are looking to Ryanair for products other than flights, and we see this as a natural progression towards 
Ryanair.com becoming the Amazon of air travel. It also echoes the change in demand from customers for different 
types of accommodation, which in turn will be reflected by the varied range "Ryanair Rooms" will offer - from five-
star hotel rooms to independent homestay. We look forward to receiving proposals from interested partners who 
want to help us disrupt the travel industry once more."

Ryanair cofounder says budget travel coming to Argentina Ryanair cofound...
Ryanair cofounder says budget travel coming to Argentina; Ryanair 
cofound...
Business World (Digest)
June 20, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 197 words
Highlight: The owners of Ireland's Ryanair Holdings Plc aim to bring budget air travel to Argentina in 2017, co-
founder Declan Ryan told newspaper La Nacion after meeting with government officials in the South American 
nation.
Body
The owners of Ireland's Ryanair Holdings Plc aim to bring budget air travel to Argentina in 2017, co-founder Declan 
Ryan told newspaper La Nacion after meeting with government officials in the South American nation.
La Nacion reported the move would likely come through an acquisition, and said Salta-based Andes Laneas Aereas 
is a target, citing anonymous sources.
Ryanair is present in Mexico and Colombia through investments by its holding company Irelandia Aviation in other 
airlines. Irelandia Aviation said about dollar 50 million was needed to start operations with an initial fleet of five 
aircraft, according to La Nacion.
Ryan said he was optimistic about Argentine President Mauricio Macri's economic reforms but noted high inflation 
and corruption in the country were still concerns. "We have started negotiating with all the countries in the region 
except for Brazil where there is lots of corruption," he told the paper. Ryan did not specify possible routes in 
Argentina, but said he was surprised to learn students frequently traveled 20 hours by bus to the mountains of 
Bariloche, noting budget airlines could compete with bus fares. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: June 24, 2016
End of Document

Low-cost carriers continue to fly the path to big profits
Low-cost carriers continue to fly the path to big profits
Flight International
June 14, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 1068 words
Body
Low-cost carrier (LCC) traffic, revenue and profit figures continued to grow in 2015, as the spread of the model 
showed no sign of abating.
The latest Flightglobal/Airline Business low-cost carrier survey shows strong growth among leading carriers in the 
sector. Passenger numbers among the top 100 low-cost and leisure carriers in 2015 topped 1.1 billion: an increase 
of almost 11% over the previous year.
LCC revenues and profits, especially among the sector’s biggest players, were also up sharply in local currencies. 
However, big exchange rate movements against the strong US dollar mean this growth does not show when these 
figures are converted for comparison purposes.
When Ryanair ended the 2015 calendar year by passing the 100 million passenger mark, it further underlined the 
huge expansion the low-cost sector has continued to experience over recent years.
The Irish carrier became the second operator in the segment to reach the milestone, with 106 million passengers on 
an earned-seat basis for its financial year to March 2016. That reflects a return to double-digit passenger growth, 
after an hiatus ensuing from delays in sealing a follow-up aircraft order. It has added 25 million passengers in two 
years after putting its foot back on the accelerator. During this period, its fleet has increased from just under 300 
Boeing narrowbodies to almost 350.
Southwest Airlines remains the largest LCC in the world, carrying just shy of 145 million passengers last year. Its 
own passenger levels were sharply increased after its acquisition of AirTran, which was fully integrated at the end of 
2014.Between them, Southwest and Ryanair carried over 250 million passengers in 2015, accounting for almost a 
quarter of the 1.1 billion passengers the sector handled last year.going strongBut growth over recent years has 
been strong across the sector. Fourteen airlines each carried over 20 million passengers in 2015 and the 20 biggest 
operators had a combined passenger count of 713 million. By contrast, this stood at 420 million for the biggest 20 
LCC airlines in 2008.
Low-cost carriers continue to fly the path to big profits
More striking still is the individual growth shown by the 20 biggest LCCs in 2015 compared with their performances 
in 2008. These carriers have more than doubled collective passenger numbers over that period, some emerging 
virtually from scratch. Brazil’s Azul, the 12th biggest operator in 2015 with over 20 million passengers, only 
launched in December 2008.
Azul, aided by its acquisition of Brazilian regional operator Trip, is among the fastest-growing airlines over this 
period, together with Indian carrier IndiGo and Indonesia’s Lion Air. IndiGo, which listed on the Mumbai stock 
exchange last year, has grown from just below five million passengers in 2008 to over 31 million. Lion has gone 
from seven million passengers in 2008 to an estimated 32 million last year, although its rapid expansion has been 
tempered more recently after slowing its capacity growth.
This illustrates the rapid expansion of LCCs within emerging markets. In 2008, only four Asia-Pacific carriers ranked 
among the 20 biggest low-cost operators. That had reached six carriers by 2015. Virgin Australia – which has since 
repositioned as a network operator – was the only Asian carrier in 2008’s top 10. But IndiGo, Lion and AirAsia were 
all among the biggest carriers last year. The latter, which has doubled in size since 2008, has also developed a 
series of affiliate carriers in the region.
Not that European carriers have been left behind. Alongside the established pan-European pair of Ryanair and 
EasyJet, the likes of Norwegian, Pegasus, Vueling and Wizz Air have each more than trebled passenger levels 
since 2008.North American carriers, too – including JetBlue Airways, Virgin America, WestJet and the ultra-low-cost 
pair of Allegiant Air and Spirit Airlines – have all grown significantly during this period.
The continued impressive expansion across the sector has been achieved despite a slowdown in some key growth 
markets in Asia and Brazil.
The strong year will further increase the sector’s share of overall traffic, which has already climbed from 
representing less than 10% of passengers carried by the top 150 global airlines in 2008 to more than a quarter in 
2014.
The largest share of passengers for low-cost and leisure carriers among the leading 100 operators comes from 
Europe – which represents almost 38% of the sector; followed by the Asia-Pacific and North American markets.
Revenues for all but six of the 50 biggest airlines in the sector in 2015 covered by the report increased in local 
currency, although the sharp movements against the US dollar mean that, in several cases, they fall when 
converted into dollars for comparison purposes.
Revenues in local currency were down at only one carrier among the 20 biggest low-cost operators: Gol, as it 
battled Brazil’s economic challenges. Figures are not available for another of the country’s major LCCs, Azul.
Profits also continue to rise. At a net level, the 20 most profitable LCCs, for which figures are available, made a 
combined profit of $8.2 billion last year. That compares to $5.1 billion among the top 20 by net profit in 2014. The 
four biggest – EasyJet, JetBlue, Ryanair and Southwest – all posted operating profits topping $1 billion for their 
most recent financial years, and combined operating profit of $8 billion.
profits soar
Southwest remains the biggest LCC, generating revenues of almost $20 billion in 2015 and, in line with the strong 
profits across US airlines in the year, an operating profit of more than $4 billion.
Revenues were also up sharply at the fourth-biggest airline by revenue, JetBlue, which more than doubled 
operating profit for 2015. North American carriers, echoing the wider picture, led in LCC profitability. Six of the nine 
most profitable carriers at a net level were from North America, as Allegiant, Spirit, Virgin America and WestJet join 
Southwest and JetBlue.
Low-cost carriers continue to fly the path to big profits
Ireland’s Ryanair increased operating profit 40%, and net profit 43%, in local currency for the year ended March, to 
reach a new high – even before accounting for the one-off gains made from the sale of its largely written-down Aer 
Lingus stake.
NEWS FOCUS
Combined 2015 passenger numbers for sector’s 100 largest airlines topped 1.1 billion, as model continues global 
spread
2014 integration of AirTran bolstered performance of US operator Southwest Airlines
AirTeamImages

Ryanair forced to cancel 44 flights Ryanair forced ...
Ryanair forced to cancel 44 flights; Ryanair forced ...
Business World (Digest)
June 14, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 172 words
Highlight: Ryanair has been forced to cancel 44 flights today to/from and over France in what will be the 50th 
French strike since 2009 and 10th in the past 12 weeks.
Body
Ryanair has been forced to cancel 44 flights today to/from and over France in what will be the 50th French strike 
since 2009 and 10th in the past 12 weeks.
The airline has called on the European Commission to take action to prevent the skies over Europe being closed by 
French ATC union strikes which they say are targeting the European Championships.
Ryanair advised customers travelling today to check the status of their flight on the Ryanair.com website before 
travelling to the airport.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs commented, "These ongoing strikes by the French ATC unions 
are being directly aimed not only at families taking a well-deserved summer holidaybut also at the millions of 
football fans coming to France this summer for the Euros." He added, "It is shocking that a small group of unionized 
workers can hold a continent of football fans to ransom, and we regret that once again we have been forced to 
cancel a number of flights due to the selfish actions of these workers." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Body

January 2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's January traffic grew by 25% to 7.5m customers, while our 
load factor jumped 5% points to 88%, thanks to Ryanair offering lower fares as part of our load factor active/yield 
passive policy. These record monthly numbers and load factors are also due to the continuing success of our 
"Always Getting Better" customer experience programme, which continues to deliver stronger than expected 
forward bookings, traffic and load factors."

Fastjet appoints new top manager Airlines
Fastjet appoints new top manager; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
June 10, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 15
Length: 387 words
Byline: Nicholas Megaw
Body
Shares in Fastjet rose 14 per cent yesterday after the Africa-focused airline poached the boss of a rival carrier to 
lead its turnround efforts.
Nico Bezuidenhout , chief executive of South African Airways subsidiary Mango Airlines, is moving to take up the 
same role at London-listed Fastjet in August.
Fastjet started its African services in 2012, emulating the model that easyJet and Ryanair have used in Europe, but 
its shares have fallen 98 per cent over the past three years.
Political troubles and economic weakness in Tanzania, Fastjet's main market, have led to a series of profit warnings 
, and last week the company reported a pre-tax loss of $21.6m for 2015.
Fastjet has been without a chief executive since March, when Ed Winter stepped down after pressure from Sir 
Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the company's second-largest shareholder and founder of easyJet.
Colin Child , Fastjet's executive chairman, said Mr Bezuidenhout's decision to join the company "is a vote of 
confidence in the concept. He's given up a very good job at Mango and isn't wanting to step backwards".
Sir Stelios welcomed Mr Bezuidenhout's appointment as "better late than never," but renewed his criticism of Mr 
Child, saying he "is not the right man for the job of chairman".
Fastjet appoints new top manager Airlines
Last month easyGroup, Sir Stelios's private investment vehicle through which he holds his shares in Fastjet, 
requested a special shareholder meeting to remove Mr Child, saying it had "lost faith in Colin Child being able to 
turn the company around".
Sir Stelios had criticised Fastjet in a public letter in March, and questioned its ability to service its debts.
Mango is one of only a few low-cost carriers to become profitable in Africa, reporting earnings in eight of the past 10 
years. Mr Bezuidenhout has led the airline since it was established in 2006, and served two stints as interim chief 
executive of SAA.
Mr Child said "neither [Mr Bezuidenhout] nor we are hiding from the fact it's a challenging environment, but the 
more I see the more I am convinced that this is a market that's going to happen".
He said a number of the institutional investors in the company indicated they were "delighted that we've got 
someone of Nico's calibre", and said he was hopeful the company could avoid further disputes with shareholders. 
Fastjet's shares rose 14 per cent to 29.5p.
Load-Date: June 9, 2016
End of Document

Low-cost carrier Ryanair launches budget accommodation service
Low-cost carrier Ryanair launches budget accommodation service
City A.M.
June 10, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 175 words
Byline: JAMES NICKERSON
Body
BUDGET airline Ryanair will launch an accommodation service, offering customers a choice of hotels, hostels and 
more at the lowest prices.
Its low-price accommodation service, Ryanair Rooms, will launch from 1 October, in a bid to expand its offering to 
its 116m customers and compete with the likes of Airbnb.
The service will offer hotels, hostels, B&Bs, holiday villas and homestay options, via the www.Ryanair.com website, 
but pledges that whatever is chosen will always be at the lowest prices.
"With Ryanair Rooms, we're going to transform booking accommod-ation," said Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs.
"More and more customers are looking to Ryanair for products other than flights, and we see this as a natural 
progression towards www.Ryanair.com becoming the Amazon of air travel.
"Customers are looking to Ryanair for products other than flights, and we see this as a natural progression towards 
www.Ryanair.com becoming the Amazon of air travel."
Ryanair will charge commissions to accommodation suppliers less than that charged by some online aggregators.
Graphic
 
Low-cost carrier Ryanair launches budget accommodation service
Checking in: Ryanair, run by Michael O'Leary, is moving into cut-price accommodation
Load-Date: June 10, 2016

Fastjet's feat: Africa carrier plucks chief of Mango
Fastjet's feat: Africa carrier plucks chief of Mango
Financial Times (London, England)
June 10, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 22
Length: 199 words
Body
Shares in Fastjet rose 14 per cent yesterday after the Africa-focused airline poached the boss of a rival carrier to 
lead its turnround efforts.
Nico Bezuidenhout , chief executive of Mango Airlines, a South African Airways subsidiary, is to take up the 
equivalent role in the London-listed group in August.
Fastjet started its African services in 2012, aiming to copy the low-cost model of easyJet and Ryanair. Its shares 
have fallen 98 per cent in three years. Political and economic woes in Tanzania, its main market, have led to a 
series of profit warnings , and last week Fastjet reported a pre-tax loss of $21.6m for 2015.
The carrier has been without a chief executive since March, when Ed Winter stepped down after pressure from 
Stelios Haji-Ioannou , the easyJet founder who is the second-largest shareholder.
Sir Stelios welcomed Mr Bezuidenhout's appointment but renewed his criticism of Colin Child, saying he was "not 
the right man for the job of chairman".
In a public letter in March Sir Stelios had questioned Fastjet's ability to service its debts.
Mango is one of the few low-cost carriers in Africa to make a profit. Mr Bezuidenhout led the airline since it was 
established in 2006.
Fastjet's feat: Africa carrier plucks chief of Mango
Load-Date: June 9, 2016
End of Document
' Ryanair Rooms' to launch in October ' Ryanair Rooms'...
'Ryanair Rooms' to launch in October; 'Ryanair Rooms'...
Business World (Digest)
June 9, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 184 words
Highlight: Ryanair have today announced that they will launch a low price accommodation offer, "Ryanair 
Rooms"from 1st October next, offering its 116m customers the widest choice of hotel, hostel, B&B, holiday villa and 
homestay optionsbut always at the lowest price
Body
Ryanair have today announced that they will launch a low price accommodation offer, "Ryanair Rooms"from 1st 
October next, offering its 116m customers the widest choice of hotel, hostel, B&B, holiday villa and homestay 
optionsbut always at the lowest prices.
Ryanair is inviting all interested accommodation providers to submit proposals to become partners in "Ryanair 
Rooms".
The airline will widen the range of accommodation it offers to customers beyond just hotels to include (a) hotels, (b) 
hostels and B&Bs and (c) homestay/villas and other 'room' offers, but all will be at the lowest possible prices for 
Ryanair customers.
Ryanair Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said, "Ryanair Rooms will offer consumers the biggest range of 
accommodation, including hotels, hostels, B&Bs, homestays and villas, via the Ryanair.com website, but all with the 
same lowest prices we guarantee with our flights. More and more customers are looking to Ryanair for products 
other than flights, and we see this as a natural progression towards Ryanair.com becoming the Amazon of air 
travel." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Pint or flight? Brands are vying for your EU view
Pint or flight? Brands are vying for your EU view
City A.M.
June 8, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 353 words
Byline: Stephan Shakespeare
Body
AS THE 23 June referendum creeps ever closer, businesses are joining politicians in nailing their colours to the 
mast over Britain's membership of the EU.
Over the next couple of weeks, more organisations and business leaders will make their views public as voters 
agonise over their decision. Two brands that have already jumped in to the Brexit debate on opposite sides of the 
fence are budget airline Ryanair and pub chain JD Wetherspoon.
Ryanair boss, Michael O'Leary, has pushed for Britain to remain a mem-ber, while Wetherspoon chief, Tim Martin, 
wants to leave.
Both are using the business tools at their disposal to push politics, with the pub chain producing 200,000 anti-EU 
beermats, and the budget airline reportedly emailing its subscribers with a call for them to register for the vote.
Using YouGov Profiles, we can assess how these overt political actions will resonate with customers of both 
brands.
Ryanair customers are significantly more likely than the average punter to favour remaining in the EU.
Over half of the people who fly with the company want to stay (55 per cent), as opposed to fewer than four in 10 (37 
per cent) who want to leave. There are eight per cent who are yet to be convinced either way.
JD Wetherspoon customers are a little closer to the national average and pretty evenly split on the issue, with 45 
per cent wanting to leave and 46 per cent identifying as Remainians.
Both brands entering the political fray in such a public way has attracted more headlines for them.
Pint or flight? Brands are vying for your EU view
YouGov BrandIndex data shows that there has been an increase in the number of people talking about both 
Ryanair and Wetherspoon with their colleagues, friends and family.
Ryanair in particular has seen its Attention score rise to a yearly high of 25 in recent days, up from 14 in the middle 
of the month.
More organisations will enter the debate in the next two weeks.
What we don't yet know is whether overt political interventions from brands on either side of the referendum debate 
will harm their standing among customers who take a different view towards the EU.
Stephan Shakespeare is the chief executive of YouGov
Load-Date: June 8, 2016
End of Document

Insider Trading
Sunday Business Post
June 5, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 497 words
Byline: Ruth O’Connor
Highlight: Like it, want it, covet it:  Ruth O’Connor is our style insider
Body
Style counsel
If you’ve ever wondered what your style is, or tried to grasp the many styles and trends inherent in fashion, then For 
the Love of Style is for you. Going through styles such as preppy, bohemian and romantic, the book contains lots of 
great photos and tips from stylists and designers on style advice. For the Love of Style by Corinna Williams and 
Nina Zywietz, teNeues, €39. teneues.com 
Showcase for a not-so-mad hatter
Why is a raven like a writing desk? Because Dublin’s Westin Hotel has announced the talented (not so mad) hatter 
Laura Kinsella as its in-house milliner, and her custom-made hat is now on display in the hotel foyer. As part of the 
collaboration, the hotel has launched a marvellous Mad Hatter’s Afternoon Tea for parties of 18 or more guests who 
want to celebrate a special event in style. Visitors can expect quail’s egg and tarragon mayonnaise in a brioche roll, 
green tea cones with lemon yuzu cream and red velvet cake as well as the Red Rose Queen cocktail and of course 
a selection of teas. As the March Hare said to Alice: “Take more tea.” €49.50 per head. thewestindublin.com 
Luggage to catch the eye
If only we looked quite as glamorous as this when we’re on the Ryanair red-eye! Pictured here are pieces from the 
Italian luggage brand Bric’s, which was established in 1952. The brand makes pretty slick luggage in the form of 
wheeled duffle bags, soft and hard-case wheeled  carry-on trolleys, and terrific holdalls in classic colour 
combinations perfect for any destination. The Magellano hold-all costs €374, while the Bellagio 32-inch carry-on 
trolley costs €673. brics.it. 
Best dressed bulmers live
Insider Trading
This Thursday sees the Beacon Hotel return to sponsor best dressed at Bulmer’s Live at Leopardstown. Every 
Thursday till August, guests can compete for €1,500-worth of prizes. The finalists will be brought back on August 11 
as VIP guests to compete for the Dare To Be Different prize valued at €3,000. See thebeacon.com for details. 
Classic brand Vans
Skateboarder favourite Vans is just one of those classic brands with shoes that come in a design to suit all tastes. 
We are already fans of their classic slip-ons (and you’ll see them copied in every high street collection), but how 
about this collaboration between Vans and & Other Stories? The collection includes the classic slip-on and the Old 
Skool style in canvas and leather. Our favourite? The summery art print leather version designed by Pauline 
Abascal, pattern designer at the & Other Stories atelier in Paris, €100. stories.com 
CA Design floppy hat-esquw lamps
Speaking of hats, I love these floppy hat-esque lamps from CA Design. They are guaranteed to make a statement 
at 63cm wide and with a 3m cord; they can be placed over a dining table or coffee table to create a focal point in the 
room. €440 including bulb and cord. cadesign.ie  
Dolce & Gabbana
 We’re really feeling the summer holiday vibes with this painterly printed silk top by Dolce & Gabbana, €595, Brown 
Thomas.

Stobart Air axing routes between Dublin and Britain
Stobart Air axing routes between Dublin and Britain
Sunday Business Post
June 5, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 469 words
Byline: Fearghal O’Connor
Highlight: Routes from Dublin to East Midlands, Doncaster-Sheffield, and Cardiff to be axed
Body
Stobart Air is to axe three of the routes it operates from Dublin to Britain as part of its franchise deal with Aer 
Lingus, this newspaper has learned. 
The airline confirmed that Aer Lingus Regional routes between Dublin and East Midlands, Dublin and Doncaster-
Sheffield, and Dublin and Cardiff will cease with effect from November 1. 
It said it had plans to increase services on other routes and that all scheduled flights on the impacted routes would 
operate as normal between now and  October 31. 
The routes are operated as part of a wider franchise agreement with Aer Lingus that has long been seen as a key 
part of plans to turn Dublin into a transatlantic hub for US-bound passengers from Britain. 
But Stobart may soon face increased competition for those transfer passengers with negotiations under way 
between Aer Lingus and Ryanair that could see Michael O’Leary’s airline coordinating up to 50 of its short-haul 
routes into Dublin to allow for transfers on to Aer Lingus’ transatlantic services. 
The axing of the three UK services also comes at a time of heightened speculation around the future ownership and 
direction of Stobart Air after its chief executive Seán Brogan resigned last month after a board rejection of his 
management buyout bid for the carrier. 
But a spokesman for Stobart said that “these commercial decisions are the result of a systematic review of our Aer 
Lingus Regional route network which will see increases on other routes across the network later this year. The 2016 
winter schedule will be released for sale over the next two weeks. 
“Stobart Air’s continued growth is driven by its strategic and commercial focus on route development and 
performance. 
Stobart Air axing routes between Dublin and Britain
“This approach affords us the flexibility to respond to new opportunities and to make the necessary decisions on 
routes in order to protect and drive our continued growth,” he said. 
Meanwhile, Aer Lingus chief executive Stephen Kavanagh told this newspaper that his airline is on course to create 
more jobs than it promised the government it would do as part of last year’s IAG deal to buy the state’s 25 per cent 
stake. 
The airline last May pledged it would create 635 net new jobs by 2020. 
“I’m very confident that we will overshoot. If you look in 2016 alone we have added three aircraft to the north 
Atlantic, opening three new gateways. The aspiration at the time of transaction was five over a five-year period.” 
But Kavanagh refused to be specific about how many new jobs he now thought Aer Lingus could create because 
“at this moment there are too many imponderables”. 
“But we have 2.5 per cent of market share between Europe and North America. That’s a very low share position 
and a great opportunity. Even small changes in that market share are significant in terms of the size and scope of 
our operation,” he said.
Load-Date: June 10, 2016
End of Document
Transdev could learn lessons from Irish Ferries
Transdev could learn lessons from Irish Ferries
Sunday Business Post
June 5, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 540 words
Byline: Fearghal O’Connor
Highlight: ICG has kept its head down and concentrated on strengthening the business
Body
If the managers at Luas operator Transdev are looking for lessons in how to regain lost ground after a costly and 
disruptive strike, they could do worse than to look to Dublin Port for lessons. 
Irish Ferries, a company with a troubled industrial relations past, has gone from strength to strength since the end of 
a bitter two-year industrial dispute that ended in 2006. 
The announcement last week that its publicly quoted parent company Irish Continental Group is to invest €144 
million to build a new cruise ferry was further evidence of a company with the wind in its sails. 
An unsuccessful management buyout attempt aside, ICG management has kept its head down ever since and 
concentrated on strengthening the business. 
In recent years, as the recession ended and exports and imports rose, ICG was an obvious early beneficiary. 
Its previous unsavoury ruthlessness on staff costs, and, more particularly, falling fuel costs boosted profits. 
Savvy management played a part, particularly in how it has bought and sold ships and other assets. For example, 
last November, as demand continued to recover across the Irish Sea, the company spent €24 million on four 
container vessels. 
It was a bargain deal, effectively giving it four vessels for the price of one. 
Management will hope that its most recent decision to invest in the new ferry will ultimately prove equally as savvy. 
The new ferry will accommodate 1,855 passengers and crew, with 435 cabins and with capacity for 165 freight 
vehicles, plus a car deck that can cater for 300 cars. 
Transdev could learn lessons from Irish Ferries
Not for the first time, Irish Ferries has opted to follow the lead of Ireland’s most successful transport company, 
Ryanair. 
The airline’s massive orders of Boeing 737 aircraft in the past have not just provided for growth but have driven it. 
Irish Ferries management, with a brand new high-spec ship to market, will hope the €144 million investment will 
have a similar positive impact. 
Nevertheless, where Ryanair has an entire continent into which to place its steady flow of new aircraft, Irish Ferries 
is effectively limited to a few routes between Ireland and Britain and France. 
Its belief that it can fill its brand new ship day after day, as competition increases both at sea and in the air, is 
dependent on continued economic growth here in Ireland. 
Of course, like a canny poker player, before taking the big punt on a new ship, ICG took a smaller each way bet. 
The new ship will actually replace the Epsilon, a chartered ferry, which was introduced on to the Dublin to Holyhead 
route in December 2013. 
Back then, the market was just beginning to grow again and the recovery appeared altogether more shaky. 
The Epsilon was brought in to test the waters and, such was the rapid growth in passenger numbers, was proving 
too small a ship for the company’s expanding needs. 
The Epsilon’s lease runs out at the end of this year so a decision was needed whether to lease a bigger ship or take 
the plunge and invest in a new one. 
The decision to invest in the new vessel is a sign of ICG’s ambition. It is also a vote of confidence in the Irish 
economy and clear evidence that, for one transport company at least, there is plenty of life after industrial turmoil 
regardless of negative publicity.
Load-Date: June 10, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair to close Norwegian base on back of new tax
Ryanair to close Norwegian base on back of new tax
Sunday Business Post
June 5, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 68 words
Byline: Emma Kennedy and Fearghal O’Connor
Body
Ryanair has confirmed that it will close its Rygge base in Oslo later this year, following the Norwegian government’s 
decision to introduce a new passenger tax. 
“This tax will severely damage Norwegian tourism, particularly around regional airports. The Norwegian government 
has instantly made Norway uncompetitive and less attractive to airlines and tourists.” 
David O’Brien, chief commercial officer, Ryanair

Dublin now one of top 5 transatlantic hubs in Europe Dublin now one ...
Dublin now one of top 5 transatlantic hubs in Europe; Dublin now one ...
Business World (Digest)
June 3, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 623 words
Highlight: Decades after long-range airliners endedIreland's role as the stepping stone to Europe for Americans, 
who sipped Irish coffees as their propeller-driven planes refuelled, the country is slowly re-establishing itself as a 
major transatlantic aviation hub.
Body
Decades after long-range airliners endedIreland's role as the stepping stone to Europe for Americans, who sipped 
Irish coffees as their propeller-driven planes refuelled, the country is slowly re-establishing itself as a major 
transatlantic aviation hub.
Last year Dublin for the first time entered the top-five rankings for transatlantic hubs in Europe, data showed, after 
British Airways owner IAG started to implement plans to use Dublin as an alternative to the continent's top hub at 
London Heathrow.
With Irish low-cost giant Ryanair considering using its fleet to feed long-haul services, senior airline executives at 
the first annual meeting of the International Air Transport Association to be held in Dublin since 1962 talked up 
prospects for further growth.
"It's an absolutely enormous opportunity for Dublin," said Pat Byrne, chief executive of Irish regional airline CityJet, 
which announced plans to double its fleet to 50 planes. "The last timeIrelandhas had this significance (for 
transatlantic travel) was when airplanes had to stop to fuel." In the 1940s and 50s U.S. presidents and movie stars 
would stop off near Shannon on the west coast ofIrelandbefore flying on to Europe's great cities, bringing a touch of 
glamour to one of the most under-developed regions in Western Europe. Locals claim the Irish Coffee, finished with 
a dash of whiskey, was invented by a local barman catering for the visiting stars. But the airport went into decades 
of decline when long-range jets could fly further. Ireland's resurgence has been fuelled in recent years by strong 
sterling, a large under-utilised terminal completed just afterIreland's 2008 banking crisis and the only pre-clearance 
facility for travelling to the United States in an EU capital. Transfer traffic has been growing at Dublin by between 25 
and 30%a year as former flag carrier Aer Lingus has built up its long-haul fleet from seven in 2010 to a target of 20 
by 2020, a spokesman said. Meanwhile all transfer traffic through Dublin airport rose 50%to 250,000 passengers in 
Dublin now one of top 5 transatlantic hubs in Europe Dublin now one ...
the first four months of the year, the Dublin Airport Authority said. Heathrow had 230,000 transatlantic seats 
available weekly at the peak of last summer compared with fifth-placed Dublin with 41,000, according to aviation 
data and analytics company OAG. Dublin has focused on the 25 regional UK airports it has direct flights to, but the 
focus is shifting towards other parts of western Europe, said Dublin Airport Authority chief executive Kevin Toland. 
The next stage could be to harness Ryanair, whose second largest base in Europe is Dublin, with 86 destinations. 
Long averse to connecting flights due to logistical difficulties, Ryanair has said it will experiment with connections 
this summer with a view to feeding long haul airlines in the future. But Ryanair Chief Commercial Officer David 
O'Brien told Reuters it would need a "stronger compelling economic reason" before it starts regular feeds for rival 
carriers. Executives also citedIreland's pro-business regulator as a plus. The Irish Aviation Authority has been 
pushing to allow Norwegian Air Shuttle's Irish subsidiary to start flying transatlantic routes, despite heavy resistance 
from U.S. carriers against it. Aer Lingus Chief Executive Stephen Kavanagh, who has been spearheading his 
airline's hub plan since its takeover by IAG last year, said the key to further growth is being opportunistic, poaching 
passengers from overcrowded hubs in Europe and the United States. "Poor airports in North America is an 
opportunity to connect cities on the east coast directly to Dublin," he said. "We have such a small home market, we 
have to be internationally relevant in everything we do." (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair cuts baggage fees Airlines
Ryanair cuts baggage fees; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
June 3, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 23
Length: 283 words
Byline: Murad Ahmed
Body
Ryanair, the Irish no-frills airline, has cut baggage fees for the vast majority of its passengers and simplified its 
luggage options in another effort to repair its reputation for poor customer service.
The Dublin-based short-haul carrier said that it would reduce baggage fees for checked-in items for 92 per cent of 
customers and attempt to tackle confusion around the fees by cutting the options from 108 down to six.
Those flying for less than two hours will find fees cut by 50 per cent, while travellers on flights of less than three 
hours will save up to 17 per cent. Baggage fees for passengers flying for more than three hours will remain the 
same.
Yesterday, the company announced passenger traffic grew to 10.6m in May, a 12 per cent year-on-year rise, 
despite a difficult period for the European travel industry, which has been hit by terrorist attacks and strikes. 
Following two profit warnings in autumn 2013, Michael O'Leary , chief executive, admitted the company had 
annoyed too many customers and announced a strategic overhaul. He scrapped or lowered a number of hated 
fees, including charges for failing to print out boarding cards in advance of arriving at the airport.
Ryanair has also introduced more flexible tickets for business passengers as it tries to attract customers who have 
traditionally shunned budget airlines.
Kenny Jacobs, chief marketing officer, said the baggage fee reductions formed part of this programme.
Ryanair cuts baggage fees Airlines
In February, the company said that it intended to return EUR800m to investors this year through its largest ever 
share buyback programme, while reporting third-quarter net profit of EUR102.7m, up 110 per cent compared with 
the same period in 2014.
See Lombard
Load-Date: June 2, 2016

Emotional baggage
Emotional baggage
Financial Times (London, England)
June 3, 2016 Friday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LOMBARD; Pg. 22
Length: 103 words
Byline: Oliver Ralph
Body
Ryanair has done us all a favour. Henceforth, instead of having 108 baggage options when we book our flights, we 
will have only six. For this we are supposed to be thankful.
By the time Lombard has made it to the baggage options page, enthusiasm for the booking has long since waned. 
Who knows how much a bag is likely to weigh in several months' time?
Still, others would do well to follow Ryanair's lead. TV companies, energy suppliers, fund managers and countless 
others all do very nicely out of befuddling the public with 100 subtly different options. But there is a certain beauty in 
simplicity.
oliver.ralph@ft.com 
Load-Date: June 2, 2016
End of Document
WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
City A.M.
June 2, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 436 words
Body
FINANCIAL TIMES EX-BARCLAYS EMPLOYEES TELL JURY OF HUMILIATION Five former Barclays employees 
on trial for allegedly conspiring to rig interest rates have taken the stand in their own defence, with several telling 
the jury of the stress and pressure they felt while working at the UK bank. Jonathan Mathew described how his boss 
used to call him a "deaf git" and "humiliate" him by "whacking" him on the back of the head with a 12-inch baseball 
bat.
EX-ANGLO IRISH EXECS GUILTY OF (EURO)7.2BN FRAUD Two former execs at the ill-fated Anglo Irish Bank 
have been convicted of conspiracy to mislead investors after the longest criminal trial in Irish legal history. John 
Bowe and Willie McAteer were found guilty in Dublin on a charge of arranging a (EURO)7.2bn (£5.6bn) financial 
transaction that disguised the state of health of Anglo before it collapsed.
THE TIMES US FED A HACKING VICTIM Spies and hackers broke into the computer system of the US central 
bank on multiple occasions between 2011 and 2015, resulting in more than 50 cyberbreaches, Fed records 
disclose. The Fed's cybersecurity experts identified 310 incident reports during the four-year period, and classified 
140 as hacking attempts and four as espionage.
ARMANI EKES OUT SMALL PROFIT RISE The upmarket fashion retailer had a small rise in operating profit as 
growth in the wider luxury sector continues to slow. Giorgio Armani's operating profits rose by one per cent to 
(EURO)513m last year.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH OSLO BASE CLOSURE Ryanair has come under attack for deciding to close its base at 
Oslo Rygge airport, 66 kilometres from the Norwegian capital, a move that is expected to result in the loss of 1,000 
jobs - after Norway introduced a new tax on air passengers.
WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
MORTGAGE RATES DROP ON HINTS OF BANK CUT Home buyers in April paid the lowest interest rates ever on 
their mortgages amid suggestions the Bank of England might cut rates. In April, the average borrower paid just 2.41 
per cent on a new mortgage, down from 2.49 per cent in March and 2.64 per cent in April 2015.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL FITBIT NAMES FIRST WOMEN TO BOARD Fitbit named its first women to its 
board - Williams-Sonoma's Laura Alber and Glenda Flanagan of Whole Foods - part of a recent movement by tech 
companies to hire more women as top decision makers.
NEW CARS FOUND TO HAVE FAULTY TAKATA AIR BAGS At least four car makers confirmed equipping new 
vehicles with defective Takata air bags that eventually will need to be replaced. Toyota, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, 
Volkswagen and Mitsubishi have all confirmed equipping some new vehicles with rupture-prone Takata air bags.

Ryanair hits back over Norway air tax Airlines
Ryanair hits back over Norway air tax; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
June 2, 2016 Thursday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 15
Length: 433 words
Byline: Richard Milne, Nordic Correspondent
Body
Ryanair is to close its main base in Norway and cut half of its flights to the Nordic country in retaliation for Oslo's 
decision to introduce a tax on air travel.
The Irish low-cost airline announced its decision to close its base at Oslo Rygge - which in turn is likely to shut 
down the airport itself - on the day that Norway introduced the tax of NKr80 ($9.60) per passenger for international 
flights and NKr88 for domestic journeys.
Ryanair will start flying to London and Vilnius daily from Oslo's main Gardermoen airport and move some flights to 
Torp, an airport 75 minutes south-west of the capital, but 16 routes in all will be cancelled, reducing Ryanair's flights 
by a half to Norway.
Norway and Ryanair have been in a stand-off for some time over various issues, from labour conditions and pay to 
the introduction of the tax.
Erna Solberg, Norway's centre-right prime minister, said last week: "This government will not be blackmailed by 
Ryanair."
David O'Brien , Ryanair's chief commercial officer, called the introduction of the tax illogical and unfair as it 
penalised the Irish airline more than local rivals SAS and Norwegian Air Shuttle, which often have higher fares.
Ryanair hits back over Norway air tax Airlines
Both SAS and Norwegian have also criticised the tax.
He deflected criticism from the Norwegian government that Ryanair was merely using the tax as cover to close 
down its Rygge base.
"Call our bluff . . . I want to make it clear: the only reason we are closing it down is the new tax," Mr O'Brien said, 
adding that Ryanair would reopen the base if the tax was withdrawn.
Ryanair claimed Belgium, Ireland and the Netherlands had all scrapped similar taxes.
Rygge airport, which is located near Moss, about 45 minutes south of Oslo, has already said it will close down later 
this year if Ryanair shut its base.
Ms Solberg said yesterday that the government would not back down.
"They drive a hard bargain, they have done that in many other countries. The question is whether all countries 
should just give in. There are many countries that have chosen not to change their tax policies despite Ryanair's 
pressure."
She added: "NKr88 per flight is not a reason for such a powerful company not to continue at Rygge."
It is not Ryanair's first brush with Scandinavian countries.
The Irish airline threatened to pull out of Denmark last year after a labour court allowed Danish trade unions to 
blockade and strike against Ryanair aircraft.
Ryanair then closed down its base in Billund, home to Legoland, but at the end of last year claimed that the dispute 
had served to boost its business there, making its Danish flights 90 per cent full.
Load-Date: June 1, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair cuts bag fees for 92% of customers Ryanair cuts ba...
Ryanair cuts bag fees for 92% of customers; Ryanair cuts ba...
Business World (Digest)
June 2, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 158 words
Highlight: Ryanair have today announced that they have cut the checked-in bag fees for 92% of their116m 
customers.
Body
Ryanair have today announced that they have cut the checked-in bag fees for 92% of their116m customers.
They have also claimed that they have simplified the number of bag fee options (from 108 to 6), as part of their 
"Always Getting Better" (AGB) programme.
Customers on domestic flights under 2 hours will have their bag fees cut by 50%, while customers on all other 
flights under 3 hours will enjoy savings of up to 17%. Customers on flights over 3 hours will see no change to their 
checked bag fees.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said, "Over 92% of our customers will enjoy reduced bag fees and 
will pay the same price for checking-in a bag whether bought at the time of the initial booking or added to the 
booking, regardless of seasonality." He added, "Furthermore, customers will also be able to add bags to their 
bookings via the Ryanair app up to 3 hours before their scheduled time of departure." Source: 
www.businessworld.ie

Malaysia Airlines appoints new CEO
Malaysia Airlines appoints new CEO
AirFinance Journal
June 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: LATEST NEWS,AIRLINES,BREAKING NEWS,DEALS,MALAYSIA,ASIA
Length: 407 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Highlight: Christoph Mueller goes on leave and new leader takes the helm tomorrow.
Body
Group managing director and CEO of Malaysia Airlines Berhad (MAB) Christoph Mueller will go on leave on 1 July 
and step down from the MAB board, with his newly-appointed replacement Peter Bellew taking the helm of the 
restructuring Malaysian flag carrier.
Mueller resigned from his position on 10 March and is serving his notice period until 9 September. He will "remain 
available to the company until the end of his notice period to help ensure a smooth leadership transition."
A spokesperson for the airline did not immediately respond to a request for clarification as to what "remain 
available" means.
Malaysia Airlines said it has been looking for a new CEO since April and that the process has involved internal and 
external as well as local and foreign candidates.
Bellew, a former Ryanair executive, has been a member of MAB's senior management team since 1 September 
2015, when the company started operations. The airline said his appointment will "ensure continuity in the 
execution of the Malaysia Airlines turnaround plan and further progress of the overall restructuring effort, as set out 
by Khazanah in its 12-point MAS Recovery Plan".
"It also allows for an accelerated and seamless leadership transition from Mr Mueller," the airline added.
Airfinance Journal reported on 28 June that Bellew had been made an executive director of the board.
Although Mueller has not publicly disclosed where he will work next, an unconfirmed report by German-language 
publicationManager Magazindated 26 June says that he will join Dubai-based carrier Emirates as its chief 
transformation officer in charge of "digitalisation".
"I'm afraid Malaysia Airlines is not able to comment on Mr Mueller's next steps," a spokesperson for Malaysia 
Airlines told Airfinance Journal when asked to comment on the Manager Magazin report.
Malaysia Airlines appoints new CEO
As part of its restructuring, Malaysia Airlines is reducing its fleet and optimising routes. The old company Malaysian 
Airline System (MAS) sub-leased all its aircraft to a newly created company Malaysian Airlines Berhad (MAB). 
Banks and lessors with exposure to Malaysia Airlines were asked last year to consent to the proposal and the 
airline has been in negotiations with its creditors to try to secure reductions in lease rentals and loan principal 
payments, as well as the return of some aircraft.
To see all of Malaysia Airlines' recent and historic deals visitAirfinance Journal's Deals Database.

Malaysia Airlines expects to make a loss in 2016
Malaysia Airlines expects to make a loss in 2016
AirFinance Journal
June 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: AIRCRAFT,AIRLINES,LESSORS,PEOPLE NEWS,BREAKING NEWS,DEALS,MALAYSIA,ASIA
Length: 520 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Highlight: Restructuring Malaysian flag carrier says loss will be smaller than initially budgeted.
Body
Malaysia Airlines, which is undergoing financial restructuring process, expects to report a loss for fiscal year 2016, 
according to a statement from the airline.
It adds, however, that the loss would be "significantly smaller than initially budgeted at the beginning of the year, 
and ahead of the turnaround plan for the airline to be sustainably profitable by 2018".
In the first quarter, revenue was down 21.7%, while ASK (available seat kilometres) decreased 30.2%. Average 
yield per passenger rose 23.4% against the same quarter in 2015, but the overall load factor of 68.9% was lower, 
though is now "trending upward".
"The market environment is showing strong signs of improvement in China and North Asia. Route profitability also 
improved in Australasia, although demand in certain markets remains week," the airline says.
The airline has ordered two additional Airbus A350-900s, adding to the original four it has on order. This is to "reach 
a critical fleet size which allows for scheduled maintenance and future network expansion".
Malaysia Airlines says preparation for the introduction of these aircraft, planned for late 2017, is ahead of schedule 
with initial pilot and engineering training "well underway".
This year, all the airline's A380s will undergo a C-check, which will be performed in-house for the first time.
"Even though personal circumstances mean I will not complete my full term as chief executive, I am confident that 
the foundations are now in place for the national carrier to achieve sustainable profitability in the stated timeframe 
and regain its rightful place as a symbol of national pride," says Christoph Mueller, the airline's chief.
Malaysia Airlines says Mueller has expressed a desire to continue to remain on the board of directors as a non-
executive director "if circumstances permit". The airline's board has appointed current chief operating officer and 
former Ryanair executive Peter Bellew as executive director of the board with immediate effect "[i]n order to 
facilitate a smooth transition" when Mueller leaves.
Malaysia Airlines expects to make a loss in 2016
Although Mueller "" who is serving out a six-month notice period after announcing his resignation in April "" has not 
publicly disclosed where he will work next, an unconfirmed report by German-language publication Manager 
Magazin dated 26 June says that he will join Dubai-based carrier Emirates as its chief innovation officer in charge of 
"digitalisation". Airfinance Journal could not verify the report at the time of going to press.
As part of its restructuring, Malaysia Airlines is reducing its fleet and optimising routes. The old company Malaysian 
Airline System (MAS) sub-leased all its aircraft to a newly created company Malaysian Airlines Berhad (MAB). 
Banks and lessors with exposure to Malaysia Airlines were asked last year to consent to the proposal and the 
airline has been in negotiations with its creditors to try to secure reductions in lease rentals and loan principal 
payments, as well as the return of some aircraft.
To see all of Malaysia Airlines' recent and historic deals visitAirfinance Journal's Deals Database.
Michael.Allen@euromoneyplc.com
