Ryanair opens new European training center in London Stansted Airport
Ryanair opens new European training center in London Stansted Airport
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
June 1, 2016 Wednesday 12:36 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 676 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd., an Irish airline, has opened its new European training center in London Stansted Airport.
Body
Ryanair confirmed that it will create over 1,000 new jobs for pilots, cabin crew, and engineers in 2016, more than 
450 of which will be located at Ryanair's 13 UK airport bases to support its 14 new Boeing 737-800 aircraft, an 
investment of over $1.4bn in the British economy. These new jobs will bring to more than 3,500 well paid aviation 
professionals that Ryanair employs directly in Britain, in addition to sustaining thousands of support jobs at 
Ryanair's 18 UK airports. Welcoming the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Rt Hon George Osborne MP, to its new 
European Training Centre today, Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary called for a strong "Remain" vote in the European 
Referendum on 23rd June next. Ryanair believes that Britain's economy will be stronger if it remains part of the 
European Union because: This will lead to more UK jobs and stronger economic growth; It will encourage more 
foreign inward investment in the UK of exactly the type that Ryanair has announced today; The EU single market 
has created the low fare air travel revolution which has transformed UK tourism and jobs; Prime Minister Cameron 
has negotiated significant reforms to protect Sterling, limit immigration, and prevent Britain from being dragged into 
closer Union while reducing bureaucracy for British businesses; and UK foreign inward investment will be lost to 
competitor EU member states such as Ireland and Germany if Britain votes to leave the European Union. 
Speaking at London Stansted Airport, Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said: "We are pleased to welcome Chancellor 
Osborne to open our new European Training Centre which now includes 4 flight simulators, a full aircraft interior for 
cabin crew training, and an industry leading full scale engineering training aircraft. These new facilities will allow 
Ryanair to recruit and train over 1,000 pilots, cabin crew and engineers in 2016, and many of these jobs will be 
based across Ryanair's 13 UK based airports, where we are adding 14 new aircraft, and growing our UK traffic from 
36m passengers to 41m passengers in 2016. "It is this type of large scale foreign inward investment that is helping 
to drive the UK economy and job creation. It is exactly this type of investment that will be lost to other competitor EU 
members if the UK votes to leave the European Union. The single market has enabled Ryanair to lead the low fare 
air travel revolution in Europe, as we bring millions of British citizens to Europe each year, and welcome millions of 
European visitors to Britain, and we are calling on everyone to turn out in large numbers and vote "Remain" on the 
23rd June. I am absolutely certain that the UK economy is better off in Europe, and that is why Ryanair is 
Ryanair opens new European training center in London Stansted Airport
campaigning hard and actively calling on UK voters to vote "Remain" on the 23rd June." Charlie Cornish, Chief 
Executive of MAG, owner of London Stansted Airport, said: "I'm delighted Ryanair has chosen London Stansted 
Airport as the base for its new training and engineering facilities, particularly at a time when both businesses are 
seeing significant growth. "Together, London Stansted and Ryanair have been at the forefront of the European air 
travel revolution of the last 20 years. When Ryanair first started flying from London Stansted, passengers had a 
choice of just a dozen EU destinations but this morning they can choose from over 140 EU destinations, more than 
at any other UK airport. As competition has strengthened, airlines have become more efficient, air fares have fallen, 
and choice has increased. By opening up the European travel market to competition, the EU has done far more for 
British consumers and businesses than any government could ever have done acting on its own. "London Stansted 
delivers more European visitors into London than any other airport, generating a significant economic boost to 
London's economy and UK PLC. Leaving the EU would undoubtedly be a huge backward step for UK aviation, a 
sector that employs around 1 million people and supports some of our most successful and innovative industries."

AirFinance Journal

Highlight: Flag carrier receives 2009-vintage 737 from the aircraft lessor.
Body
SMBC Aviation Capital (SMBC AC) has placed its first aircraft with Ukraine International Airlines (UIA), according to 
an announcement.
The placement of the Boeing 737-800 is the first leasing agreement between the lessor and the airline.
According to theAirfinance Fleet Analystdatabase,the 2009-vintage aircraft (MSN 35005) was previously on lease to 
Ryanair. Records indicate that Ryanair ordered the aircraft and then leased it from SMBC AC under a sale 
leaseback agreement.
A spokesperson for SMBC AC confirmed that the aircraft is the first from a lease agreement for three Boeing 737-
800s with UIA. The other two aircraft are scheduled for delivery in July and September.
The spokesperson declined to reveal more about the lease length. UIA did not immediately respond to a request for 
more details.

Beaufort Securities Reaffirms Buy Rating for Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Beaufort Securities Reaffirms Buy Rating for Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Watchlist News
May 31, 2016 Tuesday 8:16 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 573 words
Byline: Mark Dietrich
Body
May 31, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)            
http://www.watchlistnews.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgBeaufort Securities reissued their buy rating on 
shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) in a research note released on Wednesday. RYAAY has been 
the topic of several other research reports. 
Zacks Investment Research upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a hold rating to a strong-buy rating and 
set a $95.00 target price on the stock in a report on Saturday, April 16th. Raymond James raised their target price 
on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc to $100.00 in a report on Friday, March 25th. Finally, Vetr[1] cut shares of 
Ryanair Holdings plc from a strong-buy rating to a buy rating and set a $83.00 target price on the stock. in a report 
on Wednesday, February 10th. One research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, four have given a hold 
rating and five have given a buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair Holdings plc has a consensus rating of Hold 
and a consensus price target of $94.50. Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) opened at 85.91 on 
Wednesday. The stock's 50 day moving average is $81.08 and its 200 day moving average is $82.09. The 
company has a market capitalization of $22.53 billion and a PE ratio of 13.24. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1-year 
low of $67.89 and a 1-year high of $88.24. Several hedge funds have made changes to their positions in RYAAY.

Michael Murray: Ryanair well placed for decent growth
Michael Murray: Ryanair well placed for decent growth
Sunday Business Post
May 29, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1432 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: Carrier looks in a good place despite intensifying competition and risk of excess capacity
Body
As businesses reach maturity, management often struggle to find profitable new pathways to growth - especially 
when competition is intensifying. A common ‘solution’ to this problem has been for a company to try to sustain 
earnings per share growth by buying back its own shares. But Ryanair’s latest share buyback programme was not 
motivated by lack of growth opportunities. 
Half of the most recent buyback proceeds came from the sale of its minority stake in Aer Lingus, the rest from the 
superior margins and handsome cashflow returns on capital employed being generated by the core business. Its 
share buybacks are being run in parallel with the continued build up of the fleet with – remarkably – no net gearing 
on the balance sheet at present. 
Many Ryanair watchers think, and some (mainly anti-private sector ideologues) hope, that there will be a stop to the 
gallop of this fantastically successful airline and its brash chief executive. But chief executive Michael O’Leary 
exposed more effectively than any other organisation or individual just how massively inefficient the former state-
owned Aer Lingus was, and the huge waste of taxpayers’ funds it engaged in over decades before the late Tony 
Ryan’s low-cost carrier came on the scene and his highly competitive pressure forced change. 
No economy benefited more than Ireland’s from Ryanair’s success, as inward and outbound travel on a large and 
widely affordable scale became a reality, generating huge increases in economic activity. Our rival state airline – 
after 50 years of gross inefficiency and sucking cash from the taxpayer – was forced to shape up. 
Aer Lingus, happily, is no longer owned by the taxpayer, and is no longer listed on the stock market either. Instead 
it has been swallowed up by its former and most effective-ever boss Willie Walsh, now at IAG. Only the Aer Lingus 
brand, legacy aircraft and routes are left, and Ryanair shareholders (by virtue of their former minority stake) have 
benefited handsomely from its sale to IAG. 
Michael Murray: Ryanair well placed for decent growth
While Ryanair continues to excel, elephants don’t gallop. With a market capitalisation of €17.7 billion, it is now three 
times the size of EasyJet, and 15 times the size of Eastern European airline Wizz Air. It is about 25 per cent bigger 
than international airline group IAG, the acquirer of Aer Lingus. 
Having propelled itself from nothing over 35 years to this position, its next growth phase cannot be as it was from 
the much smaller base of even a decade ago – notwithstanding consistently improving its business model and 
leaving no stone unturned for new ways to drive revenue growth, improve customer experience and load factors 
and drive costs out of the business through technology, purchasing power, scale economies, low operating costs 
and a low maintenance cost, fuel-efficient fleet. 
At last week’s results announcement, Michael O’Leary, side by side with his equally formidable chief financial officer 
Neil Sorohan, had plenty to announce in terms of both the short and medium-term outlook – on costs, on revenues, 
on fleet capacity, on marketing initiatives, and on new routes to fuel future growth – much of it to come from the 
emerging markets of Eastern Europe where Wizz Air is the main, but much smaller competitor, in the low-cost 
space. 
So here are the essential elements of the recent initiatives and the business plan that is intended to underpin the 
company’s medium-term growth prospects and with it the share price – which doesn’t look rich relative either to last 
year’s earnings, prospective earnings, or stock market ratings as a whole. 
1.  Its access to new airports: Ryanair continues to open new routes across Europe and retains ambitious growth 
plans, in particular through new emerging Eastern European routes. 
2.  Increasing penetration of main airports: Historically, Ryanair was confined to many peripheral airports at a good 
distance from the major cities. This limited its appeal to the business traveller where travel time from airport to city 
centre was a key driver of choice. But as Ryanair continues to penetrate the main ‘nearer-to-city’ airports, its appeal 
to the higher margin business traveller rises and the revenue from that market segment should rise with it. 
3.  Its increased market segmentation, facilitated by that rising proportion of business travellers, is also now a driver 
of new ancillary earnings – from options on premium seat choice, on priority boarding, and other mainly technology-
driven revenue enhancers made more accessible to the customer through the new Ryanair apps, with car and hotel 
bookings easily executed along with flights and boarding passes. This is driving ancillary revenues as well as 
facilitating more efficient targeted marketing at lower cost. 
4.  Its fleet acquisition programme will increase the fleet numbers by 16 per cent and deliver a step change in 
performance in cost and scale economies. More fuel efficient consumption and seating capacity rising from the 
current 189 per aircraft in the existing core fleet to 197 seats in the new, will spread both the lower fixed and 
variable operating costs over a larger passenger base. However, caution is needed here. Competitors also have 
significant orders for new capacity over the next six years. If deliveries coincide with a downturn in what is after all a 
cyclical industry, load factors, pricing power and earnings could suffer significantly. That said, Ryanair’s financial 
strength and cost advantages over rivals should leave the company nicely placed to squeeze some of the 
competition out. 
5.  Its oil price hedging: Ryanair’s recent trading performance has to be viewed in the context of unfavourable fuel 
hedging relative to competitors. Fuel was hedged over the last 12 months at $90 per barrel, but is now 95 per cent 
hedged at $62, and 44 per cent hedged to full year 2018 at $50. Savings of $360 million from the hedging 
programme are estimated in total. 
     On all other metrics, Ryanair continued to improve its cost performance relative to the competition and to 
achieve meaningfully higher load factors (around 93 per cent versus below 90 per cent or lower for the competition). 
Last year, costs per seat fell by 2 per cent (excluding fuel), beating the competition. Now that the unfavourable fuel 
price hedges have substantially run their course, the new forward hedged fuel prices for 2017 and 2018 and the 
dollar aircraft purchases hedged at $1.31 are set to deliver substantial cost savings relative to recent years. 
Michael Murray: Ryanair well placed for decent growth
6.  An ungeared balance sheet on a net basis and long-term fixed rate bonds provides cheap funding over the 
medium to long term. The balance sheet muscle will be critical in the event of a downturn in the industry (induced 
perhaps by a combination of excess capacity from new fleet deliveries across the sector coinciding with a slowdown 
in macroeconomic growth). 
7.  The company’s ‘always getting better’ programme is broadening its appeal beyond the cost-conscious traveller 
in terms of airport accessibility, segmented business customer offerings, winning metrics in on-time arrivals and the 
lowest lost baggage figures of all the European airlines. The rise of the business traveller on Ryanair, aside from 
boosting overall margins is also important for driving growth in ancillary revenues and increased access to main city 
airports should continue to be a growth driver as well as the company’s plans for many more route openings in 
Eastern Europe. 
8.  Ryanair’s management team is proven in terms of its experience and success with a strong corporate culture in 
keeping with the no nonsense ethos of its chief executive. 
While there are all of these positives, the company is not understating the risks. Fare reductions this year are 
estimated at 7 per cent in an endeavour to sustain load factors at the market beating 93 per cent. But with fuel costs 
now substantially down from the elevated hedged levels, the company has guided a post tax earnings rise of 13 per 
cent, notwithstanding the fare reductions. However, it acknowledges that disruption by air traffic controllers or a 
repeat of terrorist attacks could upset this guidance. 
Ryanair’s financial strength and market power are a significant comfort and I see its current modest low teens price 
earnings ratio as a potentially attractive level at which to top up my currently modest holding. But I will wait to see 
how the French air traffic controllers behave in coming weeks before jumping in. 
Ryanair By the numbers
€1,242m:Profit after tax for year to March 31 
106.4m: Customer numbers for year to March 31 
€46.67: Average fare
Load-Date: May 30, 2016
End of Document

Low fuel costs and higher volumes lift Wizz Air Airlines
Low fuel costs and higher volumes lift Wizz Air; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
May 26, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 20
Length: 359 words
Byline: Andrew Byrne in Budapest
Body
Low fuel costs and increased volumes lifted profits at Wizz Air to record levels as the company forecast further rises 
in profit in 2017 despite heightened price competition.
The UK-listed Hungarian airline yesterday reported adjusted net profit for the year ending in March at EUR224m, up 
53 per cent from the previous year, and ahead of the company's March forecast of EUR200m-EUR210m.
The airline's profit measure excludes currency moves and exceptional items.
The airline carried a record 20m passengers - a 21 per cent rise - while revenue rose 16 per cent to EUR1.43bn. 
Earnings were lifted by lower fuel prices and increased volumes.
Jozsef Varadi , Wizz Air founder and chief executive, pledged that the company would do "whatever it takes" to 
remain competitive on pricing as the airline faced a period of increased competition with Ryanair, which also 
reported increased profits this week.
Wizz Air's Dublin-based rival, which carried more than 100m passengers in the last year, is planning to base a 
further nine aircraft in central and eastern Europe this year, foreshadowing an increased race to capture the 
region's 300m consumers.
Low fuel costs and higher volumes lift Wizz Air Airlines
Mr Varadi said the airline had matched Ryanair on costs. "Whatever the market demands to remain competitive, we 
will do it. Our unit costs will decline by 5 per cent thanks to lower fuel prices and flat unit costs."
The carrier is one of the fastest-growing members of a breed of low-cost airlines like Norwegian, which are offering 
greater competition to legacy carriers and Ryanair.
The company floated on the London Stock Exchange at the start of 2015, with an initial price of £14.50 per share. 
The shares were trading at £19.91 by early afternoon yesterday.
The carrier has set a profit target range of between EUR245m and EUR255m for the year to March 2017, although 
it added that the guidance was "heavily caveated" by how it performed in the second half.
Analysts said the airline's stronger than expected revenue performance in Q4 2016 suggested that profit guidance 
for 2017 was conservative. But they warned that Wizz faced several risks, including the possibility that Britain would 
leave the European Union.
Load-Date: May 25, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair announces two new routes from Luxembourg
Ryanair announces two new routes from Luxembourg
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 26, 2016 Thursday 11:04 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 265 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced its first Luxembourg flights, with two new routes, one daily to London Stansted 
and other five times a week to Porto starting from September 2016, which will deliver 200,000 customers per 
annum at Luxembourg Airport.
Body
Ryanair celebrated its new Luxembourg flights by releasing seats for sale at prices starting from just E19.99 for 
travel in September, which are available for booking until midnight Monday (23 May). In Luxembourg, Ryanair's 
Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair is pleased to announce that low fares have arrived in 
Luxembourg, our 33rd country of operation, with 2 new routes to London Stansted and Porto, beginning in 
September, which will help deliver 200,000 annual customers at Luxembourg Airport. Our London and Porto routes 
will be ideal for both business and leisure customers, who can enjoy the benefits of Ryanair's "Always Getting 
Better" programme, which includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low 
fares. "To celebrate our new Luxembourg routes, we are releasing seats to London Stansted and Porto from just 
E19.99 for travel in September, which are available for booking until midnight Monday (23 May). Since these 
amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
Luxembourg Airport President & CEO, Johann Venneste said: "There has been a lot of speculation about the arrival 
of Ryanair at Luxembourg Airport; now we can finally confirm the airline has decided to serve Luxembourg. 2016 is 
becoming a very successful year for our airport and Ryanair is the 5th new airline to decide to fly from Luxembourg 
this year. Passengers now have a very wide choice of 70 destinations served directly by a selection of full service 
airlines and low fare airlines."

Ryanair to open new base at Prague Airport
Ryanair to open new base at Prague Airport
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 25, 2016 Wednesday 1:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 352 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced it will open a new base at Prague Airport, from October 30, 2016, with two 
aircraft and two new routes to Milan and Rome, which will deliver 625,000 customers per annum and support 470 
jobs at Prague Airport.
Body
Ryanair's Prague winter 2016 schedule will deliver: 2 based aircraft ($200m); 2 new routes to: Milan B (daily) & 
Rome C (daily); 5 routes in total incl. Brussels C (9 wkly), Dublin (daily) and London (2 x daily); Over 40 weekly 
flights; 625,000 customers p.a. (+100,000); and 470 "on-site" jobs p.a. In Prague, Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, 
Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to announce our first Czech base at Prague (No.84) from 30th October with 2 
based aircraft, (an investment of $200m) and 2 new routes to Milan and Rome, which will deliver 625,000 
customers p.a. and support 470 jobs at Prague Airport. "This growth is an integral part of our continued expansion 
plans for both the Czech Republic and Eastern Europe, as we connect Prague with Europe's key centres of 
business with high frequency business-friendly services, including a double daily service to London and a daily 
route to Dublin, making Ryanair the ideal choice for both business and leisure customers. 
"Our 106m customers can look forward to further improvements, as we continue our "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, a new app, new cabin interiors and new crew uniforms "To celebrate 
the launch of our new Prague base, we are releasing seats for sale from just 639 CZK, which are available for 
booking until Monday (11 Apr) for travel in May and June. Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up 
quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Jirii Vyskoc, Prague Airport Aviation 
Business Director, commented: "We are pleased that Ryanair keeps expanding its aviation business at Vaclav 
Havel Airport Prague. With nearly half a million passengers transported a year, the carrier ranks among the largest 
top 5 airlines in Prague. The plan to launch 2 new routes to Milan and Rome from Prague confirms both the 
continued interest of foreign tourists in trips to Prague and the positive trend of a growing share of Czech travellers 
at Vaclav Havel Airport Prague. Establishing Ryanair's base confirms this trend and we expect Czech passenger 
numbers to continue growing."

Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA) Receives 'Buy' Rating from Beaufort Securities
Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA) Receives 'Buy' Rating from Beaufort Securities
Watchlist News
May 24, 2016 Tuesday 9:39 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 206 words
Byline: Nicole Kennedy
Body
May 24, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Ryanair Holdings Plc 
(LON:RYA)'s stock had its 'buy' rating reiterated by equities researchers at Beaufort Securities in a research note 
issued on Tuesday. Shares of Ryanair Holdings Plc (LON:RYA) opened at 13.6000 on Tuesday. The company has

is GBX 17.94 billion. Ryanair Holdings Plc has a 1-year low of GBX 11.39 and a 1-year high of GBX 15.59. Ryanair

Ryanair promise on low fares sets off a price war
Ryanair promise on low fares sets off a price war
City A.M.
May 24, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 6
Length: 210 words
Byline: FRANCESCA WASHTELL
Body
BUDGET airline Ryanair missed expectations in its full-year profits yesterday, as the impact of terrorist attacks on 
bookings and low oil prices began to take their toll.
But the no-frills carrier said it will respond by cutting fares by seven per cent, adjusting to a market in which lower 
airfare prices are required in an era of unrelentingly cheap oil.
Rival airlines including British Airways owner International Airlines Group have warned of increasing competition on 
airfares to ensure flights stay full.
Ryanair's adjusted net profits came in at (EURO)1.24bn (£961m) for the 52 weeks to 31 March, a 43 per cent 
increase on the previous year, although this missed analysts' estimate of (EURO)1.3bn. However, the company's 
results were in line with its own forecasts.
Revenue was up 16 per cent at (EURO)6.54bn, which was marginally below analysts' forecasts of (EURO)6.55bn.
Ryanair said its Easter bookings had been adversely impacted by more than 500 flight cancellations following the 
Brussels terrorists attack and repeated, mostly French, traffic controller strikes.
The airline has warned its first quarter yields will also be hit negatively by cancellations, lower airfares, the early 
Easter and sterling weakness in the run up to the referendum in June.
Load-Date: May 24, 2016
Ryanair promise on low fares sets off a price war

Brexit threatens London's world beating tourism industry: Don't let the capital become a museum
Brexit threatens London's world beating tourism industry: Don't let the 
capital become a museum
City A.M.
May 24, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 21
Length: 629 words
Byline: Matt Hill
Body
TOURISM is one of our biggest exports - and London is the most-visited city on earth. But the industry is worried 
that this world-beating ranking could be at risk if Britain cuts itself off from Europe.
In fact, Europe is our biggest tourist market, with more than 60 per cent of visitors to the UK coming from the EU. 
Nearly three-quarters of business visitors come from the continent. So anything that encourages those visitors to 
think of other destinations is a concern for London's hotels, flagship stores and attractions.
Of course, we'll still be physically in the same location. The appeal of the capital's iconic sights, unparalleled 
heritage and vibrant West End would still exist. So why should EU status matter? In short, the EU has enabled 
lowcost, low-hassle travel. This has boosted the income generated from tourists travelling to London, and enabled 
British tourism firms to sell more not just to Brits but to the whole of Europe. Brexit would hurt the domestic tourism 
industry and our global tourism brands because it would, over time, increase friction - creating annoyances and 
costs (such as new visa requirements) that would make travel less appealing, and constrain access for UK 
businesses. Take air travel. Without the work of the EU, cheap flights across Europe would never have happened. 
The EU's liberalisation of Europe's airspace has led to the rapid growth of lowcost airlines - including UK companies 
like EasyJet, but also those like Ryanair which have put London at the heart of their networks.
These low-cost flights have fuelled British businesses' expansions, making it more affordable for smaller firms to 
visit prospective continental customers. They have also brought Europe to London, underpinning the £9.6bn spent 
in the UK by EU tourists every year.
Brexit threatens London's world beating tourism industry: Don't let the capital become a museum
A similar Open Skies deal with the US is only beginning to realise its potential. When further liberalisation between 
the EU and the rest of the world occurs, do we want to be part of that deal, or find ourselves excluded? There's 
another hit the tourism industry would face. Outside the EU, we'd see downward pressure on disposable incomes 
as the UK economy struggles with the consequences of Brexit - putting expenditure on nonessential leisure travel at 
risk, as well as impacting London's high value business travel market.
Meanwhile, the protectionist, antiimmigration rhetoric of Brexit campaigners shows we could face draconian and 
economically illiterate restrictions on workers from outside the UK. This would be horrendous for hotels and 
attractions at peak times of year.
Tourism has been able to grow so rapidly, and contribute so much in tax revenues and jobs for British workers, 
because the industry has also had access to a huge pool of European hospitality talent and can hire people to meet 
seasonal demand or fill skilled vacancies. This is a difficult argument to make in public, but it has the merit of being 
true. It's also worth bearing in mind that plenty of young Londoners gain experience by working in the Med's tourism 
resorts.
Finally, there is a real danger that lucrative business travel to London could fall into long-term decline. That's 
because the capital is currently the place global businesses want to put either their global or European 
headquarters. Outside the EU, we would start to see businesses locate their HQs in Paris, Berlin and Amsterdam. 
This would result in less investment in hotels, retail and attractions in London - and we'd see British workers losing 
their jobs.
Access to Europe has made London a world leader in business travel, flight networks, and global brands as well as 
tourist spending. London will always be a great historic city. We mustn't let it become a museum.
£ Matt Hill is tourism and retail director of London First.
Load-Date: May 24, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair expects reduced fares after EgyptAir crash Airlines
Ryanair expects reduced fares after EgyptAir crash; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
May 24, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 21
Length: 707 words
Byline: Jennifer Thompson, Lauren Fedor and Peggy Hollinger
Highlight: O'Leary comments set to intensify pressure on higher-cost legacy carriers
Body
The crash of an EgyptAir jet killing 66 people last week will help drive down fares this summer as airlines try to lure 
passengers with price cuts, according to Michael O'Leary , chief executive of the low-cost carrier Ryanair.
"Regardless of the outcome of the investigation into EgyptAir . . . it will mean lower prices through the June quarter 
and probably into the September quarter," he said.
Terrorist attacks "tend to hit our pricing over the next three to five months".
This summer prices could fall 2-3 per cent, he said, though some of the reduction was also due to the benefits of 
lower fuel costs being passed on to customers.
Mr O'Leary also said that Ryanair's push across Europe would contribute to a 7 per cent fall in prices this year.
The Ryanair boss's comments are likely to step up the pressure on higher-cost legacy carriers. Air France-KLM, 
Lufthansa, British Airways and Iberia have all either cut back on certain routes or voiced concerns over a glut of 
capacity this summer.
But Mr O'Leary insisted that Ryanair would expand its offering and pass on to customers the savings made by the 
arrival of more fuel-efficient, aircraft.
Ryanair expects reduced fares after EgyptAir crash Airlines
"We are shovelling loads of capacity into their markets where [the legacy airlines] are not able to compete on 
costs," Mr O'Leary said.
Yet even Ryanair appears to be curtailing its ambitions for expansion.
Capacity growth for the year to the end of March 2017 is expected to halve to 9 per cent. Europe's biggest low-cost 
airline indicated that net profits in 2017 would come in between EUR1.38bn and EUR1.43bn - slightly below 
consensus forecasts of EUR1.47bn.
Mr O'Leary insisted that the slowdown would not affect Ryanair's ability to continue cutting fares. The group's new 
Boeing 737 single-aisle jets would raise seating capacity 4 per cent and save 16 per cent on fuel cost per 
passenger.
"We will grow the fleet from 341 aircraft last year to almost 550 by 2024," he said. "That underwrites our ability to 
lower airfares for every one of the next eight years. We are putting more pressure on competition out there."
Nevertheless, analysts warned that this could be a difficult year for airlines in Europe struggling with repeated 
strikes, despite lower fuel prices.
"Summer 2017, especially the second quarter, faces significant capacity [over]supply in the European market," said 
Damian Brewer of RBC Capital Markets.
On top of that, bookings have been hurt by terror attacks in Belgium and Paris at a time when carriers are 
expanding capacity with new aircraft. Iata, the industry group, noted this month that capacity growth had exceeded 
passenger traffic in February and March this year. Concerns are mounting that airlines may be expanding too 
quickly into a market that is growing at a slower rate.
"Faster capacity growth is the inevitable consequence of cheaper fuel," said Gerald Khoo, transport analyst at 
Liberum. "Lower costs encourage airlines to add more capacity, or cut less, than they would otherwise have done. 
This puts downward pressure on pricing, which will inevitably result in financially weaker airlines having to 
eventually revise their plans."
Ryanair said annual profits after tax increased 43 per cent, to EUR1.24bn, in the year to the end of March. Revenue 
was EUR6.54bn, up 16 per cent on the year and just below analysts' forecasts of EUR6.55bn.
Mr O'Leary said Ryanair continued to rein in costs, with more than half of its 2018 fuel costs already hedged at $50 
a barrel. Senior and middle management had also agreed to a pay freeze for 12 months, while pilots and cabin 
crew had agreed a five-year productivity plan.
"There was evidence of non-fuel unit costs coming under control, suggesting that the 1 per cent reduction target for 
this year may be credible," said Mr Khoo.
Ryanair's net profits were helped by a EUR398m gain on the sale of its stake in Aer Lingus to International Airlines 
Group, owner of British Airways and Iberia.
Ryanair said it was "actively campaigning" for Britain to remain in the EU. "Ryanair strongly believes that the UK 
economy and its future growth prospects are stronger if it remains a member of the European Union."
Mr O'Leary warned last week that the group would cut back on investment in Britain if the UK left the single market.
Load-Date: May 23, 2016
End of Document

Body
PRIME Minister David Cameron will today highlight the potential increase in travel costs if Britain were to leave the 
European Union.
Cameron, who will be seen standing in front of a plane with EasyJet boss Carolyn McCall, is set to discuss the 
Treasury's recent warn-ing that Brexit would make Britain poorer by the equivalent of £4,300 per household by 
2030 and every year thereafter. The report also warned that a vote to leave would push the UK economy into a 
recession and lead to an increase in unemployment of around 500,000.
Cameron is set to warn that an exit from the EU would lead to the pound depreciating, resulting in the cost of travel 
rising.
Last week, chancellor George Osborne joined Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary to take a stand against Brexit.

Ryanair posts record 2016 profit, sees lower summer fares
Ryanair posts record 2016 profit, sees lower summer fares
Associated Press Financial Wire
May 23, 2016 Monday 2:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 391 words
Byline: By SHAWN POGATCHNIK, Associated Press
Dateline: DUBLIN 
Body
DUBLIN (AP) - European budget carrier Ryanair has posted record full-year profits and passenger figures, and 
expects both to hit new highs this summer amid rapid growth and declining fares.
Monday's results for the year ending March 31 showed the Dublin-based airline strengthening on every front. Net 
profit before exceptional gains rose 43 percent to 1.24 billion euros ($1.4 billion) and the percentage of seats sold 
rose 5 points to 93 percent. Total sales rose 16 percent to 6.54 billion euros and the overall number of passengers 
for the year rose 18 percent to 106.4 million.
Chief Executive Michael O'Leary says Ryanair expects average fares to fall around 6 percent this summer and 
even more in winter amid increased competition and well-hedged fuel costs. He says Ryanair should carry 116 
million passengers and record a minimum net profit in 2017 of 1.38 billion euros, 11 percent higher than Monday's 
record figure. Analysts expect Ryanair to beat that forecast by at least 100 million euros.
O'Leary said Ryanair foresees its fleet of Boeing 737-800s growing this year by 53 aircraft to reach 380 as the 
airline expands eastward with seven new bases including Bucharest, Romania; Prague, Czech Republic; Sofia, 
Bulgaria, and the German cities of Hamburg and Nuremberg. Ryanair already is central to western Europe's short-
haul traffic with the biggest market share in Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Poland and Spain. It's No. 3 in Germany and 
France and No. 2 in Britain where it's battling to dethrone budget rival easyJet.
Ryanair shares rose 2.4 percent in afternoon Dublin trading to 13.53 euros.
Monday's net profit excluded an exceptional gain of 317.5 million euros from Ryanair's November sale of its stake in 
rival Irish carrier Aer Lingus to IAG, the parent of British Airways. Ryanair launched three hostile bids for Aer Lingus 
that faced opposition from competition regulators, the Irish government and labor unions.
Analysts credit Ryanair's 2013 decision to start improving customer service and broadening its product range as 
critical in driving its latest growth. A business previously infamous for surprise extra charges and cut-throat 
inflexibility now offers smoother online sales, family and business tickets, more relaxed baggage rules and better 
space on its new Boeing models.
Ryanair posts record 2016 profit, sees lower summer fares

Ryanair FY16 Profit Climbs; Says Cautiously Expects Modest Profit Growth
Ryanair FY16 Profit Climbs; Says Cautiously Expects Modest Profit Growth
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
May 23, 2016 Monday 8:31 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 253 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that its fiscal 2016 profit 
before tax grew 43 percent to 1.72 billion euros from 982.4 million euros last year. Earnings per share were 115.63 
euros, higher than 62.46 euros last year. 
 The latest results included exceptional accounting gain of 317.5 million euros on sale of Aer Lingus shareholding.  
Adjusted pre-tax profit was 1.40 billion euros and adjusted attributable profit was 1.24 billion euros or 92.08 euros 
per share.  Revenues for the year climbed 16 percent to 6.54 billion euros from 5.65 billion euros a year ago. 
Scheduled revenues grew 17 percent and Ancillary revenues grew 13 percent.  Traffic went up 18 percent to 106.4 
million customers as load factor grew 5 percent to 93 percent.   Unit costs fell 6 percent, while it was down 2 
percent ex-fuel. Average fare dropped 1 percent.  The company noted that the fourth quarter yields on close-in 
Easter bookings were adversely impacted by over 500 flight cancellations following the Brussels terrorist attacks 
and repeated (mainly French) ATC strikes.  Looking ahead, the company said it cautiously expects full year net 
profit to rise modestly, by approximately 13 percent, to a range of 1.375 billion euros to 1.425 billion euros.  This 
guidance remains heavily dependent on the strength of close-in summer bookings and next winter's yields, the 
strength of Sterling and the absence of any further external shocks or significant ATC strikes/cancellations.

Ryanair plans sharp cuts to ticket prices as 'fare war' looms Ryanair plans s...
Ryanair plans sharp cuts to ticket prices as 'fare war' looms; Ryanair plans 
s...
Business World (Digest)
May 23, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 293 words
Highlight: Irish low-cost giant Ryanair plans to cut fares sharply in coming months, but said it expects to boost 
profit by boosting its share of an increasingly competitive European short-haul market.
Body
Irish low-cost giant Ryanair plans to cut fares sharply in coming months, but said it expects to boost profit by 
boosting its share of an increasingly competitive European short-haul market.
The airline, Europe's largest by passenger numbers, outlined the planned cut to fares on Monday as it reported net 
profit of 1.24 billion euros (dollar 1.39 billion) for the year ended March 2016, an increase of 43 percent on the 
previous year.
Fares will fall by an average of 7 percent in its current financial year, which ends on March 31, with fares falling by 
between 10 and 12 percent in the winter months, chief executive Michael O'Leary said.
"If there is a fare war in Europe, then Ryanair will be the winner," he said in a video presentation. Ryanair expects 
to carry 116 million passengers in the year to March, an annual increase of 9 percent. Ryanair said in a statement it 
"cautiously" expected net profit to increase by approximately 13 percent in the year to March 2017, to between 1.38 
billion euros and 1.43 billion euros, less than the consensus of 1.47 billion in a poll of over 10 analysts compiled by 
the company ahead of the results. Rivals including British Airways-owner IAG, Lufthansa and Air France-KLM have 
warned recently about increasing capacity in the sector and the impact on tourism from militant attacks in Paris and 
Brussels. easyJet earlier this month said strong demand for beach holidays was making up for a drop in travelling in 
the wake of the attacks. Ryanair shares closed Friday up 20 percent compared to a year ago at 13.16 euros, while 
the Thomson Reuters European Airline Index was down 3 percent. Ryanair shares have fallen 12 percent since the 
start of the year, in line with the index.(Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

European Markets Weakened At The Start Of The New Week
European Markets Weakened At The Start Of The New Week
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
May 23, 2016 Monday 5:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 746 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - The European markets ended the first session of the new trading week with modest 
losses. The markets briefly turned positive this morning, but traded in negative territory for the majority of the 
session. The European markets logged their largest increase in a month at the end of the previous week, leading 
investors to take some profits.  Traders were disappointed by the unexpected decrease in Eurozone private sector 
data Monday. 
Commodity prices also struggled at the start of the week, as the U.S. dollar strengthened.   The risks of a de-
anchoring of inflation expectations to below 1 percent or close to zero in the euro area have increased and hence, 
the central bank acted forcefully, ECB Executive Board member Peter Praet said in an interview to a newspaper, 
published Monday.   'We have seen in some countries some signs of de-anchoring in wage formation, Praet said in 
an interview with the Portuguese daily Publico.   'But, this being said, we haven't concluded that inflation 
expectations are de-anchored.'  The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip stocks decreased 0.99 percent, 
while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major U.K. companies, lost 0.46 percent.  The DAX of 
Germany dropped 0.74 percent and the CAC 40 of France fell 0.66 percent. The FTSE 100 of the U.K. declined 
0.14 percent and the SMI of Switzerland finished higher by 0.51 percent.  In Frankfurt, pharmaceutical and 
chemicals giant Bayer fell 5.72 percent after making an all-cash offer to acquire U.S. agrochemicals firm Monsanto 
Co. for $62 billion.  Nordex lost 1.66 percent despite reporting a rise in Q1 profit and sales.  Aixtron soared 16.21 
percent. China's Fujian Grand Chip Investment Fund LP said it would make a voluntary public takeover offer to buy 
the German semiconductor equipment maker for about 670 million euros ($752 million), including net cash.  
Daimler dropped 1.57 percent and BMW weakened by 0.93 percent. Volkswagen also slipped 0.58 percent.  In 
Paris, Peugeot surrendered 1.06 percent and Renault lost 1.14 percent.   In London, Inmarsat decreased 4.04 
percent after Morgan Stanley downgraded its rating on the stock to 'Equal weight' from 'Overweight.'  RBC Capital 
Markets upgraded its rating on shares of Royal Mail to 'Sector perform' from 'Underperform.' The stock finished 
higher by 4.29 percent.  Ryanair climbed 2.09 percent. The company's full year earnings per share were 115.63 
euros, higher than 62.46 euros last year.  Novartis increased 2.60 percent in Zurich after new guidelines on the 
treatment of heart failure strongly endorsed the use of its drug Entresto.  Richemont declined 3.48 percent, after it 
was downgraded by JPMorgan and Citigroup.  Insurer Aegon dropped 1.13 percent in Amsterdam after announcing 
European Markets Weakened At The Start Of The New Week
the sale of GBP 3 billion annuity liabilities to Legal & General.  Fiat Chrysler fell 4.44 percent in Milan on a report 
that the carmaker has used illegal software to manipulate pollution emissions of its vehicles.  Eurozone consumer 
confidence improved for a second straight month and at a faster-than-expected pace in May to its highest level in 
four months, preliminary data from the European Commission showed Monday.  The flash consumer confidence 
index climbed to -7 from -9.3 in April. Economists had forecast a score of 9 for the month.   Eurozone private sector 
growth weakened to the lowest level in more than a year in May as improvements in Germany and France were 
offset by softening of activity outside the big-two economies. The flash composite output index fell unexpectedly to 
a 16-month low of 52.9 from 53 in April, the results of the Purchasing Managers' Survey by Markit Economics 
revealed Monday. The index was forecast to rise to 53.2.  Germany's private sector activity expanded at a faster 
pace in May, flash survey results from Markit showed Monday. The composite output index rose to a 5-month high 
of 54.7 in May from 53.6 in April.  The French private sector growth improved to a 7-month high in May, flash survey 
data from Markit showed Monday. The composite output index rose to 51.1 in May, a 7-month high, from 50.2 in 
April.  British exporters logged a moderate growth in the first quarter, the latest Quarterly International Trade 
Outlook from the British Chambers of Commerce and DHL showed Sunday. The trade confidence index increased 
by 1.4 percent sequentially to 116.04 in the first quarter. However, it dropped 4.4 percent from the prior year.

Ryanair FY16 Profit Climbs; Says Cautiously Expects Modest Profit Growth

Body
(RTTNews) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that its fiscal 2016 profit before tax 
grew 43 percent to 1.72 billion euros from 982.4 million euros last year. Earnings per share were 115.63 euros, 
higher than 62.46 euros last year.
The latest results included exceptional accounting gain of 317.5 million euros on sale of Aer Lingus shareholding.
Adjusted pre-tax profit was 1.40 billion euros and adjusted attributable profit was 1.24 billion euros or 92.08 euros 
per share.
Revenues for the year climbed 16 percent to 6.54 billion euros from 5.65 billion euros a year ago. Scheduled 
revenues grew 17 percent and Ancillary revenues grew 13 percent.
Traffic went up 18 percent to 106.4 million customers as load factor grew 5 percent to 93 percent.
Unit costs fell 6 percent, while it was down 2 percent ex-fuel. Average fare dropped 1 percent.
The company noted that the fourth quarter yields on close-in Easter bookings were adversely impacted by over 500 
flight cancellations following the Brussels terrorist attacks and repeated (mainly French) ATC strikes.
Looking ahead, the company said it cautiously expects full year net profit to rise modestly, by approximately 13 
percent, to a range of 1.375 billion euros to 1.425 billion euros.

strength of Sterling and the absence of any further external shocks or significant ATC strikes/cancellations.

(RTTNews) - The European markets ended the first session of the new trading week with modest losses. The 
markets briefly turned positive this morning, but traded in negative territory for the majority of the session. The 
European markets logged their largest increase in a month at the end of the previous week, leading investors to 
take some profits.
Traders were disappointed by the unexpected decrease in Eurozone private sector data Monday. Commodity prices 
also struggled at the start of the week, as the U.S. dollar strengthened.
The risks of a de-anchoring of inflation expectations to below 1 percent or close to zero in the euro area have 
increased and hence, the central bank acted forcefully, ECB Executive Board member Peter Praet said in an 
interview to a newspaper, published Monday.
"We have seen in some countries some signs of de-anchoring in wage formation, Praet said in an interview with the 
Portuguese daily Publico.
"But, this being said, we haven't concluded that inflation expectations are de-anchored."
The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip stocks decreased 0.99 percent, while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, 
which includes some major U.K. companies, lost 0.46 percent.
The DAX of Germany dropped 0.74 percent and the CAC 40 of France fell 0.66 percent. The FTSE 100 of the U.K. 
declined 0.14 percent and the SMI of Switzerland finished higher by 0.51 percent.
In Frankfurt, pharmaceutical and chemicals giant Bayer fell 5.72 percent after making an all-cash offer to acquire 
U.S. agrochemicals firm Monsanto Co. for $62 billion.
Nordex lost 1.66 percent despite reporting a rise in Q1 profit and sales.
Aixtron soared 16.21 percent. China's Fujian Grand Chip Investment Fund LP said it would make a voluntary public 
takeover offer to buy the German semiconductor equipment maker for about 670 million euros ($752 million), 
including net cash.
Daimler dropped 1.57 percent and BMW weakened by 0.93 percent. Volkswagen also slipped 0.58 percent.
European Markets Weakened At The Start Of The New Week
In Paris, Peugeot surrendered 1.06 percent and Renault lost 1.14 percent. In London, Inmarsat decreased 4.04 
percent after Morgan Stanley downgraded its rating on the stock to "Equal weight" from "Overweight."

stock finished higher by 4.29 percent.
Ryanair climbed 2.09 percent. The company's full year earnings per share were 115.63 euros, higher than 62.46 
euros last year.

the use of its drug Entresto.
Richemont declined 3.48 percent, after it was downgraded by JPMorgan and Citigroup.

Legal & General.
Fiat Chrysler fell 4.44 percent in Milan on a report that the carmaker has used illegal software to manipulate 
pollution emissions of its vehicles.
Eurozone consumer confidence improved for a second straight month and at a faster-than-expected pace in May to 
its highest level in four months, preliminary data from the European Commission showed Monday. The flash 
consumer confidence index climbed to -7 from -9.3 in April. Economists had forecast a score of 9 for the month.
Eurozone private sector growth weakened to the lowest level in more than a year in May as improvements in 
Germany and France were offset by softening of activity outside the big-two economies. The flash composite output 
index fell unexpectedly to a 16-month low of 52.9 from 53 in April, the results of the Purchasing Managers' Survey 
by Markit Economics revealed Monday. The index was forecast to rise to 53.2.
Germany's private sector activity expanded at a faster pace in May, flash survey results from Markit showed 
Monday. The composite output index rose to a 5-month high of 54.7 in May from 53.6 in April.
The French private sector growth improved to a 7-month high in May, flash survey data from Markit showed 
Monday. The composite output index rose to 51.1 in May, a 7-month high, from 50.2 in April.
British exporters logged a moderate growth in the first quarter, the latest Quarterly International Trade Outlook from 
the British Chambers of Commerce and DHL showed Sunday. The trade confidence index increased by 1.4 percent 
sequentially to 116.04 in the first quarter. However, it dropped 4.4 percent from the prior year.

Corporate diary: May 23 - May 27
Corporate diary: May 23 - May 27
Financial Times (London, England)
May 23, 2016 Monday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: WEEK AHEAD; Pg. 20
Length: 1081 words
Body
TODAY 23
Ryanair is not only one of the world's biggest airlines; it is also one of the most hyperactive.
In the past 12 months it has raised its guidance on full-year 2015 to between EUR1.18bn and EUR1.23bn, 
announced an EUR800m share buyback, launched a private corporate-jet scheme and begun legal action over 
another website's allegedly misleading advertisements for its flights.
Today investors will get a chance to see how all these initiatives and announcements are reflected in the low-fare 
airline's profits.
Moreover they will want to see how chief executive Michael O'Leary intends to keep the growth momentum going, 
given the clouds on the horizon after the terrorist attack on Brussels airport, an important base for Ryanair, weaker 
sterling, and the possible end of low oil prices.
As analysts at Davy stockbrokers in Dublin put it in a results preview note for investors: "Guidance is key." Vincent 
Boland

Ryanair FY EUR0.96 (EUR0.64)
Corporate diary: May 23 - May 27
TUESDAY 24
Earnings
De La Rue FY 36.94p (44.70p)
WEDNESDAY 25
Hewlett-Packard , the maker of printers and personal computers, is expected to show a continued slide in 
revenues when it announces earnings.
The company, founded in Silicon Valley in 1939, recently split its hardware and enterprise businesses into two listed 
companies, in an attempt to help each achieve growth.
However, amid a broad contraction in printer and laptop sales, analysts expect that HP's revenues will have fallen 
to $11.7bn in the fiscal second quarter, 9 per cent lower than a year ago.
The company is looking to areas outside its core markets for eventual growth, including copiers and 3D printing.
HP released its first commercial 3D printers this month, with two models specifically aimed at manufacturing clients.
The devices, one of which costs $130,000 and will ship this year, can print linked parts out of a hard plastic 
material, at 10 times the speed of other printers.
Nike, BMW and Johnson & Johnson are among companies that are testing the commercial printer. If successful 
such devices could usher in a new style of printer-based manufacturing.
However, analysts do not expect 3D printer sales to have a meaningful impact on HP revenues this year or next. 
Leslie Hook
Earnings
HP Q2 $0.38 ($0.87)
Marks & Spencer FY 34.25p (32.90p)
Investors watch how M&S shapes up with non-food sales
Investors will be hoping that new chief executive Steve Rowe can put a stop to Marks and Spencer 's tumbling 
clothing and homeware sales as the high-street stalwart reports full-year results on Wednesday .
Shares in M&S have fallen 24 per cent in the past year as the retailer struggles to arrest falling sales in the non-
food part of its business, with like-for-like sales down 13 per cent in five years.
Mr Rowe is expected to announce a strategic review for the clothing and home division alongside annual financial 
results.
"We expect . . . a similar approach to that applied in food - a relentless focus on driving top line like-for-like via 
volume sales growth," said analysts at HSBC.
"This is a change in strategy to that of Marc Bolland, whose tenure was characterised by a significant period of 
infrastructure investment, and where against a challenging market backdrop improvements in the financial 
performance of the business were gross margin and cost led."
Mr Rowe blasted last quarter's 2.7 per cent drop in general merchandise sales as "not good enough" and said: "We 
have not been a stylish as we need to be. We've not had the right products in the right place. There's a lot more to 
do."
Corporate diary: May 23 - May 27
He added, however, that there remained "an awful lot of self-help we can do", thanks to heavy investment in 
product design, warehousing and online infrastructure in the years before his appointment.
M&S's results have long been a tale of two businesses, with its food division popular among Britain's middle 
classes, while clothing and homeware have struggled.
Revenues are forecast to inch up from £10.3bn to £10.4bn, while pre-tax profits rise 1.4 per cent from £661m to 
£670m. Paul McClean
THURSDAY 26
If ever a company should know how to stay under the radar it is Qinetiq . The company - spun out of the Ministry of 
Defence a decade ago - is responsible for sensitive defence technology research, testing and consultancy.
Qinetiq is the biggest non-US partner to the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and is an important 
UK supplier. While secrecy makes publicising what Qinetiq does a little harder than for most companies, there is not 
likely to be too much cloak and dagger about its annual results.
In fact there should be little to surprise. At a trading statement issued at the end of March Qinetiq confirmed that it 
was on course to deliver on expectations for the year.
However, some questions may need to be answered this year and next. In March the MoD announced that the 
allowed profit rate for single source contracts would be cut from 10.6 to 8.95 per cent.
Investors will want to know what the impact will be on Qinetiq as it seeks to reorganise its wide array of businesses 
under a relatively new chief executive. About a third of group revenues are potentially exposed to the rate cut.
They will also be keen to hear Steve Wadey 's strategic vision now that he has been in post for a year.
Analysts at Canaccord Genuity suspect a wave of acquisition ahead, as well as organic investment, to drive the top 
line as margins fall.
They forecast a slight fall in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation from £135.6m to £131.2m 
for the year to March 31. Peggy Hollinger
United Utilities will tell the market next week how it has fared under the first year of tougher price controls imposed 
by the regulator.
The water company will announce its full-year results, with analysts predicting slightly higher profits than for the 
previous year.
In March United said it expected to make slightly higher revenues than 2014-15 as an increase in sales in the non-
regulated parts of the business made up for tighter price controls.
The company has benefited from lower finance costs, but as it said net debt would rise slightly as it spent on 
maintaining and renewing its infrastructure.
In 2014-15 United made £341.6m in pre-tax profits. Analysts expect that to have risen to £386.8m for 2015-16.
Investors will want to hear how proposed changes to the highly regulated water market, including a government 
push for more competition, will affect United Utilities in future. Kiran Stacey

Body
DUBLIN (AP) - Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) on Monday reported fiscal fourth-quarter profit of $55.9 million.
The Dublin-based company said it had profit of 25 cents per share.
The airline posted revenue of $1.29 billion in the period.
For the year, the company reported profit of $1.72 billion, or $6.38 per share. Revenue was reported as $7.22 
billion.
Ryanair shares have declined 8 percent since the beginning of the year. The stock has risen 20 percent in the last

Ryanair 's strong passenger growth spurs 43-per-cent jump in profit
Ryanair's strong passenger growth spurs 43-per-cent jump in profit
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
May 23, 2016 Monday 11:11 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 174 words
Body
       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - Strong passenger growth, fuller planes and low fuel costs helped Europe's largest low-
cost airline, Ryanair, record a 43-per-cent jump in its annual profit, the airline said on Monday.  Ryanair promised to 
cut passenger fares this year after its post-tax profit soared to 1.24 billion euros (1.39 billion dollars) in the financial 
year to March 31, spurred by rises of 18 per cent in passengers and 16 per cent in revenue.  The airline had 
'delivered significant traffic and profit growth in all four quarters,' Ryanair owner Michael O'Leary said, adding that it 
had attracted 'millions of new customers.'  Ryanair said it flights operated at an average of 93 per cent of capacity 
and should remain at a similar level this year, while passenger numbers are expected to grow by another 9 per cent 
to 116 million in its new financial year.  It expects to reduce average fares by about 7 per cent this year and 
forecasts a 13-per-cent rise in net profit to between 1.38 billion and 1.43 billion euros.   Copyright dpa

Boardroom Briefing
Boardroom Briefing
Sunday Business Post
May 22, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 559 words
Byline: Emma Kennedy and Fearghal O’Connor
Body
Datalex strikes deal with IBM
Travel software company Datalex has announced a collaboration with tech giant IBM.In a statement issued 
to the Irish Stock Exchange last week, Datalex said it had reached an agreement with IBM to “collaborate in 
the development and delivery of joint travel retail solutions in digital commerce, cognitive computing, 
analytics, data and cloud services”.Datalex, which counts Aer Lingus, Delta Air Lines and Virgin Atlantic 
among its clients, will hold its agm in Dublin on Tuesday.The company is also due to publish an interim 
management statement that day.
Profits jump at DCC
DCC has reported a 35.5 per cent rise in full-year operating profit to £300.5 million, driven by the performance of its 
energy division following the acquisition of Butagaz and Esso Retail, the company’s biggest acquisitions to date. 
The sales, marketing, distribution and business support services group also signalled further growth ahead. “The 
group expects that the year ending March 31, 2017 will be another year of profit growth and development,” it said in 
a statement. 
Meanwhile, last week also saw some board changes at DCC. Cormac McCarthy, the former Paddy Power chief 
financial officer, has joined its board as a non-executive director. 
DCC also announced that the deputy chairman of its board, David Byrne, intends to retire from the board after the 
company’s upcoming agm on July 15.
Revenue boost for Newry firm
Revenue at financial software firm First Derivatives rose by 41 per cent to £117 million in the year to the end of 
February. 
Boardroom Briefing
The Newry-based firm announced last week that its adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and 
amortisation rose by 51 per cent to £23.3 million during the same period. Profit before tax, adjusted for factors such 
as a once-off disposal gain last year, rose by 56 per cent to £16.8 million. 
“We expect another year of strong growth, at least in line with market forecasts, while continuing to invest for growth 
in the future,” chairman Seamus Keating said. 
Ryanair unveils new routes
Ryanair has announced its first Luxembourg flights, with two new routes to London Stansted and Porto starting from 
September. 
According to figures from the airline, its new routes will deliver 200,000 customers annually at Luxembourg Airport. 
The airline will publish its full year results tomorrow. 
Non-executive appointment at IFG
IFG appointed a new non-executive director to its board last week. Kathryn Purves joined the board of the Dublin-
listed financial services company with effect from May 17. 
“Kathryn is an experienced financial services executive bringing a breadth of functional experience having worked 
across investment, commercial, legal and more recently risk management, where she has been chief risk officer of 
Partnership Life Insurance, the FTSE small-cap life insurance company,” IFG said in a statement. 
Earlier this month, IFG said thatc it was trading in line with expectations for 2016 so far, with revenues and profits 
ahead of the same period in 2015. 
The week ahead
In addition to Ryanair’s results tomorrow and Datalex’s agm on Tuesday (see above), there’s a few other things to 
keep an eye on in the coming days. 
On Tuesday, AIB will publish a trading statement. That day will also see property investment firm Hibernia Reit 
publish its results for the year to the end of March.

Invested: 15 questions to ask when investing
Invested: 15 questions to ask when investing
Sunday Business Post
May 22, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 987 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: It is important to carry out due diligence on companies you are interested in putting your money into
Body
The lifetime investor who doesn’t suffer losses from the risks inherent in stock market investing almost certainly 
hasn’t been born. The best we can do is to be as thorough in due diligence as possible. 
When looking at a prospective investment, one rarely finds the answers in the numbers alone. 
Yes, they are important. But it is the future sustainability of the business model, the company’s market position, its 
management experience and calibre, regulatory environment and the macroeconomic environment and outlook 
(and the earnings growth capacity that flows from these things) that matters from the perspective of the investor 
seeking to form a view on the sustainability of dividend payments, capital accretion and hence share price 
prospects. 
When I look for the growth drivers and their sustainability I look at the following key issues:
1.The company’s market position: is it strong and sustainable and what makes it such? 
2.Technological capability: does it have patented proprietary technology? 
3.Does it have a storehouse of expertise and experience in specialist niches that would be difficult for a competitor 
to easily replicate and that therefore enjoys some pricing power? 
4.Does it have a price advantage driven by economies of scale? 
5.Does it have a strong brand (or a portfolio of brands) which enjoys high levels of trust, built up in the consumer’s 
mind over decades, and that delivers the margins that come with the scale economies and strength of brand equity 
(Colgate Palmolive, Nestlé, Coca-Cola, or Diageo)? 
Invested: 15 questions to ask when investing
6.What is the strength and prospective strength and growth dynamics of the geographic markets into which the 
business sells and operates, how geographically diversified are those markets, and how much untapped market 
opportunity remains? 
7. Do its margins – relative to others in the sector – point to operational excellence, efficiency and market 
leadership in its segment? 
8.Can it finance more capacity to drive further growth (for example, Ryanair) or is its balance sheet already 
stretched? 
9.Is there a collaborative element in the nature of its relationship with customers in new product development and 
the quality of its research and innovation capability which gives it pricing power (Kerry Group)? 
10.Is it a market leader in a consolidating industry with a strong track record and reputation for delivery, and a 
disciplined approach to achieving shareholder accretive returns on capital when judging acquisition opportunities 
and the price to pay? 
Does it have a clear track record on acquisitions in terms of delivering on cost savings and returns on capital 
invested (DCC)? 
11.Is it a market disrupter with a technology-driven cost advantage over incumbents (Amazon)? 
12.Having satisfied myself on the sources of competitive advantage, I look at other factors: the numbers. In 
particular, the company’s balance sheet composition and strength. 
While there is no simple guideline for determining the ideal balance sheet structure, I see businesses with high fixed 
costs and operations in cyclical sectors as much less capable of supporting high debt levels relative to their 
cashflows unless they are being run on a very high risk basis. 
13.A focus on the debt metrics is important too because if the business is overburdened with debt relative to its 
cash generation, its capacity to expand and strengthen its market position and take advantage of opportunities to 
build on its economies of scale may be curtailed. 
An investor – whether institutional or private – must also bear in mind the limitations of a company’s annual 
accounts as it reveals the balance sheet position only on one day per annum (and the company has the flexibility to 
choose year end and half year end dates that offer the best prospect of showing the company in the best financial 
light). This is especially so for seasonal businesses which have peaks and troughs in their borrowing position on 
particular months of the year. Choosing the trough month for borrowings for your year end may give a false 
impression of the underlying borrowing requirements of the business through the year as a whole. 
14.I am usually happy to leave a decent slice of the annual earnings per share of most of the companies in which I 
invest in the company itself rather than seeking a big dividend payout. It is not only more tax efficient, but if the 
company is delivering stellar returns on capital, I feel it is likely to do better with my money in terms of generating 
more capital growth than paying me a high dividend that will be subject to my marginal tax rate, USC and PRSI. 
It is prudent to look at big dividend payers with a jaundiced eye. The extent to which their dividends are covered by 
after-tax earnings is important and if they have had a run of annual dividend payments close to, or above, their 
after-tax annual earnings I ask myself two questions: is that dividend sustainable? Or has the company run out of 
investment opportunities to deliver an acceptable return on capital with the cash that is being generated within the 
business? 
15.Corporate governance, management stability. Track record on execution. Delivery on market guidance. Market 
opportunities and threats arising from regulatory developments or emerging technologies or social and 
demographic changes, and the capacity and track record to undertake successful acquisitions and to build scale 
are all important too. 
Invested: 15 questions to ask when investing
And finally, I keep an eye on regulatory developments in Brussels where industry lobbyists are powerful and self 
serving. Much of the evolving regulatory programme opens up opportunities for companies and niche players in 
areas such as health and safety and environmental standards – and threats for industries such as tobacco, 
although the tobacco companies’ global spread and lobbying nous has kept them in the premier division in terms of 
equity market performance and dividend growth delivery over many decades now. 
Load-Date: May 24, 2016
End of Document

Brexit campaigners object to Ryanair 'Fly home to vote Remain' sale
Brexit campaigners object to Ryanair 'Fly home to vote Remain' sale
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
May 20, 2016 Friday 3:28 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 355 words
Body
       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - Campaigners for Britain to leave the European Union complained to police on Friday 
that Ryanair has broken election law through its 'Fly home to vote Remain' ticket promotion ahead of a referendum 
on June 23.  The airline, whose owner Michael O'Leary wants Britain to remain in the EU, offered British citizens 
one-way flights home for 19.99 pounds (29 dollars) on June 22 and June 23 for bookings made by midnight 
Thursday.  'By its discount on flights on the day before, and the day of the referendum, Ryanair is paying the 
expense, in part, of provision to voters in order to influence them to vote in the referendum,' Dominic Cummings, 
campaign director for Vote Leave, said in a letter of complaint to London's Metropolitan Police.  'This appears to be 
corrupt, since the company is offering discounts on the commercial rate to customers with the sole aim of ensuring 
that they vote and vote to remain in the European Union,' Cummings said. 
 The Metropolitan Police confirmed it had received the complaint and would examine it to determine whether any 
offence had been committed.   Reacting to the complaint, O'Leary extended the promotion for an extra 24 hours 
and said it 'fully complies with Ryanair's policy of lowering the cost of air travel' to and from Britain.  'The Leave 
campaign must be getting really desperate if they're objecting to low-fare air travel for British citizens, so we're 
pleased to extend our 'Fly home to vote Remain' sale by another 24 hours,' he said in a Ryanair statement.  'As the 
UK's largest airline, Ryanair is absolutely clear that the UK economy and its growth prospects are stronger as a 
member of the European Union and the single market than they are outside the EU,' O'Leary said.  British election 
law includes an offence of 'treating,' making it illegal for someone to 'directly or indirectly give or provide any food, 
drink, entertainment or provision to corruptly influence any voter to vote or refrain from voting.'  Cummings said 
Vote Leave believes the Ryanair offer counts as treating and could also contravene British law on bribery.   
Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: May 20, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair for Remain; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Ryanair for Remain; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
City A.M.
May 19, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 21
Length: 252 words
Body
[Re: Is Ryanair risking its own reputation by coming out strongly for Remain? Tuesday]No. Ryanair's support for the 
Remain campaign is completely congruent with the reality of its business and its brand, and people like consistency 
between what brands say and what they do.
First, the brand's core appeal is its low cost fares and extensive routes. The EU's liberalised air policy allows 
airlines to operate without restriction and additional fees, critical for low-cost-carriers. Ryanair is the biggest low cost 
carrier in Europe, with 30+ European bases and over 110m www.passengers.No other European country has an 
exit referendum pending. Even if the company offends some pro-Brexit customers in the UK, the business impact 
would not be significant.
Second, its high profile support is also consistent with its outspoken, straight-talking brand personality. It provides 
Ryanair with free publicity consistent with what people would expect and reinforces the low-cost association of the 
brand. The only question, bearing in mind Ryanair's controversial brand image, is whether Remain would want its 
endorsement.
Sophie Devonshire, The Caffeine Partnership I have no problem with businesses explaining how Brexit might affect 
them, but I do have a problem with politically-motivated chief executives trying to scare the public because they've 
been asked to by politicians. That, to me, is an abuse of those companies' position as respected figures of 
authority. And customers should react accordingly.
Name withheld
Load-Date: May 20, 2016
