Ryanair forced to cancel over 70 flights due to French ATC strike Ryanair forced ...
Ryanair forced to cancel over 70 flights due to French ATC strike; Ryanair 
forced ...
Business World (Digest)
May 18, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 221 words
Highlight: Ryanair have been forced to cancel over 70 flights tomorrow to/from and over France with further delays 
likely.
Body
Ryanair have been forced to cancel over 70 flights tomorrow to/from and over France with further delays likely.
This is the fifth French strike in two months and Ryanair havecalled on the European Commission to take action to 
prevent the strikes.
The airline says thousands of flights from the UK, Ireland, Spain and Italy - none of which either take off or land in 
France - are cancelled and hundreds of thousands of passengers' travel plans again disrupted.
Ryanair advised customers travelling on Thursday to check the status of their flight on the Ryanair.com website 
before travelling to the airport and urged all those affected to sign its Keep Europe's Skies Open petition, which it 
will present to the European Commission once it accrues a million signatures. Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, 
Kenny Jacobs commented, "Once more Europe's consumers are being held to ransom by tiny French ATC unions, 
causing hundreds of thousands of passenger flights to be cancelled or delayed, while the European Commission 
and French Government sit on their hands." He added, "As we approach the peak holiday season, European 
travellers should prepare for a summer of discontent as there is absolutely nothing preventing these selfish unions 
from staging even more strikes in the coming weeks and months." Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: May 23, 2016
End of Document
Q: After it hosted a major Osborne speech, is Ryanair risking its own reputation by openly backing Remain? 
DEBATE
Q: After it hosted a major Osborne speech, is Ryanair risking its own 
reputation by openly backing Remain?; DEBATE
City A.M.
May 17, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 22
Length: 353 words
Body
Michael Jacobides YES At a time of heightened political sensibility and populist bashing of "big business", it feels 
risky for a corporation to take a clear stance on a key political debate. Brexit campaigners have already targeted 
Mark Carney for taking a view, despite the fact that his duties clearly call for an assessment, so Ryanair will take 
some heat. Still, this is a gamble that Ryanair has to take. Companies often help shape policy and, inasmuch as 
they are transparent, it is fair game for them to make their case. Provided that Ryanair as a company has 
established that Brexit will have a major adverse impact on its business, it owes it to its shareholders, employees 
and stakeholders to speak up. Corporate leaders who act in the interest of their companies and their stakeholders, 
rather than leveraging their power to advocate their personal political views, should join in the chorus, regardless of 
the risks, so that voters can know what the business world really believes.
£ Michael Jacobides is associate professor of strategy and entrepreneurship at London Business School.
Chris Rumfitt NO The referendum is one of the biggest decisions facing the country in decades and Ryanair is quite 
right to have its say. They have made their name as an "opinionated brand" and their chief executive is famously 
one of the most outspoken in British business. Every day, their customers and employees benefit from European 
freedom of movement, so they are just the right people to stand up for Remain. Other companies have also made 
their voice heard, but in putting ordinary passengers and staff at the centre of their case, Ryanair's message is 
especially powerful.
What are the risks? Well, if the Leave campaign wins, it might seek to make companies who fought against them 
pay a price. But frankly, from the perspective of most businesses, the thought of leaving the EU is such a gamble 
that if Leave does win, everything post 23 June looks like a black hole. Against that backdrop, there is no further 
threat the Outers hold against them.
Q: After it hosted a major Osborne speech, is Ryanair risking its own reputation by openly backing Remain? 
DEBATE
£ Chris Rumfitt is founder and chief executive of Field Consulting.
Graphic
 
Michael JacobidesChris Rumfitt

Plane speaking: Leaving is one-way ticket to poverty, say old foes
Plane speaking: Leaving is one-way ticket to poverty, say old foes
Financial Times (London, England)
May 17, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 582 words
Byline: George Parker in Stansted
Body
The Brexit debate has forged some strange alliances and few more surprising than George Osborne lining up with 
former foes Ed Balls and Sir Vince Cable in an aircraft hangar to warn of the dangers of leaving the EU.
While Mr Osborne last year delighted in defeating Mr Balls and Sir Vince, his one-time rivals buried past differences 
to help the chancellor avoid a similar fate if the UK votes to withdraw from the bloc in its June 23 referendum .
Mr Balls and Sir Vince joined the chancellor at a Ryanair hangar at Stansted airport yesterday to say that leaving 
the EU's single market would be "a one-way ticket to a poorer Britain".
Meanwhile, Mr Osborne's Conservative colleague Boris Johnson was touring the country continuing to attack his 
own government, including the "scandal" that NHS accident and emergency waiting times were at their highest 
ever.
While Mr Johnson argued that Britain could spend more on the health service if it left the EU, Mr Osborne, Mr Balls 
and Sir Vince said Brexit would impoverish the country.
Mr Balls, shadow chancellor until 2015, hopes their words will carry more weight because he and Sir Vince have 
moved away from politics and are more likely to be seen nowadays on Strictly Come Dancing or The Great British 
Bake Off than in the House of Commons.
Plane speaking: Leaving is one-way ticket to poverty, say old foes
To make the point, they assembled in a shed at Stansted with a Ryanair Boeing 737 painted with Remain campaign 
slogans. Michael O'Leary , Ryanair chief executive, said his company created 450 jobs in the UK this year but 
would scale back investment if Britain left the EU's single market. "If Britain isn't in the EU, those investment and 
jobs would be going to other countries," he said.
Sir Vince pointed out that the single market was "a British vision of an open Europe" and said that the world's best 
companies came to the UK because of it; many smaller companies formed the supply chain that served them.
Mr Osborne revealed another "new" Treasury figure about the cost of Brexit, claiming Britain could lose £200bn of 
exports and £200bn of inward investment by 2030 outside the single market.
The event confirmed the Remain camp's relentless focus on the economy following confirmation last weekend by 
Michael Gove , the pro-Brexit justice secretary, that if Britain left the EU it would also leave the single market.
Mr Osborne said this was one of the "decisive moments" of the campaign and criticised opponents for suggesting 
that warnings of economic dangers were part of an establishment conspiracy.
In a jibe at Mr Gove and Mr Johnson, the chancellor said the Leave camp seemed to believe in "a massive 
conspiracy" and would next accuse him of "faking the moon landing, kidnapping Shergar and covering up the 
discovery of the Loch Ness monster".
Mr Johnson fired back a jibe at David Cameron, saying accusations of conspiracy theories were "a bit rich from 
those who said World War Three would break out if we leave the European Union".
Mr Osborne said he was sceptical of polls that suggested the Remain camp's focus on the economy did not sway 
voters, with polls showing the two sides are neck and neck. "The argument is being won by those who say it would 
be economically costly to leave," he said.
Mr Osborne's focus on the economy in the Scottish independence referendum campaign in 2014 and the general 
election in 2015 had its doubters. But the presence of Sir Vince and Mr Balls alongside him yesterday was a 
reminder that establishing economic credibility has been a powerful weapon in the past.
Load-Date: May 16, 2016
End of Document
PLEASE REMAIN Osborne's old rivals get onboard at rally
PLEASE REMAIN; Osborne's old rivals get onboard at rally
City A.M.
May 17, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 117 words
Body
CHANCELLOR George Osborne was at Stansted Airport yesterday to make an impassioned plea for staying in the 
European Union. Joined by Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary and former political rivals Ed Balls and Vince Cable, 
Osborne called Brexiters "conspiracy theorists", saying: "The next thing we know the Leave camp will be accusing 
us all of faking the moon landings, kidnapping Shergar, and covering up the existence of the Loch Ness monster." 
O'Leary warned Britain faces higher holiday cost if it voted for Brexit. "I am absolutely certain that the UK economy 
is better off in Europe, and that is why Ryanair is campaigning hard and actively calling on UK voters to vote 
'Remain' on the 23 June," he said.

Ryanair to create 1000 new jobs in 2016 Ryanair to crea...
Ryanair to create 1000 new jobs in 2016; Ryanair to crea...
Business World (Digest)
May 16, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 241 words
Highlight: It was announced today that Ryanair will create over 1,000 new jobs for pilots, cabin crew and engineers 
in 2016.
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair will create over 1,000 new jobs for pilots, cabin crew and engineers in 2016.
Over 450 of these new jobs will be located at Ryanair's 13 UK airport bases to support its 14 new Boeing 737-800 
aircraft, an investment of over dollar 1.4bn in the British economy.
These new jobs will bring to more than 3,500 aviation professionals that Ryanair employs directly in Britain, in 
addition to sustaining thousands of support jobs at Ryanair's 18 UK airports.
Welcoming the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Rt Hon George Osborne MP, to its new European Training Centre 
today, Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary called for a strong "Remain" vote in the European Referendum on 23rd June 
next.O'Leary commented, "The single market has enabled Ryanair to lead the low fare air travel revolution in 
Europe, as we bring millions of British citizens to Europe each year, and welcome millions of European visitors to 
Britain, and we are calling on everyone to turn out in large numbers and vote "Remain" on the 23rd June." The 
Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne added, "I'm delighted to be at Ryanair today to hear about their 
plans to create 450 new highly skilled jobs this year in the UK, and welcome their call for Britain to remain part of 
the European Union. Today's announcement is just another example of how British jobs and livelihoods directly 
benefit from being part of the European Union." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair April passenger traffic increases 10%
Ryanair April passenger traffic increases 10%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 16, 2016 Monday 3:54 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 140 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has reported that passenger traffic for the month of April 2016 was 9.9 million 
passengers, an increase of 10%, compared to 9.0 million passengers for April 2015.
Body
Load factor for the month of April 2016 was 93%, an increase of two percentage points, compared to 91% for April 
2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's April traffic grew by 10% to 9.9m customers, while our load factor 
jumped 2% points to 93%. These record monthly numbers and load factors were delivered despite more ATC 
strikes in Belgium, France, Greece and Italy, as lower fares and the continuing success of our "Always Getting 
Better" customer experience programme continue to deliver even more great value for our customers. "Ryanair 
customers can look forward to more improvements, as we enter Year 3 of our "Always Getting Better" programme, 
which includes even lower fares, more new routes, new digital features and new cabin interiors, as Ryanair 
continues to deliver the lowest fares and the most on time flights in Europe."

Britain 's Osborne Turns Fire on 'Out' Plan to Leave EU Single Market
Britain's Osborne Turns Fire on 'Out' Plan to Leave EU Single Market
Newstex Blogs
Voice of America
May 16, 2016 Monday 1:40 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 413 words
Body
May 16, 2016( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex)  Finance minister George 
Osborne attacked pro-Brexit campaigners for saying Britain should not just leave the European Union but also its 
single market, as he sought to convince voters that the economy faces big risks in next month's referendum. 
Osborne said Britain would lose 200 billion pounds ($287 billion) a year in trade in 15 years' time and miss out on 
the same amount in foreign investment, if it fell back on World Trade Organization rules to govern its ties with the 
EU after a Brexit. 
"Leaving the EU is a one-way ticket to a poorer Britain," Osborne told media in an aircraft hangar at Stansted 
Airport, northeast of London, where the head of airline Ryanair said his firm could lower investment after an "Out" 
vote. Opinion polls have shown that voters tend to think that staying in the EU would be better for Britain's economy 
but they also remain almost evenly split between those who want to stay in the bloc and those who want to leave. 
As part of a relentless series of warnings about the economic risks of Brexit, Osborne's finance ministry is due to 
publish a report on the short-term impact of an "Out" vote soon. A leading supporter of the "Vote Leave" campaign, 
justice minister Michael Gove said earlier this month that Britain should also leave the single market after a Brexit. If 
a post-Brexit Britain wanted to remain part of the single market, it would probably face demands from the rest of the 
bloc to keep its borders open to EU workers and to continue paying into the EU's budget, just as Norway and 
Switzerland do. The "Out" campaign has put stopping high levels of immigration and Britain's contributions to the 
EU budget at the center of their message to voters. Osborne spoke on Monday alongside former Labour Party 
economics spokesman Ed Balls, who was long a critic of Osborne, and former business minister Vince Cable, a 
senior member of the opposition Liberal Democrat party. Balls and Cable both said Britain risked economic damage 
if it left the EU. Osborne also accused the "Out" campaign of resorting to conspiracy theories ahead of the 
referendum for calling into question the motives of global bodies such as the International Monetary Fund and the 
Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development when they spoke of the economic risks of Brexit. "The 
economic argument is beyond doubt. It's not a conspiracy, it's called a consensus," Osborne said.

Michael Murray: Irish investors love to tie themselves down to property, and that is their undoing.
Michael Murray: Irish investors love to tie themselves down to property, and 
that is their undoing.
Sunday Business Post
May 15, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1590 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: Here’s how to start building a balanced portfolio
Body
One of the remarkable things about the financial crisis we went through from 2008 until recently is how little appears 
to have changed in the thought processes of so many Irish investors. Most got badly burnt by an overexposure – 
either directly or indirectly – to the property sector. 
But there is little to suggest a growing appreciation of the merits of other asset classes which can offer easier and 
potentially safer longer-term returns and advantages when you take all of the factors pertaining to property relative 
to other asset classes into account – returns, costs, liquidity, management, tenant risk, possible regulatory risk and 
asset concentration. 
Many Irish investors fail to focus on risk correlations. But one thing which hopefully has been learned is the major 
risk correlation that exists between Irish property investment and shares in Irish banks given that more than five 
times the banks’ shareholder funds are invested in property by way of loans and mortgages on property. 
By contrast, with the exception of a few Reits, property represents only a tiny proportion of the other Irish listed 
companies’ assets. 
The shares of the major Irish listed companies (ie, aside from the banks which were wrecked by property) – CRH, 
Ryanair, Kerry Group, Smurfit Kappa, DCC, Greencore, Paddy Power Betfair, and Kingspan – have delivered 
returns to their investors in the past decade ranging from 250 per cent to over 1,000 per cent. 
The returns from property over the same period have been not far from between zero at the best end and minus 20 
per cent or more at the lower end, depending on location and property segment. 
But it is not just the single asset class that private investors in this country have been over-focused on. To the 
extent that they have invested in shares, their focus has been overwhelmingly on Irish shares. Yet the size of the 
Michael Murray: Irish investors love to tie themselves down to property, and that is their undoing.
Irish equity market, by capitalisation, is less than 0.5 per cent of the size of the US market, according to the World 
Bank, less than 5 per cent of the British market, and less than 0.25 per cent of the market capitalisation of all of the 
world’s stock markets put together. 
So focusing on one small equity market exposes you to just a tiny proportion of the global equity investment 
opportunity. Why do so many Irish investors stick to the home knitting – but especially property, and shares 
correlated to property? 
Aside from the inferior historic returns on Irish property versus other asset classes, bear in mind some of the other 
disadvantages of residential property as an investment – be it in Ireland or elsewhere – compared with blue-chip 
shares and indeed other asset classes. 
First, there is the risk concentration issue with a single residential property in a single location. Secondly, there is 
the liquidity risk if the market turns sour. Thirdly, there is the tenant concentration risk of default. 
Fourthly, there are all of the outgoings on property that many investors don’t take into account when they are 
measuring the yield from the asset. 
Repair and maintenance costs, upgrading and modernisation, service charges, void periods between one tenant 
leaving and another taking over, rent loss from tenant default risk, lease registration costs, and agents’ letting fees 
plus Vat all nibble away at your return. 
Deduct all of these from the gross rent over a five-year period, and you are likely to come to a net pre-tax yield on 
the capital value of the property of not much more than 60-65 per cent of the gross yield. That brings the true pre-
tax yield for good quality residential property down to similar levels to (or even lower levels than) good quality, large 
and liquid equities. 
Every asset class has cyclical characteristics. For that reason, it is sensible to look at the returns of different asset 
classes over the long term. For this purpose, I will exclude what one might call the “indulgent” asset classes of fine 
wine, art and classic cars – all of which, if well chosen, have proved capable of delivering handsome capital 
appreciation over time. 
The asset classes I have chosen are ones which I believe are appropriate for investors seeking to build a balanced 
portfolio that takes account of the different types of investment and financial risk including inflation – and so risks to 
real returns over time. 
So, equities, corporate bonds, government bonds, index-linked bonds, and cash have a place in this portfolio. While 
inflation has been low in this country over the past decade, it makes sense to look at how assets perform in real 
terms against inflation over long periods of time and to be conscious of the possibility that, at some stage in the next 
decade or two, higher inflation may once again raise its ugly head. 
There are, of course, no perfect hedges against inflation, but there are index-linked gilts where the coupon tracks 
the rate of inflation. Since 1900, equities have consistently paid back in real terms during periods of low to high 
single-digit inflation, and during periods of deflation. 
But in periods of double-digit inflation, both equities and gilts have delivered annualised negative real returns. For 
that reason, carrying some weighting in a balanced portfolio in index linked bonds might make sense as a modest 
hedge – especially for those relying on fixed income pensions, for example. 
The time to move on such a hedge is when the vista of a return to inflation looks to be a good distance off, because 
once that vista raises its head, the price of index-linked bonds is likely to rise markedly. 
But as between equities, gilts, and cash, although equities have been more volatile than the other asset classes, 
taking the 115 years since 1900, the average annual return from British and US equities has outstripped by far the 
inflation rate, as well as the return on cash and bonds. 
Michael Murray: Irish investors love to tie themselves down to property, and that is their undoing.
In the case of Britain, the average annual total return from equities over the 115 years has been 9.3 per cent versus 
3.9 per cent for inflation, 4.7 per cent for cash and 5.2 per cent from gilts. 
Despite the devastation in the banking sector and the more recent drop in hard commodity prices and the heavy 
weightings of both of these sectors in the overall British equity market indices, over all ten, 15 and 25 year periods 
the average annual total returns from British equities have outstripped inflation quite comfortably. The same applies 
to other developed economies. 
Still, there have been some periods when equity investors have been crushed unless they held on for recovery. 
During the period of high double-digit inflation rates in the mid-1970s, equity returns more than halved over two 
years: down by nearly one quarter in 1973 and by nearly another 50 per cent in 1974. 
But patient investors saw British equity returns rebounding quickly in 1975 to 145 per cent. After a fairly flat 
performance in 1976, returns jumped to 51.8 per cent in 1977. This was followed by ten years of double digit annual 
returns. 
While the past is no guide to the future, an examination of trends over 115 years suggests to me that a heavy 
weighting in a well diversified portfolio of equities makes huge sense unless one anticipates an extraordinary 
political upheaval or event that inflicts long-term damage on businesses and capitalist economies. 
That said, I am prepared to park close on 20 per cent of my capital in cash at present – some of which I may deploy 
in other assets (such as index-linked bonds and gold) over the coming months, given the rising levels of political 
instability in pockets of Europe and the Middle East . . . not to mention Brexit risks following the British referendum 
next month. 
Asset classes aside, I view the composition of my exposure within the equity class to be critical: I am essentially a 
conservative investor seeking long-term capital growth ahead of inflation, but my portfolio is heavily weighted 
towards companies in energy distribution, healthcare services, and ones that have iconic consumer staple brands 
as well as ones that serve consumer addiction. 
Also, aside from a few medium-sized and high-growth niche operators, I keep my portfolio heavily weighted towards 
shares that are highly liquid and can be easily traded if necessary. 
As for real estate, aside from my home I have a single exposure to a well-managed pan-European multimillion 
square foot industrial property company with strong cashflows from thousands of tenants across four countries. 
But I have no further appetite for the sector, least of all for a single property in an Ireland that looks to be moving 
towards serious political instability and socialist-driven spending. In the absence of the emergence of politicians 
who have the guts and the capacity to articulate the case for capitalism, or indeed a change in our electoral system, 
this looks set to become the dangerous and unappetising norm. 
No two individuals’ personal circumstances are the same but an awareness of the multitude of investment 
opportunities and asset classes available and consideration of their relative advantages in terms of liquidity, growth 
prospects and diversification is essential. 
A portfolio diversified by asset class, by geography, and by sector will invariably deliver disappointment from time to 
time but almost certainly not devastation. 
 Over the long term, if prudently built up, it is likely to deliver returns comfortably ahead of inflation. 
And after a good decade of equity returns, a visit to the classic car showrooms, the art galleries and the wine vaults 
to modestly indulge your success might be called for.

Ryanair would pull investment from UK if it leaves EU Ryanair would p...
Ryanair would pull investment from UK if it leaves EU; Ryanair would p...
Business World (Digest)
May 13, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 380 words
Highlight: Ryanair would move some investment out of Britain if it votes to leave the European Union and the 
"extreme volatility" that would follow such an outcome could put downward pressure on air fares in the short term, 
its chief executive said on Friday.
Body
Ryanair would move some investment out of Britain if it votes to leave the European Union and the "extreme 
volatility" that would follow such an outcome could put downward pressure on air fares in the short term, its chief 
executive said on Friday.
The Irish low-cost airline, Europe's largest by passenger numbers, flies 40 million of its 100 million-plus passengers 
a year to and from the United Kingdom and has its largest hub at London's Stansted Airport.
CEO Michael O'Leary is one of the most vocal business leaders campaigning for a vote to remain ahead of the 
June 23 referendum on EU membership.
"After 9/11, after every crisis Ryanair is selling cheaper fares, we keep people flying. So the fact is it would have a 
downward effect on our pricing for six to 12 months, but we will keep people flying," O'Leary told reporters. "The 
longer term effect though is we will invest less in the UK, we will certainly switch some of our existing UK 
investment into other European counties because we want to continue to invest in the European Union and it will be 
bad for air travel and British tourism." British air fares could also rise sharply in the long term if a vote to leave 
threatened Britain's access to EU air services agreements, he added. A Brexit may also put some downward 
pressure on aircraft prices and O'Leary said there is always an opportunity for Ryanair to stock up in such a 
downturn, though its current supply of Boeing planes takes it out until 2023. However, he said the "Remain" 
campaign should be cautious about warning of "apocalyptic scenarios." While a period of extraordinary volatility 
would undoubtedly follow for six to 12 months after a Brexit, fundamental economics would then take over and 
sterling would recover, O'Leary said. Ryanair is spending around 25,000 euros to run advertisements calling on its 
customers to vote to remain, he said, and would step up that marketing drive closer to the referendum date. "Most 
of the contribution being made by Ryanair is through our email, our customer base, advocating a remain vote 
Ryanair would pull investment from UK if it leaves EU Ryanair would p...
because we fundamentally believe it's in the UK's best interests to remain in Europe," O'Leary said. "Will Ryanair 
have any effect? I think not really. Around the margins, we may." (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

the stock in a report on Monday, January 25th. One analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued a 
hold rating, six have issued a buy rating and one has assigned a strong buy rating to the company's stock. The 
company currently has an average rating of 'Buy' and a consensus price target of $89.60. Ryanair Holdings plc

Ryanair to become 'Digital travel leader' of the future; Ryanair to beco...
Ryanair to become 'Digital travel leader' of the future; Ryanair to beco...
Business World (Digest)
May 12, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 350 words
Highlight: It was announced today that Ryanair has signed a deal with Comtrade which will see the software 
engineering services and solutions provider developing the carrier's myRyanair platform, an application that speeds 
up the booking process by over 20% and assi
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair has signed a deal with Comtrade which will see the software engineering 
services and solutions provider developing the carrier's myRyanair platform, an application that speeds up the 
booking process by over 20% and assists passengers with their entire journey.
It allows customers to select their travel preferences by creating a personal profile to securely store payment and 
passport details and search Ryanair's 1,800 air fare routes; ensuring faster bookings and flight check-ins.
Based on a customer's personal profile, myRyanair can assist with other travel-related activities, from tailored 
holiday tips to money-saving logistics. At the customer's choosing, it can link them with other passengers whom 
they can share a taxi with, remember what plane seats they prefer or offer restaurant suggestions for the 
destination.
Ryanair claims the launch of myRyanair signals the airline's push to disrupt and transform the aviation industry by 
becoming a digital travel company with pioneering, customer-focused technology. With a strong emphasis on 
customer service, the carrier aims to grow its passenger numbers to 180 million per annum by 2024. Working from 
the vision of Ryanair's user interface (UI) design team, Comtrade developed myRyanair and turned it into an 
application capable of securely handling and processing the details of Ryanair's 106 million annual passengers. 
With a focus on speed, it can also fill four Boeing 737s every minute at peak booking times. CTO of Ryanair, John 
Hurley says, "In the future, I see Ryanair as a digital travel leader that happens to have an airline attached to it. We 
want to use technology to personalise the user experience for our increasingly tech-savvy customer base and 
myRyanair is very strategic and central to that vision." He added, "The scale of myRyanair is phenomenal. It is built 
to handle the details of 106 million people and as we grow, myRyanair's capabilities will grow with it. Our 
Ryanair to become 'Digital travel leader' of the future; Ryanair to beco...
partnership with Comtrade was fundamental to turning myRyanair from a vision to a reality." Source: 
www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair February passenger traffic increases 28%
Ryanair February passenger traffic increases 28%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 12, 2016 Thursday 3:52 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 142 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has reported that passenger traffic for the month of February 2016 was 7.4 million 
passengers, an increase of 28%, compared to 5.8 million passengers for February 2015.
Body
Load factor for the month of February 2016 was 93%, an increase of four percentage points, compared to 89% for 
February 2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's February traffic grew by 28% to 7.4m customers, while our 
load factor jumped 4% points to 93%. These record monthly numbers and load factors are due to our lower fares, 
our stronger forward bookings and the continuing success of our "Always Getting Better" customer experience 
programme, which continues to deliver better than expected traffic and load factors. "Ryanair customers continue to 
enjoy more service enhancements, as we continue Year 2 of our AGB programme, which includes our new website, 
new app, new cabin interiors, new crew uniforms, and improved inflight menus, as Ryanair continues to deliver 
much more than just the lowest fares and the most on time flights in Europe."

Politics of payout ratios
Politics of payout ratios
Financial Times (London, England)
May 11, 2016 Wednesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LOMBARD; Pg. 20
Length: 277 words
Byline: Jonathan Guthrie
Body
It's nice for a chap to have a hobby. Over the years Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou has campaigned for higher dividends 
from easyJet with the passion others devote to ornithology or model trains.
Result! Yesterday, the low-cost airline he founded said it would raise payouts from 40 per cent to 50 per cent of 
earnings, as he has demanded.
EasyJet framed the change in the context of a review of its capital structure. Carolyn McCall , the airline's 
impressive chief executive, pointed out that payouts had hit 50 per cent before, thanks to special dividends.
But this still looked like a victory for the entrepreneur, who controls 33 per cent of the company.
Payout ratios are in vogue for dividend setting because they spare businesses cyclical squeezes. A high payout 
ratio suggests that a business has limited opportunity to generate big returns from investing retained earnings. That 
is a characteristic of mature businesses. EasyJet's middling ratio is therefore somewhat at odds with Dame 
Carolyn's belief that she can grab lots more market share from European flag carriers.
She would be assisted, of course, by easyJet's low costs. These now include an investment-grade credit rating, 
making it possible to raise debt cheaply. Revealingly, perhaps, the group has abandoned its target gearing range of 
30-50 per cent.
Politics of payout ratios
Sales growth is meanwhile set to slow, according to S&P CIQ estimates. It seems Sir Stelios sees easyJet maturing 
faster, or at least growing more slowly, than Dame Carolyn does. Differences of this kind do not trouble Ryanair, 
another low-cost airline. That may be one reason its shares trade at a premium to those of easyJet.
jonathan.guthrie@ft.com 
Load-Date: May 10, 2016
End of Document

Ryanair still Barclays top pick despite weak performance
Ryanair still Barclays top pick despite weak performance
Sunday Business Post
May 8, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 255 words
Byline: Fearghal O’Connor
Highlight: Investors “nervous" carrier will expoit volatility to introduce low initial guidance
Body
Budget airline Ryanair has “heavily underperformed” in the aviation sector and wider market in the last month, 
according to new analysis of the aviation sector. 
Investors are “nervous that the company will take the opportunity of April/May volatility to introduce a particularly 
low” initial guidance for its likely performance next year when it announces full-year results later this month, said a 
report into the European aviation sector by analysts at Barclays.  
“Another bumpy start to the summer,” said the report about the wider sector.  
 “April/May have clearly been very tough for the European airline industry, with Brussels terror attacks weighing on 
bookings, combined with operational disruption from ATC/security strikes in France and Germany.” 
Nevertheless, Barclays is optimistic about Ryanair’s fortunes. 
It says that it continues to believe that the Irish airline’s “self-help transformation will enable it to outperform the rest 
of the industry on yields, as load factor tops out and its capacity growth slows”.  
Ryanair is described as Barclays’ “top pick” in the sector and it predicts further growth at the airline of 10 per cent 
over the summer months.  
It emerged last week that Ryanair and British Airways  are close to a passenger sharing deal. 
Barclays highlights Dublin, as well as Copenhagen, Cologne, Stansted and Rome’s Fiumicino, as likely growth 
airports for the airline.   
“We believe Ryanair has engaged in significant promotional activity to stimulate traffic following Brussels,” said the 
report. 
Ryanair still Barclays top pick despite weak performance

Aer Lingus and Ryanair close to a deal Aer Lingus and ...
Aer Lingus and Ryanair close to a deal; Aer Lingus and ...
Business World (Digest)
May 6, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 235 words
Highlight: The Irish Independent has today reported that Ryanair is likely to feed passengers to the Aer Lingus 
long-haul network as part of what would be an unprecedented formal agreement between the two former arch 
rivals, according to IAG chief executive Willie W
Body
The Irish Independent has today reported that Ryanair is likely to feed passengers to the Aer Lingus long-haul 
network as part of what would be an unprecedented formal agreement between the two former arch rivals, 
according to IAG chief executive Willie Walsh.
The proposed deal could see Ryanair feeding passengers from its extensive network at Dublin to Aer Lingus routes 
serving North America.
Mr Walsh said IAG remains open to the feeder idea with Ryanair and that there's "no objection to it". Speaking 
yesterday, the IAG chief executive said, "If customers want to connect from a Ryanair flight, we're very happy to do 
that. There were some commercial issues, but I think it's workable."
The IAG chief executive said he doesn't agree with Mr O'Leary's prediction that legacy carriers such as British 
Airways or Lufthansa will eventually cull their short-haul networks. Last month, Mr O'Leary told the Irish 
Independent that Ryanair will trial interlining at London Stansted and Barcelona later this summer. He said that 
would allow passengers travelling from cities that may not have a major Ryanair route network, such as Belfast, to 
connect to other Ryanair services at Stansted to onwards destinations. IAG, which also owns British Airways, Iberia 
and Vueling, acquired Aer Lingus last year for E1.36bn. Ryanair had tried three times to buy Aer Lingus but was 
blocked by Brussels. Source: www.businessworld.ie

Boeing and Ryanair announce delivery of 737-800 aircraft
Boeing and Ryanair announce delivery of 737-800 aircraft
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 6, 2016 Friday 7:45 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPONENTS & MAINTENANCE
Length: 219 words
Highlight: The Boeing Company and Ryanair Ltd. have announced the delivery of the airline's 400th next-
generation 737-800.
Body
"The Boeing 737-800 aircraft, with its industry leading technical reliability and seating capacity, has been the 
foundation upon which our successful and safe growth has been built upon, since we took our first delivery in March 
1999," said Ryanair's Chief Operations Officer, Michael Hickey. "We are delighted to be now taking delivery of our 
400th 737-800, which includes the new Boeing Sky Interior and slimline seats, offering extra leg room and an 
enhanced customer experience, as part of our 'Always Getting Programme'." "A key factor in Ryanair's continued 
success is the outstanding economics of the Next-Generation 737-800," said Monty Oliver, vice president, 
European Sales, Boeing Commercial Airplanes. 
"This 400th 737 delivery is a special milestone for both our companies and we are honored that Ryanair continues 
to be an all-Boeing operator." Ryanair has more than 130 unfilled orders for Next-Generation 737-800s and is also 
the launch customer for the 737 MAX 200, the newest member of the 737 MAX family. The Dublin-based carrier 
ordered 100 737 MAX 200s, a variant based on the successful 737 MAX 8, that can accommodate up to 200 seats, 
increasing revenue potential and providing airlines with up to 20 percent better fuel efficiency per seat than today's 
most efficient single-aisle airplanes.

Ryanair commences works on flight simulator project in Dublin
Ryanair commences works on flight simulator project in Dublin
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 5, 2016 Thursday 7:43 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 269 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has commenced works on a new flight simulator project at its headquarters in Swords, 
Dublin.
Body
Once complete, this new flight simulator will allow Ryanair to assess cadets and provide an industry leading 
opportunity for pilots to practice their manual handling skills in a relaxed environment. Atkins is providing 
multidiscipline services including; civil and structural, architecture, M&E and fire safety engineering. 
Design works where provided from concept stage through to construction including planning and tender stages. 
Atkins is also providing PSDP and assigned certifier roles. The new annex building which includes a link bridge to 
the existing Ryanair HQ will house the first of a new generation fixed base flight simulator. The building includes two 
new briefing rooms and a large open area in which the simulator will be located. Construction is currently underway 
on site and is expected to complete by the end of May 2016. Justin Norman, director, Atkins, said: "Atkins is 
delighted to be project designers for the new annex to house the simulator. We look forward to completing this 
exciting project successfully with Ryanair and Ganson contractors." Garry Hanratty, project manager, Atkins, said: 
"It's exciting to work with such a dynamic client. The proposed building is being constructed on an existing 
reinforced concrete podium slab which brings its own set of challenges from a design and construction perspective. 
Another interesting challenge is the requirement to keep the Ryanair HQ building and surround infrastructure 
operational at all times. Atkins ultimate goal is to ensure Ryanair has a purpose built building to showcase their first 
new generation fixed base flight simulators."

Airlines will keep on flying for no money
Airlines will keep on flying for no money
Financial Times (London, England)
May 5, 2016 Thursday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMMENT; Pg. 9
Length: 875 words
Byline: John Gapper on Business
Body
Europe's airlines are cutting costs and pledging to pare back the expansion of routes and flights across the 
continent as the boost to their profits from low oil prices fades. Lufthansa this week followed International Airlines 
Group, which owns British Airways and Iberia, in promising to curb capacity .
Should we believe that they - and the US airlines that have been making the highest profits in the world - can 
change their ways and ensure that the industry behaves in a more disciplined fashion than before? Put it this way: 
history is not on their side.
The global airline industry has achieved a remarkable feat in the past couple of years. For the first time since US 
airline deregulation in 1978, it has made sufficiently high profits to be worth investing in. Its recovery from the twin 
shocks of the September 11 2001 terrorist attacks and the financial crisis of 2008 has led to something unfamiliar - 
a respectable bottom line .
You would not know that from the reaction of investors: share prices of US airlines have fallen in 2016, although it is 
likely to be their most rewarding year ever. Like airline luggage, what travels hopefully may not arrive. Shareholders 
have little faith that the companies will resist their old instinct to redistribute all profits to their customers by adding 
new flights and trimming fares.
As one of these customers, I welcome that. Air travel may not be a pleasant experience, but it has become 
remarkably cheap and flexible. I recently found, for example, a return flight from London City Airport to Rotterdam - 
Airlines will keep on flying for no money
both secondary airports - on CityJet, the Irish airline, for £140 including taxes. That would have been outlandish in 
the past but is now commonplace.
Another example: when booking a holiday in Turkey (fares are soft following recent terrorist attacks in Istanbul and 
Ankara), I saw that EasyJet allowed me the choice of landing at three different airports in southern Turkey. At times, 
it feels as if low-cost airlines such as easyJet and Ryanair have taken lessons from Starbucks in clustering 
destinations as tightly as coffee shops.
They can do so profitably because their costs are low, but the relentless growth in flight capacity in the past few 
decades makes it harder for rivals such as Air France-KLM. The number of direct flights such as London-Rotterdam 
has risen from 6,000 globally in 1980 to 17,000 this year; passenger air travel has expanded tenfold in 40 years as 
more people fly more often.
This persistent imbalance of supply and demand - worsened by the fact that new entrants tend to keep on adding 
flights even when legacy carriers try to retrench - has turned airlines into what Warren Buffett once called "a death 
trap for investors". Berkshire Hathaway's chairman should know, having invested $358m in US Air (now part of 
American Airlines) in 1989 and bemoaned his mistake ever since.
Consolidation into the big three legacy airlines - American, Delta and United Airlines - with low-cost Southwest 
making four, has perked up US profitability. "Capacity discipline", the US industry's term for not behaving as laxly as 
usual, helped global airlines to make a respectable return on capital last year. Even so, Mr Buffett is right to prefer 
US railways to airlines as an investment. By coincidence, Delta matched BNSF, the railroad company owned by 
Berkshire, on two measures last year. Both held a 17 per cent share of their respective industries; both made 
operating profits of about $7.8bn.
The resemblance ends there. Even in an exceptional year, Delta's operating margin was 19 per cent compared with 
BNSF's 35 per cent in an ordinary one (it took Delta $41bn of revenues to achieve this operating profit while BNSF 
required only $22bn). BNSF, which runs 32,500 miles of track , is also far better shielded from competition - no one 
will build a matching set of lines.
In theory, airlines should not risk the sacrifice of hard-won profits by adding to capacity at the peak of the cycle and 
returning to wasting capital. Those such as IAG and Lufthansa are trying to avoid it by offering route cuts this week, 
although Lufthansa's share price fell after its first-quarter results .
But there are several obstacles to what would count as common sense in other industries. One is the fierce 
response of regulators. The US Justice Department nearly blocked the merger of American and US Airways in 2013 
because of worries about a potential reduction in competition. Last year, it launched an inquiry into possible 
collusion after airline chief executives talked publicly of "capacity discipline".
Even if regulators were not determined to stamp on profitability, airlines will probably do it themselves. A 
combination of high fixed costs and low seat prices makes it hard to shed capacity - keeping an aircraft sitting on 
the tarmac can end up being more expensive than filling the seats with people paying low fares. As Air France has 
found with recalcitrant pilots , it is difficult for legacy airlines to reduce their wage bills.
In other words, an industry that has been run for decades like a privately financed public utility, with shareholders 
being squeezed and customers reaping the benefits, will probably carry on like that. Happy travels, everyone.
john.gapper@ft.com 
Load-Date: May 4, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair says Brussels attacks still dampening demand Ryanair says Br...
Ryanair says Brussels attacks still dampening demand; Ryanair says Br...
Business World (Digest)
May 4, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 245 words
Highlight: The attacks on Brussels in March continue to dampen demand for flying in Europe, though traffic was 
strong during the Easter holidays, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said on Wednesday.
Body
The attacks on Brussels in March continue to dampen demand for flying in Europe, though traffic was strong during 
the Easter holidays, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said on Wednesday.
O'Leary last month predicted Ryanair's profits would fall by 10-20 million euros in January-March as a result of the 
Brussels attacks and air traffic control strikes, and forecast airlines would have to cut fares.
British Airways-owner IAG and Lufthansa in recent days cited the Brussels attacks as a factor in trimming growth 
plans for the year.
"The Brussels effect has dampened demand into April-May though funnily enough it did not create as much 
disruption over the Easter period, but I think that's because a lot of families had holidays booked," O'Leary told 
journalists at a conference in Dublin. He said Brussels Zaventem airport, where suicide bombs killed 16 people, 
would be back up to full capacity by the end of June and the impact on summer demand would depend on whether 
there were further attacks. "The danger for us is that you have one or two more of these events somewhere in 
Europe during the summer and that will effect confidence," he said. Asked if he was concerned about summer 
demand, O'Leary said he was "always worried about (consumer) confidence ... business is going great and when 
business is going great, that's when you worry." Ryanair is due to announce its results for the year to the end of 
March on May 23. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: May 9, 2016
End of Document

(RYAAY)
DailyPolitical

Body
May 03, 2016( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Clearbridge Investments LLC 
decreased its position in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 2.6% during the fourth quarter, Holdings 
Channel[1] reports. The institutional investor owned 153,028 shares of the company's stock after selling 4,072 
shares during the period. Clearbridge Investments LLC owned 0.06% of Ryanair Holdings plc worth $13,231,000 at

Ryanair expands Leeds Bradford winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair expands Leeds Bradford winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
May 2, 2016 Monday 12:01 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 308 words
Highlight: Ryanair has expanded its Leeds Bradford winter 2016 schedule with a new route to Warsaw Modlin, in 
addition to a new route to Gran Canaria announced earlier.
Body
Ryanair's Leeds Bradford winter 2016 schedule will deliver: 2 new routes: Gran Canaria (2 weekly) & Warsaw 
Modlin (2 weekly); New winter service to Faro (2 weekly); More flights to: Alicante (5 weekly), Krakow (4 weekly), 
Lanzarote (3 weekly) & Tenerife (3 weekly); 13 routes in total; 47 weekly flights; 1.1m customers p.a.; and 825 "on-
site" jobs p.a. Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 13 Leeds 
Bradford routes in winter 2016 and look forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. 
Ryanair's Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch this new route from Leeds Bradford to Warsaw, as part of our 
winter 2016 schedule, which will deliver 1.1 million customers p.a. and support 825jobs at Leeds Bradford Airport, 
as we grow by 20%. This twice weekly service will be popular with both leisure and business customers and we 
look forward to continuing to grow both routes and jobs at Leeds Bradford Airport. "To celebrate our new route to 
Warsaw, we are releasing seats for sale from just GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Wednesday (4 
May) for travel in November and December. 
Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid 
missing out." Tony Hallwood, Aviation Development Director at Leeds Bradford Airport said: "Ryanair's Warsaw 
route from Leeds Bradford Airport is a great addition to their winter schedule from LBA; it's a fantastic destination 
for both city breaks and for business travel. We're really pleased that Ryanair are investing further in their routes 
from LBA, helping to secure jobs for people across our region and provide even more route choice to our 
customers."

Millar joins Stellwagen Group
Millar joins Stellwagen Group
AirFinance Journal
May 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: LATEST NEWS,EUROPE,AIRCRAFT,LESSORS,BREAKING NEWS,IRELAND
Length: 261 words
Highlight: Former Ryanair deputy CEO to lead initial $1 billion capital raise drive for new investment vehicle.
Body
Howard Millar, former Ryanair deputy chief, will head Stellwagen Capital, a subsidiary of Aviation Finance Company 
(AFC).
He will also serve as chief operating officer of Stellwagen Group, the holding company of AFC and Seraph Aviation 
Management.
Stellwagen Capital has announced plans for a $1 billion initial capital raise from institutional investors in Europe and 
the USA by the fourth quarter of this year.
The company expected to raise up to $5 billion from worldwide institutional investors over the next three years.
Investors will include insurance funds, pension funds, banks and investment funds. The group plans to list the 
investment vehicle on the Dublin Stock Exchange via loan notes.
"We will use innovative and highly efficient structures to raise capital for secured financing of both new and 
delivered aircraft, and generate significant returns for our investors," says Millar. "The leveraging of my own and the 
group's outstanding aircraft financing knowledge and experience will have a transformational impact on the 
industry."
Millar brings "game changing" ability to the group with 23 years' experience in aviation, including raising capital in 
the public and debt markets, says Douglas Brennan,Stellwagen Group's chief executive.
"Howard will lead this innovative financing vehicle in raising capital from both the debt markets and from large 
institutional investors mainly, in Europe and the US. This capital will enable the Group to provide secured aircraft 
financing to airlines across the globe," adds Brennan.
Olivier.Bonnassies@euromoneyplc.com
Load-Date: June 6, 2016
Millar joins Stellwagen Group
End of Document
Millar to raise $5bn for operating lease alternative
Millar to raise $5bn for operating lease alternative
AirFinance Journal
May 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: LATEST NEWS,EUROPE,AIRLINES,CAPITAL,LESSORS,BREAKING NEWS,IRELAND
Length: 433 words
Highlight: CEO of StellCap looks to raise capital to fund narrowbodies, A350s and 787s.
Body
Howard Millar, the new CEO of Stellwagen Capital (StellCap) and former CFO of Ryanair, intends to raise $5 billion 
to provide airlines an alternative to operating leasing.
"The economics for an airline in terms of an operating lease are at certain times, not hugely advantageous," he tells 
Airfinance Journal. "We will raise capital, through StellCap. Our sister company AFC will originate the loans and I 
will raise capital and collateralise the loans."
Through StellCap, a newly-formed subsidiary of Stellwagen Finance Company, Millar looks to raise $1 billion by the 
final quarter of 2016 to provide financing for airlines buying aircraft, reaching a total of $5 billion over three years.
"That's our first fund. It will be a 10-year fund, so for the first raise, we've gone to our US lawyers last week and 
we're appointing the people who are going to run our regulated vehicle this week," he adds. "So our plan is to list 
the loan notes on the Dublin Stock Exchange. We are preparing the prospectus for that and we would hope to go 
live in the fourth quarter."
According to Millar, the fund will primarily focus on financing narrowbody aircraft, including Boeing 737s and Airbus 
A320s, but will also consider looking at financing A350 and 787s as well. AFC will continue to work in more 
specialised funds for A380s.
Over a 10-year period, Millar is offering loan-to-values (LTVs) of 80-85% and with "a significant balloon payment of 
the end", of a higher percentage than a typical transaction.
"This is something that is designed to appeal to large pension funds, insurance companies who want to put capital 
to work for a 10-year period and get a targeted return of 8 to 9% per annum," he says.
Millar adds that he has been speaking to investors in the US, Europe, the Middle East and an investor about a 
potential renminbi loan note as well.
Airlines that use the fund will get to own the aircraft at the end of the loan. This is not the case in operating leases 
where the lessor maintains ownership of the aircraft.
Millar to raise $5bn for operating lease alternative
At the end of the 10-year period, the airline can decide to either refinance the aircraft or it can decide to sell it and 
pay off the balloon.
"It's a similar structure to a finance lease, but it's more like a mortgage-debt-type financing. It's a relatively simple 
structure. Airlines pay away huge amounts of maintenance reserves and the operating lessors are making a lot of 
their trading gains from the maintenance reserves."
Millar says that the structure will offer "superior cashflows for the airline" when compared to an operating lease of 
the same tenor.
Jack.Dutton@euromoneyplc.com
Load-Date: June 13, 2016
End of Document
O’Leary: ‘challenges’ mean no pay rise for Ryanair top earners
O’Leary: ‘challenges’ mean no pay rise for Ryanair top earners
Sunday Business Post
May 1, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 271 words
Byline: Colette Sexton
Highlight: No raises for those earning over €100,000 per year except in very exceptional circumstances
Body
Top executives at Ryanair will not receive a pay rise this year because the airline is facing significant challenges, 
according to a note issued to staff from its chief executive, Michael O’Leary. 
Ryanair’s senior management team has seen its pay and bonuses frozen until April 2017 at the earliest. There will 
be no pay increase for non-crew employees earning over €100,000 per year except in very exceptional 
circumstances, O’Leary said. 
In the note, seen by The Sunday Business Post, O’Leary said the factors causing the challenges included the 
terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, increasing price competition from other airlines, targets for traffic growth, and 
an expectation that fares would continue to fall this year after a flat year in 2015. 
O’Leary said he had expected fares to be flat in the last quarter of 2015, but they fell by 1 per cent, while in the 
three months to March, he had expected fares to fall by 3 per cent, but they were now forecast to fall by 6 per cent. 
The note said the airline had “little room for movement this year on pay”, as it would have to further cut its costs to 
fund lower fares, in order to deliver more value and better service for customers. 
The Ryanair board approved a pay increase of 2 per cent for non-crew employees earning under €100,000 per year 
who had no performance or attendance issues in the past 12 months. The company recently concluded long-term 
pay agreements with pilots and cabin crews. 
In February, the airline said its pre-tax profit for the three months to the end of December rose to €103 million, up 
from €49 million for the same period the previous year.
Load-Date: May 2, 2016
O’Leary: ‘challenges’ mean no pay rise for Ryanair top earners
End of Document

â,¬867 million in the previous year.
Total revenues reached â,¬6.53 billion last year, a 16% increase from the â,¬5.65 billion the previous year.
"FY16 was a year in which we delivered significant traffic and profit growth in all four quarters (despite an average 
oil price of $90 per barrel as a consequence of hedges put in place in 2014) as our AGB (Always Getting Better) 
service programme is attracting millions of new customers to our lowest fare and lowest cost model," Michael 
O'Leary, the carrier's CEO, said in a statement.
During the year, traffic increased 18% to 106.4 million passengers. Year-on-year unit costs fell by 6%, says 
Ryanair.
The carrier expects its fuel bill to fall some â,¬200 million in fiscal year 2017 as lower Euro pricing is partially offset 
by bigger volumes due to growth.
Ryanair anticipates between â,¬1.37 billion and â,¬1.42 billion for its 2017 full year net profit guidance. "This 
remains heavily dependent on the strength of close-in summer bookings and next winter's yields, the strength of 
Sterling and the absence of any further external shocks or significant ATC strikes/cancellations," it comments in a 
statement.
Ryanair recorded a â,¬317.5 million gain after selling a 29.8% shareholding in Aer Lingus for â,¬398 million.
During the year, â,¬1.84 billion net cash flow was generated by operating activities.
In its 2016 fiscal year Ryanair took delivery of 41 new Boeing 737-800 units and net capital expenditure reached 
â,¬1.21 billion.
Cash and cash equivalents reached 1.26 billion at the end of the year, up from â,¬1.18 billion in 2015.
Debt repayments accounted for â,¬384.9 million.
Ryanair 's year-on-year profit rises by 43%
This year the Irish low-cost carrier plans to receive 52 aircraft, which will grow its fleet to 380 units by year-end.

Tony Fernandes : Consolidation has always been my plan
Tony Fernandes: Consolidation has always been my plan
AirFinance Journal
May 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: LATEST NEWS,BREAKING NEWS,MALAYSIA,ASIA
Length: 111 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Highlight: AirAsia boss says ownership rules restrict him from having a similar structure to EasyJet and Ryanair.
Body
AirAsia's CEO Tony Fernandes is not ruling out consolidation of his low-cost carrier's regional airline units into one 
entity, according to an article in Malaysian newspaper The Star.
"This has always been my plan, to consolidate, but we have to talk to many different authorities to do so. There is 
no timeframe yet," he was quoted as saying.
"If you compare us with EasyJet or Ryanair, they don't have an EasyJet Poland, etc. They just have an entity. 
Because of ownership rules, we have to have the kind of structure that we have today," he added.
To see all of AirAsia's recent and historic deals visitAirfinance Journal's Deals Database.

Ireland 's most reputable organisations in 2016 Ireland 's most .
Ireland's most reputable organisations in 2016; Ireland's most .
Business World (Digest)
April 29, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 473 words
Highlight: Ireland's most reputable organisations are being celebrated today after the Reputations Agency 
released their Ireland RepTrak 2016 study.
Body
Ireland's most reputable organisations are being celebrated today after the Reputations Agency released their 
Ireland RepTrak 2016 study.
The study was compiled by the Reputations Agency and their global partners the Reputation Institute and ranks the 
100 largest and most visible organisations in Ireland based on 5,093 responses gathered from the general public 
from 4th January to 14th March 2016.
Bord Bia has been named the most reputable organisation in Ireland followed by Eason & Son (2nd), An Post (3rd), 
Google (4th) and Lidl (5th).
The independent study ranked each company on its RepTrak Pulse score, representing an average measure of 
four emotional indicators: trust, esteem, admiration and good feeling. It also studied how organisations were rated 
across the seven more rational dimensions of reputation - leadership, products & services, innovation, governance, 
workplace, performance and citizenship. This is the seventh year of the most comprehensive study of corporate 
reputations undertaken in Ireland. This year's report shows that organisations operating in food related sectors were 
among those with the top reputations, with eight ranked in the top 20 - Bord Bia (1st), Lidl (5th), Aldi (7th), 
SuperValu (11th), Kellogg's (14th ), Glanbia (15th), Cadbury (16th) and Kerry Group (20th). Indigenous Irish 
organisations were also well represented in the top rankings with four listed in the coveted top six positions - Bord 
Bia (1st), Eason & Son (2nd), An Post (3rd), and The Irish League of Credit Unions (6th). The reputation of the 
leading sporting bodies was tracked with the IRFU achieving the highest ranking in that sector at 23rd place overall. 
GAA was ranked 49th while FAI was placed in 95th position overall. The report indictes that the reputation of 
companies among the general public fell slightly in 2016 having flatlined in 2015, following rises in trust recorded in 
2013 and 2014. Furthermore, the report shows that companies investing in building their reputation are winning 
competitive advantage. Ryanair's continued focus on customer experience with its "Always Getting Better" 
Ireland 's most reputable organisations in 2016 Ireland 's most .
programme, now in its third year, has seen it rise from 99th place in 2013 to 63rd position in 2016. During that 
period its share price has almost tripled. Managing Director at The Reputations Agency, Niamh Boyle says, 
"Reputation drives business results as a strong reputation helps to win customers, attract the right people, gain 
support from key stakeholders and ultimately drive business performance." She added, "Therefore, it is essential for 
organisational leaders to have a deep understanding of what is driving their own reputational ranking. Armed with 
the insights from this reputational analysis a business can take steps to build on their strengths and correct their 
weaknesses." Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: May 4, 2016
End of Document

MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 29, 2016 Friday 6:28 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 247 words
Highlight: Ryanair has expanded its Newcastle winter 2016 schedule with three new routes to Gdansk, Warsaw 
and Wroclaw, bringing the total number of routes to eight including Lanzarote and Tenerife.
Body
Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 8 Newcastle routes in 
winter 2016 and look forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme, which 
includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Robin Kiely 
said: "We are pleased to launch 3 new routes from Newcastle to Gdansk, Warsaw and Wroclaw, as part of our 
significantly expanded winter 2016 schedule, bringing the total number of routes to 8 including Lanzarote and 
Tenerife, which will help deliver 400,000 customers p.a. and support 300 jobs, as we more than double our 
operation at Newcastle Airport. "To celebrate our 3 new routes to Gdansk, Warsaw and Wroclaw, we are releasing 
seats for sale from just GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Wednesday (4 May) for travel in November 
and December Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto 
www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
David Laws, CEO at Newcastle International Airport: "We are delighted to see Ryanair continue to build its 
presence in the region and the announcement of these exciting new city routes is great news for the North East 
travelling public. Poland is a vibrant country with a host of attractions on offer and we expect these flights to 
Gdansk, Warsaw and Wroclaw to be extremely popular, offering our passengers even more choice and availability 
from Newcastle Airport."
Load-Date: May 13, 2016

Ryanair expands Birmingham winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair expands Birmingham winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 29, 2016 Friday 6:28 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 151 words
Highlight: Ryanair has expanded its Birmingham winter 2016 schedule with a new route to Warsaw, in addition to a 
new route to Sofia which was announced earlier.
Body
Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 22 Birmingham routes in 
winter 2016 and look forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme, which 
includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Robin Kiely 
said: "We are pleased to launch this new route from Birmingham to Warsaw, as part of our significantly expanded 
winter 2016 schedule, which will help deliver 2 million customers and support 1,500 on-site jobs p.a. at Birmingham 
Airport, as we grow by over 50%. "To celebrate our new route to Warsaw, we are releasing seats for sale from just 
GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Wednesday (4 May) for travel in November and December. Since 
these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid 
missing out."

Ryanair forced to cancel over 100 flights today over French ATC strikes Ryanair forced ...
Ryanair forced to cancel over 100 flights today over French ATC strikes; 
Ryanair forced ...
Business World (Digest)
April 28, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 208 words
Highlight: Ryanair yesterday called on the European Commission to take action to prevent the skies over Europe 
being closed by French ATC unions striking.
Body
Ryanair yesterday called on the European Commission to take action to prevent the skies over Europe being closed 
by French ATC unions striking.
Ryanair has been forced to cancel over 100 flights today with further delays likely. They claim this is the fourth time 
in the last six weeks and the forty-fourth time in the last seven years that this has happened.
The airline has advised customers travelling on Thursday to check the status of their flight on the Ryanair.com 
website before travelling to the airport.They have also urged all those affected to sign its Keep Europe's Skies Open 
petition which it will present to the European Commission once it accrues a million signatures.
Chief Financial Officer & Deputy CEO at Ryanair, Kenny Jacobs said, "Once more Europe's consumers are being 
held to ransom by tiny French ATC unions, causing hundreds of thousands of passenger flights to be cancelled or 
delayed." 
He 
added, 
"We 
urge 
every 
disrupted 
customer 
to 
sign 
up 
to 
Ryanair's 
petition, 
www.KeepEuropesSkiesOpen.com, and we call on the European Commission to prevent Europe's skies being 
closed by French ATC yet again. How many more flights and customers will be disrupted before the Commission 
finally takes action?" Source:            www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: May 3, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair expands Belfast winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair expands Belfast winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 28, 2016 Thursday 5:42 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 432 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has expanded its Belfast winter 2016 schedule with three new routes to Gdansk, Warsaw 
and Wroclaw, in addition to the seven new routes announced earlier to Alicante, Berlin, Krakow, Lanzarote, Malaga, 
Milan and Tenerife.
Body
Ryanair's Belfast W 2016 schedule will deliver: three based aircraft; 10 new routes to: Alicante (2 wkly), Berlin (3 
wkly), Gdansk (2 wkly), Krakow (3 wkly), Lanzarote (2 wkly), Malaga (3 wkly), Milan (2 wkly), Tenerife (2 wkly), 
Warsaw (2 wkly) & Wroclaw (2 wkly); more flights to London Gatwick (5 daily); 11 routes in total; 60 weekly flights; 
Over 1m customers p.a.; and 750 on-site jobs p.a. These new Belfast routes make Ryanair the perfect choice for NI 
business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 11 Belfast routes in winter 2016 at the lowest fares and 
look forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme, which includes more 
new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, 
Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to launch 3 new routes from our Belfast base to Gdansk, Warsaw and 
Wroclaw, as part of our winter 2016 schedule, in addition to the 7 new routes announced earlier to Alicante, Berlin, 
Krakow, Lanzarote, Malaga, Milan and Tenerife, and the extra flights to London Gatwick (5 x daily), which will 
deliver over 1 million customers p.a. and support 750 jobs at Belfast International Airport. 
Our new Polish routes will be ideal for both business and leisure customers and we look forward to growing routes, 
traffic and jobs in Belfast in the coming months and years. "To celebrate, we are releasing seats for sale from just 
GBP19.99 our new Gdansk, Warsaw and Wroclaw routes, which are available for booking until Wednesday (4 May) 
for travel in November and December. Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers 
should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Belfast International Airport Managing Director, Graham 
Keddie, said: "This is more fantastic news from Ryanair. It means that this winter should be one of our busiest ever. 
Gdansk, Warsaw and Wroclaw follow Krakow and deliver a very comprehensive network to a new and important 
Polish market. "We currently stand as the eleventh largest airport in the UK, but I expect that with continuing airline 
expansion and growth in passenger numbers, we will break into the 'Top Ten' before too long. The airport is 
delivering real economic benefit for Northern Ireland and that means new employment and business opportunities. 
"These new Polish routes are delivered without any government support and show only a fraction of what could be 
Ryanair expands Belfast winter 2016 schedule
achieved if APD were removed. Despite this 'headwind', we're making great progress and have reason to believe 
we can maintain the momentum."

Ryanair expands Manchester winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair expands Manchester winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 28, 2016 Thursday 6:18 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 284 words
Highlight: Ryanair has expanded its Manchester winter 2016 schedule with a new route to Wroclaw, in addition to 
the three new routes announced earlier to Berlin, Hamburg and Nuremberg.
Body
Ryanair's Manchester winter 2016 schedule will deliver: 4 new routes: Berlin (daily), Hamburg (daily), Nuremberg 
(daily) & Wroclaw (3 wkly); 8 new winter routes: Bratislava (3 wkly), Carcassonne (2 wkly), Limoges (2 wkly), Malta 
(3 wkly), Murcia (3 wkly), Palma (3 wkly), Paris (3 wkly) & Valencia (2 wkly); 35 routes in total; Over 200 weekly 
flights; 4.1m customers p.a.; and 3,100 "on-site" jobs p.a. Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure 
customers, who can now choose from 35 Manchester routes in winter 2016 and look forward to further 
improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme, which includes more new routes, new digital 
features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch a new 
Manchester route to Wroclaw, as part of our significantly expanded winter 2016 schedule, which also includes 3 
new routes to Berlin, Hamburg and Nuremberg, which will help deliver 4.1m customers p.a. and support 3,100 jobs 
at Manchester Airport, as we grow by 33%. "To celebrate our new route to Wroclaw, we are releasing seats for sale 
from just GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Wednesday (4 May) for travel in November and 
December. 
Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid 
missing out." Stephen Turner, Commercial Director at Manchester Airport, said: "It is great to see Ryanair add 
another destination to its offering here at Manchester Airport, the UK's third largest. "The new route to Wroclaw 
strengthens the airport's offering to Poland and gives the 22m people in our large catchment area more choice 
when flying from the North."

Ryanair expands Edinburgh winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair expands Edinburgh winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 28, 2016 Thursday 5:44 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 238 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has expanded its Edinburgh winter 2016 schedule with a new route to Warsaw, in addition 
to the six new winter services announced earlier to Bologna, Bordeaux, Bratislava, Gran Canaria, Palma and 
Poznan.
Body
Ryanair's Edinburgh winter 2016 schedule will deliver: one new route to Warsaw (3 wkly); 6 new winter services to 
Bologna (2 wkly), Bordeaux (2 wkly), Bratislava (2 wkly), Gran Canaria (2 wkly), Palma (2 wkly) & Poznan (2 wkly); 
more flights to Alicante (4 wkly), Barcelona (5 wkly), Copenhagen (4 wkly), Malaga (4 wkly), Rome Ciampino (5 
wkly) & Tenerife (4 wkly); 24 total routes; 118 weekly flights; 2.5m customers p.a. (+20%); and 1,900 on-site jobs 
p.a. Ryanair is the ideal choice for business and leisure customers, who can now choose from 24 Edinburgh routes 
in winter 2016 and look forward to further improvements, under Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" programme, 
which includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. Ryanair's Robin 
Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch this new route from Edinburgh to Warsaw, as part of our significantly 
expanded winter 2016 schedule, which includes 6 new winter services to Bologna, Bordeaux, Bratislava, Gran 
Canaria, Palma and Poznan, which will help deliver 2.5 million customers p.a. and support 1,900 jobs at Edinburgh 
Airport. 
"To celebrate our new Warsaw route, we are releasing seats for sale from just GBP19.99, which are available for 
booking until Wednesday (4 May) for travel in November and December. Since these amazing low prices will be 
snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out."
