Carnegie Court Hotel goes for sale
Carnegie Court Hotel goes for sale
Sunday Business Post
April 28, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 175 words
Byline: Mary Hallissey
Highlight: Guide price of €4.75m for 36-room airport-adjacent three-star
Body
The three star Carnegie Court Hotel in Swords, Co Dublin, has been brought to the market by Savills with a guide 
price of €4.75m.
The well-established 36-bedroom hotel, located close to Dublin Airport, was purpose-built in 2001 and comes with 
full grant of planning to convert existing areas into an additional 35 bedrooms.
The hotel also houses one of Swords' best-known bars the Harp, the Courtyard restaurant and Rouge nightclub.
Carnegie Court is a popular venue for weddings and special occasions with conference and banqueting facilities. 
The property was granted planning permission for an additional 35 bedrooms within the existing ground and first 
floors. If completed this would result in 71 bedrooms in total.
The hotel has excellent connectivity to the city and Ireland’s busiest airport. Over 25 million passengers used Dublin 
Airport in 2015 and passenger numbers grew by 17 per cent in q1. 
Dublin Airport recently announced the planned construction of a second runway for €320m.
Other local businesses include Fyffes, Medtronic and Ryanair.
Load-Date: May 30, 2016
End of Document

Apr 26, 2016( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Alliancebernstein L.P. increased 
its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 49.9% during the fourth quarter, Holdings 
Channel[1] reports. The institutional investor owned 417,522 shares of the company's stock after buying an 
additional 138,919 shares during the period. Alliancebernstein L.P. owned about 0.16% of Ryanair Holdings plc 
worth $36,099,000 as of its most recent SEC filing. 
Several other large investors have also made changes to their positions in RYAAY. Fifth Third Bancorp increased 
its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 932.5% in the fourth quarter. Fifth Third Bancorp now owns 108,828 
shares of the company's stock valued at $9,409,000 after buying an additional 98,288 shares during the period. 
Visium Asset Management LP increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 599.1% in the fourth quarter. 
Visium Asset Management LP now owns 75,500 shares of the company's stock valued at $6,527,000 after buying 
an additional 64,700 shares during the period. AJO LP increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 
57.6% in the fourth quarter. AJO LP now owns 66,824 shares of the company's stock valued at $5,778,000 after 
buying an additional 24,410 shares during the period. Standard Pacific Capital LLC CA acquired a new stake in 
shares of Ryanair Holdings plc during the fourth quarter valued at $3,605,000. Finally, Gluskin Sheff ...soc Inc. 
increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 64.0% in the fourth quarter. Gluskin Sheff ...soc Inc. now 
owns 1,206,588 shares of the company's stock valued at $104,322,000 after buying an additional 471,028 shares 
during the period. Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) opened at 80.49 on Tuesday. The stock has a market 
capitalization of $21.24 billion and a PE ratio of 12.57. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 week low of $65.13 and a 52 
week high of $88.24. The stock's 50 day moving average is $83.09 and its 200-day moving average is $82.25. 
RYAAY has been the subject of several analyst reports. Zacks Investment Research[3] raised shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $95.00 price target for the company in a report on 
Monday, January 25th. Vetr[4] cut shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'strong-buy' rating to a 'buy' rating and set 
a $83.00 price target for the company. in a report on Wednesday, February 10th. Beaufort Securities reissued a 
'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a report on Tuesday, April 5th. Finally, Raymond James increased 
their target price on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc to $100.00 in a report on Friday, March 25th. One research 
analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have given a hold rating, six have given a buy rating and one has 
given a strong buy rating to the company. Ryanair Holdings plc presently has an average rating of 'Buy' and an 
average price target of $89.60. Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[5]) is a holding company for Ryanair 
Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco.Want to see what other hedge funds are

Ryanair launches Bristol 2016 winter schedule
Ryanair launches Bristol 2016 winter schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 22, 2016 Friday 6:50 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 262 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has launched its Bristol 2016 winter schedule with three new routes to Krakow, Milan and 
Venice, and additional flights to Alicante, Faro, Lanzarote, Malaga and Warsaw.
Body
Ryanair's Bristol winter 2016 schedule will deliver: 3 new winter routes: Krakow (3 weekly), Milan Bergamo (3 
weekly) & Venice Treviso (2 weekly); More flights to: Alicante, Faro, Lanzarote, Malaga & Warsaw; 18 routes in 
total; 68 weekly flights (+24%); 1.7m customers p.a. (+200,000); and 1,300 "on-site" jobs p.a. UK consumers and 
visitors can choose from 18 Bristol routes in winter 2016 and can look forward to further improvements, as Ryanair 
continues to grow strongly, while improving its customer experience through the "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, new digital features, new cabin interiors and even more low fares. 
Ryanair's Robin Kiely said: "These new winter services will be ideal for business and leisure customers, and will 
allow us to grow our traffic by 200,000 customers at Bristol Airport this year. "To celebrate the launch of our Bristol 
winter 2016 schedule, we are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European network at fares starting from 
just GBP19.99 which are available for booking until Monday (25 April) for travel in May and June. Since these 
amazing low prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." 
Shaun Browne, Aviation Director, Bristol Airport said: "We are delighted to have Ryanair's winter programme on 
sale with additional flights to key destinations, providing improved options for year round travel to cities such as 
Milan and Venice, as well as increased frequencies to sun destinations in Spain, Portugal and the Canary Islands."

Ryanair to launch new route from Nis to Berlin
Ryanair to launch new route from Nis to Berlin
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 22, 2016 Friday 10:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 164 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced the launch of its first Serbia flights, with a new route from Nis to Berlin 
commencing on September 4, 2016.
Body
Ryanair's Serbian operations will deliver: 1 new route to Berlin (2 x weekly - Thursday & Sunday); 2 weekly return 
flights to/from Nis Airport; and 30,000 customers p.a. Ryanair's Chiara Ravara said: "Ryanair is pleased to 
announce our entry into the Serbian market from September 2016, our 32nd country, with one new route to Berlin 
Schonefeld which will deliver 30,000 customers annually. "Serbian customers can look forward to Ryanair service 
improvements in the coming months, including new aircraft interiors, new uniforms and more new routes, under our 
"Always Getting Better" programme, as we continue to offer so much more than just the lowest fares. "To celebrate 
our new route we are releasing seats from Nis to Berlin from E24.99 for travel in September to November, which 
are available for booking from tomorrow until midnight Wednesday (27 April). Since these amazing low fares will be 
snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out."

Illegal migrants could enter over and over again
Illegal migrants could enter over and over again
Financial Times (London, England)
April 19, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Pg. 12
Length: 168 words
Body
Sir, Theresa Villiers, the Northern Ireland secretary, tells the FT that Nigel Lawson, another leading campaigner for 
Brexit, "made a mistake" when he said "there would have to be border controls" to stop migrants entering the UK 
from the Republic of Ireland if Britain left the EU ( report , April 15).
But, if there are no border controls with Ireland, how will the Leave campaign keep its promise to stop free 
movement of people from the EU? Ms Villiers' answer is that migrants who entered illegally via the Irish border 
could be dealt with by the authorities once they had arrived. Presumably, that means tracking down these EU 
citizens and sending them home.
Forget the fact that the UK government is not terribly good at finding illegal migrants. Even if it did grab them, what 
would be the point in sending them home? Wouldn't they just jump on the next Ryanair to Dublin and return to the 
UK? After all, any EU citizen would still have the right to go to Ireland.
Hugo Dixon
Chairman,
InFacts,
London SW1, UK
Illegal migrants could enter over and over again

No Headline In Original
No Headline In Original
Flight International
April 19, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORKING WEEK
Length: 660 words
Body
Have you always been interested in aviation?
Yes, I have always been a big fan of flying. When I saw the advertisement for an aircraft maintenance 
apprenticeship it immediately caught my eye, as it would enable me to learn exactly how aircraft got in the air and 
stayed there.
What are your qualifications?
I am an avionic technician. My experience is mainly in heavy base maintenance on the Boeing 737, 757, 767 and 
777. I am in the process of applying for a B2 licence and I plan to apply for a B1 licence next year.
You recently competed in the WorldSkills Competition. What is it and how did you become involved?
The WorldSkills Competition is held every two years and is the biggest vocational education and skills excellence 
event in the world. It is designed to show off your vocational skills and compete against the best in your field. To 
qualify for the championship, in the aircraft maintenance category, I took part in the 2014 and 2015 Irish National 
Skills competition. I won the 2014 event and was invited to compete again the following year as a guest. After this I 
was selected to represent Ireland in the 43rd WorldSkills Competition in São Paulo, Brazil. From June to mid-
August 2015, I trained intensely at the Shannon training centre. The competition itself lasted four days. During that 
time, I competed in seven disciplines: sheet metal repair; flight control rigging; daily inspection of an aircraft; gas 
turbine engine borescope inspection and hot section inspection; gas turbine compressor inspection and blade 
blending and polishing; powered flying control unit removal, inspection, reassembly and rigging; and fabrication and 
installation of an electrical wiring loom and fault finding. It is an experience that I will carry with me always and I 
know that it has helped mould and mature me, both professionally and personally.
What does your job entail?
My day-to-day work, with Ryanair, includes routine and non-routine rectifications, servicing, inspections, 
troubleshooting, functional testing and especially avionic modifications. I am an avionic technician so the majority of 
my work is based around aircraft electrical systems.
No Headline In Original
Describe your typical day
At the moment I am working nights, so I will describe my typical night. I get up around 16:30 and leave for work at 
20:00. After a quick team meeting I get started on the modification – I am currently working on an avionic 
modification programme. The work consists of aircraft strip-out to get access for the new wiring, wiring installation 
and continuity checks, aircraft rebuild and, finally, function testing of the disturbed systems. I finish at 08:00 and 
after a quick snack and a chat with my wife I go to bed.
What are your ambitions?
I am in the process of applying for my B2 licence. Once I get my licence I want to become a certifying engineer on 
the aircraft. Later on down the line I would like to be involved with [the] training of aircraft maintenance technicians.
What activities do you do in your spare time?
I am currently working a four- days-on, four-days-off shift in England, so on my days off I am back in Ireland 
spending time with my wife and our puppy, going for walks or watching a film. I am a huge rugby fan, so I also try to 
watch as many matches as I can, especially Leinster and Ireland. n
WORK EXPERIENCE ros wynne
Technician’s skills put to the test
Avionic specialist Ros Wynne was initially attracted by an apprenticeship advert. After gaining experience on a 
range of Boeing types, he demonstrated his vocational expertise during a WorldSkills Competition in Brazil

licence I want to
become a certifying
engineer, and later be

kate.sarsfield@flightglobal.com

Boardroom Briefing
Boardroom Briefing
Sunday Business Post
April 17, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 561 words
Byline: Emma Kennedy and Fearghal O'Connor
Body
Ryanair unveils new customer initiatives
Ryanair has announced plans for a number of new initiatives, including new business and leisure packages, 
simplified baggage options and a dedicated travel agency for school tours, as part of its 'Always Getting Better' 
programme aimed at improving customer service. 
The airline also plans to launch a 'My Ryanair' Club, which will offer 24-hour priority access to seat sales, and a top-
up facility which will allow customers to top up the accounts of friends or family as gifts. 
The airline, which will roll out the initiatives over the next year, said its load factor had risen to 92 per cent from 81 
per cent since the start of the programme two years ago. 
"The continued drive to improve our customer experience has been reflected in the record passenger numbers and 
load factors we have had over the past two years," said Kenny Jacobs, Ryanair's chief marketing officer. 
ICG snaps up high-speed vessel
Irish Continental Group has struck a multi-million dollar deal to acquire a high-speed vessel. 
The company announced last week that it had reached an agreement to purchase the Westpac Express from BALI 
Westpac 2006 for $13.25 million. 
Under the terms of the deal, title to the vessel will transfer to ICG on delivery which is expected by late May, the 
company said in a statement. 
The vessel was built in 2001 by Austal Ships in Australia. It has passenger capacity of 900 and a car carrying 
capacity of 182, according to ICG's statement. 
Boardroom Briefing
FBD appoints new director
Insurer FBD has announced the appointment of a new chief financial officer. 
John O'Grady, a chartered accountant, will join FBD's board on July 1 as an executive director and chief financial 
officer. 
O'Grady will join FBD from Liberty Insurance, where he is currently finance director. He previously worked for Aviva 
and "its predecessor companies in Ireland in various roles between 1989 and 2013, including finance director, 
claims director and operations director", FBD said in a statement. 
O'Grady will take over from Paul D'Alton, who has held the role of interim chief financial officer since last October. 
Davy upgrades its economic forecasts
Davy Stockbrokers has raised its Irish economic growth forecasts, and now expects GDP to grow by 6 per cent this 
year and 4 per cent next year "due to the exceptionally strong momentum in the economy that has been maintained 
into early 2016". 
However, Davy also warned that the possibility of Brexit, along with political uncertainty at home, posed a threat to 
its forecasts. It had previously forecast GDP growth of 4 per cent this year and 3.7 per cent next year. 
In a research note, Davy economist Conall Mac Coille said that last year's exceptional growth rate of 7.8 per cent 
meant that even if the economy flat-lined, it would still expand by 3.3 per cent in 2016. 
Strong quarterly figures released by ISE
Total listings on ISE markets have grown to almost 34,400 securities from over 4,000 issuers in 80 countries, 
according to the latest quarterly statistics from the Irish Stock Exchange (ISE). 
The ISE figures indicated that equity trades reached record levels and turnover rose by 26 per cent, compared with 
the previous quarter. 
Among the global companies listing new debt instruments on the ISE during the first three months of this year were 
car maker Ferrari and telecommunications giant Vodafone.
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document
O'Leary: ' Irish politics depresses me'
O'Leary: 'Irish politics depresses me'
Sunday Business Post
April 17, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 499 words
Byline: Jack Horgan-Jones
Highlight: Ireland should slash personal tax rates to lure Russian oligarchs
Body
Tax avoidance by high-net worth individuals will continue unabated despite scandals like the Panama papers, 
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary has said. 
"That will always be with us," he said. "Wealthy people can move. The wealthy people have the luxury of making 
those choices, and will." 
He said that Ireland should slash its personal tax rates in an attempt to lure high net worth individuals from London. 
"Why are all the Russian oligarchs and Chinese in London? It's because London is a very low-tax system if you're 
rich. Why doesn't Dublin do something like that, why don't we encourage them to come and live here in Dublin? 
Because, even though it's the intelligent thing to do, it's not politically attractive." 
He also predicted that tax avoidance by multinational companies would not be stamped out, despite moves by 
Brussels to clamp down on corporate profit-shifting. 
"The Europeans as usual, led by some idiots in France, believe: 'If we pass a law, we can tax them all here in 
France.' It simply won't work and it's why the French economy is in the complete toilet," he said. 
"It's the regulators coming around after the event and trying to close the stable door after the horse has bolted. 
Multinational companies will have no difficulty producing country-by-country accounts. They will tell you just as little 
as the multinational single set of accounts do now." 
The European Commission last week introduced new rules which could lead to companies with over (EURO)750 
million in revenue publicly disclosing information about what they earn, and how much tax they pay in individual 
countries. 
O'Leary: ' Irish politics depresses me'
On the subject of personal tax avoidance, O'Leary said that wealthy people would naturally gravitate towards 
jurisdictions which allowed them to reduce their tax bills. 
The tycoon was speaking at the launch of the re-election campaign of TCD Senator Sean Barrett, whose candidacy 
he is endorsing. "We have far too few sound, sensible economists in the Dáil and in the Seanad. As an electorate, 
we have a terrible record of electing every lunatic and halfwit who runs, and that's why the country is in the mess it's 
currently in. We need sensible people like Sean in the Seanad," he said. 
"I'm very depressed by the state of the political system here in Ireland, but it's not fair to blame the politicians. We 
should blame ourselves as the electorate," 
O'Leary, who was paid (EURO)1.75 million in 2014 and is fully tax resident in Ireland, said that proposals from Sinn 
Féin and other figures on the left for a wealth tax were misguided. 
"If they introduce a wealth tax, I'll be gone on the next Ryanair flight out of the country," he said. 
He criticised single-issue candidates as "not capable of running the country", and asked the electorate to "please 
vote for parties that actually have an economic policy and stop voting for the local bankrupt property developer, the 
local doctor or dentist or the local sanitary officer, because they're not capable of running the country".
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document
Profile Eddie O'Leary: The other O'Leary
Profile Eddie O'Leary: The other O'Leary
Sunday Business Post
April 17, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1760 words
Byline: Fearghal O'Connor
Highlight: The brains behind Gigginstown is reluctant to share limelight
Body
Factfile
Age:54 
Appearance: quiet observer 
Newsworthiness: calls the shots at Gigginstown House Stud, which captured the Grand National last week 
Only an all-too-rare victorious Westmeath team could get the same reaction in Mullingar. Hundreds of cheering 
local people lined Austin Friar Street as Aintree Grand National winner Rule The World was paraded proudly by his 
owner, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary. 
Teenage jockey David Mullins was there. So too was Rule The World's hugely popular trainer Michael 'Mouse' 
Morris. O'Leary's mother Ger beamed proudly alongside the wider O'Leary family. 
But one person, without whom the marvellous victory could never have taken place, was missing. Michael's brother 
Eddie, racing manager - and so much more - at the aviation tycoon's Gigginstown House Stud, had gone straight 
from Aintree to the Newmarket "breeze up" sales. It was always business before pleasure for the O'Learys. 
     
Michael O'Leary's chequebook is so big he could probably buy every horse in the Grand National. But where's the 
fun in that? Instead, brother Eddie trawls auctions for raw talent that others don't see. 
Rule The World's Grand National victory, a day earlier, was the latest in a string of victories that has turned 
Gigginstown into a powerhouse of National Hunt racing. 
Profile Eddie O'Leary: The other O'Leary
Weeks earlier another Gigginstown horse, Don Cossack, had won the Cheltenham Gold Cup and Rogue Angel won 
the Irish Grand National. 
"Eddie is some judge of a horse, I can tell you," Mouse Morris tells this newspaper. "To buy one Gold Cup winner in 
a lifetime is very good. To buy two, and two Grand National winners, is effin' unbelievable. I wouldn't think anyone 
else has ever done that." 
     
Eddie O'Leary - one year Michael's junior - answers the phone. He is horrified as I explain that I am writing a profile 
of him on the back of the pivotal part he has played in his brother's Gigginstown success. 
"Oh no, no. Do the profile on him . . . I'm the silent one," he says in a stronger Westmeath accent than his brother's. 
I explain that we want to profile the real brains of the Gigginstown operation. He laughs. 
"Ah, every mug is lucky the odd time. Listen, we're having a good run at the moment, but runs tend to stop." 
People close to Gigginstown had told me that hard work over the last decade is only now paying off and well-laid 
plans are now coming to fruition. 
"Everything in this game is hopefully, hopefully, hopefully," says Eddie. "Things can go wrong so quickly. No More 
Heroes was our best young horse by a long way and we left him in Cheltenham." 
The horse was strongly in contention jumping the last fence in the RSA Chase, but slowed sharply. He had severed 
a tendon and was put down that night. 
 It wasn't the first time the two brothers had lost a horse. In 2001, having conquered the airline world, Michael told 
Eddie he wanted to "have a bit of fun". Eddie chose for him his first horse, Tuco. It won the Fairyhouse bumper. 
Two more victories followed and the elder O'Leary began to get a taste for it. But tragedy struck a year later at 
Fairyhouse. Tuco fell at the third-last fence and was killed. 
Eddie is philosophical: "We've been in horses all our lives, and unfortunately those things happen. It tends to be the 
good ones, because they go a bit faster." 
But his brother was devastated: "It was a big shock to Mike. He said that never again would his entire stream be 
wiped out in one day. 'Get me a few horses,' he told me." 
Eddie called to trainer Ger Hourigan, who had a horse that had caught his eye in a recent point to point. 
"He'd the race won easily but fell at the last. I watched the Cheltenham Gold Cup in Ger's house and then bought 
the horse. It was War of Attrition. The rest is history. If Tuco hadn't died, we wouldn't have got War of Attrition." 
St Patrick's Day 2006. The Gold Cup. Huge Irish crowds pack Prestbury Park, revelling as the Celtic Tiger enters its 
final days. Beef or Salmon, beaten in three previous Gold Cups, is favourite to finally bring home victory. War of 
Attrition drifts from 7-1 to 15-2 as the horses mill around the start. 
And they're off! War of Attrition, out wide, avoiding trouble. Forget The Past and Hedgehunter, both Irish, jostle for 
the lead. Four to go. Conor O'Dwyer, onboard War of Attrition, makes his move. Every jump perfection. Ruby Walsh 
on Hedgehunter battles back up the home stretch. The crowd erupts. War of Attrition holds on. It's a one-two-three 
for the Irish.Michael O'Leary and Gigginstown have arrived. 
"My brother Eddie bought this horse four years ago and always thought he had a chance . . . I thought he was 
dreaming," an overjoyed Michael says breathlessly, cameras clicking furiously. Four years later the Ryanair boss 
would pay emotional tribute to War of Attrition after it ran its last race at Punchestown: "Apart from the birth of my 
children, this horse has given me the best days of my life." 
Profile Eddie O'Leary: The other O'Leary
Eddie's advice to buy "staying chasers" - horses that race over three miles, or more over fences - had paid off. 
Such big, elegant horses - chosen as foals by Eddie, less for their pedigree than for what he saw in them - would 
become Gigginstown's calling card. A clear focus on buying horses to win the biggest races has helped to sustain 
the national hunt scene while other recession-hit owners crashed out of the game. 
So who's the boss, I ask Eddie O'Leary? "Oh, there's only one boss," he says, laughing. 
"It's Mike's hobby. People like Mike and JP McManus could easily be sailing yachts. But they have a hobby of 
racing horses and it's good for Ireland. It's not long ago since we had no winners at Cheltenham and every good 
horse was sold to England. It's fantastic for the country and for rural employment. Fair dues to them." 
Gigginstown is estimated to have about 200 horses, spread out across a large number of independently-run yards 
across rural Ireland. Recent estimates suggest that since 2010, Gigginstown has pocketed more than (EURO)13 
million in winnings. That may cover the cost of training the horses, but probably not the cost of buying them, 
although Gigginstown's finances are kept private. 
"There's no financial return whatsoever in jump racing," says one insider with knowledge of the Gigginstown 
business. "In flat racing, for the likes of Coolmore, it is all about residual value. A filly wins and becomes valuable as 
a mare for breeding. With jump racing, the horses are geldings and so have no residual value. 
"It's about the love of the game and nothing else. Prize money is never going to cover the costs. The horses are 
expensive to buy, expensive to train. It's a rich man's game." 
But Michael O'Leary, of all people, has no interest in throwing away money. He expects winners, and his brother 
regularly delivers. Eddie pores over auction catalogues deciding the value of young horses in which he sees 
potential. 
"At auction, Eddie's real expertise comes to pass," says the insider. "He has decided beforehand what a horse is 
worth and he stops right there if it goes higher. That's it. He knows exactly when to stop spending his brother's 
money. That's why it's successful. Loyalty and trust." 
     
The O'Learys grew up in Lynn Lodge, a fine detached home on Mullingar's Lynn Road. Their father Ted, originally 
from Kanturk, Co Cork, was a businessman who, along with wife Ger, moved to Mullingar in the 1960s. There, he 
set up a number of businesses, including a woollen business called Tailteann Textiles. 
Lynn Lodge was a hard-working place. There was little tolerance for slacking. Running your own business, rather 
than becoming an employee, was the aspiration. 
"It was before the PlayStation days," says Eddie. "We all had summer jobs. Kids didn't grow up with PlayStations. 
Mike actually worked as a barman for years, and I went towards the horses." 
After Clongowes, Michael joined KPMG, opened a sweet shop and revolutionised air travel. Eddie had very different 
ambitions. Uncle Noel O'Callaghan was building a hotel empire but it was the other O'Callaghan uncles, Tony and 
Gay, who both had built up large stud businesses, to whom Eddie gravitated. Ted O'Leary had owned racehorses 
and Eddie and his sisters were keen showjumpers and hunters. Eddie began spending much of his time at Tony's 
nearby Tally Ho stud, which focused on breeding, buying and selling yearlings for flat racing. 
"Tony kind of reared me," says Eddie. "He was a father figure. I spent all of my summers there, grew up with him. I 
was the horse-mad lunatic, Mike had the brains. It was always the game I wanted to be in." 
After Clongowes, Eddie went to Tipperary's Gurteen agricultural college, after which he built his own business 
buying mares and breeding flat racehorses. 
     
Profile Eddie O'Leary: The other O'Leary
Every morning at 6am, O'Leary is out with his horses at the 200-acre Lynn Lodge stud. It's a busy life, but he loves 
it. The opposite rhythms of flat and jump racing - summer and winter - allow him time to also manage his wealthy 
brother's hobby. 
And he has a new hobby himself, also built on winners. He and his wife Wendy travel Ireland and abroad following 
the athletic exploits of their talented 18-year-old son Jack, who begins a scholarship in Iona College, New York this 
year and has already run for both Ireland and Europe. Sixteen-year-old daughter Megan is on the Irish triathlon 
team. 
But apart from that, his responsibilities at Gigginstown and Lynn Lodge keep him very busy. Foals are bred at the 
farm for sale each autumn as yearlings at Goffs, Doncaster in England and Deauville in France. O'Leary also 
purchases yearlings and in the spring he sells them on at "breeze-up" sales in Newmarket, Kempton and St Cloud 
in France where young horses that have not raced are galloped over a short distance for prospective owners. 
The number of winners at racetracks around the world that have passed through his hands is proof of his well-
acknowledged good eye as a pinhooker. 
In 2013, O'Leary's stud hit the headlines in racing circles when it smashed the European record for the sale of a 
breeze up horse. O'Leary's operation had bought the Kentucky-bred colt in 2012 for $120,000, selling it a year later 
for 760,000 guineas ($1,215,999). 
"Eddie has a good eye," says one well-known horseracing personality who knows him well. "He knows the game 
and was well-regarded even before Michael decided to get into jumping. He knows what he is doing. 
"But with a strong budget to go along with a good eye, you're in business. Michael gives Eddie the confidence and 
the money to go and do it, and Eddie does all the right things. It's a powerful mix."
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Shares Sold by Causeway Capital Management LLC
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Shares Sold by Causeway Capital 
Management LLC
DailyPolitical
April 17, 2016 Sunday 7:40 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 706 words
Byline: Tyrone Williams
Body
Apr 16, 2016( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Causeway Capital Management 
LLC lowered its position in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 18.3% during the fourth quarter, 
according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The firm owned 
1,797,665 shares of the company's stock after selling 402,872 shares during the period. Ryanair Holdings plc 
accounts for about 3.3% of Causeway Capital Management LLC's investment portfolio, making the stock its 12th 
largest position. Causeway Capital Management LLC owned approximately 0.68% of Ryanair Holdings plc worth 
$155,426,000 at the end of the most recent quarter. 
A number of other hedge funds and other institutional investors have also bought and sold shares of the stock. 
Alliancebernstein L.P. increased its position in Ryanair Holdings plc by 49.9% in the fourth quarter. 
Alliancebernstein L.P. now owns 417,522 shares of the company's stock worth $36,099,000 after buying an 
additional 138,919 shares during the period. Fifth Third Bancorp increased its position in Ryanair Holdings plc by 
932.5% in the fourth quarter. Fifth Third Bancorp now owns 108,828 shares of the company's stock worth 
$9,409,000 after buying an additional 98,288 shares during the period. Visium Asset Management LP increased its 
position in Ryanair Holdings plc by 599.1% in the fourth quarter. Visium Asset Management LP now owns 75,500 
shares of the company's stock worth $6,527,000 after buying an additional 64,700 shares during the period. AJO 
LP increased its position in Ryanair Holdings plc by 57.6% in the fourth quarter. AJO LP now owns 66,824 shares 
of the company's stock worth $5,778,000 after buying an additional 24,410 shares during the period. Finally,

Ryanair to open new base at Prague Airport
Ryanair to open new base at Prague Airport
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 15, 2016 Friday 6:58 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 352 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced it will open a new base at Prague Airport, from October 30, 2016, with two 
aircraft and two new routes to Milan and Rome, which will deliver 625,000 customers per annum and support 470 
jobs at Prague Airport.
Body
Ryanair's Prague winter 2016 schedule will deliver: 2 based aircraft ($200m); 2 new routes to: Milan B (daily) & 
Rome C (daily); 5 routes in total incl. Brussels C (9 wkly), Dublin (daily) and London (2 x daily); Over 40 weekly 
flights; 625,000 customers p.a. (+100,000); and 470 "on-site" jobs p.a. In Prague, Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, 
Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to announce our first Czech base at Prague (No.84) from 30th October with 2 
based aircraft, (an investment of $200m) and 2 new routes to Milan and Rome, which will deliver 625,000 
customers p.a. and support 470 jobs at Prague Airport. "This growth is an integral part of our continued expansion 
plans for both the Czech Republic and Eastern Europe, as we connect Prague with Europe's key centres of 
business with high frequency business-friendly services, including a double daily service to London and a daily 
route to Dublin, making Ryanair the ideal choice for both business and leisure customers. 
"Our 106m customers can look forward to further improvements, as we continue our "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, a new app, new cabin interiors and new crew uniforms "To celebrate 
the launch of our new Prague base, we are releasing seats for sale from just 639 CZK, which are available for 
booking until Monday (11 Apr) for travel in May and June. Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up 
quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Jirii Vyskoc, Prague Airport Aviation 
Business Director, commented: "We are pleased that Ryanair keeps expanding its aviation business at Vaclav 
Havel Airport Prague. With nearly half a million passengers transported a year, the carrier ranks among the largest 
top 5 airlines in Prague. The plan to launch 2 new routes to Milan and Rome from Prague confirms both the 
continued interest of foreign tourists in trips to Prague and the positive trend of a growing share of Czech travellers 
at Vaclav Havel Airport Prague. Establishing Ryanair's base confirms this trend and we expect Czech passenger 
numbers to continue growing."

Boutique veteran buys back into ‘surprise’ stock in €1.4bn fund
Boutique veteran buys back into ‘surprise’ stock in €1.4bn fund
Citywire
April 15, 2016 Friday 11:14 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 398 words
Byline: Chris Sloley
Highlight: Contrarian investor Damien Lanternier has increased exposure to a firm previously criticised for its 
reputational risk.
Body
Boutique veteran Damien Lanternier has rebuilt exposure to airline operator Ryanair after stating the Irish company 
has undergone a huge turnaround to become increasingly shareholder friendly.
Speaking to Citywire Selector, Lanternier said he reopened a position in the company in February in his flagship 
fund, the €1.49 billion Echiquier Agressor  fund.
Lanternier, who was previously subject of the Citywire Selector Performance Clinic feature, has seen performance 
improve and used recent market volatility to put capital to work in a number of ‘unloved’ areas.
The Paris-based investor previously had limited exposure to the company in his high conviction European equity 
portfolio, having previously championed opportunities in the aeroplane industry.
‘We are now seeing a surge in low cost carriers, which are also being aided by low oil prices and also this is sector 
which can grow secularly long term.
‘The reason we have focused on Ryanair is because it is low cost but also seeing its overall costs decreasing, while 
it is also showing strong expansion into the major transport hubs and not airports on the outskirts or far from major 
cities.’
 Lanternier, who would not divulge the size of the position, said Ryanair is showing strong and aggressive 
expansion plans in terms of buying new planes as well. He pointed to deal it has struck with Boeing for several 
hundred new vehicles.
‘This is huge compared to other levels of purchasing in the industry. In addition, they are set to take order of up to 
200 737s from Boeing in 2017, which shows future plans,’ he added.
Despite the influx of low cost carriers, Lanternier said Ryanair has retained its position as market leader and even 
begun to shed its unfavourable reputation.
‘They continue to be the cheapest operator and I think there is some room for improving yield, as well as recovering 
the poor reputation it previously had. Gone are the days of talking of charging for toilets and other schemes.
Boutique veteran buys back into ‘surprise’ stock in €1.4bn fund
‘They have enacted an "Always Better" programme and the reputation is improving and I think that will surprise 
some people. It is still relatively cheap but generating a lot of cash and has become increasingly shareholder 
friendly as well.’
The Echiquier Agressor fund returned 26.4% in euro terms over the three years to the end of March 2016. This 
compares to a 24.3% rise by the FTSE World Europe TR EUR over the same timeframe.

Dalmac is continuing its major European Recruitment Campaign to fill hundreds of Cabin Crew Positions on board 
Ryanair Aircraft it was announced yesterday.
Based in Ireland and Hahn (near Frankfurt, Germany), Dalmac has a team of highly qualified and dedicated 
professionals specialising in the recruitment of cabin crew for the airline industry for more than a decade.
Successful candidates will have the opportunity to work in various Airports across Europe including Ireland. For 
Cabin Crew positions - no previous Cabin Crew experience is required, applicants must be over 18 years of age to 
apply and it helps if you are hard-working, flexible, outgoing and have a lively personality.
Dalmac's Head of Recruitment, Niall Gleeson says, "We had a fantastic response in 2015 and were extremely 
satisfied with the very high calibre candidates we met in Ireland. We are now returning to fill 100's of positions, this 
is a fantastic opportunity to join a growing industry." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair charm offensive is boosting profits Ryanair charm o...
Ryanair charm offensive is boosting profits; Ryanair charm o...
Business World (Digest)
April 12, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 547 words
Highlight: Ryanair is to launch its first loyalty scheme in decades, introduce customer satisfaction surveys and 
allow "one-tap" upgrades using mobile phones as it extends its efforts to rid itself of a reputation for poor service.
Body
Ryanair is to launch its first loyalty scheme in decades, introduce customer satisfaction surveys and allow "one-tap" 
upgrades using mobile phones as it extends its efforts to rid itself of a reputation for poor service.
The Irish low-cost airline, Europe's largest by passenger numbers, has seen profits and passenger numbers soar 
since Chief Executive Michael O'Leary announced in 2014 that he would stop "unnecessarily pissing off" his 
customers.
Since then the airline has slashed punitive fees for checking in bags and rolled out pre-assigned seating, flexible 
business fares and freshly brewed coffee on board.
After decades of refusing to contemplate the kind of reward schemes offered by other airlines, Ryanair on Tuesday 
unveiled "My Ryanair Club" which will offer customers discounts and free flights depending on how often they use 
the airline. Ryanair briefly offered a customer loyalty card before O'Leary took over as chief executive in 1994. The 
new scheme, which aims to entice people to save credit card data on their Ryanair phone apps, will offer customers 
one free return flight when they book 12 flights in a year and will make specific offers to customers depending on 
their travel habits. "We always said we would never have a scheme with cards and statements and all that 
administrative waste... But with big data each passenger can have their own (personalised) loyalty scheme," 
O'Leary told journalists, adding that this would avoid any significant additional costs. O'Leary, who has transformed 
European aviation with his dedication to a no-frills service, denied that his hand was forced two years ago by 
investors and fellow executives. Instead he said, a loss of customers to rivals such as Aer Lingus and easyJet 
made change inevitable. "We had locked ourselves into a position of, 'We're cheaper, nastier and we don't care'. 
But there were millions of passengers saying I don't care how cheap you are," O'Leary said. Once passengers 
agree to save their credit card information on their phone apps, Ryanair plans to launch "one-flick" purchases, 
mimicking the "one-click" purchases on Amazon.com. Customers will be able to pay for priority boarding, express 
Ryanair charm offensive is boosting profits Ryanair charm o...
security checks and premium seats from their phones. The app will also offer airport transfers, parking tickets - and 
eventually tickets for local landmarks and concerts - using software that recognises the phone's location. EasyJet 
offers services such as free seat reservation, fast-track security and extra cabin bag to members who pay an 
annual fee. Ryanair customers will also be prompted to rate their flight to give the company instant feedback on 
areas where customer service remains weak. O'Leary credits the company's Always Getting Better customer 
service drive with lifting annual passenger numbers to 106 million from 80 million and shrinking its average 
percentage of empty seats per flight to 8 percent from 18. Ryanair's share price has doubled to over 13 euros from 
6.50 euros in late 2014. O'Leary, whose horse won the famous Grand National steeplechase at the weekend, said 
he had learned some humility. "Customers demonstrated by moving in fairly small, but significant amounts that we 
don't know it all - that I have still things to learn." (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: April 15, 2016
End of Document
Boeing and Ryanair announce delivery of 737-800 aircraft
Boeing and Ryanair announce delivery of 737-800 aircraft
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 11, 2016 Monday 2:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPONENTS & MAINTENANCE
Length: 219 words
Highlight: The Boeing Company and Ryanair Ltd. have announced the delivery of the airline's 400th next-
generation 737-800.
Body
"The Boeing 737-800 aircraft, with its industry leading technical reliability and seating capacity, has been the 
foundation upon which our successful and safe growth has been built upon, since we took our first delivery in March 
1999," said Ryanair's Chief Operations Officer, Michael Hickey. "We are delighted to be now taking delivery of our 
400th 737-800, which includes the new Boeing Sky Interior and slimline seats, offering extra leg room and an 
enhanced customer experience, as part of our 'Always Getting Programme'." "A key factor in Ryanair's continued 
success is the outstanding economics of the Next-Generation 737-800," said Monty Oliver, vice president, 
European Sales, Boeing Commercial Airplanes. 
"This 400th 737 delivery is a special milestone for both our companies and we are honored that Ryanair continues 
to be an all-Boeing operator." Ryanair has more than 130 unfilled orders for Next-Generation 737-800s and is also 
the launch customer for the 737 MAX 200, the newest member of the 737 MAX family. The Dublin-based carrier 
ordered 100 737 MAX 200s, a variant based on the successful 737 MAX 8, that can accommodate up to 200 seats, 
increasing revenue potential and providing airlines with up to 20 percent better fuel efficiency per seat than today's 
most efficient single-aisle airplanes.

Tourists turn to Spain and Portugal for sun and safety Travel
Tourists turn to Spain and Portugal for sun and safety; Travel
Financial Times (London, England)
April 11, 2016 Monday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 380 words
Byline: Emily Cadman
Body
Britons in search of sea and sand are rediscovering the traditional western Mediterranean holiday, with bookings to 
Spain and Portugal up by a quarter so far this year.
Both countries anticipate record tourist numbers in 2016 after terrorist attacks placed destinations like Tunisia and 
Sharm el-Sheikh off-limits on Foreign Office advice.
The Association of British Travel Agents (ABTA) said there had been a clear shift and that bookings were being 
"funnelled into limited areas". They added that industry bodies elsewhere in northern Europe were reporting a 
similar trend. More limited options for holiday destinations combined with the recovery in household real incomes 
mean the industry has been able to maintain prices.
Alan Clarke, economist at Scotiabank, said that British households have more spare cash than they did; helped by 
cheaper food and fuel.
"In the past when this has happened, households have spent that windfall on holidays and cars. This, coupled with 
the weaker sterling exchange rate suggests to me that it is unlikely that anyone is going to find much of a bargain 
when booking a flight this summer."
Tourists turn to Spain and Portugal for sun and safety Travel
Analysts at HSBC estimate that EasyJet has hedged 86 per cent of its fuel requirement for this year, while Ryanair 
has hedged 95 per cent - meaning that further declines in the price of oil are unlikely to lead to cheaper flights this 
year.
Over half a million extra Britons have already booked to go to Spain or Portugal this year compared to last, 
according to the latest data from research agency GfK, which covers all of the big -traditional operators, including 
Thomas Cook, Tui, as well as lastminute.com.
As of the first week in April, over 40 per cent of British holiday bookings were for Spain.
By contrast, bookings to Egypt are down by 60 per cent, after the loss of a Russian jet led the Foreign Office to 
advice against all travel through Sharm el-Sheikh airport which is the gateway to many of the most popular beach 
resorts. Bookings to Turkey are also down by 35 per cent.
By the end of January, the industry had already sold more all-inclusive two week packages to Portugal than in the 
whole summer season last year, David Hope, director of the travel business at GfK, said.
Additional reporting by Tobias Buck in Spain and Peter Wise in Portugal
Load-Date: April 10, 2016

National could be Rule The World's last race HORSE RACING
National could be Rule The World's last race; HORSE RACING
City A.M.
April 11, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 31
Length: 276 words
Byline: FRANK DALLERES
Body
OWNER Michael O'Leary wants to retire Rule The World after the injury-plagued nine-year-old defied odds of 33-1 
to win the Grand National on Saturday at Aintree.
Ryanair chief executive O'Leary fears that further outings could risk damaging a horse who has battled back from 
two pelvic fractures, but has vowed to leave the decision to trainer Mouse Morris.
"I would be conscious now having had a Grand National winner not to do anything that would endanger him or 
threaten him or run the risk of pelvic injury," said O'Leary.
"We'll sit down and think about it over the summer. If I had my way I'd like to retire him, but I think in this case we'll 
let Mouse decide what he wants to do and I know Mouse will make the right decision by the horse. If he wants to 
train him on next year, then we'll train on. If not, we'll retire him and look after him for the rest of his life."
Rule The World had never won over fences in 13 starts before his National triumph, while 19-year-old jockey David 
Mullins - nephew of trainer Willie Mullins - was competing in the race for the first time.
It was also a poignant victory for Morris, the Tipperary trainer who saddled Irish National winner Rogue Angel last 
month and was touched by tragedy last year when his son Christopher died in an accident.
"Watching the race, I thought we were going to be third and I was going to be very happy with that," Morris said. 
"From where I was watching it, I didn't really believe it until he passed the winning post.
"I'd say it's very unlikely he'll run again this year anyway. We'll let the dust settle and we'll see where we are after 
that. The horse won't be abused, that is for sure."
National could be Rule The World's last race HORSE RACING

Dublin runway move reignites Heathrow fears; Transport
Dublin runway move reignites Heathrow fears; Transport
Financial Times (London, England)
April 8, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 14
Length: 378 words
Byline: Vincent Boland in Dublin
Body
London Heathrow is set to face more competition in the battle among Europe's hub airports after Dublin airport said 
it would build a second runway by 2020.
As the UK government continues to postpone a decision on whether to build a third runway at Heathrow, the 
announcement by Dublin Airport Authority yesterday will fuel the debate over whether London's main hub airport 
risks being further sidelined by the delay as rivals move ahead with expansion plans.
The DAA's announcement comes a year after Aer Lingus, the Irish flag carrier, was bought by International Airlines 
Group. IAG owns British Airways, and as part of its takeover proposal it promised new routes and more long-haul 
flights from Dublin, where Aer Lingus is one of the two main airline customers along with Ryanair.
Willie Walsh, IAG's chief executive , said at the time that the addition of Aer Lingus would allow IAG "to develop our 
network using Dublin as a hub between the UK, continental Europe and North America, generating additional 
financial value for our shareholders".
A big attraction for Mr Walsh of buying the Irish carrier was the prospect that a second runway would be built in 
Dublin in the next few years, which he said was "inevitable".
Dublin runway move reignites Heathrow fears; Transport
IAG said yesterday: "One of the advantages of IAG is that we can expand the group's flights via Dublin or Madrid 
should there be no capacity increase in south-east England. A second runway in Dublin provides more opportunity 
to achieve this."
Planning permission for the project was granted in 2007 but its development was put on hold when Ireland entered 
a financial crisis in 2008.
The approval remains in force, and yesterday's announcement caps weeks of speculation that the airport operator 
would proceed with the development now that Ireland's economy has started to recover.
The DAA said the new runway would be 3,110 metres long and cost EUR320m (£259m). Construction would begin 
next year. The authority said its debt levels were "comfortable and the group has a strong liquidity position".
Kevin Toland, the DAA's chief executive, said the airport's existing runway infrastructure was operating at full 
capacity during peak hours.
Paschal Donohoe, acting Irish transport minister, said a new runway was "of major strategic importance to Ireland".
Load-Date: April 7, 2016

Ryanair cancel over 100 flights due to Italian strike Ryanair cancel ...
Ryanair cancel over 100 flights due to Italian strike; Ryanair cancel ...
Business World (Digest)
April 8, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 122 words
Highlight: Ryanair have today announced the cancellation of 108 flights to and from Italy tomorrow. Ryanair flights 
from within Italy have also been cancelled.
Body
Ryanair have today announced the cancellation of 108 flights to and from Italy tomorrow. Ryanair flights from within 
Italy have also been cancelled.
Ryanair claim all affected customers have been contacted by email and SMS text message where they have been 
advised of their options of a full refund, rebooking on to the next available flight or onto an alternative route.
In a statement issued today, Ryanair said, "We sincerely apologise to all customers disrupted by these unjustified 
strikes - the 5th such ATC strike in the last 3 weeks - by ATC unions who are holding European consumers to 
ransom. We call on the Italian Government and EU Commission to take action to prevent any further ATC 
disruptions."

EasyJet fails to take off after strikes and terror
EasyJet fails to take off after strikes and terror
City A.M.
April 7, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 285 words
Byline: OLIVER GILL
Body
BUDGET airline EasyJet is expected to return to the red for the first half of the year after French air traffic controller 
strikes and the terrorist attacks in Belgium hurt traffic volumes in March.
The Luton-based budget airline said 611 flights were cancelled last month, blaming the majority on strike action in 
France.
Load factors - the proportion of seats taken up per flight - were down from 92.6 per cent to 91.3 per cent. And 
although overall passenger numbers were up 4.3 per cent compared to March 2015, this growth was well behind 
the 28 per cent increase outlined by Ryanair over the same period. Stephen Furlong, transport and logistics analyst 
at Davy Wealth Manage-ment, said: "We do not believe that the company will be profitable in the first half 
[September to March]."
EasyJet appeared to have turned a corner for the first half of the previous year, generating profit before tax of £7m 
during a period which was historically loss-making.
"The largest number of cancellations we have seen reported so far is Ryanair at around 500. Given that EasyJet is 
two-thirds the size of Ryanair, then it is [equivalent] to being almost double," said Furlong. He also pointed to the 
fact that EasyJet has a greater exposure to French destinations than its competitors.
Robin Byde of Cantor Fitzgerald was more conciliatory.
He said: "A lot happened in March. There was both the terrorist attacks and the French air traffic controllers strike.
"There is a lot of news flow today and it reads negatively, but you can't read too much into it."
EasyJet fails to take off after strikes and terror
Byde added: "Given the circumstances negative headlines are understandable. But overall the business model is 
resilient. It's a temporary issue and bookings will pick up."
Graphic
 
EasyJet isn't finding life easy

Ryanair March passenger traffic increases 28%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)

Length: 103 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has reported that passenger traffic for the month of March 2016 was 8.5 million 
passengers, an increase of 28%, compared to 6.6 million passengers for March 2015.
Body
Load factor for the month of March 2016 was 94%, an increase of four percentage points, compared to 90% for 
March 2015. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's March traffic grew by 28% to 8.5m customers, while our load 
factor jumped 4% points to 94%. These record monthly numbers were delivered (despite 3 days of unjustified 
French ATC strikes in March which caused the cancellation of over 500 flights) due to our lower fares, stronger 
forward bookings and the continuing success of our "AGB" programme. Our 106m customers can look forward to 
further improvements in 2016 as we will shortly launch Year 3 of "AGB"."

FTSE 100 Up 27 Points In Early Trade
FTSE 100 Up 27 Points In Early Trade
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
April 4, 2016 Monday 12:09 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 241 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares gained ground in early trade on Monday despite a mixed session in Asia and 
lower crude oil prices as doubts grew about the ability of big oil producing countries to agree on an output freeze.  
The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 27 points or 0.44 percent at 6,173 after losing half a percent in the previous 
session. 
 Low-cost airline Ryanair rallied 2 percent after its March traffic grew by 28 percent.  Anglo American shares gained 
1 percent. The embattled miner has solid its 70 percent stake in an open cut coal mine in Queensland, Australia, to 
a consortium led by Taurus Fund Management for an undisclosed sum.  BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rose 1-2 percent 
while Tullow Oil dropped over 1 percent.  Packaging and paper group Mondi dropped 2.5 percent after the Federal 
Antimonopoly Service of the Russian Federation said it had initiated an investigation into Mondi Syktyvkar for 
violations of antimonopoly law over offset paper.  In economic releases, the U.K. private sector growth slowed to a 
near halt in the three months to March, the latest growth indicator from the Confederation of British Industry 
showed. However, firms' expectations pointed to a recovery in growth for the next three months.  Another report 
from Markit Economics and the Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply revealed that the pace of growth in the 
UK construction industry held steady at February's 10-month low in March.      
Load-Date: April 4, 2016
End of Document
European Shares Push Higher; French Telecoms Slump
European Shares Push Higher; French Telecoms Slump
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
April 4, 2016 Monday 12:54 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 412 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European shares rebounded from a one-month low hit on Friday despite a mixed session 
in Asia and lower crude oil prices as doubts grew about the ability of big oil producing countries to agree on an 
output freeze.  Regional economic reports painted a mixed picture, with the Eurozone Sentix Investor Confidence 
Index coming in at 5.7 in April versus the 7 forecast by economists, while the euro zone's unemployment rate 
continued to slow in February to hit its lowest level since August 2011.  The U.K. private sector growth slowed to a 
near halt in the three months to March, the latest growth indicator from the Confederation of British Industry 
showed.   Another report from Markit Economics and the Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply revealed that 
the pace of growth in the UK construction industry held steady at February's 10-month low in March. 
 The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was up 0.8 percent after losing 1.3 percent on Friday. The German 
DAX, France's CAC 40 and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 were up between 0.5 percent and 0.9 percent.   Banks traded 
mostly higher, with BNP Paribas, Societe Generale Group and Commerzbank rising between half a percent and 1.5 
percent.   Low-cost airline Ryanair rallied 2 percent in London after its March traffic grew by 28 percent.  Anglo 
American shares traded marginally lower, erasing early gains. The embattled miner has solid its 70 percent stake in 
an open cut coal mine in Queensland, Australia, to a consortium led by Taurus Fund Management for an 
undisclosed sum.  Packaging and paper group Mondi dropped over 2 percent after the Federal Antimonopoly 
Service of the Russian Federation said it had initiated an investigation into Mondi Syktyvkar for violations of 
antimonopoly law over offset paper.  Bouygues Telecom slumped 15 percent in Paris and Orange tumbled 4.5 
percent after talks between them over a planned takeover of the former's telecoms unit collapsed on Friday. Rivals 
Iliad and Numericable lost 14-15 percent.  Automakers BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen traded narrowly mixed in 
Frankfurt after reporting their U.S. March sales figures.  ArcelorMittal shares rose 1 percent in Amsterdam. 
ArcelorMittal USA intends to enter into a new, five-year senior secured asset-based revolving credit facility of up to 
$1 billion, which is expected to close in the second quarter of 2016.  Castellum AB also gained 1 percent in 
Stockholm after creating a new group structure.      
Load-Date: April 4, 2016
European Shares Push Higher; French Telecoms Slump
End of Document
FTSE 100 Up 27 Points In Early Trade
FTSE 100 Up 27 Points In Early Trade
RTT News (United States)
April 4, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 253 words
Body
(RTTNews) - U.K. shares gained ground in early trade on Monday despite a mixed session in Asia and lower crude 
oil prices as doubts grew about the ability of big oil producing countries to agree on an output freeze.
The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 27 points or 0.44 percent at 6,173 after losing half a percent in the previous 
session.
Low-cost airline Ryanair rallied 2 percent after its March traffic grew by 28 percent.
Anglo American shares gained 1 percent. The embattled miner has solid its 70 percent stake in an open cut coal 
mine in Queensland, Australia, to a consortium led by Taurus Fund Management for an undisclosed sum.
BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rose 1-2 percent while Tullow Oil dropped over 1 percent.
Packaging and paper group Mondi dropped 2.5 percent after the Federal Antimonopoly Service of the Russian 
Federation said it had initiated an investigation into Mondi Syktyvkar for violations of antimonopoly law over offset 
paper.
In economic releases, the U.K. private sector growth slowed to a near halt in the three months to March, the latest 
growth indicator from the Confederation of British Industry showed. However, firms' expectations pointed to a 
recovery in growth for the next three months.
Another report from Markit Economics and the Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply revealed that the pace 
of growth in the UK construction industry held steady at February's 10-month low in March.

European Shares Push Higher; French Telecoms Slump
European Shares Push Higher; French Telecoms Slump
RTT News (United States)
April 4, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 422 words
Body
(RTTNews) - European shares rebounded from a one-month low hit on Friday despite a mixed session in Asia and 
lower crude oil prices as doubts grew about the ability of big oil producing countries to agree on an output freeze.
Regional economic reports painted a mixed picture, with the Eurozone Sentix Investor Confidence Index coming in 
at 5.7 in April versus the 7 forecast by economists, while the euro zone's unemployment rate continued to slow in 
February to hit its lowest level since August 2011.
The U.K. private sector growth slowed to a near halt in the three months to March, the latest growth indicator from 
the Confederation of British Industry showed.
Another report from Markit Economics and the Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply revealed that the pace 
of growth in the UK construction industry held steady at February's 10-month low in March.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was up 0.8 percent after losing 1.3 percent on Friday. The German 
DAX, France's CAC 40 and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 were up between 0.5 percent and 0.9 percent.
Banks traded mostly higher, with BNP Paribas, Societe Generale Group and Commerzbank rising between half a 
percent and 1.5 percent.
Low-cost airline Ryanair rallied 2 percent in London after its March traffic grew by 28 percent.
Anglo American shares traded marginally lower, erasing early gains. The embattled miner has solid its 70 percent 
stake in an open cut coal mine in Queensland, Australia, to a consortium led by Taurus Fund Management for an 
undisclosed sum.
Packaging and paper group Mondi dropped over 2 percent after the Federal Antimonopoly Service of the Russian 
Federation said it had initiated an investigation into Mondi Syktyvkar for violations of antimonopoly law over offset 
paper.
Bouygues Telecom slumped 15 percent in Paris and Orange tumbled 4.5 percent after talks between them over a 
planned takeover of the former's telecoms unit collapsed on Friday. Rivals Iliad and Numericable lost 14-15 
percent.
European Shares Push Higher; French Telecoms Slump
Automakers BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen traded narrowly mixed in Frankfurt after reporting their U.S. March 
sales figures.
ArcelorMittal shares rose 1 percent in Amsterdam. ArcelorMittal USA intends to enter into a new, five-year senior 
secured asset-based revolving credit facility of up to $1 billion, which is expected to close in the second quarter of 
2016.
Castellum AB also gained 1 percent in Stockholm after creating a new group structure.

Ryanair March traffic grows 28% Ryanair March t...
Ryanair March traffic grows 28%; Ryanair March t...
Business World (Digest)
April 4, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 110 words
Highlight: Ryanair have today announced that their traffic for March has grown 28% to 8.5m customers.Their 
figures show that Rolling annual traffic to March grew 18% to 106.4m customers.
Body
Ryanair have today announced that their traffic for March has grown 28% to 8.5m customers.Their figures show 
that Rolling annual traffic to March grew 18% to 106.4m customers.
These figures were achieveddespite threedays of French ATC strikes in March which caused the cancellation of 
over 500 flights.
Speaking today, Chief Financial Officer & Deputy CEO at Ryanair, Kenny Jacobs said, "Ryanair's March traffic grew 
by 28% to 8.5m customers, while our load factor jumped 4% points to 94%. These record monthly numbers were 
delivered due to our lower fares, stronger forward bookings and the continuing success of our "AGB" programme."
Source: www.businessworld.ie

institutional investors have also recently made changes to their positions in the company.

company's stock valued at $1,123,000 after buying an additional 1,860 shares during the last quarter. State of

buying an additional 9,937 shares during the last quarter. Finally, NorthCoast Asset Management LLC purchased a 
new position in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc during the fourth quarter valued at approximately $2,631,000.

of 13.70. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $65.13 and a 12 month high of $88.24. The stock's 50 day

Wednesday, February 10th. Finally, Zacks Investment Research[3] raised shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 
'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $95.00 price target for the company in a research report on Monday, January 
25th. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, six have assigned a hold rating and seven 
have assigned a buy rating to the company. The company presently has an average rating of 'Hold' and an average 
price target of $89.60. Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco.Want to see what other hedge funds are

Ryanair commences works on flight simulator project in Dublin
Ryanair commences works on flight simulator project in Dublin
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 30, 2016 Wednesday 11:02 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 269 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has commenced works on a new flight simulator project at its headquarters in Swords, 
Dublin.
Body
Once complete, this new flight simulator will allow Ryanair to assess cadets and provide an industry leading 
opportunity for pilots to practice their manual handling skills in a relaxed environment. Atkins is providing 
multidiscipline services including; civil and structural, architecture, M&E and fire safety engineering. 
Design works where provided from concept stage through to construction including planning and tender stages. 
Atkins is also providing PSDP and assigned certifier roles. The new annex building which includes a link bridge to 
the existing Ryanair HQ will house the first of a new generation fixed base flight simulator. The building includes two 
new briefing rooms and a large open area in which the simulator will be located. Construction is currently underway 
on site and is expected to complete by the end of May 2016. Justin Norman, director, Atkins, said: "Atkins is 
delighted to be project designers for the new annex to house the simulator. We look forward to completing this 
exciting project successfully with Ryanair and Ganson contractors." Garry Hanratty, project manager, Atkins, said: 
"It's exciting to work with such a dynamic client. The proposed building is being constructed on an existing 
reinforced concrete podium slab which brings its own set of challenges from a design and construction perspective. 
Another interesting challenge is the requirement to keep the Ryanair HQ building and surround infrastructure 
operational at all times. Atkins ultimate goal is to ensure Ryanair has a purpose built building to showcase their first 
new generation fixed base flight simulators."
Load-Date: April 5, 2016

Ryanair call on EU to take action regarding French ATC strikes Ryanair call on...
Ryanair call on EU to take action regarding French ATC strikes; Ryanair call 
on...
Business World (Digest)
March 30, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 191 words
Highlight: Ryanair yesterday called on the European Commission to take action to prevent the skies over Europe 
being closed by French ATC unions.
Body
Ryanair yesterday called on the European Commission to take action to prevent the skies over Europe being closed 
by French ATC unions.
They claim that the European Commission's failure to prevent these repeated cancellations makes a "mockery" of 
the single European market and Commissioner Junckers claims about making Europe competitive.
Ryanair have also called on the European Court to reverse its previous rulings that EU airlines must pay out to 
passengers in such cases of ATC strikes which airlines have no control over and yet by law, cannot recover these 
sums from French ATC unions.
Ryanair's CMO Kenny Jacobs said, "It's time for the European Commission to act to protect the interests of 
Europe's passengers who are frequently held to ransom by the French ATC union. "You cannot have an effective 
single market in Europe but then allow a tiny French union to close down half the skies over Europe, causing 
hundreds of thousands of passenger flights to be cancelled ordelayed, when these passengers cannot be re-
accommodated because all other flights are heavily booked during the peak Easter holiday period." Source: 
www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: April 4, 2016
End of Document

Pennsylvania Public School Empls Retrmt SYS increased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 1.7% during the fourth quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. 
The fund owned 248,199 shares of the company's stock after buying an additional 4,136 shares during the period. 
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Public School Empls Retrmt SYS's holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc were worth 
$21,459,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.

average price of $81.79 and a 200-day moving average price of $81.96. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12-month low 
of $65.13 and a 12-month high of $88.24. The stock has a market capitalization of $21.99 billion and a PE ratio of 
13.05.  RYAAY has been the subject of several recent analyst reports. Vetr[2] cut Ryanair Holdings plc from a 
'strong-buy' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $83.00 target price for the company. in a research report on 
Wednesday, February 10th. Zacks Investment Research[3] upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'hold' rating to a

research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, six have issued a hold rating and seven have issued a buy
