Aircraft repairers face probe over supplies Airlines
Aircraft repairers face probe over supplies; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 24, 2016 Thursday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 18
Length: 356 words
Byline: Peggy Hollinger in London
Body
Airlines have lodged a formal complaint with European regulators over the $60bn market for spares and repairs on 
the world's 24,000 aircraft, as EU investigators intensify their preliminary inquiry into whether carriers are being 
forced to accept anticompetitive maintenance contracts.
Iata, the industry lobby group, sent a letter to the European Commission last week listing grievances such as 
requirements by engine and component manufacturers that airlines use only their spare parts for repairs.
Meanwhile Brussels is demanding further information from aircraft suppliers in a sign that it is deepening its informal 
inquiry into the maintenance and repair market. No formal investigation has yet been launched.
The preliminary probe, first revealed by the Financial Times last year, is focused on maintenance support for the 
CFM56 turbine and Rolls-Royce's Trent XWB engines, and for components including auxiliary power systems made 
by Honeywell.
Safran, the French engine maker, and CFM, its joint venture with General Electric of the US, are among those to 
have received a follow-up letter to a questionnaire sent to dozens of suppliers last autumn.
Rolls-Royce and Honeywell said they had not received a second request for information.
Aircraft repairers face probe over supplies Airlines
The rising costs of aircraft maintenance have been attacked by chiefs at British Airways, Air France, Ryanair and 
Lufthansa. Carriers complain that some original equipment suppliers are withholding repair information from 
qualified third-party maintenance shops, limiting competition and pushing up prices.
Limits need to be set on what equipment suppliers can define as intellectual property, the airlines say. That would 
open the maintenance market to a wider range of suppliers.
Brussels refused to comment beyond confirming that it was "closely monitoring competitive conditions as regards 
maintenance of engines and components for large commercial aircraft".
The maintenance, repair and overhaul market is set for robust growth over the next decade.
ICF International and Technavio, the aerospace consultancies, estimated that the market would grow from $60bn 
this year to more than $80bn by 2025.
Load-Date: March 23, 2016
End of Document
Airlines and travel Shares fall after blasts
Airlines and travel; Shares fall after blasts
Financial Times (London, England)
March 23, 2016 Wednesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 22
Length: 171 words
Byline: Gonzalo Viña
Body
Shares in European airlines and travel groups fell yesterday after explosions in Brussels raised fears about the 
threat of terrorism.
Ryanair and easyJet lost about 4 per cent following the blasts in the Belgian capital before recovering in the early 
afternoon. Travel groups InterContinental Hotels, Thomas Cook and Tui were also affected.
The attacks in Belgium came as Thomas Cook , the UK tour operator, warned in a trading statement that "the 
uncertain geopolitical environment is causing some customers to postpone booking their holidays".
It said people had grown cautious about spending their breaks abroad after terror attacks in previously popular 
destinations such as Turkey, Tunisia and Egypt.
Last month Thomas Cook said the attacks in Paris in November and a bomb blast in Istanbul's Sultanahmet Square 
in January were causing delays to bookings.
Peter Fankhauser , chief executive, said customers were taking more time to "consider their options".
Destinations such as Spain, the US and Cuba remained popular.
Gonzalo Viña
Airlines and travel Shares fall after blasts
Load-Date: March 22, 2016
End of Document
Travel shares drop as investors move into safe havens
Travel shares drop as investors move into safe havens
City A.M.
March 23, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 184 words
Byline: BILLY BAMBROUGH
Body
TRAVEL and tourism shares in Europe and the US were affected by events in Brussels, with stocks in American 
Airlines opening down almost three per cent on speculation its check-in desk was the target in the attack.
The stock closed down 1.63 per cent after the airline said its desk was not hit. European airlines broadly dropped by 
around two per cent, with Ryanair and BA owner IAG both hit. The Euro Stoxx 600 travel and leisure index fell by 
1.9 per cent, breaking a five-day winning streak. Thomas Cook, which warned ahead of the bombings that summer 
bookings would be down on last year due to recent attacks, closed down 4.3 per cent. "Consumer confidence will 
have taken another hit, adding to existing fears after attacks in Paris and Turkey. It's hard to see a near term 
recovery in a lot of these travel stocks," Wyn Ellis, travel and leisure analyst at Numis Securities, told City A.M. The 
pound slid against the dollar and euro by 0.9 per cent as investors feared the attack could increase the possibility of 
Brexit, fleeing to safe havens. The yen, gold, and government-backed bonds all rallied.
Load-Date: March 23, 2016
End of Document
FTSE 100 Retreats After Brussels Explosions
FTSE 100 Retreats After Brussels Explosions
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 22, 2016 Tuesday 11:15 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 254 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares drifted lower on Tuesday after a suspected terrorist attack at Brussels airport 
this morning killed several people and left many more injured. Brussels airport has warned passengers not to come 
to the airport, which would be closed until further notice. 
 The focus is also on the inflation data, which showed that the U.K.'s inflation rate unexpectedly remained 
unchanged at 0.3 percent in February, far below the Bank of England's 2 percent target.  Meanwhile, a decision for 
the UK to exit the European Union would put the country's 'Aa1' credit rating at risk and would be credit negative for 
UK-based companies such as the auto, manufacturing, food and beverage, and service sectors, Moody's said.  The 
benchmark FTSE 100 was down 29 points or 0.47 percent at 6,155 after ending a choppy session 0.1 percent lower 
the previous day, tracking moves in the U.S. dollar and oil prices.    EasyJet, Ryanair Holdings and InterContinental 
Hotels lost 2-4 percent.   Thomas Cook shares plunged 5 percent. The holiday firm has reported a two percent dip 
in winter bookings and said that summer holiday bookings are lower than this time last year due to volatile market 
conditions.  Miner Anglo American edged down marginally after completing a bond buyback program.   Barclays 
tumbled 3 percent after Goldman Sachs lowered its price target for the stock.  Plumbing and heating products 
maker Wolseley dropped 1.5 percent after announcing job cuts in the U.K., citing challenging conditions.      
Load-Date: March 22, 2016
End of Document
European Shares Retreat As Geopolitical Concerns Resurface
European Shares Retreat As Geopolitical Concerns Resurface
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 22, 2016 Tuesday 12:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European shares fell on Tuesday amid risk aversion after multiple explosions in Brussels 
left at least thirteen dead and thirty five injured.  Three were three explosions in Brussels, one at a subway station in 
the suburb of Maalbeek, while two explosions occurred at the city's airport. The terror threat in Belgium was raised 
to its highest level.  With investors rushing into safe-haven assets such as the yen, gold and government bonds, a 
raft of economic data releases on Eurozone private sector growth, U.K. inflation and German economic confidence 
received little attention from markets.   The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index traded down about 0.7 percent 
after ending a choppy session 0.2 percent lower on Monday, tracking moves in the U.S. dollar and oil prices.   
Elsewhere, the German DAX was moving down half a percent, France's CAC 40 was losing 1.3 percent and the 
U.K.'s FTSE 100 was down 0.6 percent.   Hotel group Accor slumped nearly 4 percent in Paris while supermarket 
chain Carrefour dropped 1 percent.  EasyJet, Ryanair Holdings and InterContinental Hotels lost 2-3 percent in 
London.   Thomas Cook shares plunged 6 percent. The holiday firm has reported a two percent dip in winter 
bookings and said that summer holiday bookings are lower than this time last year due to volatile market conditions.      
Load-Date: March 22, 2016

(RTTNews) - U.K. shares drifted lower on Tuesday after a suspected terrorist attack at Brussels airport this morning 
killed several people and left many more injured. Brussels airport has warned passengers not to come to the 
airport, which would be closed until further notice.
The focus is also on the inflation data, which showed that the U.K.'s inflation rate unexpectedly remained 
unchanged at 0.3 percent in February, far below the Bank of England's 2 percent target.
Meanwhile, a decision for the UK to exit the European Union would put the country's 'Aa1' credit rating at risk and 
would be credit negative for UK-based companies such as the auto, manufacturing, food and beverage, and service 
sectors, Moody's said.

European shares fall European shares...
European shares fall; European shares...
Business World (Digest)
March 22, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 120 words
Highlight: European shares fell in early trading on Tuesday, with travel and leisure stocks leading the market lower 
after explosions hit the airport in Brussels.
Body
European shares fell in early trading on Tuesday, with travel and leisure stocks leading the market lower after 
explosions hit the airport in Brussels.
Explosions tore through the departure hall of Brussels airport on Tuesday morning, killing one person and injuring 
several others, the Belgian news agency Belga said. The agency said shots were fired and there were shouts in 
Arabic shortly before the explosions.
The STOXX Europe 600 Travel and Leisure index fell 2.2%, the top decliner, with shares in easyJet, Ryanair, 
Accor, InterContinental Hotels and IHG down by 2.4-4.6%.
The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index was down 0.7%, while Belgium's benchmark share index was down 
0.5%. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

European stock indexes down amid terrorism, travel fears
European stock indexes down amid terrorism, travel fears
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 22, 2016 Tuesday 10:34 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 140 words
Body
       BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Major European stock indexes fell in early Tuesday trading after reports of two explosions 
at the main airport in Brussels that left at least a dozen dead and many others injured.  Germany's DAX slipped by 
1.75 per cent to 9,775 points, followed by a slight recovery, with shares in travel-related companies seeing the 
biggest falls following the news from Brussels.  Britain's FTSE 100 was down nearly 47 points, or 0.8 per cent, at 
6,138 points. Euronext 100, the blue chip index for the pan-European Euronext exchange, fell by almost 1.2 per 
cent to 861 points.  'Once again terrorism has us firmly in its grip,' said Robert Halver, a capital markets analyst at 
Baader Bank.  Shares in airlines Ryanair, Lufthansa, easyjet and Air France were down between 2.3 and 3.6 per 
cent in Tuesday trading.   Copyright dpa

Germanwings brand name set to slowly disappear
Germanwings brand name set to slowly disappear
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 21, 2016 Monday 2:01 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 374 words
Body
       BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Last year's devastating crash of Germanwings flight 4U 9525 resulted in Lufthansa 
accelerating plans for the Germanwings brand to be integrated into the airline group's new budget airline, 
Eurowings.  By October last year, Eurowings had taken over over 55 Germanwings routes as part of its efforts to 
transform Eurowings into Europe third-biggest low-cost carrier.  Lufthansa plans to add several more Germanwings 
routes next month to Eurowings, which already handles all Germanwings sales. 
 However, Lufthansa's move to create a new budget carrier to compete with the likes of Britain's Ryanair and 
Ireland's EasyJet has been fraught with problems for the Cologne-based airline group.  Three years ago, Lufthansa 
decided to shift the lion's share of its domestic German flights to Germanwings as it attempted to cut costs and face 
up to fierce competition from European discount airlines and new Middle East-based international carriers.  But the 
switch to Germanwings - where pay rates are lower than other parts of the Lufthansa group - quickly ran into stiff 
opposition from both unions and pilots, triggering a series of damaging strikes by cabin crew and pilots.  Unit labour 
costs at Eurowings are 30 per cent lower than at the Lufthansa parent company, the airline said last week.  
Undeterred by the industrial action, Lufthansa stepped up its plans for a global discount airline by launching 
Eurowings' international operations last year.  However, the new global services have been hit by complaints about 
long delays in its services.  Lufthansa hopes to address the problem by expanding the Eurowings aircraft fleet this 
year by 10 to 98.  Despite the strikes and the March 2015 crash that overshadowed Lufthansa's 60th anniversary, 
the airline group last week reported a record annual profit.  Lufthansa said it booked a 55-per-cent surge in adjusted 
earnings before interest and taxes jumped to 1.82 billion euros (2 billion dollars) in 2015 from 1.17 billion euros in 
2014, with earnings boosted by a fall in its aircraft fuel bill and higher passenger numbers.  The Eurowings offshoot 
contributed to the annual result by posting an adjusted operating profit of 8 million euros in 2015.   Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: March 21, 2016
End of Document
Flights cancelled due to 48 hour French air traffic controller strike
Flights cancelled due to 48 hour French air traffic controller strike
City A.M.
March 21, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 131 words
Byline: CAITLÍN MORRISON
Body
BRITISH Airways, EasyJet and Ryanair cancelled several flights scheduled for yesterday and today as a result of a 
two-day strike in France.
Air traffic controllers are striking in protest against staff cuts, which industry union UNSA said are unrealistic due to 
the operational needs of control centres.
The French Civil Aviation Authority called for the cancellation of several flights for all airlines using French airspace.
A number of flights between the UK and France have been cancelled, and other routes across Europe have also 
been affected.
British Airways said: "Unfortunately in addition to cancelling some flights to and from France, other short-haul flights 
are also likely to experience delays throughout the two days, given how many flights would normally use French 
airspace."
Load-Date: March 21, 2016
End of Document
Cyprus pilot of crashed FlyDubai jet had a new job elsewhere
Cyprus pilot of crashed FlyDubai jet had a new job elsewhere
Associated Press Financial Wire
March 19, 2016 Saturday 6:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 224 words
Byline: By MENELAOS HADJICOSTIS, Associated Press
Dateline: BRUSSELS 
Body
BRUSSELS (AP) - The Cypriot pilot of the FlyDubai jet that crashed in southern Russia was going to quit the airline 
after recently accepting a job with Ryanair in Cyprus, a long-time friend said Saturday.
The friend told The Associated Press that pilot Aristos Socratous, whose wife will give birth to the couple's first child 
in a few weeks, wanted to raise his family in Cyprus despite a drop in his wages.
"The loss of income doesn't compare with being close to your family in your home country," the friend said.
The 38-year-old aviator was so looking forward to making a fresh start in Cyprus that he gave up his passion - his 
two motorcycles, which he used to drag race with, his friend said.
The friend, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he didn't want to be named discussing his friend's 
personal matters, said Socratous was an experienced pilot who had no complaints or problems with FlyDubai. He 
said Socratous was "very happy" about FlyDubai promoting him to full captain a year and a half ago.
FlyDubai CEO Ghaith al-Ghaith also called him an experienced pilot who had 5,965 hours of flying time.
Socratous, a graduate of the Oxford Aviation Training Center, had previously worked for Helios Airways, the Cypriot 
airline that shut down after one if its planes crashed in 2005. He had also worked for XL Airways and Malaysia 
Airlines.
Load-Date: March 20, 2016
End of Document

times local):

The parents of flight attendant Laura Patricia de la Cruz confirm that the Colombian woman is among the 62 victims 
of the FlyDubai plane crash in southern Russia.
Her father, Wulfram de la Cruz, tells local news media that she had been living in the UAE for three years with her 
husband, who is also a flight attendant.
He said Saturday that he and his wife will be travelling from their home in the town of Sabanalarga in a few days to 
help with the identification of his daughter's remains.
The crash Saturday in the city of Rostov-on-Don left a big crater in the airport's runway and pulverized the plane. All 
aboard were killed.

airline after recently accepting a job with Ryanair in Cyprus.

first child in a few weeks, wanted to raise his family in Cyprus despite a drop in his wages.
The friend, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he didn't want to be named discussing his friend's

about being promoted to full captain a year and a half ago.
Socratous had previously worked for Helios Airways, the Cypriot airline that shut down after a plane crash in 2005.

The pilot and co-pilot had 5,965 and 5,769 hours of flying time respectively, making them "quite experienced," al-

The plane itself was produced in 2011 and underwent a detailed maintenance inspection known as a C check in

He said he is personally leading the airline's accident response. The carrier has deployed a team to the site of the 
crash, and Emirati civil aviation investigators are also on their way.

The Dubai Media Office works under Dubai's ruler, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, who also serves as

killed all 55 passengers and six crew members.
FlyDubai's fleet is dominated by relatively young Boeing 737-800 aircraft, the same model as the one that crashed.
Boeing says it stands ready to provide technical assistance upon the request of government agencies conducting 
the investigation. It adds it won't be able to answer any questions regarding the flight "in accordance with the 
international protocol governing aviation accident investigations."

7 a.m.
A flight-tracking service says a FlyDubai plane that crashed in Russia made one failed landing before the disaster.
Ian Petchenik, a spokesman for the website Flightradar24, told The Associated Press on Saturday that the Boeing 
737-800 initially tried to land at Rostov on Don at 2231 GMT.
Petchenik says: "Based on our data, what it looks like is the aircraft made an initial landing attempt."
He said the plane then entered a holding pattern at 2327 GMT near the airport, then left the holding pattern to try 
and land again at 0028 GMT. The flight offered its last data at 0041 GMT and lost contact.
Russian officials say the plane had 55 passengers and six crewmembers. Winds were anywhere from 14 to 22 
meters per second (30-50 miles per hour) at the time of the crash and that there was light rain.

southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, killing all on board.
Rostov-on-Don was blanketed in rain showers and weather forecasters said winds there reached up to 50 
kilometers (31 miles) per hour on Saturday morning.
FlightRadar24, a flight-tracking website, showed the FlyDubai flight made a series of loops near Rostov on Don 
while apparently waiting for permission to land.

The plane belonged to the budget carrier FlyDubai and was coming from Dubai when it crashed.

Fastjet nosedives amid row with Sir Stelios Airlines
Fastjet nosedives amid row with Sir Stelios; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 19, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 16
Length: 489 words
Byline: Tanya Powley and Nathalie Thomas
Highlight: Pan-African group's shares decline as founder's public criticism escalates friction
Body
Fastjet shares plunged yesterday after a row between Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou and the pan-African low-cost airline 
escalated, with the carrier threatening legal action against its second-biggest shareholder.
The board of Fastjet warned it was taking legal advice after Sir Stelios, who founded the airline and holds a 12 per 
cent stake, wrote a public letter, reiterating concerns over whether the airline had enough cash to continue.
In a letter addressed to Colin Child , chairman of Fastjet, Sir Stelios on Thursday demanded the airline resume the 
publication of monthly passenger statistics and requested updated cash flow forecasts for the current financial year.
"We are worried that you might not be able to pay your debts in the next few months," wrote Sir Stelios.
He claimed that, by stopping the publication of passenger statistics in December, Fastjet had "potentially committed 
a breach of the current brand licence that exists between Fastjet and easyGroup Holdings".
Sir Stelios owns his stake in Fastjet via his easyGroup Holdings company, which is also the biggest shareholder in 
easyJet, the low-cost airline he founded.
On Monday, Fastjet announced that its chief executive, Ed Winter , and the airline's general counsel, Krista Bates , 
would step down following pressure from Sir Stelios, who has criticised the airline's "ridiculously high cost base".
Fastjet nosedives amid row with Sir Stelios Airlines
Last week, Fastjet's shares plunged 45 per cent after it warned that profits would be "materially lower" than 
expectations and said that it may have to raise extra funds. The warning came days after Sir Stelios voiced his 
concerns and proposed an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders.
The airline was set up to replicate the successful business model of European carriers such as easyJet and Ryanair 
by providing low-cost, no-frills flying for African travellers.
However, it has been badly hit by the weakness of many African currencies, as well as political turbulence in 
Tanzania.
Sir Stelios on Thursday also asked for further information about cash flow and ticket pricing to be made available to 
him on a confidential basis.
He warned that "failure to supply this information could give easyGroup Holdings the right to take back the Fastjet 
brand in order to prevent any further damage to its good name".
Fastjet and easyGroup have a brand-licensing agreement that dates back to May 2012. The agreement allows 
Fastjet to use the name in return for an annual royalty fee based on turnover.
The board of Fastjet responded to Sir Stelios by expressing its disappointment that easyGroup had made public Sir 
Stelios's letter "without first raising its concerns with the company".
It claimed it was "wholly inappropriate", adding that it would hold easyGroup responsible for any damage caused to 
the business by the publication of the letter.
Fastjet's shares fell 25 per cent yesterday morning but have recovered to trade at 31.42p, down 13 per cent on 
Thursday's close.
Load-Date: March 18, 2016
End of Document
Lufthansa cuts expectations amid warnings over budget carriers
Lufthansa cuts expectations amid warnings over budget carriers
City A.M.
March 18, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 142 words
Byline: VICTORIA BRYAN
Body
GERMAN airline group Lufthansa yes-terday forecast only slightly higher profits in 2016, despite lower fuel prices, 
warning of cut-price rivals and falling average fares as it ramps up its Eurowings budget business.
Like rivals Air France-KLM and British Airways owner IAG, Lufthansa benefited from low oil prices and strong travel 
demand in 2015, enabling it to restore dividend payments to shareholders.
However, low-cost rivals such as Ryanair and easyJet have also benefited and are challenging Eurowings, adding 
more seats in Europe, and especially Germany, and putting pressure on ticket prices.
Lufthansa said it expected a slight increase in profit for 2016 after reporting adjusted earnings before interest and 
tax of (EURO)1.82bn (£1.44bn) for 2015.
Before the update, analysts had on average predicted an increase in profit to (EURO)2.08bn. Reuters

Thistle can crack World Hurdle puzzle Bill Esdaile previews the World Hurdle and Pertemps Final
Thistle can crack World Hurdle puzzle; Bill Esdaile previews the World 
Hurdle and Pertemps Final
City A.M.
March 17, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 31
Length: 279 words
Byline: Bill Esdaile
Body
WHEN the Colin Tizzard-trained THISTLECRACK finished fifth in last year's Imperial Cup, even his connections 
would have thought you mad for suggesting he would be favourite 12 months on for today's Ryanair World Hurdle 
(3.30pm).
Grade One wins at Aintree last season and Ascot in December have followed and the eight-year-old has improved 
at an extraordinary rate of knots.
His latest win on Trials Day here in January proved without debate that he's the best staying hurdler on these 
shores and he can be backed at 5/4 with Betway.
If there is one negative with my selection, it's the drying ground, as all of his best form this season has come on a 
bottomless surface.
That said, it wasn't soft at Aintree last season when he won the Sefton Novices' Hurdle, so it wouldn't be enough to 
put me off.
His biggest danger looks to be Irish-raider Alpha Des Obeaux, who fell at the last in that Aintree race when 
challenging Thistlecrack.
The drying ground will certainly bolster his chances and I've got the most enormous respect for anything his shrewd 
trainer Mouse Morris runs at this meeting.
Thistle can crack World Hurdle puzzle Bill Esdaile previews the World Hurdle and Pertemps Final
However, his form is quite simply not as good as Thistlecrack's and he was certainly coming off second best when 
he fell at Liverpool.
Last year's winner Cole Harden hasn't been in any form so far this campaign, but his trainer Warren Greatrex is 
adamant that better ground is key to him.
He was benefiting from a recent wind operation 12 months ago and I've also got it in my mind that he was given a 
soft lead.
At a much bigger price, I can see Paul Nicholls' Aux Ptits Soins going well, at around 16/1, but won't desert 
Thistlecrack on his biggest day.
POINTERS Thistlecrack 3.30pm Cheltenham

Ryanair To Open New Base At Vilnius Airport On October 30
Ryanair To Open New Base At Vilnius Airport On October 30
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 15, 2016 Tuesday 12:28 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 138 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings Plc. (RYA.L, RYAAY) Tuesday said it would open a new base at Vilnius 
Airport, from October 30, with two aircraft, at an investment of $200 million. The company said its its Vilnius traffic 
grew by 16 percent.  In addition, Ryanair launched its Lithuanian winter 2016 schedule with 2 new routes to Berlin 
and Malta and 3 new winter services to Birmingham, London Luton and London Stansted. Now the airline will be 
operating in 23 routes.  The airline will operate seven routes from Kaunas with more daily flights to Luton. There will 
be 27 weekly flights. From Palanga, it will operate a route to London Stansted with weekly schedules.   The 
company will release 100,000 seats for sale across European network from just 19.99 euros, which are available for 
booking until March 18.

(RTTNews) - Ryanair Holdings Plc. (RYA.L, RYAAY) Tuesday said it would open a new base at Vilnius Airport, 
from October 30, with two aircraft, at an investment of $200 million. The company said its its Vilnius traffic grew by

In addition, Ryanair launched its Lithuanian winter 2016 schedule with 2 new routes to Berlin and Malta and 3 new 
winter services to Birmingham, London Luton and London Stansted. Now the airline will be operating in 23 routes.
The airline will operate seven routes from Kaunas with more daily flights to Luton. There will be 27 weekly flights. 
From Palanga, it will operate a route to London Stansted with weekly schedules.
The company will release 100,000 seats for sale across European network from just 19.99 euros, which are 
available for booking until March 18.

Ryanair launches corporate jet charter service
Ryanair launches corporate jet charter service
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 14, 2016 Monday 4:09 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 148 words
Highlight: Ryanair has launched a corporate jet charter service, offering a Boeing 737-700 for corporate/group hire.
Body
Ryanair's corporate jet charter offers 60 business class, reclining, leather seats; 48" seat pitch; 2x2 configuration; 
and fine dining catering facilities. The service is ideal for private corporate, sports team or group travel. Ryanair's 
Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to launch our corporate jet hire service with our newly customised Boeing 737-
700, seating up to 60 passengers, on business class, reclining, leather seats, crewed by Ryanair's industry leading 
pilot and cabin crew professionals. "More than 25 million business travellers fly with Ryanair every year, choosing 
our low fares, unbeatable on-time performance, and Europe's largest route network, along with the benefits of our 
Business Plus service. Now, business and group travellers can also enjoy the benefits of Ryanair's corporate jet 
service, as we offer a customised Ryanair Boeing 737-700 for private charter."

ICG continues to ship in the profits
ICG continues to ship in the profits
Sunday Business Post
March 13, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 2011 words
Byline: Fearghal O'Connor
Highlight: Ferry company and boss Eamonn Rothwell have turned Irish Ferries into the Ryanair of the seas
Body
Eamonn Rothwell is the last man you would want to play poker with, according to one business acquaintance who 
knows him well. 
"He is super smart. Super sharp. Always thinking two or three steps ahead." 
Rothwell has survived one of the most infamous industrial relations battles in Irish history, a failed management 
buyout attempt and economic calamity in his biggest market, yet still the company which he leads - and of which he 
owns 14.7 per cent - can lay out a set of financial results that can only be described as a flush. 
Results published last week showed that revenues at Irish Continental Group (ICG) jumped 10 per cent last year to 
(EURO)320.6 million from (EURO)290.1 million a year earlier on the back of increased passengers, lower fuel 
prices and currency fluctuations. 
The owner of Irish Ferries reported full-year earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (ebitda) of 
(EURO)75.5 million, up 49.5 per cent on the (EURO)50.5 million recorded a year earlier. 
So what is the secret behind the success? How has Rothwell built the Ryanair of the seas? 
     
Back in December 2013, Ireland's economic statistics were starting to look positive, and a very visual sign of that 
recovery sailed into Dublin Port: a huge new ferry painted in the colours of ICG subsidiary Irish Ferries. It was a 
sure sign that the Irish economy had found its pulse. But it also signified that ICG had moved on from a difficult 
period. 
The new ship, the Epsilon, was introduced onto the Dublin to Holyhead route in order to take a bigger slice of the 
growing market (it now also does a run to Cherbourg at the weekends). 
ICG continues to ship in the profits
Nevertheless, the Epsilon was an each way bet. It was a real sign that management was in the mood for growth, 
according to one source, but the Epsilon was chartered in rather than bought, enabling the company "to test the 
waters". That lease runs out at the end of this year. A key decision now faced by management is how to replace the 
ship, with sources suggesting that, although it has proven to be a hugely successful lease, it is also too small a ship 
for the company's expanding needs. 
"It is more likely that they will buy a ship," said one well-placed source, who, like most people who have dealings 
with  the famously media-shy Rothwell, has no appetite to see his name in print talking about ICG. "If you believe in 
the strength of the economy then you might as well take ownership of it and have your own ship rather than pay 
leasing costs to someone else." 
If Irish Ferries does opt to buy a new ship - which is likely to cost in the high tens of millions - that will be a very real 
vote in the long-term strength of the Irish economy, said the source. 
"There is plenty more growth to come in the Irish economy,"  he said. "Just think about the small number of houses 
we are building at the moment and the number that we are going to have to build. A lot of the materials and 
products that go in to building those houses will be shipped through Dublin Port on Irish Continental Group ships." 
ICG, with its stable cost base and high level of fixed costs, has the ability to turn this type of top line growth into 
profits very quickly and generate a lot of cash. The company has also benefited greatly from lower fuel costs. Unlike 
most of the airlines with whom it is in competition, Irish Ferries does not hedge and so gets the benefit of lower fuel 
prices more quickly than anyone else. 
The company finished the year with net debt of (EURO)44 million, but should have net cash of (EURO)6 million in 
2016. "But in terms of free cashflow, over the next couple of years the company is likely to make at least (EURO)70 
million and because the business is doing so well they are in a position to afford a ship without any real difficulties," 
said the source. 
In recent times, management have also been very smart in how they have bought and sold ships and other assets. 
In 2012, the company sold part of its container and terminal business, Feederlink. 
It also won a lucrative concession at Belfast port. Perhaps most impressive of all was the (EURO)24 million bargain 
deal in November to buy four container vessels for effectively the price of one, again boosting its ability to capitalise 
on the Irish economy. 
On top of that, smart financial planning that has seen the company balance cheap debt with generous share 
buybacks and dividends has been key to it driving up its share price inexorably. 
Industrial relations
There is, however, another, more troublesome factor in the success of ICG. Few companies in Ireland since 1913 
have managed to bring 100,000 people onto the streets. But Irish Ferries managed it during a bitter dispute with its 
staff that ran between 2004 and 2006. 
The company had attempted to pay some of its workers far below the minimum wage and had initiated a highly 
controversial redundancy programme for more senior staff as it attempted to radically alter its staffing profile to 
allow it become the lean business it is today. 
"The outsourcing was quite important to its subsequent success to ensure that it had a competitive cost base and a 
reliable team behind it so that it didn't face strikes and disruption," said a source. 
John B McGuckian, chairman, and Eamonn Rothwell, chief executive officer, of ICG Pic: Mac Innes Photography
But John Geary, professor of industrial relations and human resources at the Smurfit School of Business, said 
public reaction to the move "was quite phenomenal" and galvanised trade unions to seek better employment rights, 
collective bargaining and organisation among migrant, contract and peripheral workers. 
ICG continues to ship in the profits
"It certainly touched a raw nerve and as a dispute it stands out for me," he said. "It was amazing that a dispute 
involving one small section of a workforce in one small industry had the effect of bringing so many people out onto 
the streets. A lot more than when we were confronted with the troika and the most severe economic crisis." 
While Geary said he would be reluctant to make a value judgment, he believes employers like ICG ultimately face a 
clear choice: compete on the basis of low wages and the undermining of conditions of employment and customer 
service, or compete on higher wages but better customer services. 
"Irish Ferries took the option, quite distinctly, of following the original Ryanair model on the sea. Imposing that 
model of low wage competition put it in direct confrontation with its workforce. It's not for me to endorse that or not 
and it can be spun in a variety of ways," said Geary. 
Patricia King, general secretary of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions, who was part of the Siptu negotiating team 
at the time, roundly condemns the approach Irish Ferries took. 
"I remember being in a room one night with management and it was very fractious. They were questioning what it 
was we were looking for. I remember taking (EURO)7.65 in change out my purse, which was the minimum wage, 
and throwing it on the table. 'Count that,' I said, 'that's what I want for every one of those workers for every hour 
down in the hold of that ship.' It was bareknuckle stuff." 
But what would King say to an analyst who argues that what ICG did in terms of rationalising its workforce was 
essential to keep it in business, to allow it survive the recession and to thrive in the recovery? 
"Yes, well, that type of analysis is something you would hear from someone who just looks at figures and who 
doesn't include human beings in the equation at all. It is the analysis of someone who merely sees a company as a 
vehicle to make profits and to be money spinners. It is one way of looking at it, but the people who deliver that for 
you are human beings." 
In the end, the company was forced to back down on its plans and ended up paying out (EURO)6 million in 
redundancies. And yet, the figures would suggest that ICG lost the battle but won the war. In 2007, it paid out 
almost (EURO)33 million in employee costs. By last year, despite expansion, that was down to (EURO)21 million. 
Blue chip investor base
So what comes next for the company? Soon after the industrial dispute was dealt with, a takeover battle kicked off 
that saw Rothwell lead an ultimately unsuccessful management buyout attempt. 
With the property market in a state of insanity, management found themselves up against developer Liam Carroll, 
as well as One 51 and the Doyle Group. ICG had moved from being a ferry company to a property player based on 
its holdings around Dublin Port. But the property crash soon put paid to those notions and it remained a plc. One 
person with close knowledge of the internal workings of the company said the "steady as she goes" approach will 
continue for the foreseeable future. 
"I don't see an MBO at this company, for example. It now has a blue chip investor base that is not in a selling mode 
but looking for incremental growth. Clearly there was potential for an MBO a few years ago, but that is gone and it 
certainly looks like remaining as a public limited company for the foreseeable future." 
Nevertheless, in the medium term, some change is inevitable given that Rothwell, who owns almost 15 per cent of 
the company, is almost 60. There have been a number of new appointments to the senior management team in 
recent times. 
"I am sure that is part of a long-term succession plan. But from what I can see, Rothwell still has a huge appetite for 
the business so I don't see anything changing any time soon. There's no obvious number two just yet. This is a bit 
like Ryanair: there's a number one and there's a number one." 
ICG continues to ship in the profits
At Ryanair, longtime deputy chief executive Howard Miller never got to succeed O'Leary in the way that many 
thought he would. 
Rothwell, too, has outstayed senior executives whom some might have seen as natural successors. 
But while there are many comparisons between the two companies, ultimately ICG can never truly be a Ryanair of 
the seas given that it is likely to remain very reluctant to expand out of its Irish market. 
"That puts a cap on how much it can grow, in a sense," said a source. "But then while some companies want to 
keep on growing, others are happy to stay at a reasonable size and be very profitable." 
Storm clouds on the horizon for ICG
ICG may well be proving to be a runaway success but there are potential storm clouds on the horizon. The sharp 
rise in fuel costs that some economists are predicting could turn ICG's lack of hedging quickly into a disadvantage. 
A weakened sterling, which could make Ireland less attractive to British visitors and hit Irish exporters to Britain, 
could also dampen the strong growth the company has seen in freight. 
If Brexit comes about, the company's passenger profile - with 60 per cent inbound into Ireland from Britain - could 
put it under some pressure, particularly if the British economy and sterling were to take a kicking. 
"The company does not seem overly concerned about Brexit. You have to suspect that, whatever happens, there 
will probably be some sort of trade agreement between Ireland and the UK," said a source. 
There is also - potentially - a silver lining for the company from Brexit if duty free were to be brought back in. In the 
good old days, Irish Ferries made huge money from so-called booze cruises, with half the company's profits 
generated by duty free sales. The return of duty free on the Irish Sea following a Brexit would be an obvious boon, 
while the more likely establishment of a new free trade zone would mean business as usual for ICG, analysts have 
recently pointed out. 
Indeed, most analysts have sharply increased their earnings predictions for the company, regardless of Brexit or oil 
price hikes. Those predictions are based on the fundamental fact that across every metric, the company continues 
to outperform its competitors. 
And if there is one thing that is certain, Eamonn Rothwell will continue to play his ICG cards very close to his chest. 
The Numbers:
(EURO)320m: Revenue in 2015 
(EURO)54.1m: Profit before tax for last year, down from (EURO)56.7m 
(EURO)44.3m: Net debt 
5%: Dividend rose to 11.025 cent per share 
Load-Date: April 18, 2016

Ryanair is capturing market share quicker than expected in Germany Ryanair is capt...
Ryanair is capturing market share quicker than expected in Germany; 
Ryanair is capt...
Business World (Digest)
March 11, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 287 words
Highlight: Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost carrier, is capturing market share quicker than expected in Germany, 
an executive told Reuters on Friday.
Body
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost carrier, is capturing market share quicker than expected in Germany, an 
executive told Reuters on Friday.
Ryanair, which is expanding routes out of Cologne and Berlin in particular, ended 2015 with a 5 percent share of 
the German air travel market and expects that to rise to 8-10 percent this year, Kenny Jacobs, chief marketing 
officer, told Reuters on the sidelines of the ITB travel fair in Berlin.
"Michael has said we'll get to 20 percent within a five year period but so far we're ahead of that projection," he said, 
referring to Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary.
Ryanair is also not ruling out flying out of Frankfurt in the future, if it could get the right deal, Jacobs said. O'Leary 
has often said Frankfurt was one of the few airports Ryanair could not fly out of due to high fees and lengthy 
turnaround times. "It's a possibility," Jacobs said, although he added that Ryanair did not need to fly from Frankfurt 
or Munich, Germany's two largest airports, to reach the 20 percent market share target. In Germany, alongside 
Berlin and Cologne, Ryanair is targeting smaller airports such as Nuremberg and speaking to businesses in the 
area such as Adidas and Audi to inform its route decisions, part of a trend for budget carriers to target corporate 
travel. Jacobs said while the German market was currently underserved by low-cost carriers, Frankfurt and Munich 
would eventually have to increase the amount of low-cost flights to reflect growing demand for budget across 
Europe.. "For a country that gave us (discount supermarket chains) Aldi and Lidl, to have the lowest penetration of 
low-cost airlines, it's quite a surprise," he said. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair aims to tap into lucrative business market with launch of corporate-jet service; Airlines
Ryanair aims to tap into lucrative business market with launch of corporate-
jet service; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 10, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 23
Length: 359 words
Byline: Tanya Powley, Transport Correspondent
Body
Ryanair is casting aside its no-frills image with the launch of a corporate-jet service that promises leather reclining 
seats and fine dining catering.
The service, launched yesterday, will see the Irish low-cost airline delve further into the lucrative business market 
by appealing to companies and wealthy individuals who prefer travelling by private jet.
The airline has kitted out a Boeing 737-700 aircraft for hire with 60 business-class reclining leather seats, with a 48-
inch pitch - providing much more legroom than Ryanair's normal 30-inch configuration.
It represents a significant departure from the airline's normal approach, which has seen it upend the business 
model of Europe's flag carriers for 30 years by undercutting them on fares with its no-frills service.
Ryanair said the corporate-jet hire will be charged by the hour, and available for flights to destinations up to six 
hours away. But in typical Ryanair fashion, customers will have to pay extra for add-ons such as fine dining. "This is 
the perfect vehicle to bring government traffic or companies who want to be seen as saving money by flying Ryanair 
but still get to enjoy all the opulence of corporate travel," said the airline.
The jet, while still branded Ryanair on the outside, will be devoid of the airline's typical yellow and blue interiors. 
Ryanair has spent the past two years revamping its image after admitting its no-frills approach could "piss people 
Ryanair aims to tap into lucrative business market with launch of corporate-jet service; Airlines
off". After two profit warnings in 2013, the carrier overhauled its business model, reduced or axed unpopular fees 
and let passengers take a second, smaller item of carry-on baggage. It is also flying to more primary airports and its 
website has been upgraded to make it easier to book tickets.
In 2014, the airline made its first foray into the corporate market by offering a "business class" service on all of its 
flights. Branded "Business Plus", tickets start from EUR69.99 and allow unlimited flight changes and premium 
seating. According to Ryanair, it flies more than 25m business travellers each year.
It says it plans to start with one corporate jet to assess the market before considering whether to add more.
Load-Date: March 9, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair taxis towards private jet charter services as demand rises
Ryanair taxis towards private jet charter services as demand rises
City A.M.
March 10, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 19
Length: 124 words
Byline: JAMES NICKERSON
Body
BUDGET Irish airline Ryanair yester-day launched a corporate jet charter service, aiming to capitalise on growing 
demand for chartered jets.
A customised Boeing 737-700 jet for corporate and group hire is available, seating 60 people and capable of flying 
to destinations up to six hours away. It will also offer fine dining.
"We are pleased to launch our corporate jet hire service with our newly customised Boeing 737-700, seating up to 
60 passengers, on business class, reclining, leather seats, crewed by Ryanair's industry leading pilot and cabin 
crew profess-ionals," said Ryanair's Robin Kiely.
Meanwhile, jet financing firm Global Jet Capital and self-styled Airbnb of the private jet market Stellar Labs will both 
launch in the UK in 2016.

Icelandic airline founder believes low-cost carriers have Wow factor
Icelandic airline founder believes low-cost carriers have Wow factor
City A.M.
March 10, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 192 words
Byline: PETER MAUSHAGEN
Body
LOW-COST carriers could take up to a 25 per cent share of the market for transatlantic travel, the chief executive of 
Icelandic budget carrier Wow Air told Reuters yesterday after it made its first annual www.profit.No airline has so far 
had a major success with low-cost long-haul travel between Europe and North America, although companies such 
as Wow Air, Norwegian and Lufthansa's Euro-wings are all active in the market now. Wow Air, founded in 2011 and 
offering flights to Washington DC and Boston from Europe from (EURO)247 (£191) one way, made its first profit of 
around 1.1 billion Icelandic crowns (£6m) in 2015, against a loss of 600m crowns in 2014.
Skuli Mogensen, CEO and founder of Wow Air, said people had become used to low-cost flying and online ticket 
sales, one of the ways budget carriers seek to keep costs down.
"It's all about the timing," he said.
"You don't have to explain the lowcost model anymore. Everyone has flown with easyJet or Ryanair.
"Historically, 99 per cent of the transatlantic market has been controlled by what I call the legacy cartel. I am 
confident the low-cost carrier model can capture up to 25 per cent."
Reuters

The service will include a customised Boeing 737-700 jet crewed by Ryanair pilot and cabin crew professionals with 
fine dining catering facilities available.
Ryanair's Robin Kiely today commented, "We are pleased to launch our corporate jet hire service with our newly 
customised Boeing 737-700, seating up to 60 passengers, on business class, reclining, leather seats, crewed by

"More than 25 million business travellers fly with Ryanair every year, choosing our low fares, unbeatable on-time

Fastjet shares plunge on third profit warning; Airlines
Fastjet shares plunge on third profit warning; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 8, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 24
Length: 439 words
Byline: John Murray Brown
Highlight: Pan-African carrier eyes funds as key shareholder urges board's replacement
Body
Fastjet shares closed 36 per cent lower yesterday after the pan-African low-cost airline warned that profits would be 
"materially lower" than expectations, and said that it may have to raise extra funds.
At one stage in the morning shares in the Aim-listed carrier were trading 45 per cent lower at 36p , having closed on 
Friday at 67p. The slump comes just days after the company received demands from its second-largest shareholder 
for the board to be replaced.
In its third profits warning in the past year, Fastjet said it expected results for 2016 to be "materially below market 
expectations" and warned "the group no longer expects to be cash flow positive for the year".
It said the challenging market conditions "have been a lot more prolonged than management originally forecast". 
The company said it was monitoring its cash position "very carefully", but with more than $20m available at the end 
of February, it said it had sufficient funds to meet its operational requirements.
Nonetheless, Fastjet said it was considering raising further funds to "provide additional headroom and ensure the 
company has the necessary resources to fund future growth as market conditions improve".
Fastjet shares plunge on third profit warning; Airlines
Last week, easyJet founder Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou , Fastjet's second- largest shareholder, tabled a request for an 
extraordinary general meeting of shareholders, calling for Ed Winter , the chief executive, and Krista Bates, a board 
director, to be replaced.
EasyGroup, Sir Stelios's private investment vehicle, said it was using its rights as a 12 per cent shareholder to call 
for an EGM, adding that it had "lost faith" in the management and current board, and warning that "unless the board 
does some serious cost-cutting the company will soon run out of cash".
Sir Stelios criticised Fastjet's "ridiculously high cost base", claiming that Mr Winter had "burnt some £80m in the last 
three years". He wrote: "We now have about six months left to steady this ship. Time is of the essence."
Mr Winter, who has run the company since it was founded in 2012, said in January that he was stepping down as 
chief executive but would remain in his post until a replacement was found.
The airline was set up to replicate the successful business model of carriers such as easyJet and Ryanair, by 
providing no-frills flying for African travellers.
It flies from five airports in Tanzania and has flights to Johannesburg, Lusaka, Harare and Nairobi. In January it 
announced new routes between Zimbabwe and South Africa. However, it has been badly hit by the weakness of 
many African currencies. Since the start of 2013, shares have dropped 98 per cent.
See Lombard
Load-Date: March 7, 2016
End of Document
JetBlue 's trial approach: Will train novices to be pilots
JetBlue's trial approach: Will train novices to be pilots
Associated Press Financial Wire
March 7, 2016 Monday 4:55 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 542 words
Byline: By DAVID KOENIG, AP Airlines Writer
Dateline: DALLAS 
Body
DALLAS (AP) - JetBlue Airways is taking applications for 24 slots in a new program to train novice pilots to fly a 
passenger jet.
The airline said Monday that the program - the first of its kind at a large U.S. airline - will cost about $125,000 and 
take four years to complete. Graduates could wind up flying 100-seat passenger jets.
Warren Christie, JetBlue's senior vice president of safety and training, say the program won't replace the airline's 
traditional pipelines for pilots, many of whom come from smaller airlines. JetBlue hired more than 300 pilots last 
year, and a group of 30 new hires just started training last week, he said.
Applicants will be judged with tests measuring hand-eye coordination, multitasking, critical thinking and other skills. 
Those who survive the first cut will be interviewed.
There also will be a "personality assessment" but not psychological screening, Christie said. The debate over 
psychological screening has increased since a Germanwings pilot intentionally crashed a plane last year in France, 
killing 150 people.
JetBlue expects the first group of six prospects to begin training in late summer at the airline's training center in 
Florida. JetBlue hired CAE, a maker of flight simulators, to provide the training. CAE has run similar programs for 
EasyJet and Ryanair in Europe and several airlines in Asia.
Christie believes the program will open the profession to more people. The trainees will meet all federal 
requirements before carrying passengers, he said.
"They will absolutely be as qualified as any other pilot that is operating a JetBlue aircraft," he said.
Taking a page from programs in Europe, the students will start training with other crew members in a cockpit or 
simulator much earlier than usual, according to JetBlue and CAE. Currently, some new U.S. pilots learn by dusting 
crops or toting advertising banners - experience that may bear little resemblance to working in an airliner cockpit.
JetBlue 's trial approach: Will train novices to be pilots
The applicants will pay for their own training, and the cost is not much different from the amount that many aspiring 
pilots now spend to accumulate the 1,500 flight hours necessary for an airline pilot's license.
Christie said the students will be able to defray some of their costs by earning a salary as a CAE instructor for part 
of their training period. CAE described the salary as "competitive" without providing specifics.
Nick Leontidis, president of CAE's training business, said students who struggle will be flagged for remedial training 
and, failing that, expulsion. But washout rates in similar programs at other airlines have been "extremely low," he 
said.
"We believe this is going to be an important part of how airlines are going to create pilots in the future," Leontidis 
said.
The pilots' union at JetBlue pilots opposes the plan. Jim Bigham, chairman of the union's council, said JetBlue 
should instead hire pilots with experience at regional airlines who currently get passed over.
Bigham said he is not against training newcomers to the field, "but when they come out, I want them to go gain 
some real-world airline experience prior to becoming an apprentice at JetBlue."
___
Applications can be submitted at http://pilots.jetblue.com
Contact David Koenig at http://twitter.com/airlinewriter
Load-Date: March 8, 2016
End of Document
Boardroom Briefing
Boardroom Briefing
Sunday Business Post
March 6, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 631 words
Body
Bumper traffic at Ryanair
Ryanair's February traffic grew 28 per cent to 7.4 million customers, up from 5.8 million last February. 
Its load factor rose four points to 93 per cent, from 89 per cent last year. Meanwhile, rolling annual traffic to 
February grew 17 per cent to 104.6 million customers. 
Ryanair spokesman Kenny Jacobs said: "These record monthly numbers and load factors are due to our lower 
fares, our stronger forward bookings and the success of our Always Getting Better customer experience 
programme, which continues to deliver better than expected traffic and load factors." 
Last week, the airline launched its Belfast winter 2016 schedule. There are seven new routes to Alicante, Berlin, 
Krakow, Lanzarote, Malaga, Milan and Tenerife, and extra flights to London Gatwick. 
Profits up at Dalata to (EURO)28.5 million
Hotel group Dalata has reported a pre-tax profit of (EURO)28.5 million for last year, up from (EURO)4.2 million in 
2014, in what it described as a "transformational" year for the company. 
The company said revenues grew by 185 per cent to (EURO)225.7 million following the integration of 15 new hotels 
into the company. 
"2015 has been a remarkable year for Dalata," said chief executive Pat McCann. 
"The results for 2015 highlight the momentous change that the group has undergone as a result of the acquisition of 
15 hotels." 
Dalata said its pipeline for new opportunities remained very strong and it expected to fully invest its remaining 
(EURO)130 million this year. 
Boardroom Briefing
Strong results from CRH after billions spent on acquisitions
Building materials company CRH last week reported sales of (EURO)23.6 billion, 25 per cent ahead of 2014. 
The company's results statement highlighted "good profit growth" and an "enhanced portfolio through mergers and 
acquisitions". CRH made acquisitions and investments of almost (EURO)8 billion in 2015. 
It reported a jump in pre-tax profit, which increased from (EURO)761 million in 2014 to (EURO)1,033 million last 
year. 
Chief executive Albert Manifold said that "as a result of good performance from our heritage businesses and 
contributions from acquisitions, 2015 was a year of significant profit growth for CRH". 
Total Produce looks to further investments
Revenue at Total Produce increased by 10.4 per cent to (EURO)3.45 billion in 2015, according to results published 
by the company last week. 
Company chairman Carl McCann said it had "delivered a very strong performance in 2015", pointing to its growth in 
North America via a number of acquisitions it made last year. He added that the group "continues to actively pursue 
further investment opportunities". 
According to analysis by Davy Stockbrokers, Total Produce "retains significant financial flexibility". 
Smurfit Kappa makes London move
Smurfit Kappa shares began trading in sterling on the London Stock Exchange last week, the company's first step 
in a move toward having a full primary listing on the London exchange. 
The paper and packaging group's shares will continue to trade in euro in Dublin. Last month, the company 
confirmed it was "reviewing the listing arrangements" for its shares. 
In a statement released at the time, Smurfit Kappa said it remained "committed to retaining an Irish Stock Exchange 
euro-denominated listing, which will continue to provide access to a wide range of international investors". 
The week ahead
Tomorrow, Irish Continental Group will publish its 2015 results. Last week the company announced the appointment 
of a new director, David Ledwidge. He joined the company in 2006 and was appointed chief financial officer last 
year. 
Tuesday will see the newly merged betting giant Paddy Power Betfair publish results, while Permanent TSB will 
publish full-year results on Wednesday (see Ian Guider's Market Talk column on page 3).

reporting period.  Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) traded up 0.60% on Wednesday, reaching

average is $81.17.  Several equities research analysts have recently commented on RYAAY shares. Vetr[2]

rating and nine have issued a buy rating to the company. The stock currently has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and

Ryanair launches new London winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair launches new London winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 3, 2016 Thursday 10:49 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 297 words
Highlight: Ryanair has launched its new London winter 2016 schedule with five new routes to Alicante, Belfast, 
Hamburg, Timisoara and Toulouse, seven new winter services to Fuerteventura, Gran Canaria, Jerez, Murcia, 
Sofia, Tenerife and Vilnius, and more flights on 11 other routes, which will deliver 23.6 million customers per annum 
and support 17,700 jobs at London Stansted, London Gatwick and London Luton Airports.
Body
From Stansted there are three new routes: Hamburg (2 daily), Timisoara (1 daily) and Toulouse (1 daily); as well as 
more flights to Alicante (10 wkly), Bordeaux (5 wkly), Faro (1 daily), Gran Canaria (6 wkly), Lanzarote (5 wkly), 
Malta (4 wkly), Nuremberg (2 daily), Seville (9 wkly) & Valencia (1 daily). From Gatwick, there are two new routes to 
Alicante (6 wkly) and Belfast (5 daily) as well as more flights to Dublin (8 daily). From Luton there are five new 
winter services to Fuerteventura, Gran Canaria, Murcia, Tenerife and Vilnius as well more flights to Kaunas (daily). 
Ryanair will continue to connect London with Europe's major centres of business through high frequency services, 
including Belfast (5 daily), Dublin (19 daily) Madrid (4 daily) and Rome (5 daily), with more flights, better timings and 
the lowest fares, making Ryanair the ideal choice for business and leisure customers. In London, Ryanair's chief 
marketing officer, Kenny Jacobs, said: "We are pleased to launch our London winter 2016 schedule, which includes 
5 new routes to Alicante, Belfast, Hamburg, Timisoara and Toulouse, 7 new winter services to Fuerteventura, Gran 
Canaria, Jerez, Murcia, Sofia, Tenerife and Vilnius, and more flights on 11 other routes, which will deliver 23.6 
million customers p.a. - almost 20% of our total annual traffic - and support 17,700 jobs at London Stansted, 
London Gatwick and London Luton Airports, as we grow our London traffic by 10%. "To celebrate the launch of our 
London winter 2016 schedule, we are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European network from just 
GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Monday (29 Feb). Since these amazing low prices will be snapped 
up quickly, customers should log onto 
www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out."

Ryanair Launches Belfast Winter Schedule To 7 New Routes
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 3, 2016 Thursday 2:09 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 101 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L) Thursday launched its Belfast winter schedule with seven 
new routes to Alicante, Berlin, Krakow, Lansarote, Malaga, Milan and Tenerife. There will additional five daily flights 
to London Gatwick.  To Alicante, Berlin and Krakow, there will be three weekly flights, while there will be two weekly 
flights to Lanzarote, Milan and Tenerife. As per the new schedule there will be four weekly service to Malaga.   
Ryanair said, the winter schedule is expected to serve more than one million customers and support 750 jobs at 
Belfast International airport.

International Airport to Alicante, Gran Canaria, Lanzarote and Malaga, and three new winter services from Glasgow 
Prestwick to Barcelona, Faro and Madrid.
Body
The new routes will deliver over 1.8 million customers per annum and support 1,400 jobs at Glasgow International 
Airport and Glasgow Prestwick airports. Ryanair will continue to connect Glasgow with Europe's major centres of 
business through high frequency services, including Dublin (3 daily) and London (4 daily), with more flights, better 
timings and the lowest fares, making Ryanair the ideal choice for business and leisure customers. In Glasgow, 
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to launch our Glasgow winter 2016 
schedule, which includes 4 new routes from Glasgow International to Alicante, Gran Canaria, Lanzarote and 
Malaga, and 3 new winter services from Glasgow Prestwick to Barcelona, Faro and Malta, which will deliver over 
1.8 million customers p.a. and support 1,400 jobs at Glasgow and Prestwick airports. "To celebrate the launch of 
our Glasgow winter 2016 schedule, we are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European network from just 
GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Thursday (25 Feb). Since these amazing low prices will be 
snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and avoid missing out."

Ad watchdog rules Google links misled Ryanair's customers
Ad watchdog rules Google links misled Ryanair's customers
City A.M.
March 3, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 174 words
Byline: BILLY BAMBROUGH
Body
THE ADVERTISING watchdog has ruled that travel comparison site eDreams has been misleading cust-omers 
through its Google advertisements.
The Advertising Standards Auth-ority has been looking into customer complaints after Ryanair claimed the website 
was duping those who belie-ved they were booking directly with the airline.
The budget Irish carrier has also called on search giant Google to remove eDreams from its promoted search 
listings, but says this has been ignored.
Ryanair's chief marketing officer, Kenny Jacobs, said: "Google is clearly aware of this misleading advertising, 
because Ryanair has brought it to its attention at every level within the organisation.
"We believe that Google has thus far failed to block this misleading advertising, precisely because it boosts 
Google's advertising revenues by actively misleading consumers into believing they are booking tickets on Ryanair 
and/or other websites when in fact they are booking on a third party website."
In Germany Ryanair won a case forcing Google to remove eDreams from results.
Graphic
 
Despite the hiccup Ryanair's strength in the European short-haul market remains
Ad watchdog rules Google links misled Ryanair's customers

Ryanair Urges Google To Ban EDreams Ads
Ryanair Urges Google To Ban EDreams Ads
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 2, 2016 Wednesday 4:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 372 words
Body
       MOUNTAIN VIEW (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) said it welcomed today's ruling by the U.K. 
Advertising Standards Authority, which found that eDreams advertising on Google was 'misleading' consumers and 
breached the CAP code.   Ryanair called on Google to ban this deceptive eDreams advertising until such time that 
eDreams stops misleading consumers by passing itself off as Ryanair.  The U.K. ASA reviewed a series of 
complaints from consumers who were deceived by eDreams masquerading as Ryanair and Easyjet using the 
airlines name, brand and logo in a blatant attempt to dupe consumers into booking higher priced tickets on 
eDreams than those available on the Ryanair.com website. 
 Ryanair believes that Google has allowed this advertising, which the ASA now confirms breaches the CAP code, 
because it directly boosts the number of 'click-throughs' on Google's paid for advertising search engine, thereby 
maximizing Google's advertising revenues at the expense of consumers.   Ryanair noted that it has repeatedly 
written to Google at the highest levels, including Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt, enclosing hundreds of 
complaints by real customers who have been misled by eDreams false advertising on Google, and yet Google has 
failed/refused to take any action to prevent this deceptive advertising.  Meanwhile, a statement from an eDreams 
spokesperson said the company is encouraged by the ASA's acknowledgment that it can use relevant search terms 
and that it can promote its services as an Online Travel Agency through the use of search engine optimization.    
'We are keen to work with the ASA to ensure that there is never any potential confusion for customers when they 
search for flight availability on the eDreams website,' the spokesperson said.    The spokesperson  added, 'There is 
no intention to imitate the appearance of specific airlines, as eDreams clearly indicates to its customers that they 
are on one of its own websites, rather than that of any airline, allowing them to view thousands of flight 
combinations in a matter of seconds to find the best value flights.'  eDreams said it continuously aims to ensure 
compliance with regulators and to operate in the best interest of consumers.      
Load-Date: March 2, 2016
Ryanair Urges Google To Ban EDreams Ads
End of Document

Advertising Standards Authority which found that eDreams advertising on Google was 'misleading' consumers and 
breached the CAP code. Ryanair now calls on Google to ban this deceptive eDreams advertising until such time 
that eDreams stops misleading consumers by passing itself off as Ryanair.  The UK ASA reviewed a series of 
complaints from consumers who were deceived by eDreams masquerading as Ryanair and Easyjet using the 
airlines name, brand and logo in a blatant attempt to dupe consumers into booking higher priced tickets on 
eDreams than those available on the Ryanair.com website.  Ryanair believes that Google has allowed this

throughs' on Google's paid for advertising search engine, thereby maximising Google's advertising revenues at the

misled by eDreams false advertising on Google, and yet Google has failed/refused to take any action to prevent this

(RTTNews) - Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) said that it welcomed today's ruling by the UK Advertising Standards 
Authority which found that eDreams advertising on Google was "misleading" consumers and breached the CAP 
code. Ryanair now calls on Google to ban this deceptive eDreams advertising until such time that eDreams stops 
misleading consumers by passing itself off as Ryanair.
The UK ASA reviewed a series of complaints from consumers who were deceived by eDreams masquerading as 
Ryanair and Easyjet using the airlines name, brand and logo in a blatant attempt to dupe consumers into booking 
higher priced tickets on eDreams than those available on the Ryanair.com website.
Ryanair believes that Google has allowed this advertising, which the ASA now confirms breaches the CAP code, 
because it directly boosts the number of "click-throughs" on Google's paid for advertising search engine, thereby 
maximising Google's advertising revenues at the expense of consumers. Ryanair noted that it has repeatedly 
written to Google at the highest levels, including Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt, enclosing hundreds of 
complaints by real customers who have been misled by eDreams false advertising on Google, and yet Google has 
failed/refused to take any action to prevent this deceptive advertising.

Ryanair Urges Google To Ban EDreams Ads
Ryanair Urges Google To Ban EDreams Ads
RTT News (United States)
March 2, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 382 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) said it welcomed today's ruling by the U.K. Advertising Standards Authority, 
which found that eDreams advertising on Google was "misleading" consumers and breached the CAP code.
Ryanair called on Google to ban this deceptive eDreams advertising until such time that eDreams stops misleading 
consumers by passing itself off as Ryanair.
The U.K. ASA reviewed a series of complaints from consumers who were deceived by eDreams masquerading as 
Ryanair and Easyjet using the airlines name, brand and logo in a blatant attempt to dupe consumers into booking 
higher priced tickets on eDreams than those available on the Ryanair.com website.
Ryanair believes that Google has allowed this advertising, which the ASA now confirms breaches the CAP code, 
because it directly boosts the number of "click-throughs" on Google's paid for advertising search engine, thereby 
maximizing Google's advertising revenues at the expense of consumers. Ryanair noted that it has repeatedly 
written to Google at the highest levels, including Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt, enclosing hundreds of 
complaints by real customers who have been misled by eDreams false advertising on Google, and yet Google has 
failed/refused to take any action to prevent this deceptive advertising.
Meanwhile, a statement from an eDreams spokesperson said the company is encouraged by the ASA's 
acknowledgment that it can use relevant search terms and that it can promote its services as an Online Travel 
Agency through the use of search engine optimization.
"We are keen to work with the ASA to ensure that there is never any potential confusion for customers when they 
search for flight availability on the eDreams website," the spokesperson said. The spokesperson added, "There is 
no intention to imitate the appearance of specific airlines, as eDreams clearly indicates to its customers that they 
are on one of its own websites, rather than that of any airline, allowing them to view thousands of flight 
combinations in a matter of seconds to find the best value flights."
eDreams said it continuously aims to ensure compliance with regulators and to operate in the best interest of 
consumers.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com
Copyright(c) 2016 RTTNews.com. All Rights Reserved
Ryanair Urges Google To Ban EDreams Ads
