Analysis: easyJet closes â,¬500m debut eurobond
Analysis: easyJet closes â,¬500m debut eurobond
AirFinance Journal
March 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: LATEST NEWS,EUROPE,AIRCRAFT,AIRLINES,CAPITAL,BREAKING NEWS,ANALYSIS,UK
Length: 706 words
Highlight: After a spate of issuances in 2015, the UK carrier becomes the latest airline to tap the European capital 
markets. Jack Dutton reports.
Body
US investors make up the lion's share of aviation capital markets deals but, over the past year, an increasing 
number of airlines have been tapping the European capital markets.
In December, Norwegian opened up its investor base after issuing its debut eurobond. In March 2015, Ryanair 
returned to market with its second eurobond, with a coupon of 1.125%, setting a record for the aviation industry. 
With a strong credit rating of Baa1/BBB+ stable, it was easyJet's turn to step up to the plate.
"I think we have been able to price a transaction that's captured the attention of the market," Brendon Moran, global 
co-head of corporate origination, debt capital markets at Société Générale, tellsAirfinance Journal.
The banker, who worked on the bond, explains why.
"One reason for this is its success, in what have been incredibly tricky markets that have been and remain quite 
difficult to read," he says. "We had continuing weakness going into this deal throughout January, particularly in 
equity markets, andI think fixed-income markets looked a little bit shaky."
The UK low-cost carrier's offering is a seven-year bullet repayment with a coupon of 1.75%, payable annually.The 
initial price expectations were 165 basis points (bps) to 175bps over seven-year euro mid-swaps, but the bond 
priced at 147bps over mid-swaps.
The mandated lead arrangers were Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays and Société Générale.
Allen & Overy acted for the arrangers and Herbert Smith Freehills acted for the airline.
Soaring investor demand
The road show for the bond took place in the second week of January, during which the airline visited cities in 
Europe, including London, Edinburgh, Amsterdam, Paris and Munich.
Analysis: easyJet closes â,¬500m debut eurobond
"EasyJet went through a formal road show, meeting with fixed-income investors across the continent in the areas 
where you find big pockets of liquidity for corporate bonds. They got out there, on the back of having their ratings 
announced "" Baa1/BBB+ stable "" which is always a good story to show," says Moran.
The airline opened the book on February 2. It received a soaring oversubscription of just over â,¬5 billion ($5.5 
billion), which was reduced to â,¬4.8 billion after price tensioning.
The book included about 400 investors from France (23%), UK and Ireland (21%), Germany (21%), Luxembourg 
(9%), Italy (7%), Nordic countries (5%), Switzerland (7%) and other European countries (7%).
The proceeds from the bond will be used to pay back £182 million ($257 million) of existing commercial debt 
maturing this financial year. Proceeds will also be used to finance new aircraft deliveries.
Pipeline of issuance
"We intend this to be a pipeline of issuance. We can see ourselves coming to market every 12 to 18 months, at a 
similar size, provided the economics still work for us," Mike Hurst, group treasurer at easyJet, tellsAirfinance 
Journal.
He adds: "What's driving that requirement is the 20 to 30 new Airbus aircraft that we've got arriving per annum over 
the course of the next four to five years."
EasyJet's incoming Airbus aircraft include both A320ceos and A320neos. The Ceos are delivering now and the 
Neos will begin delivering in 2017.
According to Hurst, one of the main tenets of the Moody's report that underpins easyJet's credit rating is the 
carrier's move towards bringing new aircraft onto the balance sheet unencumbered. As at September 30 2015, 
easyJet had 241 aircraft, 114 of which were unencumbered "" 47% of the carrier's fleet.
"And obviously this is a strategic move to open up a source of unsecured funding, so when new aircraft come onto 
the balance sheet,the number of unencumbered aircraft grows over time. This is one of the key pillars of our credit, 
and it is why we have been able to obtain the credit rating we have with Moody's," says Hurst.
He adds: "What drives these sort of deals is the credit quality. To really do this well, you have to have a solid, 
investment-grade credit rating, which we do. If you look at where the rest of our peer group are in terms of credit 
rating, there are relatively few who could achieve this. Many airlines quite frankly, don't have the credit quality to be 
able to issue unsecured at this size in these markets at this level of pricing."
Jack.Dutton@euromoneyplc.com
Load-Date: March 28, 2016
End of Document
Scout Investments Inc. Has $43,812,000 Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Scout Investments Inc. Has $43,812,000 Position in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
Watchlist News
February 29, 2016 Monday 6:14 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 694 words
Byline: Hanz Christensen
Body
Feb 29, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Scout Investments Inc. 
lowered its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 34.3% during the fourth quarter, 
according to its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The institutional investor owned 
506,732 shares of the company's stock after selling 264,256 shares during the period. 
Ryanair Holdings plc accounts for about 1.1% of Scout Investments Inc.'s investment portfolio, making the stock its 
16th largest position. Scout Investments Inc. owned approximately 0.19% of Ryanair Holdings plc worth 
$43,812,000 as of its most recent filing with the SEC.  A number of other large investors have also modified their 
holdings of the stock. Russell Frank Co raised its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 408.9% in the fourth 
quarter. Russell Frank Co now owns 690,664 shares of the company's stock worth $60,060,000 after buying an 
additional 554,940 shares during the period. Adelphi Capital raised its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 
3.5% in the fourth quarter. Adelphi Capital now owns 132,371 shares of the company's stock worth $11,444,000 
after buying an additional 4,455 shares during the period. Ferguson Wellman Capital Management Inc. raised its 
stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 2.0% in the fourth quarter. Ferguson Wellman Capital Management Inc. 
now owns 71,362 shares of the company's stock worth $6,170,000 after buying an additional 1,389 shares during 
the period. Finally, BB...ecurities raised its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc by 1.6% in the fourth quarter. 
BB...ecurities now owns 11,630 shares of the company's stock worth $1,005,000 after buying an additional 185 
shares during the period.  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) traded up 0.12% on Monday, reaching 
$83.10. The company had a trading volume of 66,639 shares. The company has a 50-day moving average of 
$81.57 and a 200 day moving average of $80.99. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $63.66 and a one 
year high of $88.24. The stock has a market cap of $21.93 billion and a price-to-earnings ratio of 13.26.  RYAAY 
has been the subject of several research reports. Raymond James upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'market 
perform' rating to an 'outperform' rating in a research report on Tuesday, November 3rd. Zacks Investment

London's stags have outdone themselves
London's stags have outdone themselves
City A.M.
February 29, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 249 words
Byline: EDITH HANCOCK
Body
LONDON'S bachelors really outdid themselves this weekend. While six members of a stag party were kicked offa 
flightfrom Luton forbeing drunk and unruly, a well-heeled bachelor staying in the city managed to blow over £10,000 
on his last night of freedom.
Our spy tells us that a well-heeled stag booked a private room at Angels last weekend for a most unusual bachelor 
party.
Although the mysterious stag invited his best man, the only other guests to the party were 30 female friends and a 
few of their boyfriends for a night of harmless debauchery.
Peter Stringfellow himself conceded it was "one of the best stag nights I've seen in any of my clubs."
The troupe, which could only be described as having "aristocratic" backgrounds, managed to spend well over 
£10,000 on the stag's big night out, but a group of British bachelors may be spending their own behind bars, and 
ending up even more out of pocket, after being arrested by German police for drunken loutishness. Six men who 
were detained on a Ryanair flight to Bratislava on Friday evening for becoming rowdy and aggressive with security 
on board are now facing fines of up to (EURO)25,000 (£20,000) each. Police officers at Berlin's Schoenefeld airport 
charged the men with misdemeanours under the German aviation security laws after pilots on the flight were forced 
to make an unscheduled landing so the stags could be detained. The bridegroom was among those detained, 
according to police reports.
We know where we would've rather been.
London's stags have outdone themselves
Graphic
 
Two London stag parties racked up impressive bills this weekend

In camp is a broad church, says former M&S chief Interview: Lord Rose
In camp is a broad church, says former M&S chief; Interview: Lord Rose
Financial Times (London, England)
February 29, 2016 Monday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 888 words
Byline: Sarah Gordon, Business editor
Highlight: Head of Britain Stronger in Europe denies campaign is weighted towards London
Body
Stuart Rose used to tempt journalists with goodies from Marks and Spencer, but these days all he has are biros 
inscribed with "Britain Stronger in Europe".
Five years since he stepped down from the British food and clothing retailer, Lord Rose now occupies a sixth-floor 
office at Bridgepoint, the private equity firm which he advises, and has a portfolio of board positions, including the 
chair of Ocado, the online super-market.
Dressed in a - clearly - far more expensive suit than the trademark M&S number he used to sport on results day, he 
is also heading the campaign for Britain to remain in Europe , with its unfortunate BSE acronym.
The aura of plush capitalism surrounding him has given ammunition to Eurosceptics who claim that the London 
establishment has lined up in favour of the status quo, to the detriment of "ordinary people".
Lord Rose rebutted the criticism. "This [campaign] is not Londoncentric, this is something that everybody is 
engaged in," he said.
Although several senior businessmen, including British inventor James Dyson, Anthony Bamford of JCB, and 
Helena Morrissey of Newton Investments, have spoken out in favour of leaving the EU, the two main Out campaign 
groups lack a figure of the stature of Lord Rose.
In camp is a broad church, says former M&S chief Interview: Lord Rose
In the past two weeks, not a day has gone by without more businessmen signing up for the In campaign.
Last week, these included Richard Branson, Michael O'Leary of Ryanair and Carlos Ghosn, head of Nissan. On 
Tuesday, 198 business people, including the bosses of 36 FTSE 100 companies, signed a letter to The Times in 
support of remaining in the EU.
Lord Rose said the number of business people contacting him to ask for information on Brexit, "in order to reach a 
position", has gone up "exponentially" in recent weeks as BSE looks to hit the £7m of funding that the Electoral 
Commission permits.
"We have had contributions from big business, from financial services businesses, from medium-sized businesses 
and from, dare I put it this way, the man in the street," he said. "As Tesco would say, without being too trite, every 
little helps."
He refrained from attacking the disorder of the two Out campaigns , locked in internecine warfare as they jostle to 
be anointed as the official group.
"I've noted the sort of disarray that the other side seems to be in. Frankly, I'd rather that they got themselves 
organised and we did have a proper opportunity to engage with the people who are putting the counterargument. 
"We need to have a campaign which is represented by strong teams on both sides."
He must be relieved, though, that the campaign has finally moved from the "phoney war" of the past few months - 
when "we were busy under the water, paddling like mad" - to a clear date for a referendum .
One senses that he must be glad the date is sooner rather than later, and that the campaign can finally "move up a 
gear" since, for him, this will mean an end is in sight.
There is no doubt that Lord Rose is very committed to Europe, in part because of his personal background - a 
globally peripatetic childhood, a Russian father and a mother who was part-English, part-Scottish and part-Greek.
He says he feels British "first and foremost", but that he has "never not felt European".
But he has his finger in many pies, and it is easy to sense his impatience to return to his normal globe-trotting 
business role, out of the public spotlight.
"I expected that when I took on the job [as BSE chair], that it [would] become more time-hungry as time goes on. I'll 
do what I can do, but I am mindful that my first priority is I've got other commercial responsibilities," he says. "I'm a 
businessman. I'm not a politician. I'm not remotely a politician."
Media concerns
Bosses reluctant to speak up for fear of backlash
Some business leaders are refusing to come out publicly against Brexit because they fear being lambasted in the 
British newspapers, corporate figures have claimed.
"One of the reasons business leaders fear speaking out [on Brexit] is because of how they are treated in the press," 
said the chief executive of one major multinational firm.
The businessman, who refused to give his name, said many business people did not want to be derided or mocked 
by Eurosceptic rightwing newspapers.
Lord Rose, who chairs Britain Stronger in Europe, the In campaign, said that business leaders had become more 
cautious during the "tumult" of the last decade given the financial crash and recession.
"I think there has been, to an extent, a little bit of demonisation of business," the peer said.
In camp is a broad church, says former M&S chief Interview: Lord Rose
"People are probably a little bit more thoughtful about speaking up than they used to be."
Opinion polls suggest that trust in executives has fallen since the credit crunch. Ipsos Mori recently found that 
business leaders were trusted by only 35 per cent of those surveyed, coming 20th out of 24 professions.
Last week Downing Street displayed a letter from business chiefs supporting the In campaign, with only 36 
signatures from FTSE bosses, down from 80 who had been expected to sign.
David Cameron, asked why so many had not signed, admitted that companies were often reluctant to "make any 
form of political statement".
John Redwood, the former Tory cabinet minister, recently vowed that companies that spoke up for EU membership 
would pay a "very dear economic and financial price."  Jim Pickard and Sarah Gordon
Load-Date: February 28, 2016
End of Document

(RYAAY)

Feb 28, 2016( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Janus Capital Management

recent disclosure with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The firm owned 1,160,801 shares of the 
company's stock after selling 67,106 shares during the period. Janus Capital Management owned 0.44% of Ryanair 
Holdings plc worth $93,221,000 at the end of the most recent quarter. 
 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) opened at 83.00 on Friday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 
week low of $63.66 and a 52 week high of $88.24. The firm's 50-day moving average price is $81.57 and its 200

Wednesday, February 10th. Zacks Investment Research[3] upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'hold' rating to a

has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and an average target price of $87.00. Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]) 
is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline 
serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco.

Ask Emma
Ask Emma
Sunday Business Post
February 28, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 630 words
Byline: Emma Kennedy
Highlight: What should I do with my lump sum?
Body
What should I do with my lump sum?
Question: I have a sum of around (EURO)25,000 to invest. What would be a good investment for three to 
five years? I am unable to decide between a managed fund and shares in two or three of the bigger 
companies, such as Kerry, Ryanair and so on. They seem to have been doing well over the past year or so, 
but I have no way of knowing what the future may hold for them. What would you suggest?
Patrick, Galway 
Answer: Patrick, thank you for your letter. 
First off, I'd suggest that you take care investing in individual shares, as that is quite a risky play. You don't mention 
in your letter what other investments you have, so perhaps you'd see those shares as forming part of an overall 
balanced investment portfolio. However, if individual shares would be your only investment, proceed with caution. 
Key to figuring out where to put your money is deciding what your investment objectives are and how much risk you 
are willing to take on. 
You mentioned that you want to invest for a three to five-year time horizon. Do you need the money for a specific 
purpose at the end of the five-year period, or would you be prepared to invest for longer? Also do you need access 
to your money over the next five years? Think about the level of liquidity you might need in the coming years. 
According to Jonathan Sheahan, managing director of Compass Private Wealth, individual shares are "far too 
volatile". "It's not something that I'd recommend for someone that's not a seasoned investor," Sheahan said. Once 
again, your approach on this depends on your investment objectives and your attitude to risk. 
Ask Emma
Taking a portfolio approach, whereby you invest in a wide range of asset classes, is one option worth considering. 
This could be done via a fund, as you suggest. In Sheahan's view, anyone with below (EURO)100,000 to invest 
should consider multi-asset funds, which are typically designed with varying risk levels on offer. Investing in this 
way, he said, allows investors with smaller sums to invest to "benefit from economies of scale". 
"Those sort of lifestyle funds are based on levels of risk. You could, for example, go for a 'middle of the road' fund 
risk-wise, and switch if your appetite for risk changed." 
Bear in mind that you will face fees if you invest in a fund. "You can generally expect an annual management fee of 
1 to 1.5 per cent," Sheahan said. 
He said that the fee structure will "depend on what you want", with greater liquidity, for example, coming with higher 
fees. "Someone, say, who is prepared to lock in their money for longer might possibly benefit from a lower 
management fee," he said. 
The consumer website of the Competition and Consumer Protection Commission (CCPC), ConsumerHelp.ie, 
provides advice on various investment options, with information on the fees you might face. 
It recommends carefully examining the fees and charges before investing in a fund. "They can significantly reduce 
the value of your investment, especially the charges that are ongoing and are based on a percentage of your 
investment," it warned. "These have a bigger impact because the charge itself gets bigger the more your 
investment grows." 
Also bear in mind that higher fees do not correlate with better performance. "Different investment products may 
have higher charges, but this is no reflection on how well they will perform," the CCPC website warns. 
Patrick, good luck with your investment decisions. I hope this advice helps as a starting point. Before making any 
big decisions, I'd suggest getting some more detailed advice. Perhaps talk to an independent financial adviser who 
can discuss your investment choices in the context of your broader personal financial circumstances. 
Email your financial questions to yourmoney@sbpost.ie 
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document
Aer Lingus owner IAG sees 40% profit growth this year Aer Lingus owne...
Aer Lingus owner IAG sees 40% profit growth this year; Aer Lingus owne...
Business World (Digest)
February 26, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 364 words
Highlight: Aer Lingus-owner IAG forecast a more than 900 million euros or 40%profit rise this year as Chief 
Executive Willie Walsh said he planned to steer the group towards further growth.
Body
Aer Lingus-owner IAG forecast a more than 900 million euros or 40%profit rise this year as Chief Executive Willie 
Walsh said he planned to steer the group towards further growth.
IAG, whose portfolio also includes British Airways andVueling , will this year benefit from lower fuel prices, a long-
term strategy of reducing costs and growing demand for travel.
But the company faces uncertainty in the shape of volatile currencies, Britain's June vote on leaving the EU, and 
pressure on ticket prices from increased competition in Europe and on transatlantic routes.
Walsh said IAG was well positioned to grow in spite of those headwinds. "Clearly it will a challenging environment 
but the good news is that we're very confident in terms of our performance," he told reporters on Friday. The 54-
year-old, who once said he would retire at 55, is also planning to stick around to oversee that growth for at least 18 
months. "I'll still be 55 until October of 2017, until my 56th birthday, so there's still time for me," he told BBC radio. 
The forecast of 40% growth in the current year represents a slower pace than the 65 percent jump in operating 
profit it reported for 2015. That guidance puts it on course to post a result of 3.2 billion euros, slightly behind the 3.4 
billion euro consensus forecast according to Reuters data. IAG stock initially spiked to its highest in more than a 
month in reaction to the results, before trading down 2.9% at 543 pence by 1025 GMT. Like many European 
airlines, IAG will this year be helped by an oil price which has almost halved over the past 12 months, as long-term 
fuel hedges fall away allowing more of the benefits to be felt. The challenge for IAG is to retain the benefits of 
cheaper fuel amid pressure on ticket prices from operators such as budget airline Ryanair. Recent falls in the pound 
on uncertainty about the outcome of a referendum on Britain's EU membership are also a risk to IAG because its 
major expenditure is on fuel, priced in dollars. As for the vote itself, Walsh said that outcome would not affect IAG. 
"We don't believe it would have a material impact on our business," he told the BBC. (Reuters) Source: 
www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair Hates Brexit Plan
Ryanair Hates Brexit Plan
RTT News (United States)
February 25, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 202 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Budget airline Ryanair's (RYA.L, RYAAY) CEO Michael O'Leary is advocating for Britain to stay in the 
European Union.
O'Leary has warned that the Irish Airline will cut investment in Britain and might increase flight prices if Britain 
leaves the EU bloc.
Prime Minister David Cameron has set June 23 as the date of the referendum to determine if Britain remains a 
member of the European Union.
However, if "Brexit-- Britain's exit from the EU-- happens then Ryanair will invest more in European countries such 
as Poland and the Czech Republic, O'Leary said.
Ryanair Cheif said the carrier will actively campaign for Britain to stay in the EU by running newspaper ads that 
promote EU membership and also posting pro-EU slogans on Ryanair planes.
"We'll be getting involved in the debate and trying to influence people to vote in favor of Europe because the UK 
economy and UK jobs are better off in Europe," O'Leary said.
More than 35 million passengers per year use Ryanair flights to travel between the U.K. and Europe. Ryanair 
expects 20 percent of its passengers to depart from London airports this year.

Ryanair joins airlines urging public to vote to stay in EU Industry campaigners
Ryanair joins airlines urging public to vote to stay in EU; Industry 
campaigners
Financial Times (London, England)
February 25, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 283 words
Byline: Tanya Powley, Transport Correspondent
Body
Michael O'Leary , chief executive of Ryanair, has urged the British public to vote to stay in the EU , warning that an 
exit would create huge economic uncertainty.
The outspoken boss of the Irish low-cost airline said he would "bore everyone to death" by campaigning over the 
next few months. Ryanair is also planning adverts detailing the benefit for UK travellers of staying in the EU.
Mr O'Leary said the EU's policy on deregulation and competition had driven down the cost of air travel over the past 
30 years and that the public had more to fear from UK bureaucracy than European regulation.
"The campaigners who believe that Brussels bureaucrats are terrible and British bureaucrats are some of the most 
fantastic forward-thinking gurus . . . they can't make a decision on a runway to save their lives . . . and the only 
impact they've had on air travel over the past 10 years since Gordon Brown is to raise taxes on aircraft," he said.
Mr O'Leary said any future rise in air fares was likely to result from UK government policies such as air passenger 
duty. "What will really drive air fares up over the next five years is APD. If the UK economy is stalling post a Brexit, I 
think APD is one of the things [the UK government] will raise."
Ryanair joins airlines urging public to vote to stay in EU Industry campaigners
Ryanair is not the first airline to warn on the impact of leaving the EU. Carolyn McCall, chief executive of easyJet, is 
campaigning against Brexit, while the chief executives of Heathrow , Gatwick and Stansted were among the 
business leaders that signed a letter on Tuesday backing David Cameron's reform deal.
Mr O'Leary's comments were made as Ryanair disclosed plans to expand its London traffic by 10 per cent, taking 
the number of its customers to 23.6m.

Ryanair calls for 'Yes' in Brexit referendum Ryanair calls f...
Ryanair calls for 'Yes' in Brexit referendum; Ryanair calls f...
Business World (Digest)
February 24, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 215 words
Highlight: Ryanair have today called for a 'Yes' vote in the European referendum on 23 June.The airline have 
claimed that some of the benefits of low fare air travel for British consumers have been eroded by Government 
regulation including UK APD travel tax and the
Body
Ryanair have today called for a 'Yes' vote in the European referendum on 23 June.The airline have claimed that 
some of the benefits of low fare air travel for British consumers have been eroded by Government regulation 
including UK APD travel tax and the EU's failure to deliver its single sky project.
Ryanair say they are critical of both UK and EU Government for failing to promote low fare tourism growth in areas 
such as the UK travel tax, however, they remain a committed supporter of the UK remaining in Europe.
Ryanair believe that EU membership means more UK jobs and better economic growth. They also believe that 
foreign inward investment in the UK will be lost to Ireland and Germany if the UK leaves Europe.
Ryanair's Michael O'Leary today commented, "As the UK's largest airline, Ryanair is absolutely clear that the UK 
economy and its future growth prospects are stronger as a member of the European Union than they are outside of 
the EU. "Leaving Europe won't save the UK money or red tape because like Norway the UK will still have to 
contribute to Europe, and obey its rules if it wants to continue to trade freely with Europe, so it's clear that UK voters 
should vote Yes to Europe and Yes to the reformed Europe, that David Cameron has delivered." Source: 
www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair launches Manchester winter 2016 schedule
Ryanair launches Manchester winter 2016 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
February 24, 2016 Wednesday 6:12 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 398 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has launched its Manchester winter 2016 schedule with three new routes to Berlin, 
Hamburg and Nuremberg, eight new winter services to Bratislava, Carcassonne, Limoges, Malta, Murcia, Palma, 
Paris and Valencia, and more flights on 10 existing routes, which will deliver 4.1 million customers per annum and 
support 3,100 jobs.
Body
Ryanair will continue to connect Manchester with Europe's major centres of business through high frequency 
services, including Berlin (daily), Brussels (2 daily), Dublin (6 daily) and Madrid (daily), with more flights, better 
timings and the lowest fares, making Ryanair the ideal choice for business and leisure customers. UK consumers 
and visitors can choose from 34 Manchester routes in winter 2016 and can look forward to further improvements, as 
Ryanair continues its "Always Getting Better" programme, which includes more new routes, a new app, new cabin 
interiors and new crew uniforms. Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer Kenny Jacobs said: "We are pleased to launch 
our Manchester winter 2016 schedule, which includes 3 new routes to Berlin, Hamburg and Nuremberg, and 8 new 
winter routes to Bratislava, Carcassonne, Limoges, Malta, Murcia, Palma, Paris and Valencia, as well as extra 
flights on 10 other Manchester routes, which will deliver 4.1 million annual customers and support 3,100 jobs at 
Manchester Airport. 
Our 106m customers can look forward to further improvements, as we continue our "Always Getting Better" 
programme, which includes more new routes, a new app, new cabin interiors and new crew uniforms. "To celebrate 
the launch of our Manchester winter 2016 schedule, we are releasing 100,000 seats for sale across our European 
network from just GBP19.99, which are available for booking until Monday (22 Feb). Since these amazing low 
prices will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto ryanair.com and avoid missing out." Ken O'Toole, 
Managing Director at Manchester Airport said: "We are pleased to see one of our largest carriers add new routes 
and increase frequency at Manchester Airport. The introduction of flights to Nuremberg, where Ryanair will be the 
only carrier on the route, has been widely welcomed by key corporates in the North West and will see further growth 
in business and inbound tourism from a key strategic European market. "The additional choice, accessibility and 
availability from winter 2016 will be well received by the 22m people in our catchment area, which spans as far 
north as Scotland and as south to the West Midlands. Furthermore it is pleasing to see the additional jobs created 
Ryanair launches Manchester winter 2016 schedule
by Ryanair's growth and further illustrates the positive impact of a growing Manchester Airport in supporting 
economic growth for the region."

Business leaders warn Brexit would 'deter investment, threaten jobs'
Business leaders warn Brexit would 'deter investment, threaten jobs'
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
February 23, 2016 Tuesday 12:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 289 words
Body
       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - A group of more than 100 leaders of major businesses on Tuesday backed Prime 
Minister David Cameron's campaign for Britain to remain in the European Union, saying a British exit, or Brexit, 
would 'deter investment and threaten jobs.'  'Business needs unrestricted access to the European market of 500 
million people in order to continue to grow, invest and create jobs,' the business leaders said in a letter published in 
the Times. 
 'We believe that leaving the EU would deter investment, threaten jobs and put the economy at risk,' the letter read.  
The nearly 200 signatories included top executives from 36 companies listed on London's FTSE 100 index.  Among 
the companies represented are Airbus UK, British Telecom, BP, Diageo, EasyJet, Goldman Sachs International, 
GSK, HSBC, Rio Tinto, Rolls Royce, Royal Dutch Shell, Ryanair, SABMiller, Siemens Manufacturing, Standard 
Chartered, Virgin Media and Vodafone.  'The businesses we lead represent every sector and region of the UK,' they 
wrote. 'Together we employ hundreds of thousands of people across the country.'  Cameron's deal with the 27 
other EU leaders last week means 'Britain is better off staying in a reformed European Union,' they added, 
highlighting agreements to reduce bureaucracy, deepen the single market and pursue international trade deals.  
The Confederation of British Industry, which represents some 190,000 businesses, has also backed Cameron, 
praising the EU reform package as 'a major step forward.'  Britain will conduct a referendum on June 23 on whether 
or not to remain part of the EU.  Eurosceptics inside Cameron's ruling Conservative party have provided the 
strongest support for the 'leave' campaign.   Copyright dpa

Invested: Crisis or the curse of total recall?
Invested: Crisis or the curse of total recall?
Sunday Business Post
February 21, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1854 words
Byline: Ian Guider
Highlight: Memories of 2008 and a rough start to the new year are making investors wary, but there is value out 
there for those prepared to take a risk,  writes Ian Guider
Body
What's going on? The question on the mind of every investor since the beginning of the year. 
We have witnessed the worst start to a year for global markets since the Great Depression in the US in the 1930s. 
Such has been the battering stock markets have taken, that we are now in bear market territory, having reached all-
time highs just last May. The capitulation has seen government bond yields fall to record lows as investors shove 
their money into safer assets. Credit default swaps, which investors buy to protect themselves, have soared, as has 
the price of gold.  
It has been brutal and punishing, with the casualties mounting up.  
The price of oil seemingly doesn't know where it will settle, its plunge below $30 a barrel has caused chaos, not just 
for the major oil companies which are seeing their profits wiped out, but for countries whose revenues are 
inextricably linked with its fortunes.  
In China, the communist government has been so spooked by slumping stock markets in Shanghai and Shenzhen 
and the slowest rate of growth in its economy for two decades that it has been forced into extraordinary actions to 
prevent the situation getting worse. 
Across Europe, fears are mounting that banks, still sitting on toxic loans from the 2008 crash, may face difficulty 
repaying bondholders. Their shares are not just back to levels seen then, but to prices last recorded in the 1990s. 
Even in America, with its jobless rate falling to under 5 per cent in recent months, everyone is nervous. Shouldn't 
workers' earnings be rising faster with such a low unemployment rate? Why are company earnings so anaemic? 
Was the Federal Reserve's decision in December to raise interest rates for the first time in nine years the worst 
possible timing? 
Invested: Crisis or the curse of total recall?
Closer to home, the turmoil has begun to bite. The Irish stock exchange, one of the best-performing in the last few 
years, has gotten off to a rough start. The banks have taken a big hit as have household names including Paddy 
Power, Ryanair and CRH. The declines on the Iseq are double those experienced by London's benchmark Ftse100. 
This sell-off has been a long time coming. Since 2009, fuelled by the unprecedented money printing, or quantitative 
easing, by central banks, markets have been on a run that saw most American, European and Asian indices reach 
all-time highs even as the global economy has struggled to achieve any type of meaningful recovery.  
The money unleashed has chased returns. It has gone into equities, emerging markets, commodities, private equity 
and everything else to make up for low sovereign bond yields. It may also have created the monster markets now 
face. 
"There are fires going off in every market around the world. It is an extension of what happened in 2007 and 2008. 
For me it's not a separate crisis, it is the same crisis re-evolving in a different manner," said Paul Sommerville, 
founder of Sommerville Advisory Markets. "People are saying this is a China slowdown story or an oil story. For me 
they are just some of the effects. There is way more to this than a simple sell off." 
Nick Bullman is founder and chairman of CheckRisk, a company that advises pension and investment funds around 
the world. He believes that events are now beginning to spill over into the real economy. 
"The sentiment has just been appalling and is probably worse than the fundamentals. But that being said, all the 
major markets have broken through the September lows and from a technical perspective, that is very bad news. 
The slowdown in China got people going. And that moved on to the weakness in the oil price that rather than being 
something that would stimulate the economy, it's a signal that demand is very weak. The feedback loop from weak 
oil is that a lot of European banks have effectively taken all of the money from quantitative easing and put it into 
emerging markets, commodities and oil companies," he said. 
The volatility itself is causing investors concerns. The gyrations up and down daily are getting worse and it is 
flummoxing even the savviest of experts. Mohamed El-Erian, one of the best known financial commentators and 
chief economic adviser to Allianz, took to Twitter to express his views. "While a relief, Dow's 200 plus point surge in 
less than ten minutes is adding to the general sense of confusion and in security in markets," he tweeted, in the 
wake of one particularly turbulent trading day in February. 
What has also exacerbated the concerns was the view that heading into this period, many stocks were trading at 
very high earnings multiples. As corporate earnings disappointed in the last couple of quarters and with investors 
bidding up some big-name tech stocks, it is worsening the scale of the declines. LinkedIn, for example, lost a third 
of its value in a day when its earnings came in below estimates. 
According to some commentators, what we are experiencing right now is directly the result of the very medicine that 
was given out to resolve the 2008 crisis. 
"People will blame speculators and traders. It is not. It is absolutely central bank policy that has caused a huge 
bubble in all asset prices and they are readjusting," said Sommerville. "My view is that the markets have been in an 
induced coma triggered by the central banks and they are waking up to the negative consequences of quantitative 
easing and central banks' failure to manage monetary policy. And the engine of all this is the US economy is just 
not performing the way markets were told it was performing. They have created their own bubble and that has to 
deflate to get back to normal market." 
John Mattimoe, head of equity analysis at Dublin-based fund managers Appian Asset Management, believes that 
so far the economic data we've seen, at least out of the US, has not been as bad as some fear.  
"In the last set of jobs data, not only had you the reduction in unemployment, but the first acceleration in terms of 
wage growth and in terms of number of hours worked. That is encouraging," said Mattimoe. 
Invested: Crisis or the curse of total recall?
Even in Europe, where the influence of the debt crisis is still lingering, there are chinks of light. Last year, the 
eurozone economy expanded by 1.5 per cent, although Greece remains in recession. Germany grew by a little 
stronger than the average at 1.7 per cent, but that disappointed. What analysts can't tell yet is how quickly all of that 
will change as a result of what is happening in markets.  
And what should investors do? The turmoil has frayed nerves. It is a brave person who decides to make a call on 
whether we've hit bottom.  
"We have reduced our equity recommendation from overweight to underweight for the next three to six months. 
People should be neutral or risk-off and if there is a rally they should be selling into it," said Bullman. 
Mattimoe saidAppian had been steadily reducing its allocation to equities for the last two years because it felt 
company valuations were getting too high. It had cut its equity holdings to about 35 per cent, he said.  
Still, for those who are prepared to dip their toe back into stock markets, there may be a chance to pick up 
companies with more realistic valuations. 
"In terms of people who are longer-term focused and want exposure to real assets, what is becoming more 
apparent now is that with equity markets off by a mid-teen rate you are seeing pockets of value. It is a sensible 
strategy to stagger in, rather than going in in one swoop," he said. 
How do markets prevent the calamities of 2008 repeating themselves and just who can step in to end the crisis? 
Ironically, the world is turning back to central banks for action once again.  
Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairman, told US lawmakers in February that it was closely monitoring 
conditions in financial markets and would respond if there were signs of doing damage.  
The Fed had set a course of hiking interest rates as many as four times this year. That is now highly unlikely and 
Yellen admitted that reversing course to move to negative interest rates was a possibility, albeit a remote one at this 
stage.  
The European Central Bank is set to expand its programme of asset purchases in order to get banks lending again. 
Its president Mario Draghi has spent a year printing (EURO)60 billion a month and has promised whatever it takes 
to kickstart Europe's ailing economy.  
Nick Bullman, though, doesn't see an easy way out of the quagmire. 
"There has been $62 trillion of new money created since 2008 and the only way you escape the weight of that is to 
have global [gross domestic product] growing at 3.5 per cent or inflation picking up and we've seen no sign of that," 
said Bullman. 
But there are those whose faith in policymakers and the action they have taken since 2008 is unshaken and leads 
them to believe there are tools still available to halt another recession.  
"Time and time again, policymakers have shown themselves to be bolder and more inventive than asset markets 
give them credit for," Steven Englander, a strategist at Citigroup, said in a research report to clients.  
Among the things that could be put on the table are tax cuts, with central banks using their firepower to buy 
government bonds to pay for them, he wrote. 
However, Paul Sommerville said: "Many people are expecting the Fed to reverse course. I don't think they will be 
able to do that. I think it would be a worse signal to the market." 
Mattimoe believes missteps from the main global central banks are the biggest risk to some sort of stability.  
Invested: Crisis or the curse of total recall?
"It is down to Draghi continuing to convince people he is prepared to do whatever it takes to keep the eurozone on 
a direction to a gradual recovery. In the US, it is the balancing act so that if the threats are high, the Fed won't move 
too prematurely, and if you are seeing growing domestic inflation pressure, the Fed won't wait too long [to raise 
interest rates]. There is a real worry if you get currency weakness out of China, whether devaluation or letting [their 
currency] peg go, that could have implications for devaluation across the global economy. 
"In terms of possible upside, you have got to take some recognition that we are in a zero [interest] rate world and 
that there is no return available on risk-free assets. So that provides liquidity for real assets when value does 
emerge.  
"The second issue is the US consumer because the employment picture is beginning to get the firepower to make a 
material contribution to growth."  
So has the negativity and fear been overdone?  
For all the gloom, the actual economic data has been benign. The US is pretty much close to full employment, 
Europe for all its woes is growing. For canny investors prepared to take a risk, there is value out there.  
However, the painful memories of 2008 and all that followed are etched into the minds of many. That we are only a 
few years out from the great recession makes what is happening, the swiftness at which events are occurring, very 
familiar.  
Are we doomed by the response that policymakers set in train with their unprecedented quantitative easing and the 
addiction of markets to the cheap money? Nobody knows. And that is making it all the worse. 
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document

Air France - KLM plans more cost cuts despite first annual profit in 5 years
Air France-KLM plans more cost cuts despite first annual profit in 5 years
Financial Times (London, England)
February 19, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FRONT PAGE - COMPANIES & MARKETS; Pg. 13
Length: 342 words
Byline: Tanya Powley in London
Body
Lower fuel bills and continued cost-cutting helped Air France-KLM to its first annual net profit for five years, sending 
its shares up 10.6 per cent.
The Franco-Dutch airline, which is 16 per cent owned by the French government, reported a net profit of EUR118m 
for 2015, against a loss of EUR225m the previous year.
The return to the black comes as it continues to battle trade unions as well as increased competition from 
aggressive Middle Eastern and budget rivals.
Air France-KLM has been fighting to reduce costs, which are high compared with low-cost carriers such as easyJet, 
which operate on short-haul routes, and fast-growing Gulf airlines such as Emirates. It has struggled to implement 
its full cost-cutting programme, demonstrated most publicly by a violent confrontation with executives at an 
employee meeting last year. The group has already announced a reduction of 1,000 jobs for this year.
Alexandre de Juniac , chief executive, insisted that the airline needed to push through further cost cuts. "Yes we 
have seen improvements and we are now in the black. But our competitors have also shown an improvement and 
there is still a gap," he said. "We have to be at the same level of our competitors . . . so to do that, we have to lower 
our costs."
Air France - KLM plans more cost cuts despite first annual profit in 5 years
Analysts pointed to the airline's weak profitability, with operating margins of 3.1 per cent compared with Ryanair's 
18 per cent. Gerald Khoo, analyst at Liberum, said: "2015 represented progress against a very weak benchmark."
The company gave no profit forecast for 2016 but warned that fuel savings would be offset significantly by negative 
currency effects and pressure on unit revenues as rivals added capacity.
Net profit fell in the fourth quarter to EUR276m from EUR308m the previous year, with revenues down by an 
estimated EUR120m because of the terrorist attacks in Paris in November.
Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation for the full year were EUR2.5bn, up from EUR1.6bn a 
year ago. Revenues rose 4.6 per cent to EUR26bn on the back of higher passenger numbers.

Ryanair to sponsor Cheltenham World Hurdle Ryanair to spon...
Ryanair to sponsor Cheltenham World Hurdle; Ryanair to spon...
Business World (Digest)
February 18, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 137 words
Highlight: It was announced today that Ryanair will sponsor the World Hurdle at the 2016 Cheltenham Festival on 
Thursday, 17th March.
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair will sponsor the World Hurdle at the 2016 Cheltenham Festival on Thursday, 
17th March.
The Stg300,000 Ryanair World Hurdle, a three-mile championship race, is the second Grade 1 race to be 
sponsored by Ryanair in addition to the Ryanair Chase, which also takes place on St Patrick's Thursday,
Ryanair CEO, Michael O'Leary today commented, "We are very happy to add this sponsorship of the Ryanair World 
Hurdle alongside the Grade 1 Ryanair Chase and remain wholly supportive of the Jockey Club's stance with regard 
to authorised betting partners which has led to this race becoming available for sponsorship this year."
He added, "All we need now is for a Ryanair horse to win one of these races, something we haven't managed to do 
in 10 years of sponsorship." Source: www.businessworld.ie

company's stock after selling 1,661 shares during the period. Diversified Trust Co's holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc 
were worth $1,162,000 at the end of the most recent quarter.

Is the airline bull-run taking off or losing altitude?
Is the airline bull-run taking off or losing altitude?
Citywire
February 16, 2016 Tuesday 12:01 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 745 words
Body
Over the last 18 months, airlines have been a major beneficiary of the falling oil price. A slump in jet fuel has 
expanded margins to unprecedented levels, but these could be in danger as ticket prices look set to move lower. Is 
the airline bull run coming to an end?
It's hard to make money in airlines or it used to be. In the 100-odd years the industry has existed, it has been a 
'death trap' for investors, according to Warren Buffett. Yet things have been different for several years and the 
sector has made backers a significant return.
Ryanair shares are up sixfold since 2008 lows, EasyJet fivefold, and British Airways owner International 
Consolidated Airlines Group has more than doubled since late 2011.
Historically, it was hard to make money as the sector has a high cost base, making the marginal gain on each 
additional passenger very small. If an airline cannot fill most seats it is easy to make a loss.
It is these high fixed costs that make margins so thin. According to the International Air Transport Association 
(IATA), the industry net profit margin in 2014 was just 2.3%, an improvement on 2013's 1.5%.
Margins are forecast to rise in 2015 to 4.6% and 5.1% in 2016, boosted by oil. IATA has used an average price of 
$55 a barrel for 2015 and $58.6 a barrel in 2016: should it stay at current levels (and assuming airlines haven't 
overcautiously hedged), it is possible margins could be even higher.
However, ticket prices are also expected to fall and this is a real threat to margins. Ryanair said recently that prices 
between January and March were expected to fall an average of 6%, ahead of its previous expectations of 4%.
With margins being so thin, they could evaporate completely. 'We expect the lower fare environment to continue for 
the foreseeable future, with some respite during the summer months,' said Ryanair chief executive, Michael 
O'Leary.
There has been a lot of investment in aircraft and extra capacity is expected to exceed growth in passengers. 
Increased competition could threaten yields, with price cuts and rising labour overheads paring the positive of lower 
fuel.
So what is the outlook for the main UK-listed airlines?
Is the airline bull-run taking off or losing altitude?
International Consolidated Airlines Group (-14% over the year to date)
The owner of British Airways, Iberia, Aer Lingus and Vueling has seen its shares fall the furthest this year because 
it is very exposed to transatlantic routes, which tend to be hit hard in a slowdown.
This is particularly significant as British Airways is expanding transatlantic capacity in the mid-single digits. If there 
is a slowdown and a resultant slide in demand, ticket prices are likely to come under pressure.
The company is also planning to rapidly expand its low-cost carrier Vueling, which could trigger significant 
competitive pressure from rivals easyJet and Ryanair.
Positively, management have turned around Iberia. There is scope for material upside in margins at the carrier and 
potential synergies from the integration of Aer Lingus.
EasyJet (-9%)
EasyJet has employed a successful strategy of targeting market share gains from legacies at major airports. 
However, as capacity is rising, yields could come under pressure from price cuts.
Here, easyJet is at a disadvantage to main competitor Ryanair, as the fees of its primary airports tend to be higher. 
The company's strategy of winning over business customers from struggling full-service rivals has worked well.
This has been helped by the launch of allocated seating and by pushing into major airports that business customers 
tend to favour. EasyJet's management has been very shrewd at selecting routes and managing capacity, and 
added lucrative Alpine ski destinations.
Ryanair (-4%)
Ryanair has benefited from being nicer to its customers, evidenced in its recent profit upgrades, the latest in 
September. The European short-haul market remains buoyant and the company has the dominant share at 15%. It 
has a very efficient operational structure and low costs, helping it benefit from structural changes in a market where 
larger carriers are reducing short haul capacity. Any derailment in the eurozone recovery could hit shares hard.
Of course, the main threat to all three would be a sharp rise in the oil price, which would dampen sector sentiment 
and hit margins. Excluding this, airlines will be able to make the most of heady margins. Any spike in the oil price 
would be a signal to take profits.
Garry White is head of investment commentary at Charles Stanley Direct
Load-Date: February 16, 2016
End of Document
International markets remain nervous but Irish banks sparkle
International markets remain nervous but Irish banks sparkle
Sunday Business Post
February 14, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 631 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: Janet Yellen's testimony to Congress was especially unsettling
Body
Despite the stock market rebound on Friday, international markets remain nervous following Thursday's rout, which 
reinforced the major declines across all of the main market indices since the start of the year. 
Aside from continuing concerns about China - not helped by the lack of transparency and confidence in its official 
figures - Janet Yellen's downbeat testimony to Congress- (including hints of a possible move to negative interest 
rates) was especially unsettling for financial stocks. 
Despite rising employment and real wage growth, it suggested that the Fed chairwoman had underlying concerns 
about the health of the US economy. Negative interest rates undermine bank profitability and this, combined with 
continued weakening in the oil price, has heightened market concerns about the adequacy of bank capital. 
The significant share purchase by JP Morgan chief Jamie Dimon steadied market nerves on Friday. This was 
despite similar director share purchases in their banks back in 2008, having proved subsequently to be a false 
signal of soundness. 
But despite these international trends, Irish bank shares have sparkled since early February. Bank of Ireland and 
AIB shares were up by 20 per cent, performing strongly contrary to international market trends. This is despite the 
uncertainty about the outcome of the general election and its implications for economic stability and the constraints 
on the banks' mortgage lending.  
Clearly, enough investors see value and are confident that the banks can continue to strengthen their earnings with 
the write-back of bad debts and increased personal and SME loan demand from a strongly recovering economy. 
Another notable Irish exception to the substantial knock to global equity markets last Thursday was DCC. It issued 
a trading statement that morning that was significantly more upbeat than the market had been expecting. Due to the 
higher than normal winter temperatures of recent months - which was expected to impact negatively on DCC's 
energy division's performance - the market had been marking down the company's share price since the start of the 
International markets remain nervous but Irish banks sparkle
year. But the trading statement confirmed previous guidance of expected earnings per share growth being 
substantially ahead of the previous year. Continued tight cost control improved margins and progress on integration 
of the company's recently-acquired energy distribution businesses enabled DCC to confirm their previous guidance 
of expected earnings for the year to the end of March to be significantly ahead of the previous year.  
The shares rose by more than 4 per cent on Thursday - one of the few exceptions to the overall market rout in 
London where DCC is listed. However, when the market recovered on Friday, an Irish share which didn't follow the 
recovery was Ryanair, as the market saw the sudden spike in the oil price as a potential headwind for the airline.  
As to the Irish market overall, investors are likely to keep a watchful eye on the outcome of the general election. 
While most of Ireland's largest companies are internationalised and unlikely to be affected by a result which 
suggests that political instability beckons, the impact on the Irish bond market and knock-ons for the banks of such 
an outcome would almost certainly be negative. 
Not all is gloom internationally. Europe's economy is recovering and with continued employment and earnings 
growth in the US, in the absence of deepening problems in China and increased instability in the Middle East, 
growth prospects in the developed world look reasonable. However, investor expectations for returns from equity 
markets for the rest of the year will be tempered by some material macroeconomic and geopolitical risks that 
remain (including Brexit), as well as the unknown unknowns about China. 
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document
Four sporting protests The List
Four sporting protests; The List
Financial Times (London, England)
February 13, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FT WEEKEND SUPPLEMENT - LIFE & ARTS; Pg. 2
Length: 394 words
Byline: Elsa Court
Body
It's been a big week for sporting protests. After Liverpool fans walked out of a match at Anfield in protest at 
proposed ticket-price increases, supporters of German club Borussia Dortmund staged a similar protest. Subverting 
the German expression "great tennis" - meaning something very good - they launched a barrage of tennis balls on 
to the field during a cup game. Here are four other outbreaks of spectator rebellion.
1. On June 4, 1913, Emily Davison, suffragette and former school teacher, threw herself under King George V's 
horse at the Epsom Derby. Davison, who was already known to the police for various acts of public rebellion, died 
of her injuries a few days later and became an emblem of the suffragette movement. Opinion is still divided over 
whether she actually intended to die or was simply trying to attract attention to women's rights by disrupting the 
race.
2. In one of the more unusual on-pitch protests, John Foley handcuffed himself to the goalposts during Everton's 
Premier League match against Manchester City at Goodison Park in January 2012. Believing Ryanair's chief 
executive Michael O'Leary to be in attendance at the game, Foley directed his protest at the "exploitation" of young 
cabin crew trainees by the budget airline. After being cut free by the police, Foley was banned from attending 
games for three years.
3. The 158th University Boat Race was interrupted when Australian activist Trenton Oldfield entered the river 
Thames and swam into the path of the rowers near Hammersmith Bridge. It was the first time in its history the race 
had been disrupted by a bather. The race was restarted half an hour later and ended in a Cambridge victory after 
Four sporting protests The List
Oxford broke an oar. Oldfield, who said he'd embarked on his act of "civil disobedience" as a protest against the 
elitism represented by the race, was sentenced to six months in prison.
4. "Paper bag protests" have been widespread in the United States, particularly among fans of American football. 
The trend - in which supporters wear brown bags over their heads to express embarrassment at their team's 
wavering fortunes - is thought to have started in 1980, when fans of the New Orleans Saints wore bags after the 
team ended the season with just one win and 15 losses, the worst ever result for a team at that time. Fans renamed 
the team the "Aints" for the occasion.
Elsa Court
Load-Date: February 12, 2016
End of Document
Twitter 's decline brings hope of end to corporate gaffes
Twitter's decline brings hope of end to corporate gaffes
Financial Times (London, England)
February 13, 2016 Saturday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: THE TOP LINE; Pg. 9
Length: 552 words
Byline: Brooke Masters, Companies Editor
Body
Some denizens of cyber space are starting to sour on Twitter. The social media site reported this week that the 
number of total active monthly users stalled at 320m in the fourth quarter. When people who only use SMS - and 
don't see adverts - are excluded, usage actually fell for the first time, by 2m to 305m.
However, chief financial officer Anthony Noto said that growth in new users had continued throughout the period, 
and numbers of daily users remained broadly stable. Doing the maths, that means that occasional users - the non-
addicts - must be starting to bail out in droves.
While troubling for Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey, the declining enthusiasm for 140-character messages may 
not be such a bad thing for the rest of us. Gaffes can and do happen anywhere, from internal staff memos to dumb 
Instagram photos, and when they happen online trolls can be counted on to leap on them. But there is something 
about Twitter that seems to bring out the worst in everyone. From the PR executive who tweeted she would not get 
Aids in Africa because "I'm white" to the person who was so "sick of the US government. I'm moving to California", 
Twitter users often type first and think later.
This week, venture capitalist Marc Andreessen became the latest person to get himself into hot water. A Facebook 
board member, he lashed out at Indian regulators for blocking the company's scheme to provide free but limited 
mobile access, calling the move " economically suicidal . . . anti-colonialism". The ensuing Twitter storm turned so 
brutal that Mr Andreessen eventually deleted the comments and apologised. Even so, Facebook founder Mark 
Zuckerberg felt the need to distance himself publicly from his longtime backer. Using a Facebook post, rather than a 
Twitter 's decline brings hope of end to corporate gaffes
tweet, Mr Zuckerberg said he "found the comments deeply upsetting, and they do not represent the way Facebook 
or I think at all".
Corporate Twitter users have repeatedly embarrassed themselves. Some do it while trying to connect with their 
customers. JPMorgan Chase's 2013 #AskJPM question and answer session was supposed to be offering career 
advice for would-be bankers. Instead, it sparked a cascade of bitter complaints about the US bank's various 
financial scandals. British Gas and budget airline Ryanair had similarly disastrous experiences with Twitter 
engagement sessions.
Consumer-facing groups can also get into trouble with inappropriate tweets linked to current events. UK 
supermarket Tesco was roundly ridiculed for tweeting that it was "time to hit the hay" during a scandal about selling 
horsemeat, and US pizza group DiGiorno used a hashtag about domestic violence (#WhyIStayed) to promote its 
products. Finally, there is the human factor. Disgruntled staff took over music retailer HMV's account to announce 
that they were all being fired in a "mass execution", and Twitter's own Mr Noto mistakenly tweeted out confidential 
deal plans.
Part of the problem is that Twitter's format encourages snap comments and rapid responses, so errors get made. 
And when that happens, the public nature of the site and its widespread use by journalists, means that critics can 
and do pounce.
Twitter says user growth rebounded in January, but some reluctant corporate users may well be hoping that this is 
the beginning of the end.
brooke.masters@ft.com 
Load-Date: February 12, 2016
End of Document

Highlight: Ryanair Ltd., a European airline company, has announced three new daily winter services from 
Manchester to Berlin, Hamburg and Nuremberg, beginning at the start of November 2016.
Body

Nuremberg, which will operate daily from the start of November, which are on sale now from www.ryanair.com. "UK 
customers can look forward to further improvements in the coming months, including new aircraft interiors, new

offering from Manchester. I am sure all of the three routes will also prove popular with leisure passengers looking 
for a European city break. We will continue to work to grow our route network and connect the North with key 
business and leisure destinations across the world."

EasyJet founder calls for higher investor payouts Airlines
EasyJet founder calls for higher investor payouts; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
February 10, 2016 Wednesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 20
Length: 504 words
Byline: Tanya Powley, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Sir Stelios presses for dividends to be set at 50% of post-tax profits
Body
Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou , founder of easyJet and its largest shareholder, is stepping up pressure again on the 
budget airline by calling for a further increase in dividends.
Ahead of easyJet's annual meeting tomorrow, Sir Stelios called for the company to increase its dividend payout 
from 40 per cent of post-tax profits to 50 per cent.
He also said easyJet should halt its practice of paying special dividends and instead return any surplus cash 
through share buybacks.
The ratcheting up of pressure comes after two years of relative tranquility between Sir Stelios and easyJet's board - 
until early 2014, he fought the company over dividends, executive pay and fleet expansion.
Sir Stelios said yesterday that easyGroup, his investment vehicle, would use a token 20m shares in easyJet - 
representing about 5 per cent of the company's total stock - to oppose the re-election of John Barton , chairman, so 
as to make the case for an increase in the dividend payout.
"In the last five years, the easyJet board's scattergun approach has meant a haphazard mixture of ordi-nary and 
special dividend payments that has left investors confused and uncertain as to the company's intentions when 
EasyJet founder calls for higher investor payouts Airlines
rewarding shareholders," said Sir Stelios, who established easyJet in 1995 and stepped down from the board in 
2010.
He then launched campaigns for the introduction of dividends and a halt to fleet expansion, arguing the company 
should focus on shareholder returns.
After consulting with its shareholders, easyJet issued a maiden dividend in 2011 that was widely seen as a victory 
for Sir Stelios.
But Sir Stelios lost campaigns against a large aircraft order placed by easyJet in 2013, and a big increase in the pay 
of Carolyn McCall , chief executive, in 2014.
EasyJet has increased dividends from 20 per cent of profits in 2011 to 40 per cent in 2015. Two special dividends 
have also been paid.
If shareholders approve dividends proposed at the annual meeting, they will have received a total of £988m since 
2011. Sir Stelios and his family have a 34 per cent stake in easyJet, and secured about £340m in dividends.
Sir Stelios said buybacks offered a "better way" than special dividends to maximise shareholder value, and noted 
Ryanair's practice of purchasing its stock so as to return cash to investors.
He also highlighted how Ryanair's shares had risen 87 per cent in the past two years, while easyJet's stock had 
fallen by 12 per cent.
This partly reflects how Ryanair's shares dropped after two profit warnings in the autumn of 2013 and then 
recovered after an improved customer service strategy was unveiled.
EasyJet's shares have fallen almost 10 per cent since its first-quarter trading update in January, when it said 
revenue had been squeezed by the terrorist attacks in Egypt and France.
Sir Stelios said he did not want to see Mr Barton removed because he was doing a good job, but warned that 
"directors will need vigilance against a background of a 23 per cent share price deterioration in the last 52 weeks".
EasyJet declined to comment.
Load-Date: February 9, 2016
