Ryanair and BA compete on new Stansted routes Ryanair and BA ...
Ryanair and BA compete on new Stansted routes; Ryanair and BA ...
Business World (Digest)
February 9, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 194 words
Highlight: British Airways said it would begin flying from Stansted Airport, establishing a presence at London's 
No.3 airport for the first time and bringing it into direct competition with budget carrier Ryanair on leisure routes.
Body
British Airways said it would begin flying from Stansted Airport, establishing a presence at London's No.3 airport for 
the first time and bringing it into direct competition with budget carrier Ryanair on leisure routes.
BA, owned by International Airlines Group, said on Tuesday that from May it would fly to Faro in Portugal, as well 
as Ibiza, Malaga and Palma in Spain, from 49 pounds one way.
The full-service operator, which provides complimentary refreshments on flights, will compete directly on those 
routes with no-frills Ryanair, whose cheapest flights in May cost about 25 pounds one way.
BA's move into secondary airport Stansted enters traditional budget carrier territory, a change from a wider trend of 
low cost airlines increasingly flying from a city's main airport and stealing market share from full-service airlines. 
Stansted, 35 miles north of London, will become BA's fourth airport in the region. It already flies from London's 
Heathrow, Gatwick and City airports. BA said the flights would be operated by its BA CityFlyer subsidiary on two-
cabin 98-seat Embraer jets which are usually based at London City. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: February 12, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair modestly puts its current boon down to oil prices
Ryanair modestly puts its current boon down to oil prices
Sunday Business Post
February 7, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1542 words
Byline: Fearghal O'Connor
Highlight: But is the born-again airline simply biding its time before going for low-cost, long-haul king Norwegian?
Body
There is only one word to describe the performance of Ryanair in the two years since since it decided to morph into 
a more understated, more customer-friendly version of its brash self: phenomenal. 
Where once the airline revelled in Michael O'Leary's colourful outbursts, it now relies on simple black-and-white 
numbers to tell the story: (EURO)103 million in profits after tax in its latest quarterly results; 200 airports in 31 
countries, with 78 main bases; 6million app downloads and 350 more 737 aircraft on order from Boeing. 
Most impressively of all, it is translating all of this into passenger growth at a relentless pace. Last year was the first 
year it passed the 100 million passenger mark. The airline says it will carry 106 million passengers in its current 
financial year to the end of March and it has targeted growth to 180 million passengers per annum by 2024. But 
calculations by this newspaper suggest that if Ryanair's monthly growth in 2015 was to be repeated in 2016, it 
would finish 2016 with total passenger numbers of close to 120 million. 
That, of course, presumes Ryanair can continue to place its new aircraft successfully into new bases or existing 
bases with capacity for growth. Ryanair's chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs is, for Ryanair, uncharacteristically 
modest. 
"If you are an airline at the moment who can't make a profit with the price of fuel where it is, then you are doing a 
spectacularly bad job. We are not the geniuses that we might look like. No one expected oil to be at this level," he 
said. 
Jacobs is quick to warn that the fuel price bonanza will not continue for ever, and that a rise in oil prices will change 
the aviation industry dynamic. 
"Probably one or two airlines will go bust when the price of fuel goes up. And the price of fuel will go up. You will 
then see who is swimming with their trunks on or off," he said. 
Ryanair modestly puts its current boon down to oil prices
Such a scenario would, no doubt, present opportunities to cash-rich Ryanair and force it to answer a fundamental 
question: is it happy to continue on its steady path of growth for the next decade or would it risk the complexities of 
a big game-changing acquisition? 
Speculation surfaced in the US last month that Ryanair could buy rival Easyjet. Irish and European analysts spoken 
to by this newspaper poured cold water on the notion. Competition issues alone would rule out such a deal. Neither 
would it give Michael O'Leary anything he does not already have, apart from headaches. 
But much more interesting, agreed a number of industry analysts, would be the prospect of Ryanair, at some point, 
moving to buy low-cost competitor Norwegian. It has had success developing a low-cost model to the US, 
something Ryanair has long contemplated. But if the Scandinavian airline's rapid growth runs out of steam, Ryanair 
could swoop, said analysts. 
A crowded European market
"Any such deal will not be immediate, but could happen in the next three years," said German-based aviation expert 
Heinrich Grossbongardt. "Ryanair is currently very busy changing its business model and relocating its fleet to hub 
airports. That requires financial means and management attention. But once that is complete, acquiring someone 
could be the next step." 
"Norwegian has something that Ryanair lacks that in the long run will be critical: a long-haul product with big growth 
potential. The European market will become more and more crowded with Ryanair, Easyjet, Norwegian, not to 
mention the aggressively growing Wizz Air in eastern and central European markets. It is inevitable that a carrier 
the size of Ryanair will need to get a foot in the long-haul market, and Norwegian has already achieved this." 
If Norwegian hits financial turbulence and is struggling to finance its aggressive growth and fleet plans by itself, that 
could be the moment that Ryanair strikes, said Grossbongardt, who is managing director of Hamburg-based 
Expairtise. 
"It would be a good move by Ryanair and could work well," he said. 
One well-informed Irish aviation analyst said an airline "would want to be on their knees bleeding before Ryanair 
would swoop", but added that Norwegian is without doubt the most interesting asset in the European airline industry 
for Ryanair, given Norwegian's low-cost, long-haul business, as well as Ryanair's relatively scant coverage of 
Scandinavia. 
"The simple thing for O'Leary is to grow the business out to 150 million passengers over the next five years and 
make a lot of money doing that," he said. 
"But my view is that Ryanair should stay close to Norwegian in case it does get into difficulties. In that scenario, 
Ryanair would be perfect to come in and run it as a separate brand." 
Although Norwegian continues to grow strongly, it faces a range of challenges such as financing an enormous 
aircraft order book relative to its size and has had to aggressively drop fares to fill aircraft during a period of rapid 
growth, he said. It also faces regulatory issues in the US that threatens some new routes, including its proposed 
Cork to Boston service. 
"Its last corporate bond issue was done at 10 per cent or above, very expensive given that Ryanair borrows money 
at less than 2 per cent," said the analyst. 
But he said that a key hurdle to any such deal, should the opportunity arise, would come from within Ryanair. 
"The board of Ryanair is very suspicious and sceptical of low-cost long-haul. O'Leary has said he would only do it if 
the planes came at a really cheap price. So such a deal would not be without its challenges even before the EU 
Commission ever took a look at it." 
Ryanair modestly puts its current boon down to oil prices
Indeed, according to Kenny Jacobs, there is no temptation within Ryanair to "dip a toe" into an Atlantic route using 
its narrow-body Boeing 737 fleet aircraft the way others have. Right now, he said, things are working so well for the 
airline that management does not want to get distracted. 
"That would be a distraction and we have too much to go after in Europe. We'll stick to our knitting here, adding new 
bases and working with what we have. We don't need an acquisition to get to the 180 million passenger mark. It 
would push us beyond that. But if the right opportunity came along at the right time, we would look at it. But we 
don't need to to deliver the plan," said Jacobs. 
Sense and sensibility
But Jacobs did confirm that negotiations are progressing with Norwegian about a deal that would see Ryanair feed 
short-haul passengers into the Scandinavian airline's long-haul network. Such an operation could be underway 
before the end of this year and would provide Ryanair a blueprint to sell to other more reticent potential partners, for 
example, IAG's Aer Lingus, said Jacobs. 
"If we are feeding Norwegian on long-haul, then it would be interesting to give that a year and see how the industry 
evolves," he said. 
"We think this is a natural thing that is going to happen in the European industry as low-cost comes to dominate. It 
solves two problems for the high-cost airlines, which history has shown are better concentrating on long-haul. It 
gives them extra demand and also means they are less reliant on going head-to-head with low-cost carriers on 
short-haul routes to feed their hubs," said Jacobs. 
But, in reality, Ryanair is in the comfortable position that it can focus on the day job of filling its ever increasing fleet 
of 737s as they are delivered by Boeing and dispatched to bases throughout Europe. 
Germany is likely to be a key focus of this growth, according to Jacobs. The airline had a relatively modest, by its 
own standards, 5 per cent market share in Europe's biggest market last year, flying eight million customers. By 
2024, that figure could rise to 30 million passengers, with key cities such as Cologne and Hamburg presenting 
particular growth opportunities. 
"If Germany provides a big chunk of our growth, then you also have to look at some of the markets around 
Germany, such as the Netherlands and Austria, where we are relatively small," said Jacobs. 
"Take Scandinavia. We are still very happy to let Norwegian and SAS scrap it out in a price war there so we won't 
add huge amounts of capacity there for now, outside of primary airports. But between now and 2024, Scandinavia 
could account for 15 million extra passengers per annum for us." 
In central and eastern Europe, the airline is also taking the fight to Wizz Air, the latest low-cost pretender to its 
throne. Economic growth in Romania and Bulgaria, as well as an increasing appetite in the Polish market for sun 
travel, is helping to fuel the airline's expansion. Any future move by the Turkish authorities to open its skies to 
European carriers would likely be met by an enthusiastic Ryanair response, particularly from Germany, said 
Jacobs. 
Dublin too, where Ryanair added 1.2 million extra passengers last year, could be a continued focus of growth for 
the airline, he said, and the airline could add a similar number of passengers here again next year "as long as there 
are sensible airport charges and a sensible airport plan". 
Undoubtedly, any deviation from sense will see Ryanair's polite new mask slip very quickly indeed. 
Ryanair's numbers
(EURO)103m:third quarter profit 
25%:January passenger growth 
Ryanair modestly puts its current boon down to oil prices
102.9m: passengers carried in past 12 months 
180m: passenger target by 2024

Where mobile meets cloud
Where mobile meets cloud
Sunday Business Post
February 7, 2016
Copyright 2016 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 536 words
Byline: Ian Campbell
Highlight: Vodafone believes it is perfectly positioned to make the connection work best for customers
Body
Last year's Vodafone Cloud Barometer report confirmed what many suspected: that the cloud is now an established 
part of IT delivery and its adoption is on the rise. The survey of 700 senior IT decision makers across 16 countries 
revealed that 89 per cent of enterprises anticipate using some kind of cloud by the end of 2016, up from 77 per cent 
in 2014. 
More surprising perhaps was the revelation that 70 per cent of enterprises use or would consider using the cloud for 
mission-critical enterprise applications, such as business intelligence and ERP (enterprise resource planning) 
systems. 
All of this chimes nicely with Vodafone, which has been reinventing itself, first as a one-stop network and 
communications company, and more recently as cloud services provider. "Seven years ago we were a mobile-only 
company and offering data centre services would have seemed a stretch," said Liam O'Brien, head of business 
products at Vodafone Ireland. "Delivering complex services to customers like Ryanair and Paddy Power has given 
us a lot of credibility." 
With access to 14 data centres across nine countries - including three in Ireland - the company is working hard to 
expand its cloud portfolio, competing directly against the likes of BT with managed private clouds and a similar 
capability when it comes to connecting publics clouds and hybrid services. 
Co-location, managed hosting with bespoke hardware, private cloud services and infrastructure-as-a-service are all 
part of a product portfolio that comes with the option of a managed service wrap. It's all striking a chord with 
multinationals that are using Ireland as a launch pad into Europe and the rest of the world. 
Like other telcos, Vodafone has seen the market move its way with the network becoming a primary component in a 
new wave of IT service delivery. "The network makes the cloud," said O'Brien. "Whatever application you are 
Where mobile meets cloud
running in the cloud, whether it's public or private, you will need a good quality data network to get those 
applications on to a device and into the hands of employees." 
What makes Vodafone different from most of its competitors is its roots in cellular services. With 80 per cent of 
participants in the Barometer survey saying that mobilising the workforce is a key input into their data centre 
strategy, it's a useful pedigree to have. 
"Consuming apps on mobile devices is a driver for cloud services. A cloud model allows you to deliver applications 
to a device that is no longer connected to the corporate network easily and efficiently," he said. "It's all about having 
a high-spec, good-quality device in your hand with a secure connection across 3G or 4G, a VPN, then on to a core 
network and into the data centre. We can offer all of that." 
O'Brien claims that there isn't another company on the planet that can provide the same scale of mobility as 
Vodafone and tie it in to cloud services.  
And it's about connecting to just about any cloud - not just Vodafone's. He reels off a list that includes IBM 
SoftLayer, HP Helium, Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services. "We are currently working with partners to 
create a single pane of glass to provide services across public and private clouds," said O'Brien. 
Load-Date: April 18, 2016
End of Document
On the Beach customers shun eastern Mediterranean
On the Beach customers shun eastern Mediterranean
Financial Times (London, England)
February 6, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 16
Length: 155 words
Byline: Nicholas Megaw
Body
Online travel agent On the Beach this week said the threat of terror attacks was causing a shift in its customers' 
holiday preferences, as consumers avoid the eastern Mediterranean and head to countries such as Spain and 
Portugal.
The company said events such as the bombing of a Russian jet over Egypt and attacks on European tourists in 
Sharm el-Sheikh had caused "significant volatility in traffic" over the four months to January 31, echoing recent 
reports from Ryanair and EasyJet about weaker demand for air travel.
However, a spokesperson for On the Beach said its lack of fixed assets meant the company could respond well to 
changing demand. Chief executive Simon Cooper said the company had "delivered a solid period of growth".
The company failed to convince some investors, with shares falling 6 per cent yesterday. But a closing price of 
287p still represented a 56 per cent rise since its IPO in September.

Ryanair August passenger traffic increases 10%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
February 5, 2016 Friday 9:28 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved

Length: 154 words
Highlight: Ryanair Limited has reported that passenger traffic for the month of August 2015 was 10.4 million 
passengers, an increase of 10%, compared to 9.4 million passengers for August 2014.
Body
Load factor for the month of August 2015 was 95%, an increase of two percentage points, compared to 93% for 
August 2014. Ryanair chief marketing officer, Kenny Jacobs, said: "Ryanair's August traffic grew by 10% to 10.4m 
customers, while our load factor jumped 2% points to 95%. These record monthly numbers and load factors are due 
to our lower fares, our stronger forward bookings and the continuing success of our "Always Getting Better" 
customer experience programme, which continues to deliver stronger than expected traffic and load factors on our 
biggest ever summer schedule. "Ryanair customers can look forward to more service enhancements in the autumn, 
as we continue Year 2 of our AGB programme, which include our new car hire service, a new website, new app, 
new cabin interiors, new crew uniforms, and improved inflight menus, as Ryanair continues to deliver so much more 
than just the lowest fares in Europe."

Body
Ryanair have today reported that traffic grew 25% to 7.5m customers in January. Their load factor rose 5% points to 
88% and rolling annual traffic to January grew 17% to 102.9m customers.
Ryanair raised its full-year profit forecast by 25 percent in early September, citing poor summer weather in northern 
Europe, strong sterling and the impact of improved customer service.
But security alerts after attacks in Paris in November and strong competition has since forced it to cut average 
fares, which fell 1 percent in the last three months of 2015 and will fall 6 percent in the first three months of 2016.
"We expect the lower fare environment to continue for the foreseeable future" with some respite during the summer 
months, Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said in a video presentation. Rival easyJet said last week its revenue per 
seat fell 3.7 percent in the three months to Dec. 31 and that it would continue to fall in early 2016. Ryanair last year 
was the first airline in the world to carry 100 million international passengers. On Monday, it increased its forecast 
for its financial year to March 31 to 106 million from 105 million and said it expected to grow to 113 million in its next 
financial year. Chief Financial Officer at Ryanair, Kenny Jacobs today commented, "Ryanair's January traffic grew 
by 25% to 7.5m customers, while our load factor jumped 5% points to 88%, thanks to Ryanair offering lower fares 
as part of our load factor active/yield passive policy. "These record monthly numbers and load factors are also due 
to the continuing success of our "Always Getting Better" customer experience programme, which continues to 
deliver stronger than expected forward bookings, traffic and load factors." (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

Body
It was announced today that 85 full-time and 30 part-time jobs are being created by six businesses operating at 
Belfast International Airport.
This is the third consecutive announcement of a major jobs boost at the airport and will mean the injection in wages 
of more than £1.5 million into the Northern Ireland economy.
This latest batch will bring to 298 the total number of new jobs announced at the airport within the past two months. 
The jobs are across a wide cross-section of aviation support activities including on-site food outlets, taxi operations 
and private charter services.
Caterers SSP is planning to increase its workforce by 20 full-time and 30 part-time staff while the Fed & Watered 
outlet will add 10 new employees to the payroll. The airport taxi firm, Belfast Airport Taxis, is taking on thirty 
additional drivers to deal with the expected increase in passenger numbers with planned expansion by existing 
airlines and the opening of a three-aircraft hub by Ryanair at the end of March. Catering, retail and logistics 
company, LSG, has 16 places to fill. Private charter company, Jet Assist, will create 6 jobs with Car Care Solutions 
adding 3additional jobs. All of the jobs will be featured at an Airport Jobs Fair to be held in the Templeton Hotel, 
Templepatrick, next Monday afternoon, 8th February. Belfast International Airport Director of Commercial 
Development, Brian Carlin said, "These jobs have little or no lead-in times. There's a need for them now as we 
prepare for a bumper year with hundreds of thousands more passengers. Right across the board, we're seeing 
welcome growth. "Airlines and airports generate jobs and new business opportunities at little or no cost to the 
taxpayer. We've announced almost 300 new jobs over a nine-week period and that's the equivalent of a major 
overseas inward investment costing millions of pounds. In a real sense, we're growing the business without reliance 
on the public purse." Source: www.businessworld.ie

Ryanair's new flight path pays off for investors; Planned EUR800m share buyback is strongest evidence of 
recovery yet
Ryanair's new flight path pays off for investors; Planned EUR800m share 
buyback is strongest evidence of recovery yet
Financial Times (London, England)
February 2, 2016 Tuesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 15
Length: 754 words
Byline: Tanya Powley in London
Body
Ryanair plans to return EUR800m to investors through its largest share buyback to date, highlighting how Europe's 
leading budget airline has made significant progress to overhaul its aggressive image and poor customer service.
The Dublin-based low-cost carrier yesterday reported third-quarter net profit of EUR102.7m, up 110 per cent 
compared with the same period in 2014.
The EUR800m buyback is the strongest evidence yet of Ryanair's recovery after two profit warnings in the autumn 
of 2013, when Michael O'Leary , its outspoken chief executive, admitted the company annoyed too many 
passengers and promised a strategy overhaul.
Changes to Ryanair's business model included cutting baggage fees and other charges that put some people off 
travelling with the airline. It also sought to copy easyJet's strategy of wooing business people, partly by announcing 
plans to fly to more major European hubs rather than obscure airports far from city centres.
The company credits this new approach for the improvement in its fortunes, which saw it become the first airline to 
carry 100m international passengers during a single year in 2015. Last September, Ryanair raised its full-year profit 
guidance for the year to March 2016 by 25 per cent, to a range of between EUR1.17bn and EUR1.22bn.
Ryanair's new flight path pays off for investors; Planned EUR800m share buyback is strongest evidence of 
recovery yet
"They have radically transformed their business and the exciting thing is it seems like they've still got a long way to 
go," says Oliver Sleath, an analyst at Barclays.
But not all of Ryanair's recent progress is down to its new strategy. European airlines in general are benefiting from 
Europe's modest economic recovery and lower fuel prices. Even Air France-KLM and Lufthansa, flag carriers hit by 
strikes, are predicting record profits for 2015.
There have also been setbacks. Ryanair's third-quarter earnings missed analysts' expectations because it felt 
compelled to cut fares after November's terrorist attacks in Paris, which caused some people to shun air travel.
The airline said average fares fell 1 per cent to EUR40 in its third quarter, and warned they could decline by 6 per 
cent in the three months to March 31.
Ryanair is not the only transport group to be affected by the Paris attacks. Last week, easyJet warned its revenue 
per seat in the three months to December 31 was due to fall, while Stagecoach, the bus and train operator, said last 
year its earnings could be affected.
Ryanair also warned that its fourth quarter and next financial year could see average fares hurt by unfavourable 
currency movements and a EUR2.50 increase in Italy's municipal tax that is levied on passengers.
However, analysts say Ryanair has allayed fears that changes to its business model, notably its move into more 
major European airports, would result in significantly higher costs. Ryanair said it expected unit costs excluding fuel 
to fall by 2 per cent in 2015-16.
"The shift in strategy seems to have worked well in the context of cash," says Stephen Furlong, an analyst at Davy, 
Ryanair's broker.
"It's a cash machine. And the cost base continues to be industry leading and falling."
Plans for the EUR800m buyback come after Ryanair said in September it would hand EUR400m to shareholders 
after the sale of its 29.8 per cent stake in Aer Lingus to International Airlines Group, owner of British Airways. This 
is being supplemented in 2015-16 by a EUR400m buyback.
While investors have benefited from ad hoc capital returns, Neil Sorahan , Ryanair's finance director, said the airline 
had no plans to commit to a regular dividend or share buyback.
He partly justified this stance by referring to a volcanic eruption in Iceland in 2010 that caused travel chaos by 
causing some of the biggest European airspace closures since the second world war.
"It's a very cyclical industry, you can wake up to find a volcano erupting in your back yard, so we don't want to 
commit to a regular dividend," he said. "We prefer to do ad hoc chunky buybacks . . . which we think is a better 
position for our shareholders."
Ryanair needs its new customer service strategy to work - in the spring of 2013 it agreed to buy 175 short-haul 
passenger jets from Boeing in a $16bn deal.
Such is Ryanair's confidence that it confirmed yesterday that it expected to hit the upper end of its net profit target 
for 2015-16. It also predicted it will carry 106m passengers.
This momentum looks unlikely to disappear. Ryanair is aiming to carry 180m passengers a year by 2024, by which 
time Mr O'Leary is targeting net profit of EUR2bn.
Additional reporting by Nathalie Thomas
See Lex
Ryanair's new flight path pays off for investors; Planned EUR800m share buyback is strongest evidence of 
recovery yet
Load-Date: February 1, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair : share fly backs
Ryanair: share fly backs
Financial Times (London, England)
February 2, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 16
Length: 393 words
Body
Dividends do not mix very well with airlines' business models. Of the large listed European airline groups, only 
easyJet has paid a regular and progressive dividend over the past few years. It is not hard to see why. Aviation is a 
capital-intensive industry, reliant on substantial debt financing of aircraft purchases. It is also cyclical and prone to 
external shocks from terrorist attacks , volcanic eruptions and oil price volatility.
There is a way around these uncomfortable realities. Ryanair has never paid a regular dividend. Since 2008 it has 
returned a total of EUR2.9bn to investors via a combination of special dividends and share buybacks that fit around 
its capital allocation priorities. It said yesterday that it would kick off another EUR800m programme of share 
repurchases; the shares rose 5 per cent even though Ryanair missed analysts' forecasts for net income.
A blueprint for other cyclical, capital-intensive industries? Up to a point. One criticism of share buybacks - that they 
leave investors with a bigger slice of a smaller pie - is blunted by Ryanair's rapid growth. Its share count has fallen 8 
per cent since 2008 as equity has risen 62 per cent. The relatively smooth ascent of its share price has meant it 
rarely suffered the indignity of buying back shares only to see the stock fall back.
Ryanair thinks it will keep growing; full-year profit will be at the top of its forecast range and it plans to carry 80 per 
cent more passengers by 2024. The shares do not look particularly overvalued (though they do trade at a higher 
multiple of profits than easyJet's). Yet much of the benefit of expected lower fuel prices will be passed through to 
customers in the form of lower fares, just when the industry is embarking on a period of above-average capacity 
growth. European capacity will grow more than 7 per cent in 2016, says Citigroup, putting more pressure on ticket 
prices.
Ryanair : share fly backs
As a low-cost carrier, Ryanair will weather those conditions better than most of its rivals. Still, for buybacks to carry 
on working, Ryanair needs a lot to go right. For future returns, the company should instead consider paying a 
special dividend, as it did after selling its Aer Lingus stake . That may have tax implications for investors but it does 
afford those who are less ebullient about industry prospects a choice in how the cash is deployed.
Load-Date: February 1, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair shares in full flight as buyback drafted
Ryanair shares in full flight as buyback drafted
City A.M.
February 2, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 216 words
Byline: EMMA HASLETT
Body
RYANAIR is planning to return (EURO)800m (£609m) to its shareholders, after it unveiled a huge share buyback.
The company said by the end of the nine-month process, it will have returned (EURO)4bn to shareholders over 
eight years.
The announcement came as the Irish budget airline posted results showing profits after tax jumped to (EURO)103m 
in the three months to the of December, a 110 per cent increase on the year before. Traffic rose 20 per cent to 25m 
passengers, with revenues rising 17 per cent to (EURO)1.3bn.
Average fares fell one per cent to (EURO)40, which the company put down to its snappily-titled "load factor 
active/yield passive" pricing strategy.
However, Michael O'Leary, the airline's chief executive, said bookings had fallen after the terrorist attacks in Paris 
and Brussels.
"We reacted to this softness by running price promotions and discounted fares to stimulate double digit traffic 
growth."
The airline added that it expects net profits will be towards the upper end of the (EURO)1.17bn to (EURO)1.22bn 
range.
"We caution, however, that this guidance is heavily dependent on the absence of further unforeseen events 
impacting close-in bookings and yields in the fourth quarter, especially over Easter," he added.
Shares took off yesterday, rising 5.45 per cent by the close.

Ryanair expects to hit profit target despite obstacles; Ryanair expects...
Business World (Digest)
February 1, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 409 words
Highlight: Ryanair forecast record passenger numbers will enable it to hit its annual profit target, despite falling 
ticket prices due to security alerts in Europe and cheaper oil.
Body
Ryanair forecast record passenger numbers will enable it to hit its annual profit target, despite falling ticket prices 
due to security alerts in Europe and cheaper oil.
The low-cost giant said on Monday average fares will continue to fall in the coming months as more airlines take 
advantage of lower fuel prices.
It also announced an 800 million euro share buyback over the next nine months.
Ryanair hiked its full-year profit forecast by 25 percent in early September, citing poor summer weather in Northern 
Europe, weak sterling and the impact of improved customer service. But security alerts after attacks in Paris in 
November and strong competition has since forced it to cut average fares, which fell 1 percent in the last three 
months of 2015 and will fall 6 percent in the first three months of 2016. "We expect the lower fare environment to 
continue for the foreseeable future" with some respite during the summer months, Chief Executive Michael O'Leary 
said in a video presentation. Rival easyJet last week said its revenue per seat fell 3.7 percent in the three months to 
Dec. 31 and that it would continue to fall in early 2016. O'Leary said he expected to pass on a "significant amount" 
of 430 million euros of Ryanair's fuel cost savings, but that would be offset by a further 8 percent increase in 
passenger numbers in 2016. Ryanair last year was the first airline in the world to carry 100 million international 
passengers and on Monday increased its forecast for its financial year to March 31 to 106 million from 105 million. It 
plans to carry 26 percent more passengers in the first three months of 2016 compared to the same period last year. 
'LITTLE UPSIDE' ON PROFIT Ryanair re-affirmed its expectation to post net profit at the upper end of a range of 
1.175 billion to 1.225 billion euros for its financial year. O'Leary said that the current forecast was heavily dependent 
on a strong Easter and the presumption there will be no major militant attacks in Europe. Ryanair will start its 800 
million euro share buyback in the coming days, but said it had no plans to commit to a regular dividend or share buy 
back, and that these would be ad hoc. Shares in the airline closed Friday up 36 percent on the year at 13.69 euros, 
Ryanair expects to hit profit target despite obstacles Ryanair expects...
while the Thomson Reuters European Airline Index was flat. Ryanair shares have fallen 8.8 percent since the start 
of the year, compared to a fall of 10 percent in the index. (Reuters) Source: www.businessworld.ie

FTSE 100 Dips 29 Points As Oil Falls On China Data
FTSE 100 Dips 29 Points As Oil Falls On China Data
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
February 1, 2016 Monday 12:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 333 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares fell on profit taking on Monday, as oil prices fell around 2 percent following 
last week's sharp rally and disappointing data out of China and South Korea rekindled growth worries.   Asian 
markets surrendered early gains to end mixed, with Chinese stocks coming under significant selling pressure after 
the latest batch of manufacturing and service sector data heightened concerns of a deeper economic slowdown.   
U.S. stock futures also drifted lower amid fresh concerns over China's economy. 
After disappointing fourth-quarter GDP data, investors await U.S. personal income and spending, construction 
spending and manufacturing PMI numbers later in the day for further clues on the future path of rate increases.  
Closer home, the benchmark FTSE 100 was down 29 points or 0.47 percent at 6,055 after climbing 2.6 percent on 
Friday, supported by higher oil prices and hopes for more stimulus measures in China, Europe and Japan.  
Commodity-related shares traded mostly lower, with Antofagasta, BP Plc and Royal Dutch Shell losing 1-2 percent.  
Rolls-Royce Holdings lost 1 percent despite winning a $2.7 billion order for Trent 1000 engines.  HSBC Holdings 
dropped 1.8 percent on a report it will impose a hiring and pay freeze globally in 2016 as part of its drive to cut as 
much as $5 billion in costs by the end of 2017.  BT Group rallied 3 percent after the telecom giant delivered a strong 
performance in the final quarter of 2015 and announced a new organizational structure.   Ryanair Holdings jumped 
3 percent after strong third-quarter earnings.  In economic releases, British manufacturing growth quickened 
unexpectedly at the start of the year to the strongest level in three months, survey data from Markit Economics 
showed. The corresponding PMI rose to 52.9 from 52.1 in December.   U.K. mortgage approvals rose unexpectedly 
to 70,837 in December from 70,424 in November, the Bank of England reported. This was the highest since August 
2015.

Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs On Higher Traffic; Says Comfortable With FY View
Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs On Higher Traffic; Says Comfortable With FY View
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
February 1, 2016 Monday 7:53 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 203 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that its third-quarter profit after tax 
climbed 110 percent to 103 million euros from last year's 49 million euros.  Earnings per share grew 119 percent to 
7.73 euro cents from 3.53 euro cents a year ago.  Revenue for the quarter climbed 17 percent to 1.33 billion euros 
from 1.132 billion euros last year.  Traffic grew 20 percent to 24.9 million customers from 20.8 million customers a 
year ago. Average fares fell 1 percent to 40 euros, while load factors rose 5 percent points to 93 percent. Unit costs 
fell by 5 percent, and ex-fuel was down 1 percent.  Looking ahead, for the fourth quarter, the company expects that 
traffic will grow by 26 percent, compared to previous estimate of 22 percent.  Further, the company said it remains 
comfortable with full year guidance that net profits will be towards the upper end of the 1.175 billion euros to 1.225 
billion euros range, pre-exceptions.  The company cautions, however, that this guidance is heavily dependent on 
the absence of further unforeseen events impacting close-in bookings and yields in Q4, especially over Easter, 
where it is working to deliver 26 percent traffic growth.

European Shares Give Up Early Gains
European Shares Give Up Early Gains
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
February 1, 2016 Monday 1:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 429 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European shares gave up early gains on Monday, as oil prices fell around 2 percent 
following last week's sharp rally and disappointing data out of China and South Korea rekindled growth worries.   
Asian markets surrendered early gains to end mixed, with Chinese stocks coming under significant selling pressure 
after the latest batch of manufacturing and service sector data heightened concerns of a deeper economic 
slowdown.   U.S. stock futures also drifted lower amid fresh concerns over China's economy. 
After disappointing fourth-quarter GDP data, investors await U.S. personal income and spending, construction 
spending and manufacturing PMI numbers later in the day for further clues on the future path of rate increases.  
Closer home, the pan-European STOXX 600 was down about 0.1 percent after climbing 2.2 percent on Friday, 
supported by higher oil prices and hopes for more stimulus measures in China, Europe and Japan.   Elsewhere, the 
German DAX, France's CAC 40 and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 were down between 0.4 percent and 0.6 percent.   
Commodity-related shares traded mostly lower in London, with Antofagasta, BP Plc and Royal Dutch Shell losing 1-
2 percent.  Rolls-Royce Holdings slid half a percent despite winning a $2.7 billion order for Trent 1000 engines.  
HSBC Holdings dropped 2 percent on a report it will impose a hiring and pay freeze globally in 2016 as part of its 
drive to cut as much as $5 billion in costs by the end of 2017.  BT Group rallied 3 percent after the telecoms giant 
delivered a strong performance in the final quarter of 2015 and announced a new organizational structure.   Ryanair 
Holdings jumped 4 percent after strong third-quarter earnings.  Dialog Semiconductor rose over 2 percent in 
Frankfurt. The chipmaker is eyeing new acquisition targets to spur growth, its chief executive told German weekly 
Euro am Sonntag.  Lab equipment maker Sartorius climbed 5 percent after updating its medium-term forecast.  
Nokia shares fell more than 10 percent after the Finnish firm said it had settled a lengthy patent dispute with South 
Korea's Samsung.  In economic releases, the euro area manufacturing sector growth slowed as estimated in 
January with rates of expansion in output, new orders and new export business all easing at the start of the year, 
final survey data from Markit showed.  While British manufacturing growth quickened unexpectedly at the start of 
the year to the strongest level in three months, U.K. mortgage approvals rose unexpectedly to 70,837 in December 
from 70,424 in November.      
European Shares Give Up Early Gains
Load-Date: February 1, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs, Lifts Traffic Forecast; To Buy Back EUR 800 Mln Shares
Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs, Lifts Traffic Forecast; To Buy Back EUR 800 Mln 
Shares
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
February 1, 2016 Monday 9:40 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 512 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that it's third-quarter profit 
more-than-doubled from last year with strong traffic growth and lower unit costs, despite lower fares. Looking 
ahead, the company said it remains comfortable with full year guidance, and lifted its traffic forecast for the fourth 
quarter and fiscal 2016. Further, the Board has approved an 800 million euros share buy-back to commence on 
February 5.  Ryanair's CEO, Michael O'Leary, said, 'We are pleased to report that our low fares policy delivered 
strong Q3 traffic and profit growth... Following a strong first half of Q3, we noted weaker pricing and bookings 
immediately after the terrorist events in Paris and Brussels. We reacted to this softness by running price promotions 
and discounted fares to stimulate double digit traffic growth.' 
 For the third quarter, pre-tax profit grew 105 percent to 111.1 million euros from 54.3 million euros a year ago. 
Profit for the quarter, all attributable to equity holders, climbed 110 percent to 103 million euros. Earnings per share 
grew 118 percent to 7.68 euro cents.  Revenue for the quarter climbed 17 percent to 1.33 billion euros from 1.132 
billion euros last year.  Scheduled revenues increased 18 percent year-over-year to 987.1 million euros driven by 
higher traffic, partly offset by lower average fares.  Ancillary revenues grew 16 percent to 342.4 million euros driven 
by a solid performance in on-board sales and reserved seating offset by reduced travel insurance and lower car-
hire.  Traffic grew 20 percent to 24.9 million customers from 20.8 million customers a year ago. Load factors rose 5 
percent points to 93 percent.  While average fares fell 1 percent to 40 euros, this was offset by 5 percent drop in 
unit costs, while unit costs excluding fuel was down 1 percent.  In the quarter, fuel and oil rose 7 percent to 485.1 
million euros due to an 11 percent increase in hours offset by lower euro fuel prices per gallon.  Looking ahead, for 
the fourth quarter, the company expects that traffic will grow by 26 percent, compared to previous estimate of 22 
percent.  With limited visibility of close-in Easter bookings in March, the company now expects fourth quarter fares 
to fall by 6 percent, compared to previous view for drop of 4 percent.  With stronger load factors, the company 
raised fiscal 2016 traffic target to 106 million customers from previously expected 105 million customers. This 
represents a 17 percent increase on last year's 90.6 million customers.  Further, the company said it remains 
comfortable with full year guidance that net profits will be towards the upper end of the 1.175 billion euros to 1.225 
billion euros range, pre-exceptions.  The company cautions, however, that this guidance is heavily dependent on 
Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs, Lifts Traffic Forecast; To Buy Back EUR 800 Mln Shares
the absence of further unforeseen events impacting close-in bookings and yields in Q4, especially over Easter, 
where it is working to deliver 26 percent traffic growth.  In London, Ryanair shares were trading at 14.01 euros, up 
1.89 percent.      
Load-Date: February 1, 2016
End of Document
European Markets Pulled Back On China Concerns & Falling Crude Prices
European Markets Pulled Back On China Concerns & Falling Crude Prices
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
February 1, 2016 Monday 5:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 959 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - The European markets ended the first session of the new trading week in the red. 
Following the rally at the end of the prior trading week, stocks gave up early gains Monday due to falling crude oil 
prices and renewed concerns over China. Disappointing Chinese manufacturing data spooked investors and 
caused oil prices to turn lower.  Chinese manufacturers signaled deterioration in operating conditions at the start of 
2016 but the pace of contraction slowed slightly from December, the results of a private survey showed Monday. 
  However, official data released by the government showed that the manufacturing sector underwent a faster 
contraction than seen at the end of 2015.   The Caixin Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 48.4 in January from 
48.2 in December, Markit said. Nonetheless, activity has been contracting for the eleventh successive month.   At 
the same time, the official manufacturing PMI fell to 49.4 in January from 49.7 in December. According to the 
National Bureau of Statistics report, the sector contracted for the sixth straight month.  The official non-
manufacturing PMI dropped to 53.5 from 54.4 in December but stayed in positive territory.  The European Central 
Bank will review and possibly reconsider its monetary policy stance when it meets in March, Executive Board 
member Benoit Coeure said Monday.   'But for the recovery to become structural - and thus to increase growth 
potential and reduce structural unemployment - monetary policy does not suffice,' policymaker said at a conference 
in Budapest.  The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip stocks decreased 0.79 percent, while the Stoxx 
Europe 50 index, which includes some major U.K. companies, lost 0.43 percent.  The DAX of Germany dropped 
0.41 percent and the CAC 40 of France fell 0.56 percent. The FTSE of the U.K. declined 0.39 percent and the SMI 
of Switzerland finished lower by 0.11 percent.  In Frankfurt, Dialog Semiconductor rose 1.30 percent. The 
chipmaker is eyeing new acquisition targets to spur growth, its chief executive told German weekly Euro am 
Sonntag.  Lab equipment maker Sartorius climbed 6.86 percent after updating its medium-term forecast.  BMW 
dropped 1.64 percent and Daimler fell 0.65 percent. Volkswagen also finished lower by 0.94 percent.  In Paris, Total 
sank 2.25 percent, but Technip advanced 0.92 percent.  Vivendi decreased 5.34 percent and LafargeHolcim 
weakened by 2.73 percent.   In London, HSBC Holdings dropped 1.60 percent on a report it will impose a hiring and 
pay freeze globally in 2016 as part of its drive to cut as much as $5 billion in costs by the end of 2017.  Rolls-Royce 
Holdings finished unchanged despite winning a $2.7 billion order for Trent 1000 engines.  BT Group climbed 1.93 
percent after the telecoms giant delivered a strong performance in the final quarter of 2015 and announced a new 
European Markets Pulled Back On China Concerns & Falling Crude Prices
organizational structure.   Ryanair Holdings jumped 5.45 percent after strong third-quarter earnings.  Nokia sank 
11.29 percent in Helsinki, after the firm said it had settled a lengthy patent dispute with South Korea's Samsung.  
The euro area manufacturing sector growth slowed as estimated in January with rates of expansion in output, new 
orders and new export business all easing at the start of the year, final survey data from Markit showed Monday.   
The final manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 52.3 in January from 53.2 in December. The reading 
matched flash estimate.  British manufacturing growth quickened unexpectedly at the start of the year to the 
strongest level in three months, survey data from Markit Economics showed Monday. The Markit/Chartered Institute 
of Procurement & Supply Purchasing Managers' Index for manufacturing rose to 52.9 in January from 52.1 in 
December. Economists had expected the index to fall to 51.8.  U.K. mortgage approvals rose to a 4-month high in 
December, the Bank of England reported Monday. The number of mortgage approvals rose unexpectedly to 70,837 
in December from 70,424 in November. This was the highest since August 2015. Economists had forecast 
approvals to fall to 69,600 in December.  U.S. manufacturing activity contracted for the fourth straight month in 
January, according to a report released by the Institute for Supply Management, although the index of activity in the 
sector did show a slight increase.  The ISM said its purchasing managers index inched up to 48.2 in January from a 
downwardly revised 48.0 in December, but a reading below 50 continues to indicate a contraction in manufacturing 
activity. Economists had expected the index to climb to a reading of 48.3 from the 48.2 originally reported for the 
previous month.  Personal income in the U.S. rose in line with economist estimates in the month of December, 
according to a report released by the Commerce Department on Monday, although the report also said personal 
spending came in virtually unchanged.  The report said personal income climbed by 0.3 percent in December, 
matching the increase seen in November as well as economist estimates.  Meanwhile, the Commerce Department 
said personal spending edged down by less than 0.1 percent in December after rising by 0.5 percent in the previous 
month. Spending had been expected to inch up by 0.1 percent.  With a jump in spending on public construction 
partly offset by a drop in spending on private construction, the Commerce Department released a report on Monday 
showing that U.S. construction spending rose much less than expected in December.  The Commerce Department 
said construction spending inched up 0.1 percent to an annual rate of $1.117 trillion in December from the revised 
November estimate of $1.116 trillion. Economists had expected spending to climb by 0.6 percent.      
Load-Date: February 1, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs On Higher Traffic; Says Comfortable With FY View
Ryanair Q3 Profit Climbs On Higher Traffic; Says Comfortable With FY View
RTT News (United States)
February 1, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 216 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Irish airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that its third-quarter profit after tax climbed 110 
percent to 103 million euros from last year's 49 million euros.
Earnings per share grew 119 percent to 7.73 euro cents from 3.53 euro cents a year ago.
Revenue for the quarter climbed 17 percent to 1.33 billion euros from 1.132 billion euros last year.
Traffic grew 20 percent to 24.9 million customers from 20.8 million customers a year ago. Average fares fell 1 
percent to 40 euros, while load factors rose 5 percent points to 93 percent. Unit costs fell by 5 percent, and ex-fuel 
was down 1 percent.
Looking ahead, for the fourth quarter, the company expects that traffic will grow by 26 percent, compared to 
previous estimate of 22 percent.
Further, the company said it remains comfortable with full year guidance that net profits will be towards the upper 
end of the 1.175 billion euros to 1.225 billion euros range, pre-exceptions.
The company cautions, however, that this guidance is heavily dependent on the absence of further unforeseen 
events impacting close-in bookings and yields in Q4, especially over Easter, where it is working to deliver 26 
percent traffic growth.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com

Load-Date: February 1, 2016
End of Document
FTSE 100 Dips 29 Points As Oil Falls On China Data
FTSE 100 Dips 29 Points As Oil Falls On China Data
RTT News (United States)
February 1, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 343 words
Body
(RTTNews) - U.K. shares fell on profit taking on Monday, as oil prices fell around 2 percent following last week's 
sharp rally and disappointing data out of China and South Korea rekindled growth worries.
Asian markets surrendered early gains to end mixed, with Chinese stocks coming under significant selling pressure 
after the latest batch of manufacturing and service sector data heightened concerns of a deeper economic 
slowdown.
U.S. stock futures also drifted lower amid fresh concerns over China's economy. After disappointing fourth-quarter 
GDP data, investors await U.S. personal income and spending, construction spending and manufacturing PMI 
numbers later in the day for further clues on the future path of rate increases.
Closer home, the benchmark FTSE 100 was down 29 points or 0.47 percent at 6,055 after climbing 2.6 percent on 
Friday, supported by higher oil prices and hopes for more stimulus measures in China, Europe and Japan.
Commodity-related shares traded mostly lower, with Antofagasta, BP Plc and Royal Dutch Shell losing 1-2 percent.
Rolls-Royce Holdings lost 1 percent despite winning a $2.7 billion order for Trent 1000 engines.
HSBC Holdings dropped 1.8 percent on a report it will impose a hiring and pay freeze globally in 2016 as part of its 
drive to cut as much as $5 billion in costs by the end of 2017.
BT Group rallied 3 percent after the telecom giant delivered a strong performance in the final quarter of 2015 and 
announced a new organizational structure.
Ryanair Holdings jumped 3 percent after strong third-quarter earnings.
In economic releases, British manufacturing growth quickened unexpectedly at the start of the year to the strongest 
level in three months, survey data from Markit Economics showed. The corresponding PMI rose to 52.9 from 52.1 in 
December.
U.K. mortgage approvals rose unexpectedly to 70,837 in December from 70,424 in November, the Bank of England 
reported. This was the highest since August 2015.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com
FTSE 100 Dips 29 Points As Oil Falls On China Data

Airline CFO interview: Southwest Airlines
Airline CFO interview: Southwest Airlines
AirFinance Journal
February 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: NORTH AMERICA,AIRLINES,ANALYSIS
Length: 1293 words
Byline: Joe Kavanagh
Highlight: After a bumper 2015, the US low-cost carrier's chief financial officer Tammy Romo discusses the 
airline's strategy with Joe Kavanagh.
Body
Fitch Ratings upgraded Southwest Airline's outlook from stable to positive in October. The news was an 
endorsement of the carrier's recent successes.
As well as earning an upgrade from Fitch, the airline generated its highest third-quarter profit and tapped the capital 
markets with a $500 million unsecured bond carrying the low coupon of 2.650%.
Southwest's strong cash position and stable leverage has set it up well for 2016. The airline has taken advantage of 
low interest rates and strong financial results to decrease gradually its leverage and refinance existing debt.
Tammy Romo, chief financial officer at the carrier, was understandably upbeat about the airline's achievements 
when she spoke with Airfinance Journal to discuss Southwest's strategy. "This quarter was a record performance 
on almost every front. So we couldn't be more delighted," she says.
Tapping the unsecured market
In November, Southwest closed a $500 million offering of five-year senior unsecured notes. The deal was 
especially notable for achieving a 2.650% coupon, which is competitive in the unsecured bond markets.
Unsecured debt is an option only available to a select few airlines because most could only issue paper at 
prohibitively high margins. Instead, many opt for commercial loans and aircraft securitizations to achieve tighter 
pricing.
The list of airlines that can choose unsecured debt consists largely of investment-grade carriers. According to 
Airfinance Journal's Deals Database, the 2015 group includes just a handful of legacy carriers such as Etihad, 
American Airlines and Latam.
One of Southwest's European counterparts, Ryanair, also opted for unsecured debt, in March 2015. The Irish airline 
priced its â,¬850 million ($882.3 million) eight-year Eurobond at the lowest coupon for an aviation issuance: 
1.125%.
Airline CFO interview: Southwest Airlines
Southwest's November issuance should be thought of as a refinancing, says Romo. The airline has substantial debt 
maturities "" totalling about $600 million "" due in 2016, including about $300 million in a single bullet payment. 
November's issuance will refinance those debt payments at tighter spreads.
The carrier was helped in this regard by its October upgrade from Fitch ratings. In its analysis of Southwest's credit 
rating, Fitch drew attention to its strong financials. It expects the airline to continue performing strongly.
In a statement, it wrote: "Going forward, Fitch expects Southwest to continue to generate solid free cash flow, 
exhibit stable or modestly declining leverage, and maintain its substantial financial flexibility. Southwest's 
investment-grade credit ratings are also supported by its competitive position in the US domestic market, its strong 
brand, and its sizeable base of high-quality unencumbered assets."
Speaking about the bond, Romo notes: "The market was favourable and the coupon rate was 2.65%, and we were 
delighted with that. That was actually below the debt that we issued last year, which was 2.75%."
She adds: "We were more than five times oversubscribed pretty much instantly. The morning went fast and furious, 
and there was obviously a healthy appetite for our notes." Tammy Romo, CFO of Southwest
Romo expects Southwest to continue tapping the bond markets for unsecured debt in the coming year. She points 
out that commercial debt and aircraft securitizations are a good option for many carriers, but if an airline can tap 
unsecured debt at low rates then it should do so.
Speaking about these other sources of financing, Romo says: "All of those are good opportunities in this low 
interest rate environment. For carriers who don't have the good fortune to have the strong credit rating that we do, I 
think EETCs [enhanced equipment trust certificates] continue to be a nice opportunity. But obviously for us, at the 
rates we're getting unsecured [debt], it just doesn't make sense in our situation."
She adds: "To the extent we decide to do additional refinancing next year, I would suspect that unsecured would be 
high on our list, obviously if the interest rate environment continues to be favourable."
Since Romo spoke with Airfinance Journal, the Federal Reserve lifted interest rates for the first time since 2006. In 
December last year, the Fed finally announced plans to hike interest rates, pushing them up by 25 bps to 0.5%.
Although the increase is relatively small, it will have an impact on the industry. For carriers like Southwest, the 
immediate effect will be a higher cost of borrowing. However, historically speaking there is no definitive link between 
interest rates and profitability.
Airlines have succeeded and failed in higher interest rate environments. What matters more is the traffic growth 
driven by higher levels of disposable income.
According to its third-quarter 2015 results, Southwest has an additional $310 million of 5.125% notes due 2017, so 
it may choose to do another refinancing in 2016.
There are other factors at play, but if the airline continues to post strong numbers and is still looked on favourably 
by the ratings agencies, then another unsecured issuance should not come as a surprise.
Snapping up 737-700s
Southwest has a large order book with Boeing for 737 Max aircraft. It became the launch customer for the Max 
variant when, in May 2013, it converted 30 existing orders for current models to the latest generation of Boeing's 
narrowbody family.
As of September, the airline's fleet consisted of almost 700 aircraft, including 119 -300s, 12 -500s, 463 -700s and 
98 -800s.
Airline CFO interview: Southwest Airlines
The carrier's unfilled orders with Boeing total 200 737 Max aircraft, 34 737-800s and 25 737-700s, according to the 
latest numbers from the manufacturer.
Although the airline is set to take a large number of new aircraft, it has also been very busy in the used market. 
Southwest has plans to take delivery of almost 60 737-700s in the next few years.
When discussing the carrier's activity in the secondary market for these aircraft, Romo says, with some 
understatement: "It's definitely true that we've been active in that market."
Airfinance Journal has heard some operators, active in the market for used -700s, speak about Southwest's buying 
spree with something bordering on irritation. The carrier has bought so many, one executive confided, that the 
aircraft are now quite difficult to come by.
Romo outlines the scale Southwest's aircraft purchases. "We have been very active in that market for a bit now, 
and we are at a point where there's not as many -700s that there were a year or two ago," she says. "For instance, 
in 2015 what we last reported was 24 additional -700 aircraft and 15 for 2016, and we've got 14 coming in 2017 and 
four in 2018. Including all of 2015, that's 57 pre-owned -700s."
As Romo explains, these deliveries are replacing the 717s Southwest acquired during its merger with Air Tran in 
2011. Southwest has been sub-leasing its 717s to Delta, helping it to keep the uniform fleet that is central to its low-
cost business model.
She adds: "The pre-owned market came together very nicely. As we were replacing the 717s, the pre-owned 
market was quite favourable, and we jumped in and took advantage of that.
"We have been very focused on our fleet planning here for the last several years, and the benefits from our fleet-
modernization efforts. We're right on track with what we were expecting, which is a $700 million Ebit [earnings 
before interest and tax] contribution just from a result of our fleet-modernization efforts."
In the absence of external shocks, 2016 looks promising for Southwest.
The airline continues to post record profits during a fleet modernization programme.
On the back of a very successful year, the carrier has also continued to issue enviably cheap debt - and it looks set 
to continue doing so, even in a higher interest rate environment.
Load-Date: February 22, 2016
End of Document
